--Word--
b 
--Type--
abbreviation, noun, abbreviation
--Meanings--
Barn(s).
Born (used to indicate a date of birth)
(on scorecards) bowled by.
(on scorecards) bye(s)
The second letter of the alphabet.
Denoting the second in a set of items, categories, sizes, etc.
The second highest class of academic mark.
(in the UK) denoting a secondary road.
Denoting the second-highest-earning socio-economic category for marketing purposes, including intermediate management and professional personnel.
Denoting the second file from the left, as viewed from White's side of the board.
The second fixed constant to appear in an algebraic equation.
Denoting a soil horizon of intermediate depth, typically the subsoil.
The human blood type (in the ABO system) containing the B antigen and lacking the A.
(with numeral) denoting a series of international standard paper sizes each twice the area of the next, as B0, B1, B2, B3, B4, etc., B4 being 250 × 353 mm.
The seventh note of the diatonic scale of C major.
A key based on a scale with B as its keynote.
Belgium (international vehicle registration).
Bishop (used in recording moves in chess)
Black (used in describing grades of pencil lead)
Bomber (in designations of US aircraft types)
The chemical element boron.
Magnetic flux density.
--Examples--
‘George Lloyd (b.1913)’
‘AC Hudson b Prasad 146’
‘extras (b 6, lb 24, nb 9) 39’
‘my grade on that first paper was a B’
‘the B4248’
‘B-roads’
‘Be5’
‘2B pencils’
‘a B-52’

ba 
--Type--
noun
abbreviation
--Meanings--
In ancient Egypt, the supposed soul of a person or god, which survived after death but had to be sustained with offerings of food. It was typically represented as a human-headed bird.

British Airways.

Buenos Aires.

--Word--
Babism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A religion founded in 1844 by the Persian Mirza Ali Muhammad of Shiraz (1819–50) (popularly known as ‘the Bab’), who taught that a new prophet would follow Muhammad.
--Examples--
--Word--
baba 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
A small, rich sponge cake, typically soaked in rum-flavoured syrup.
Father (often as a proper name or as a familiar form of address)
A respectful form of address for an older man.
A holy man (often as a proper name or form of address)
A child, especially a male one (often in names or as an affectionate form of address)

‘‘Remove the paper whenever you are ready, baba.’’

Babbage, Charles 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1791–1871), English mathematician, inventor, and pioneer of machine computing. He designed a mechanical computer with Ada Lovelace but was unable to complete it in his lifetime.

--Word--
babblative 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Given to babbling; loquacious, prattling. Also: characterized by an excess of talk; verbose, bombastic. Now somewhat archaic.
--Examples--
--Word--
babble 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Talk rapidly and continuously in a foolish, excited, or incomprehensible way.
Utter something rapidly and incoherently.
Reveal something secret or confidential by talking carelessly.
(of a stream) make the continuous murmuring sound of water flowing over stones.
The confused sound of a group of people talking simultaneously.
Foolish, excited, or confused talk.
Background disturbance caused by interference from conversations on other telephone lines.
The continuous murmuring sound of water flowing over stones in a stream.
--Examples--
‘they babbled on about their holiday’
‘‘Thank goodness you're all right,’ she babbled’
‘he babbled to another convict while he was in jail’
‘a gently babbling brook’
‘a babble of protest’
‘her soft voice stopped his babble’
‘the babble of a brook’

babe 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

‘you have a babe, who will surely be treated as a king when he grows’
‘I wish you weren't quite such a babe’

--Word--
Babesia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of protozoans of the group Apicomplexa, the members of which are parasites of invertebrates and vertebrates causing babesiosis in domestic and wild mammals (and occasionally in humans); (also babesia) a protozoan of this genus.
--Examples--
--Word--
Babesia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of protozoans of the group Apicomplexa, the members of which are parasites of invertebrates and vertebrates causing babesiosis in domestic and wild mammals (and occasionally in humans); (also babesia) a protozoan of this genus.
--Examples--
--Word--
babesiosis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A disease of cattle and other livestock, transmitted by the bite of ticks. It affects the red blood cells and causes the passing of red or blackish urine.
--Examples--
--Word--
babesiosis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A disease of cattle and other livestock, transmitted by the bite of ticks. It affects the red blood cells and causes the passing of red or blackish urine.
--Examples--
--Word--
Babi 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An adherent of Babism.
--Examples--
--Word--
baby 
--Type--
noun, adjective, verb
--Meanings--
A very young child.
A very young animal.
The youngest member of a family or group.
A timid or childish person.
One's particular responsibility or concern.
A lover or spouse (often as a form of address)
A thing regarded with affection or familiarity.
Comparatively small or immature of its kind.
(of vegetables) picked before reaching their usual size.
Treat (someone) as a baby; pamper or be overprotective towards.
--Examples--
‘his wife's just had a baby’
‘a baby girl’
‘bats only have one baby a year’
‘baby rabbits’
‘Clara was the baby of the family’
‘‘Don't be such a baby!’ she said witheringly’
‘‘This is your baby, Gerry,’ she said, handing him the brief’
‘my baby left me for another guy’
‘this baby can reach speeds of 120 mph’
‘a baby version of the Oxford Movement’
‘baby carrots’
‘her aunt babied her and fussed over her clothes’
--Word--
Babiana 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of southern African plants of the family Iridaceae, comprising spring-flowering perennial plants which grow from corms and produce spikes of funnel-shaped yellow, purple, or scarlet flowers. Also (usually in form babiana): a plant of this genus.
--Examples--
--Word--
baby-blue-eyes 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A plant of western North America with blue bowl-shaped flowers.

noun, adjective, verb
--Meanings--
A very young child.
A very young animal.
The youngest member of a family or group.
A timid or childish person.
One's particular responsibility or concern.
A lover or spouse (often as a form of address)
A thing regarded with affection or familiarity.
Comparatively small or immature of its kind.
(of vegetables) picked before reaching their usual size.
Treat (someone) as a baby; pamper or be overprotective towards.
--Examples--
‘his wife's just had a baby’
‘a baby girl’
‘bats only have one baby a year’
‘baby rabbits’
‘Clara was the baby of the family’
‘‘Don't be such a baby!’ she said witheringly’
‘‘This is your baby, Gerry,’ she said, handing him the brief’
‘my baby left me for another guy’
‘this baby can reach speeds of 120 mph’
‘a baby version of the Oxford Movement’
‘baby carrots’
‘her aunt babied her and fussed over her clothes’
--Word--
baby 
--Type--
noun, adjective, verb
--Meanings--
A very young child.
A very young animal.
The youngest member of a family or group.
A timid or childish person.
One's particular responsibility or concern.
A lover or spouse (often as a form of address)
A thing regarded with affection or familiarity.
Comparatively small or immature of its kind.
(of vegetables) picked before reaching their usual size.
Treat (someone) as a baby; pamper or be overprotective towards.
--Examples--
‘his wife's just had a baby’
‘a baby girl’
‘bats only have one baby a year’
‘baby rabbits’
‘Clara was the baby of the family’
‘‘Don't be such a baby!’ she said witheringly’
‘‘This is your baby, Gerry,’ she said, handing him the brief’
‘my baby left me for another guy’
‘this baby can reach speeds of 120 mph’
‘a baby version of the Oxford Movement’
‘baby carrots’
‘her aunt babied her and fussed over her clothes’
--Word--
baby's breath 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A herbaceous plant of delicate appearance which bears tiny scented pink or white flowers.
--Examples--
--Word--
baby face 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A smooth round face like a baby's.
(in professional wrestling) a wrestler who adopts a likeable or sympathetic persona in the ring.
--Examples--
‘an essential component of having a top babyface is for fans to feel compassion for them’
--Word--
baby-faced 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having a youthful or innocent face.
--Examples--
‘baby-faced tough guys’
--Word--
featured 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having distinctive attributes or aspects of a specified kind.
Having facial parts, such as the mouth, nose, and eyes, of a specified kind.
(of a newspaper or magazine article, broadcast programme, or show) made a special attraction.
--Examples--
‘the front of the chassis is well featured’
‘the complexities of a fully featured computer’
‘this blond, blue-eyed, regular-featured queen’
‘my aunt was a tall, hard-featured lady’
‘our featured interview for this issue’
‘he was the featured guest artist’
--Word--
babyfied 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having or characterized by the attributes of a baby.
--Examples--

noun, adjective, verb
--Meanings--
A very young child.

--Type--
noun, adjective, verb
--Meanings--
A very young child.
A very young animal.
The youngest member of a family or group.

--Word--
baby-like 
--Type--
adverb, adjective
--Meanings--
In the manner of a baby.
Resembling (that of) a baby; characteristic of a baby; babyish, infantile.
--Examples--
--Word--
Babylon 
--Type--
proper noun, noun
--Meanings--
An ancient city in Mesopotamia, the capital of Babylonia in the 2nd millennium BC. The city (of which only ruins now remain) lay on the River Euphrates and was noted by classical writers for its luxury, its fortifications, and its legendary Hanging Gardens.
(chiefly among Rastafarians) a contemptuous or dismissive term for aspects of white culture seen as degenerate or oppressive, especially the police.
--Examples--
‘praise them for bringing a new rectitude to Babylon’
--Word--
Babylonia 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An ancient region of Mesopotamia, formed when the kingdoms of Akkad in the north and Sumer in the south combined in the first half of the 2nd millennium BC.
--Examples--
--Word--
Babylonian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
An inhabitant of Babylon or Babylonia.
The dialect of Akkadian spoken in ancient Babylon.
Relating to Babylon or Babylonia.
--Examples--

babe 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A sexually attractive young woman.

A baby.
An innocent or helpless person.

‘it was the best day of my life—except for meeting you, babe’
‘you have a babe, who will surely be treated as a king when he grows’
‘I wish you weren't quite such a babe’

babish 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Characteristic of or befitting a baby; having features associated with a baby; baby-like.
Specifically depreciative. Unduly childish; babyish, infantile; immature.
--Examples--
--Word--
babyship 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Babyhood. Compare "babeship". Now rare.
With preceding possessive adjective: a mock title of respect given to a baby, especially one considered to be excessively pampered.

--Word--
Babism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A religion founded in 1844 by the Persian Mirza Ali Muhammad of Shiraz (1819–50) (popularly known as ‘the Bab’), who taught that a new prophet would follow Muhammad.
--Examples--

baby-snatching

noun
--Meanings--
Abduction of a very young child; (in extended use) the action or fact of marrying or having a sexual relationship with a much younger partner.

baby's tears 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of various plants characterized by some feature considered to resemble small teardrops, as the shape and size of the leaves or petals, teardrop-shaped markings on the leaves, etc.; specifically the helxine, Soleirolia soleirolii.

baboon 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A large Old World ground-dwelling monkey with a long doglike snout and large teeth.
An ugly or uncouth person.
--Examples--
--Word--
baboonery 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Grotesque or absurd ornamentation, carving or pictures; an example of this. Compare "baboon"baberyhistorical after Middle English.
Originally: †a colony of baboons (obsolete rare). In later use: a captive collection of baboons.
Baboonish nature, character, or behaviour; especially foolishness, stupidity.
--Examples--
--Word--
baboonish 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Reminiscent or characteristic of a baboon; resembling that of a baboon.

Babouvism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The beliefs of François Noël Babeuf or his followers; the Babouvist movement.
--Examples--
--Word--
Babouvist 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A follower or supporter of Babeuf or his beliefs, most notably the doctrine of universal equality of income and the abolition of private property; specifically a member of any of various 19th-cent. French political organizations espousing this principle.
Of, relating to, or characteristic of Babeuf, the Babouvists, or their beliefs.
--Examples--
--Word--

Babur 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1483–1530), first Mogul emperor of India 1526–30, descendant of Tamerlane; born Zahir ad-Din Muhammad. He invaded India c.1525 and conquered the territory from the Oxus to Patna.
--Examples--

noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
baccalaureate 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

A university bachelor's degree.

--Examples--

--Word--
baccarat 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A gambling card game in which players hold two- or three-card hands, the winning hand being that giving the highest remainder when its face value is divided by ten.
--Examples--

--Word--
bach 
--Type--
noun, verb, noun
--Meanings--
Used as a term of endearment, often after a personal name.
(especially of a man) live alone and do one's own cooking and housekeeping.
A small holiday house.
--Examples--
‘Thomas bach, you are looking tired’
‘Baldy bached in a hut down the road a bit’
--Word--
Bacharach, Burt 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(born 1928), US writer of popular songs. His songs, many of which were written with lyricist Hal David (1921–2012), include ‘Walk On By’ (1961), ‘Alfie’ (1966), and ‘Raindrops Keep Falling on my Head’ (1969).
--Examples--
--Word--
bach 
--Type--
noun, verb, noun
--Meanings--
Used as a term of endearment, often after a personal name.
(especially of a man) live alone and do one's own cooking and housekeeping.

‘Baldy bached in a hut down the road a bit’
--Word--
bachelor 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A man who is not and has never been married.
A male bird or mammal prevented from breeding by a dominant male.
A person who holds a first degree from a university or other academic institution (only in titles or set expressions)
A bachelor apartment.
A young knight serving under another's banner.
--Examples--
‘one of the country's most eligible bachelors’
‘a Bachelor of Arts’
‘it's just one room, a bachelor’

serjeant-at-arms

A knight or armed officer in the service of the monarch or a lord.

--Word--
back 
--Type--
noun, adverb, verb, adjective
--Meanings--
The rear surface of the human body from the shoulders to the hips.
The upper surface of an animal's body that corresponds to a person's back.
The spine of a person or animal.
The main structure of a ship's hull or an aircraft's fuselage.
The part of a chair against which the sitter's back rests.
The part of a garment that covers a person's back.
A person's back regarded as carrying a load or bearing an imposition.
The side or part of something that is away from the spectator or from the direction in which it moves or faces; the rear.
The position directly behind someone or something.
The side or part of an object that is not normally seen or used.
A player in a team game who plays in a defensive position behind the forwards.
The grounds of Cambridge colleges which back on to the River Cam.
In the opposite direction from the one that one is facing or travelling towards.
Expressing movement of the body into a reclining position.
At a distance away.
Behind.
Losing by a specified margin.
So as to return to an earlier or normal position or condition.
At a place previously left or mentioned.
Fashionable again.
In or into the past.
In return.
Give financial, material, or moral support to.
Supplement in order to strengthen.
Be in favour of.
(in popular music) provide musical accompaniment to (a singer or musician)
Bet money on (a person or animal) winning a race or contest.
Cover the back of (an article) in order to support, protect, or decorate it.
Walk or drive backwards.
(of the wind) change direction anticlockwise around the points of the compass.
Put (a sail) aback in order to slow the vessel down or assist in turning through the wind.
(of a building or other structure) have its back facing or adjacent to.
Lie behind or at the back of.
Put a piece of music on the less important side of (a vinyl recording)
Of or at the back of something.
In a remote or subsidiary position.
From or relating to the past.
Directed towards the rear or in a reversed course.
(of a sound) articulated at the back of the mouth.
--Examples--
‘he lay on his back’
‘back pain’
‘the adults have white bodies with grey backs’
‘Demetrius broke its back on the rocks in a force 11 gale’
‘a top with a scooped neckline and a low back’
‘the Press are on my back’
‘at the back of the hotel is a secluded garden’
‘a rubber dinghy with an engine at the back’
‘she unbuttoned her dress from the back’
‘the back of a postcard’
‘their backs showed some impressive running and passing’
‘he moved back a pace’
‘she walked away without looking back’
‘he leaned back in his chair’
‘sit back and relax’
‘keep back from the roadside’
‘he knew that other people were back of him’
‘the team was five points back’
‘she put the book back on the shelf’
‘he drove to Glasgow and back in a day’
‘things were back to normal’
‘the folks back home are counting on him’
‘sideburns are back’
‘he made his fortune back in 1955’
‘they wrote back to me’
‘he had a newspaper empire backing him’
‘his mother backed him up on everything’
‘firefighters, backed up by helicopters and planes, fought to bring the flames under control’
‘over 97 per cent backed the changes’
‘on his new album he is backed by an American group’
‘he backed the horse at 33–1’
‘a mirror backed with tortoiseshell’
‘she tried to back away’
‘the government backed away from the plan’
‘he backed the Mercedes into the yard’
‘the wind had backed to the north-west’
‘his garage wall backs on to the neighbouring property’
‘the promenade is backed by lots of cafes’
‘the new single is backed with a track from the LP’
‘the back garden’
‘the back pocket of his jeans’
‘back roads’
‘she was owed back pay’
‘a back header’
‘a long back vowel, as in 'dance' or 'bath'’

--Word--
angle 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The space (usually measured in degrees) between two intersecting lines or surfaces at or close to the point where they meet.
A corner, especially an external projection or an internal recess of a part of a building or other structure.
A measure of the inclination of one line or surface with respect to another.
A position from which something is viewed or along which it travels or acts, typically as measured by its inclination from an implicit horizontal or vertical baseline.
A particular way of approaching or considering an issue or problem.
Each of the four cardinal points of a chart, from which the first, fourth, seventh, and tenth houses extend anticlockwise respectively.
Angle iron or a similar constructional material made of another metal.
Direct or incline at an angle.
Move or be inclined at an angle.
Present (information) to reflect a particular view or have a particular focus.
--Examples--
‘in any triangle, the longest side is opposite the largest angle’
‘spring-loaded hinges open the doors to any angle up to 90°’
‘a skylight in the angle of the roof’
‘sloping at an angle of 33° to the horizontal’
‘from this angle Maggie could not see Naomi's face’
‘discussing the problems from every conceivable angle’
‘he always had a fresh angle on life’
‘the supporting frame is usually of aluminium angle bolted together’
‘he angled his chair so that he could watch her’
‘still the rain angles down’
‘angle your answer so that it is relevant to the job for which you are applying’

--Word--
check 
--Type--
verb, noun, exclamation
--Meanings--
Examine (something) in order to determine its accuracy, quality, or condition, or to detect the presence of something.
Verify or establish to one's satisfaction.
Verify the accuracy of something by comparing it with (something else)
Agree or correspond when compared.
Look at; take notice of.
Stop or slow the progress of (something, typically something undesirable)
Curb or control (one's feelings or reaction)
Hamper or neutralize (an opponent) with one's body or stick.
Provide a means of preventing.
(of a passenger) consign (baggage) to the care of the transport provider with whom they are travelling.
Deposit (a coat, bag, or other item) for temporary safekeeping in the cloakroom of a restaurant, theatre, etc.
Mark or click on (a box) in order to select a particular option on a form, questionnaire, etc.
Move a piece or pawn to a square where it attacks (the opposing king)
(in poker) choose not to make a bet when called upon, allowing another player to do so instead.
(of a hound) pause to make sure of or regain a scent.
(of a trained hawk) abandon the intended quarry and fly after other prey.
An examination to test or ascertain accuracy, quality, or satisfactory condition.
A stopping or slowing of progress.
A means of control or restraint.
An act of hampering or neutralizing an opponent with one's body or stick.
A temporary loss of the scent in hunting.
The movement made by a hawk when it abandons its intended quarry and pursues other prey.
A move by which a piece or pawn directly attacks the opponent's king and by which the king may be checkmated.
The bill in a restaurant.
A token of identification for left luggage.
A counter used as a stake in a gambling game.
A part of a piano which catches the hammer and prevents it retouching the strings.
A crack or flaw in timber.
Expressing assent or agreement.
Used by a chess player to announce that the opponent's king has been placed in check.
--Examples--
‘customs officers have the right to check all luggage’
‘a simple blood test to check for anaemia’
‘phone us to check the availability of your chosen holiday’

‘keep your receipt to check against your statement’
‘check the remix’
‘efforts were made to check the disease’
‘he learned to check his excitement’
‘processes to check against deterioration in the quality of the data held’

‘the drinks weren't expensive and there's no cover charge but you do have to check your coat for $3.00’

‘a health check’
‘there was no check to the expansion of the market’
‘a permanent check upon the growth or abuse of central authority’
‘let's get the check’

back

noun, adverb, verb, adjective
--Meanings--
The rear surface of the human body from the shoulders to the hips.

The spine of a person or animal.

The position directly behind someone or something.
The side or part of an object that is not normally seen or used.
A player in a team game who plays in a defensive position behind the forwards.
The grounds of Cambridge colleges which back on to the River Cam.
In the opposite direction from the one that one is facing or travelling towards.
Expressing movement of the body into a reclining position.
At a distance away.

So as to return to an earlier or normal position or condition.

In or into the past.

Bet money on (a person or animal) winning a race or contest.

Walk or drive backwards.
(of the wind) change direction anticlockwise around the points of the compass.
Put (a sail) aback in order to slow the vessel down or assist in turning through the wind.
(of a building or other structure) have its back facing or adjacent to.
Lie behind or at the back of.
Put a piece of music on the less important side of (a vinyl recording)
Of or at the back of something.
In a remote or subsidiary position.
From or relating to the past.
Directed towards the rear or in a reversed course.
(of a sound) articulated at the back of the mouth.

backgammon 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

The most complete form of win in the game of backgammon.

Strike with a backhanded blow or stroke.
--Examples--
‘he drove a backhand into the net’
‘a backhand volley’
‘a backhand blow hammered into his wrist’
‘in a flash, he backhanded Ace across the jaw’

backhouse 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The rear part of a house, or a subsidiary building situated to the rear of the main premises of a house, especially one used for a specific purpose, as a wash house, storage space, etc. Chiefly regional in later use (now rare).
North American. A small building or room containing a toilet, especially one which is behind or outside a main building.

plaster 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A soft mixture of sand and cement and sometimes lime with water, for spreading on walls, ceilings, or other structures, to form a smooth hard surface when dried.
A hard white substance made by the addition of water to powdered and partly dehydrated gypsum, used for holding broken bones in place and making sculptures and casts.
The powder from which plaster of Paris is made.
An adhesive strip of material for covering cuts and wounds.
A bandage on which a poultice or liniment is spread for application.
Cover (a wall, ceiling, or other structure) with plaster.
Coat or cover something with (a substance), especially to an extent considered excessive.
Make (hair) lie flat by applying a liquid to it.
Display widely and conspicuously.
Apply a plaster cast or medical plaster to (a part of the body).
Bomb or shell (a target) heavily.
--Examples--
‘strip away the plaster to expose the bare brick’
‘the crumbling plaster ceiling’
‘he had both arms in plaster’
‘a small plaster statue of Our Lady’
‘waterproof plasters’
‘a large piece of plaster on her forehead’
‘the inside walls were plastered and painted’
‘the old windows have been filled and plastered over’
‘a face plastered in heavy make-up’
‘his hair was plastered down with water’
‘her story was plastered all over the December issue’
‘are they expecting the air force to plaster the city tonight or what?’

--Word--
putty 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A soft, malleable greyish-yellow paste, made from ground chalk and raw linseed oil, that hardens after a few hours and is used for sealing glass in window frames and filling holes in wood.
Any of a number of similar malleable substances used inside and outside buildings, e.g. plumber's putty, lime putty, or used for modelling or casting, e.g. epoxy putty.
A polishing powder, usually made from tin oxide, used in jewellery work.
Seal or cover (something) with putty.
--Examples--
‘countersink the screws so they can be covered with putty’
‘the manufacture of paints and putties’
‘give me a minute until I putty these windows in’
‘lightly puttied joints’

back 
--Type--
noun, adverb, verb, adjective
--Meanings--
The rear surface of the human body from the shoulders to the hips.
The upper surface of an animal's body that corresponds to a person's back.
The spine of a person or animal.
The main structure of a ship's hull or an aircraft's fuselage.
The part of a chair against which the sitter's back rests.
The part of a garment that covers a person's back.
A person's back regarded as carrying a load or bearing an imposition.
The side or part of something that is away from the spectator or from the direction in which it moves or faces; the rear.
The position directly behind someone or something.
The side or part of an object that is not normally seen or used.
A player in a team game who plays in a defensive position behind the forwards.
The grounds of Cambridge colleges which back on to the River Cam.
In the opposite direction from the one that one is facing or travelling towards.
Expressing movement of the body into a reclining position.
At a distance away.
Behind.
Losing by a specified margin.
So as to return to an earlier or normal position or condition.
At a place previously left or mentioned.
Fashionable again.
In or into the past.
In return.
Give financial, material, or moral support to.
Supplement in order to strengthen.
Be in favour of.
(in popular music) provide musical accompaniment to (a singer or musician)
Bet money on (a person or animal) winning a race or contest.
Cover the back of (an article) in order to support, protect, or decorate it.
Walk or drive backwards.
(of the wind) change direction anticlockwise around the points of the compass.
Put (a sail) aback in order to slow the vessel down or assist in turning through the wind.
(of a building or other structure) have its back facing or adjacent to.
Lie behind or at the back of.
Put a piece of music on the less important side of (a vinyl recording)
Of or at the back of something.
In a remote or subsidiary position.
From or relating to the past.
Directed towards the rear or in a reversed course.
(of a sound) articulated at the back of the mouth.
--Examples--
‘he lay on his back’
‘back pain’
‘the adults have white bodies with grey backs’
‘Demetrius broke its back on the rocks in a force 11 gale’
‘a top with a scooped neckline and a low back’
‘the Press are on my back’
‘at the back of the hotel is a secluded garden’
‘a rubber dinghy with an engine at the back’
‘she unbuttoned her dress from the back’
‘the back of a postcard’
‘their backs showed some impressive running and passing’
‘he moved back a pace’
‘she walked away without looking back’
‘he leaned back in his chair’
‘sit back and relax’
‘keep back from the roadside’
‘he knew that other people were back of him’
‘the team was five points back’
‘she put the book back on the shelf’
‘he drove to Glasgow and back in a day’
‘things were back to normal’
‘the folks back home are counting on him’
‘sideburns are back’
‘he made his fortune back in 1955’
‘they wrote back to me’
‘he had a newspaper empire backing him’
‘his mother backed him up on everything’
‘firefighters, backed up by helicopters and planes, fought to bring the flames under control’
‘over 97 per cent backed the changes’
‘on his new album he is backed by an American group’
‘he backed the horse at 33–1’
‘a mirror backed with tortoiseshell’
‘she tried to back away’
‘the government backed away from the plan’
‘he backed the Mercedes into the yard’
‘the wind had backed to the north-west’
‘his garage wall backs on to the neighbouring property’
‘the promenade is backed by lots of cafes’
‘the new single is backed with a track from the LP’
‘the back garden’
‘the back pocket of his jeans’
‘back roads’
‘she was owed back pay’
‘a back header’
‘a long back vowel, as in 'dance' or 'bath'’

backscatter 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
Deflection of radiation or particles through an angle of 180°.
Radiation or particles that have been deflected through an angle of 180°.
Light from a flashgun or other light source that is deflected directly into a lens.
Deflect (radiation or particles) through an angle of 180°
--Examples--
‘backscatter causes an underexposed picture with a blizzard effect’
‘the temperature of an optical fibre subtly affects how much light is backscattered’
‘backscattered sound reaches the sonar receiver’

back 
--Type--
noun, adverb, verb, adjective
--Meanings--
The rear surface of the human body from the shoulders to the hips.
The upper surface of an animal's body that corresponds to a person's back.
The spine of a person or animal.
The main structure of a ship's hull or an aircraft's fuselage.
The part of a chair against which the sitter's back rests.
The part of a garment that covers a person's back.
A person's back regarded as carrying a load or bearing an imposition.
The side or part of something that is away from the spectator or from the direction in which it moves or faces; the rear.
The position directly behind someone or something.
The side or part of an object that is not normally seen or used.
A player in a team game who plays in a defensive position behind the forwards.
The grounds of Cambridge colleges which back on to the River Cam.
In the opposite direction from the one that one is facing or travelling towards.
Expressing movement of the body into a reclining position.
At a distance away.
Behind.

So as to return to an earlier or normal position or condition.
At a place previously left or mentioned.
Fashionable again.
In or into the past.
In return.

--Word--
spike 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A thin, pointed piece of metal, wood, or another rigid material.
A large stout nail, especially one used to fasten a rail to a railway sleeper.
Each of several metal points set into the sole of a running shoe to prevent slipping.
A pair of running shoes with metal points set into the sole.
A pointed metal rod standing on a base and used for filing paper items such as bills, or journalistic material considered for publication and rejected.
A hypodermic needle.
A sharp increase in the magnitude or concentration of something.
A pulse of very short duration in which a rapid increase in voltage is followed by a rapid decrease.
A hostel ward offering temporary accommodation for the homeless.
Impale on or pierce with a sharp point.
Injure (a player) with the spikes on one's shoes.
(of a newspaper editor) reject (a story) by or as if by filing it on a spike.
Stop the progress of (a plan or undertaking); put an end to.
Render (a gun) useless by plugging up the vent with a spike.
Form into or cover with sharp points.
Take on a sharp, pointed shape.
Increase and then decrease sharply; reach a peak.
Add alcohol or a drug to contaminate (drink or food) surreptitiously.
Add sharp or pungent flavouring to (food or drink)
Enrich (a nuclear reactor or its fuel) with a particular isotope.
(in volleyball) hit (the ball) forcefully from a position near the net so that it moves downward into the opposite court.
Fling (the ball) forcefully to the ground, typically in celebration of a touchdown or victory.
--Examples--
‘the oil price spike’
‘he queued at the soup kitchen or the spike’
‘she spiked another oyster’
‘the editors deemed the article in bad taste and spiked it’
‘he doubted they would spike the entire effort over this one negotiation’
‘his hair was matted and spiked with blood’
‘lightning spiked across the sky’
‘oil prices would spike and fall again’
‘she bought me an orange juice and spiked it with vodka’
‘spike the liquid with lime or lemon juice’
‘the plutonium mixture could be spiked with caesium-137’

Give financial, material, or moral support to.
Supplement in order to strengthen.
Be in favour of.
(in popular music) provide musical accompaniment to (a singer or musician)
Bet money on (a person or animal) winning a race or contest.
Cover the back of (an article) in order to support, protect, or decorate it.
Walk or drive backwards.
(of the wind) change direction anticlockwise around the points of the compass.
Put (a sail) aback in order to slow the vessel down or assist in turning through the wind.
(of a building or other structure) have its back facing or adjacent to.
Lie behind or at the back of.
Put a piece of music on the less important side of (a vinyl recording)
Of or at the back of something.
In a remote or subsidiary position.
From or relating to the past.
Directed towards the rear or in a reversed course.
(of a sound) articulated at the back of the mouth.
--Examples--
‘he lay on his back’
‘back pain’
‘the adults have white bodies with grey backs’
‘Demetrius broke its back on the rocks in a force 11 gale’
‘a top with a scooped neckline and a low back’
‘the Press are on my back’
‘at the back of the hotel is a secluded garden’
‘a rubber dinghy with an engine at the back’
‘she unbuttoned her dress from the back’
‘the back of a postcard’
‘their backs showed some impressive running and passing’
‘he moved back a pace’
‘she walked away without looking back’
‘he leaned back in his chair’
‘sit back and relax’
‘keep back from the roadside’
‘he knew that other people were back of him’
‘the team was five points back’
‘she put the book back on the shelf’
‘he drove to Glasgow and back in a day’
‘things were back to normal’
‘the folks back home are counting on him’
‘sideburns are back’
‘he made his fortune back in 1955’
‘they wrote back to me’
‘he had a newspaper empire backing him’
‘his mother backed him up on everything’
‘firefighters, backed up by helicopters and planes, fought to bring the flames under control’
‘over 97 per cent backed the changes’
‘on his new album he is backed by an American group’
‘he backed the horse at 33–1’
‘a mirror backed with tortoiseshell’
‘she tried to back away’
‘the government backed away from the plan’
‘he backed the Mercedes into the yard’
‘the wind had backed to the north-west’
‘his garage wall backs on to the neighbouring property’
‘the promenade is backed by lots of cafes’
‘the new single is backed with a track from the LP’
‘the back garden’
‘the back pocket of his jeans’
‘back roads’
‘she was owed back pay’
‘a back header’
‘a long back vowel, as in 'dance' or 'bath'’

backstroke 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A swimming stroke performed on the back with the arms lifted alternately out of the water in a backward circular motion and the legs extended and kicking.
A race, usually of a specified length, in which backstroke is used.
A pull of the tail end of the rope from its highest position so as to swing the bell through a full circle.
--Examples--
‘I concentrated on the backstroke most of the time’
‘he's getting ready to swim the channel backstroke’
‘he was fifth in the 200 m backstroke’

--Word--
surge 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A sudden powerful forward or upward movement, especially by a crowd or by a natural force such as the tide.
A sudden large increase, typically a temporary one.
A major deployment of military forces to reinforce those already in a particular area.
A powerful rush of an emotion or feeling.
A sudden marked increase in voltage or current in an electric circuit.
(of a crowd or a natural force) move suddenly and powerfully forward or upward.
Increase suddenly and powerfully.
(of an emotion or feeling) affect someone powerfully and suddenly.
(of an electric voltage or current) increase suddenly.
(of a rope, chain, or windlass) slip back with a jerk.
--Examples--
‘flooding caused by tidal surges’
‘the firm predicted a 20% surge in sales’
‘Sophie felt a surge of anger’
‘the journalists surged forward’
‘shares surged to a record high’
‘indignation surged up within her’

Beat (someone) repeatedly as a punishment.
Of a yellowish-brown color.
(of a pale-skinned person) having golden-brown skin after exposure to the sun.
Tangent.

--Word--
titrate

verb
--Meanings--
Ascertain the amount of a constituent in (a solution) by measuring the volume of a known concentration of reagent required to complete a reaction with it, typically using an indicator.
Continuously measure and adjust the balance of (a physiological function or drug dosage)

‘the sample is titrated at a pH near 10 with EDTA solution’
‘titrate 25 cm³ of this solution against 0.10 M hydrochloric acid’
‘each patient received intravenous diazepam and pethidine, the doses being titrated according to the response’

trip

verb, noun
--Meanings--
Catch one's foot on something and stumble or fall.
Cause to stumble and fall.
Make a mistake.
Detect or expose someone in a mistake or inconsistency.
Walk, run, or dance with quick light steps.
(of words) flow lightly and easily.
Activate (a mechanism), especially by contact with a switch, catch, or other electrical device.
(of part of an electric circuit) disconnect automatically as a safety measure.
Release and raise (an anchor) from the seabed by means of a cable.
Turn (a yard or other object) from a horizontal to a vertical position for lowering.
Experience hallucinations induced by taking a psychedelic drug, especially LSD.
Be behaving in an irrational or crazy way.
Go on a short journey.
A journey or excursion, especially for pleasure.
The distance from start to finish of a race.
A stumble or fall due to catching one's foot on something.
A mistake.
A hallucinatory experience caused by taking a psychedelic drug, especially LSD.
An exciting or stimulating experience.
A self-indulgent attitude or activity.
A device that activates or disconnects a mechanism, circuit, etc.
A light, lively movement of a person's feet.
--Examples--
‘he tripped over his cat’
‘she tripped up during the penultimate lap’
‘she shot out her foot to trip him up’
‘taxpayers often trip up by not declaring taxable income’
‘the man was determined to trip him up on his economics’
‘they tripped up the terrace steps’

‘a trip to America’

‘trips and falls cause nearly half of all accidents’
‘an occasional trip in the performance’
‘acid trips’
‘it was quite a trip talking to you’
‘I'm not sure if she really liked me or if I was just part of her power trip’

‘yonder comes Dalinda; I know her by her trip’

--Word--
backwash 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The motion of receding waves.
A backward current created by an object moving through water or air.
The unpleasant after-effects of an event.
The liquid that flows back into a bottle, glass, etc. after someone has taken a drink, assumed to contain that person's saliva.
Clean (a filter) by reversing the flow of fluid through it.
--Examples--
‘the backwash is reduced in energy by the percolation of water into the shingle’
‘the backwash of a truck on the autobahn’
‘the backwash of the Cuban missile crisis’
‘Can you please stop drinking straight from the milk carton? I don't want your backwash!’
‘the very fine mesh is backwashed to remove solids’

A supporter of the theory that Bacon wrote the plays attributed to Shakespeare.

bacterium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of a large group of unicellular microorganisms which have cell walls but lack organelles and an organized nucleus, including some which can cause disease.

bacteroid 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Of the nature of or resembling a bacterium.
A bacteroid organism or structure, especially a modified cell formed by a symbiotic bacterium in a root nodule of a leguminous plant.

--Word--
Bactria 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An ancient country in central Asia, corresponding to the northern part of modern Afghanistan. It was the seat of a powerful Indo-Greek kingdom in the 3rd and 2nd centuries BC.
--Examples--

--Word--
bad 
--Type--
adjective, adverb
--Meanings--
Of poor quality or a low standard.
(of a person) not able to do a particular thing well.
Not appropriate in a particular situation.
Not such as to be hoped for or desired; unpleasant or unwelcome.
(of something causing pain, danger, or other unwelcome consequences) severe or serious.
Unfavourable; adverse.
Having a harmful effect on.
Failing to conform to standards of moral virtue or acceptable conduct.
(of language) using words generally considered offensive; vulgar.
(of a part of the body) injured, diseased, or painful.
(of a person) unwell.
(of food) decayed; putrid.
(of the atmosphere) polluted; unhealthy.
Regretful, guilty, or ashamed about something.
Worthless; not valid.
Good; excellent.
Badly.
--Examples--
‘a bad diet’
‘bad eyesight’
‘I'm so bad at names’
‘a bad listener’
‘morning was a bad time to ask Andy about anything’
‘bad news’
‘it was the worst day of his life’
‘bad luck’
‘bad headaches’
‘a bad crash’
‘a bad mistake’
‘bad reviews’
‘soap was bad for his face’
‘the bad guys’
‘bad behaviour’
‘a bad back’
‘I tried medication but felt even worse the next morning’
‘everything in the fridge went bad’
‘bad air’
‘she feels bad about ending their engagement’
‘I feel bad that our business is benefiting from something so horrible’
‘he ran up 87 bad cheques’
‘they want the baddest, best-looking Corvette there is’
‘he beat her up real bad’
--Word--
Badarian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Designating an early predynastic culture of Upper Egypt, evidence of which was first discovered at Badari in 1924; of or relating to this culture.
A person belonging to the Badarian culture.
With the. The Badarian culture.

noun, adjective

--Type--

Baden-Baden 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A spa town in the Black Forest; population 54,900 (est. 2007). It was a fashionable resort in the 19th century.
--Examples--
--Word--
Baden-Powell, Robert 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
1st Baron Baden-Powell of Gilwell (1857–1941), English soldier and founder of the Boy Scout movement; full name Robert Stephenson Smyth Baden-Powell. He became a national hero after his successful defence of Mafeking (1899–1900) in the Boer War.

badge 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A small piece of metal, plastic, or cloth bearing a design or words, typically worn to identify a person or to indicate membership of an organization or support for a cause.
A distinguishing object or emblem.
A feature or sign which reveals a particular quality.
Mark with a badge or other distinguishing emblem.
--Examples--
‘the badge of the Cheshire Regiment’
‘they wore plastic name badges’
‘the car's front badge is much loved by thieves’
‘philanthropy was regarded as a badge of social esteem’
‘vendors can badge their products ‘certified’’

badgeman 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A man who wears a badge by way of accreditation; specifically (a) a licensed beggar, an almsman; (b) (formerly, at Trinity College, Dublin) a servant who ran errands for undergraduates; (c) an authorized or licensed porter.

noun, verb

--Word--
badly 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In an unsatisfactory, inadequate, or unsuccessful way.
In a critical or unfavourable way.
In an unacceptable or unpleasant way.
Used to emphasize the seriousness of an unpleasant event or action.
Very much or intensely.
In a guilty or regretful way.
--Examples--
‘England have played badly this year’
‘the war was going badly’
‘try not to think badly of me’
‘she realized she was behaving rather badly’
‘the building was badly damaged by fire’
‘I wanted a baby so badly’
‘I felt badly about my unfriendliness’

Unfavourable; adverse.
Having a harmful effect on.
Failing to conform to standards of moral virtue or acceptable conduct.
(of language) using words generally considered offensive; vulgar.
(of a part of the body) injured, diseased, or painful.
(of a person) unwell.
(of food) decayed; putrid.
(of the atmosphere) polluted; unhealthy.
Regretful, guilty, or ashamed about something.
Worthless; not valid.
Good; excellent.
Badly.
--Examples--
‘a bad diet’
‘bad eyesight’
‘I'm so bad at names’
‘a bad listener’
‘morning was a bad time to ask Andy about anything’
‘bad news’
‘it was the worst day of his life’
‘bad luck’
‘bad headaches’
‘a bad crash’
‘a bad mistake’
‘bad reviews’
‘soap was bad for his face’
‘the bad guys’
‘bad behaviour’
‘a bad back’
‘I tried medication but felt even worse the next morning’
‘everything in the fridge went bad’
‘bad air’
‘she feels bad about ending their engagement’
‘I feel bad that our business is benefiting from something so horrible’
‘he ran up 87 bad cheques’
‘they want the baddest, best-looking Corvette there is’
‘he beat her up real bad’

--Word--
Badon Hill, Battle of 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An ancient British battle in which, according to one theory, the forces of King Arthur successfully defended themselves against the Saxons in AD 516. Another source implies that the battle was fought c.500 but does not connect it with King Arthur.
--Examples--

--Word--
bad 
--Type--
adjective, adverb
--Meanings--
Of poor quality or a low standard.
(of a person) not able to do a particular thing well.
Not appropriate in a particular situation.
Not such as to be hoped for or desired; unpleasant or unwelcome.
(of something causing pain, danger, or other unwelcome consequences) severe or serious.
Unfavourable; adverse.
Having a harmful effect on.
Failing to conform to standards of moral virtue or acceptable conduct.
(of language) using words generally considered offensive; vulgar.
(of a part of the body) injured, diseased, or painful.
(of a person) unwell.
(of food) decayed; putrid.
(of the atmosphere) polluted; unhealthy.
Regretful, guilty, or ashamed about something.
Worthless; not valid.
Good; excellent.
Badly.

Baedeker, Karl 
--Type--

Baedeker, Karl 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1801–59), German publisher. He is remembered chiefly for the series of guidebooks to which he gave his name and which are still published today.

--Word--
Baeyer, Adolf von 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1835–1917), German organic chemist; full name Johann Friedrich Wilhelm Adolf von Baeyer. He prepared the first barbiturates and investigated dyes, synthesizing indigo and determining its structural formula. Nobel Prize for Chemistry (1905).
--Examples--
--Word--
Baekeland, Leo Hendrik 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1863–1944), US chemist and inventor; born in Belgium. He invented the synthetic resin Bakelite in 1907.
--Examples--
--Word--
Baer, Karl Ernest von 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1792–1876), German biologist. He discovered that ova were particles within the ovarian follicles, and formulated the principle that in the developing embryo general characteristics appear before special ones. His studies were used by Darwin in the theory of evolution.
--Examples--
--Word--
Baez, Joan 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(born 1941), US folk singer and civil rights activist. She is best known for her performances at civil rights demonstrations in the early 1960s. Notable albums: Any Day Now (1968) and Diamonds and Rust (1975).
--Examples--
--Word--
Baffin, William 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(c.1584–1622), English navigator and explorer, the pilot of several expeditions in search of the North-West Passage 1612–16. He discovered the largest island of the Canadian Arctic in 1616; this and the strait between it and Greenland are named after him.
--Examples--
--Word--
baffle 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Totally bewilder or perplex.
Restrain or regulate (a fluid, sound, etc.)
A device used to restrain the flow of a fluid, gas, etc. or to prevent the spreading of sound or light in a particular direction.
--Examples--
‘an unexplained occurrence that baffled everyone’
‘to baffle the noise further, I pad the gunwales’
‘you can cut out glare from a strip light by concealing it behind a baffle’
‘a baffle plate’

bag 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A flexible container with an opening at the top, used for carrying things.
The amount contained in a bag.
A woman's handbag.
A piece of luggage.
The amount of game shot by a hunter.
Loose folds of skin under a person's eyes.
Loose-fitting trousers.
Plenty of.
A woman, especially an older one, perceived as unpleasant or unattractive.
One's particular interest or taste.
A base.
(in southern Africa) a unit of measurement, used especially of grain, equal to 70 kg (formerly 200 lb).
Put (something) in a bag.
Succeed in killing or catching (an animal)
Succeed in securing (something)
(of clothes, especially trousers) form loose bulges due to wear.
Abandon or give up on.
Criticize.
Fit (a patient) with an oxygen mask or other respiratory aid.
--Examples--
‘he arrived at the children's ward carrying a bag full of toys for the young patients’

bagatelle 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A game in which small balls are hit and then allowed to roll down a sloping board on which there are holes, each numbered with the score achieved if a ball goes into it, with pins acting as obstructions.

--Word--
bearing 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person's way of standing or moving.
The way a person behaves or conducts themselves.
Relation; relevance.
The ability to tolerate something bad or to be tolerated.
A part of a machine that allows one part to rotate or move in contact with another part with as little friction as possible.
The direction or position of something, or the direction of movement, relative to a fixed point. It is usually measured in degrees, typically with magnetic north as zero.
Awareness of one's position relative to one's surroundings.
A device or charge.
--Examples--
‘a man of precise military bearing’
‘she has the bearing of a First Lady’
‘the case has no direct bearing on the issues being considered’
‘school was bad enough, but now it's past bearing’
‘the Point is on a bearing of 015°’
‘there were no steeples or bridges from which to take a bearing’
‘he flashed the torch around, trying to get his bearings’
‘armorial bearings’

Bagehot, Walter 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1826–77), English economist and journalist. He became editor of the Economist in 1860, a post which he held until his death. Notable works: The English Constitution (1867), Lombard Street (1873).

--Word--
flower 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The seed-bearing part of a plant, consisting of reproductive organs (stamens and carpels) that are typically surrounded by a brightly coloured corolla (petals) and a green calyx (sepals).
A flower together with its stalk, picked for use as a decoration.
The state or period in which a plant's flowers have developed and opened.
Used as a friendly form of address, especially to a young girl or woman.
The finest individuals out of a number of people or things.
(of a plant) produce flowers; bloom.
Induce (a plant) to produce flowers.
Be in or reach an optimum stage of development; develop fully and richly.
--Examples--
‘a bunch of flowers’
‘the roses were just coming into flower’
‘all right then, flower?’
‘he wasted the flower of French youth on his dreams of empire’
‘Michaelmas daisies can flower as late as October’
‘she flowered into as striking a beauty as her mother’

--Word--
Baghdad 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The capital of Iraq, on the River Tigris; population 6,194,800 (est. 2009). A thriving city under the Abbasid caliphs in the 8th and 9th centuries, it was taken by the Ottoman sultan Suleiman in 1534 and remained under Ottoman rule until the First World War. In 1920 it became the capital of the newly created state of Iraq.
--Examples--
--Word--

A travelling salesman.

‘for a brief time he was chief bagman for both the provincial Liberal and Conservative parties’

--Word--
bagpipe 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A musical instrument with reed pipes that are sounded by the pressure of wind emitted from a bag squeezed by the player's arm. Bagpipes are associated especially with Scotland, but are also used in folk music in Ireland, Northumberland, and France, and in varying forms across Europe and western Asia.
--Examples--

reef

noun, noun, verb

A ridge of jagged rock, coral, or sand just above or below the surface of the sea.
A vein of ore in the earth, especially one containing gold.
Each of the several strips across a sail which can be taken in or rolled up to reduce the area exposed to the wind.
Take in one or more reefs of (a sail)

--Word--
bag 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A flexible container with an opening at the top, used for carrying things.
The amount contained in a bag.
A woman's handbag.
A piece of luggage.
The amount of game shot by a hunter.
Loose folds of skin under a person's eyes.
Loose-fitting trousers.
Plenty of.
A woman, especially an older one, perceived as unpleasant or unattractive.
One's particular interest or taste.
A base.
(in southern Africa) a unit of measurement, used especially of grain, equal to 70 kg (formerly 200 lb).
Put (something) in a bag.
Succeed in killing or catching (an animal)
Succeed in securing (something)
(of clothes, especially trousers) form loose bulges due to wear.
Abandon or give up on.
Criticize.
Fit (a patient) with an oxygen mask or other respiratory aid.
--Examples--
‘he arrived at the children's ward carrying a bag full of toys for the young patients’
‘a bag of sugar’
‘a velvet evening bag’
‘she began to unpack her bags’
‘an estimated bag of 3,000 ducks’
‘there were dark bags under her eyes’
‘a pair of flannel bags’
‘I had bags of energy’
‘an interfering old bag’
‘ask the manager about mild curries, if that's your bag’
‘customers bagged their own groceries’
‘Mike bagged nineteen cod’
‘we've bagged three awards for excellence’
‘get there early to bag a seat in the front row’
‘these trousers never bag at the knee’
‘she ought to just bag this marriage and get on with her life’
‘the fans should be backing him not bagging him’

--Word--
Baha'i 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A monotheistic religion founded in the 19th century as a development of Babism, emphasizing the essential oneness of humankind and of all religions and seeking world peace. The Baha'i faith was founded by the Persian Baha'ullah (1817–92) and his son Abdul Baha (1844–1921).
An adherent of the Baha'i faith.
--Examples--

--Word--
bay 
--Type--
noun, noun, noun, adjective, noun, verb, noun
--Meanings--
A broad inlet of the sea where the land curves inwards.
An indentation or recess in a range of hills or mountains.
An evergreen Mediterranean shrub with deep green leaves and purple berries. Its aromatic leaves are used in cooking and were formerly used to make triumphal crowns for victors.
A space created by a window line projecting outwards from a wall.
A section of wall between two buttresses or columns, especially in the nave of a church.
A compartment with a specified function in a vehicle, aircraft, or ship.
An area specially allocated or marked off.
A short terminal platform at a railway station also having through lines.
(of a horse) brown with black points.
A bay horse.
(of a dog, especially a large one) bark or howl loudly.
(of a group of people) shout loudly, typically to demand something.
Bay at.
The sound of baying.
--Examples--
‘a boat trip round the bay’
‘Sandy Bay’
‘the Bay of Biscay’
‘a bomb bay’
‘a loading bay’
‘the dogs bayed’
‘a jackal baying at the moon’
‘the crowd bayed for an encore’
‘a pack of wolves baying the moon’
‘the bloodhounds' heavy bay’
--Word--
baya 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A weaver bird that typically has a brown back, yellow cap, and black face, common throughout the Indian subcontinent and in SE Asia.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--
‘the bayadère emerged from a Hindu temple to perform her ritual dance’

--Word--
Rustin, Bayard 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1910–87), US civil rights leader and peace activist. As a special assistant to Martin Luther King, Jr., he helped to organize the 1963 March on Washington. He was the executive director of the A. Philip Randolph Institute 1964–87.

--Word--
Baikal, Lake 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A large lake in southern Siberia, the largest freshwater lake in Europe and Asia and, with a depth of 1,743 m (5,714 ft), the deepest lake in the world.

--Word--
Baikonur 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A mining town in central Kazakhstan. The world's first satellite (1957) and the first manned space flight (1961) were launched from the former Soviet space centre nearby.
--Examples--
--Word--
bail 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The temporary release of an accused person awaiting trial, sometimes on condition that a sum of money is lodged to guarantee their appearance in court.
Money paid by or for someone in order to secure their release on bail.
Release or secure the release of (a prisoner) on payment of bail.
--Examples--
‘he has been released on bail’
‘they feared the financier would be tempted to forfeit the £10 million bail and flee’
‘nine were bailed on drugs charges’
‘he was bailed to appear at Durham Crown Court’
‘his son called home to get bailed out of jail’

--Meanings--
A municipal officer and magistrate in Scotland.
--Examples--
--Word--
bailie 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A municipal officer and magistrate in Scotland.
--Examples--
--Word--
bailiff 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A sheriff's officer who executes writs and processes and carries out distraints and arrests.
The agent of a landlord.
An official in a court of law who keeps order, looks after prisoners, etc.
The sovereign's representative in a district, especially the chief officer of a hundred.
The first civil officer in the Channel Islands.
--Examples--
--Word--
bailiff 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A sheriff's officer who executes writs and processes and carries out distraints and arrests.
The agent of a landlord.
An official in a court of law who keeps order, looks after prisoners, etc.
The sovereign's representative in a district, especially the chief officer of a hundred.
The first civil officer in the Channel Islands.
--Examples--
--Word--
bailiff 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
bail 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The temporary release of an accused person awaiting trial, sometimes on condition that a sum of money is lodged to guarantee their appearance in court.
Money paid by or for someone in order to secure their release on bail.
Release or secure the release of (a prisoner) on payment of bail.
--Examples--
‘he has been released on bail’
‘they feared the financier would be tempted to forfeit the £10 million bail and flee’
‘nine were bailed on drugs charges’
‘he was bailed to appear at Durham Crown Court’
‘his son called home to get bailed out of jail’
--Word--
Baylis, Lilian 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1874–1937), English theatre manager; full name Lilian Mary Baylis. She is noted for her management of the Old Vic and for her initiative in reopening the old Sadler's Wells Theatre in 1931.
--Examples--
--Word--
bailiwick 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
One's sphere of operations or area of interest.
The district or jurisdiction of a bailie or bailiff.
--Examples--
‘after the war, the Middle East remained his bailiwick’
‘the warden had the right to arrest all poachers found within his bailiwick’

bailor 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person or party that entrusts goods to a bailee.
--Examples--

bailment 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An act of delivering goods to a bailee for a particular purpose, without transfer of ownership.
--Examples--
‘a contract of hire is a species of bailment’

Baylor, Elgin 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(born 1934), US basketball player; full name Elgin Gay Baylor. He played for the Lakers (Minneapolis until 1960, then Los Angeles) 1958–71. Basketball Hall of Fame (1977).

--Word--
bay 
--Type--
noun, noun, noun, adjective, noun, verb, noun
--Meanings--
A broad inlet of the sea where the land curves inwards.
An indentation or recess in a range of hills or mountains.
An evergreen Mediterranean shrub with deep green leaves and purple berries. Its aromatic leaves are used in cooking and were formerly used to make triumphal crowns for victors.
A space created by a window line projecting outwards from a wall.
A section of wall between two buttresses or columns, especially in the nave of a church.
A compartment with a specified function in a vehicle, aircraft, or ship.
An area specially allocated or marked off.
A short terminal platform at a railway station also having through lines.
(of a horse) brown with black points.
A bay horse.
(of a dog, especially a large one) bark or howl loudly.
(of a group of people) shout loudly, typically to demand something.
Bay at.
The sound of baying.
--Examples--
‘a boat trip round the bay’
‘Sandy Bay’
‘the Bay of Biscay’
‘a bomb bay’
‘a loading bay’
‘the dogs bayed’
‘a jackal baying at the moon’
‘the crowd bayed for an encore’
‘a pack of wolves baying the moon’
‘the bloodhounds' heavy bay’
--Word--
Johnson, Lyndon Baines 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1908–73), American Democratic statesman, 36th president of the US 1963–9; known as LBJ. His domestic programs, such as those for civil rights, were labeled the Great Society. During his administration, US involvement in Vietnam increased, undermining his popularity, and he did not seek re-election.
--Examples--
--Word--
bain-marie 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A pan of hot water in which a cooking container is placed for slow cooking.
--Examples--
‘cook in a bain-marie until the custard thickens slightly’

--Word--
bayonet 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A blade that may be fixed to the muzzle of a rifle and used to stab an opponent in hand-to-hand fighting.
Denoting a fitting for a light bulb, camera lens, etc. which is engaged by being pushed into a socket and then twisted to lock it in place.
Stab (someone) with a bayonet.
--Examples--
‘a bayonet fitting’
‘stragglers were bayoneted where they fell’

--Word--
Baird, John Logie 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1888–1946), Scottish pioneer of television. He made the first transatlantic transmission and demonstration of colour television in 1928 using a mechanical system which was soon superseded by an electronic system.
--Examples--

--Word--
bay 
--Type--
noun, noun, noun, adjective, noun, verb, noun
--Meanings--
A broad inlet of the sea where the land curves inwards.
An indentation or recess in a range of hills or mountains.
An evergreen Mediterranean shrub with deep green leaves and purple berries. Its aromatic leaves are used in cooking and were formerly used to make triumphal crowns for victors.
A space created by a window line projecting outwards from a wall.
A section of wall between two buttresses or columns, especially in the nave of a church.
A compartment with a specified function in a vehicle, aircraft, or ship.
An area specially allocated or marked off.
A short terminal platform at a railway station also having through lines.
(of a horse) brown with black points.
A bay horse.
(of a dog, especially a large one) bark or howl loudly.
(of a group of people) shout loudly, typically to demand something.
Bay at.
The sound of baying.
--Examples--
‘a boat trip round the bay’
‘Sandy Bay’
‘the Bay of Biscay’
‘a bomb bay’
‘a loading bay’
‘the dogs bayed’
‘a jackal baying at the moon’
‘the crowd bayed for an encore’
‘a pack of wolves baying the moon’
‘the bloodhounds' heavy bay’
--Word--
salt 
--Type--
noun, adjective, verb
--Meanings--
A white crystalline substance which gives seawater its characteristic taste and is used for seasoning or preserving food.
Something which adds freshness or piquancy.
Any chemical compound formed from the reaction of an acid with a base, with all or part of the hydrogen of the acid replaced by a metal or other cation.
An experienced sailor.
Impregnated with, treated with, or tasting of salt.
(of a plant) growing on the coast or in salt marshes.
Season or preserve with salt.
Make (something) piquant or more interesting.
Sprinkle (a road or path) with salt in order to melt snow or ice.
Fraudulently make (a mine) appear to be a paying one by placing rich ore into it.
(of a horse) having developed a resistance to disease by surviving it.
--Examples--
‘he described danger as the salt of pleasure’
‘he was one of many old salts who lined up to volunteer’
‘salt water’
‘salt beef’
‘the region is rich in salt plant communities and reed beds’
‘cook the carrots in boiling salted water’
‘there was good talk to salt the occasion’
‘local authorities worked to improve travel conditions by gritting and salting roads’
‘I shall want to see some evidence that there really is a seam—no salting it, no faking’

--Word--
bait 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
Food placed on a hook or in a net, trap, or fishing area to entice fish or other animals as prey.
Something intended to entice someone to do something.
Deliberately annoy or taunt (someone)
Cause dogs to attack (a trapped or restrained animal)
Put bait on (a hook) or in (a trap, net, or fishing area) to entice fish or animals.
--Examples--
‘herrings make excellent bait for pike’
‘fishing with live baits’
‘many potential buyers are reluctant to take the bait’
‘the other boys revelled in baiting him about his love of literature’
‘people who bait badgers’
‘I used a hook baited with fat’

--Word--
Baja California 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A mountainous peninsula in north-western Mexico that extends southwards from the border with California and separates the Gulf of California from the Pacific Ocean. It consists of two states of Mexico: Baja California (capital, Mexicali) and Baja California Sur (capital, La Paz).
--Examples--

bajada

--Meanings--

--Word--
Bajau 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a nomadic maritime people distributed throughout the islands and coastal areas from the Malay peninsula and Indonesia to the southern Philippines, and formerly associated with piracy.
The Austronesian language spoken by the Bajaus.
Of, relating to, or designating the Bajaus or their language.
--Examples--

bajra 
--Type--

--Meanings--
(in South Asia) pearl millet or similar grain.

--Word--
Baka 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of a nomadic Pygmy people inhabiting the rainforests of south-eastern Cameroon and northern Gabon.
The Bantu language of the Baka.
--Examples--

baked 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of food) cooked by dry heat in an oven.
Intoxicated by drink or drugs, especially cannabis.
--Examples--
‘baked apples’
‘I just want to get baked and watch a movie’
--Word--
bake 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Cook (food) by dry heat without direct exposure to a flame, typically in an oven.
(of food) be cooked by baking.
(of the sun or other agency) subject (something) to dry heat, especially so as to harden it.
Be or become extremely hot in prolonged sun or hot weather.
A dish consisting of a mixture of ingredients cooked in an oven.
A social gathering at which baked food of a specified kind is eaten.
--Examples--
‘they bake their own bread and cakes’
‘the bread was baking on hot stones’
‘the soil in the desert is baked dry by the fierce heat of the sun’
‘the city was baking in a heatwave’
‘a vegetable bake’
‘lobster bakes’

bakeshop 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A place where bread and cakes are made or sold; a bakery.
--Examples--
--Word--
bakeware 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Tins, trays, and other items used during baking.
--Examples--
--Word--
Bakewell tart 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A baked open pie consisting of a pastry case lined with jam and filled with almond sponge cake.
--Examples--
‘the recipe for Bakewell tart’
--Word--
bake 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Cook (food) by dry heat without direct exposure to a flame, typically in an oven.
(of food) be cooked by baking.
(of the sun or other agency) subject (something) to dry heat, especially so as to harden it.
Be or become extremely hot in prolonged sun or hot weather.
A dish consisting of a mixture of ingredients cooked in an oven.
A social gathering at which baked food of a specified kind is eaten.
--Examples--
‘they bake their own bread and cakes’
‘the bread was baking on hot stones’
‘the soil in the desert is baked dry by the fierce heat of the sun’
‘the city was baking in a heatwave’
‘a vegetable bake’
‘lobster bakes’
--Word--
baked 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of food) cooked by dry heat in an oven.
Intoxicated by drink or drugs, especially cannabis.
--Examples--
‘baked apples’
‘I just want to get baked and watch a movie’

baklava

noun

--Word--
Bakst, Léon 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1866–1924), Russian painter and designer; born Lev Samuilovich Rozenberg. He was a member of the Diaghilev circle and the Ballets Russes, for which he designed exotic, richly coloured sets and costumes.
--Examples--
--Word--
Baku 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The capital of Azerbaijan, on the Caspian Sea; population 1,917,000 (est. 2008). It is an industrial port and a centre of the oil industry.
--Examples--
--Word--
Bakunin, Mikhail 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1814–76), Russian anarchist; full name Mikhail Aleksandrovich Bakunin. He took part in the revolutions of 1848, and participated in the First International until his expulsion in 1872.
--Examples--

--Examples--
--Word--
balance 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An even distribution of weight enabling someone or something to remain upright and steady.
The ability of a boat to stay on course without adjustment of the rudder.
A situation in which different elements are equal or in the correct proportions.
Mental or emotional stability.
The relative volume of various sources of sound.
Harmony of design and proportion.
An apparatus for weighing, especially one with a central pivot, beam, and two scales.
The zodiacal sign or constellation Libra.
A counteracting weight or force.
The regulating device in a clock or watch.
A predominating amount; a preponderance.
A figure representing the difference between credits and debits in an account; the amount of money held in an account.
The difference between an amount due and an amount paid.
An amount left over.
Put (something) in a steady position so that it does not fall.
Remain in a steady position without falling.
Offset or compare the value of (one thing) with another.
Counteract or equal the effect or importance of.
Establish equal or appropriate proportions of elements in.
Compare debits and credits in (an account) so as to ensure that they are equal.
(of an account) have credits and debits equal.
--Examples--
‘she lost her balance and fell’
‘the obligations of political balance in broadcasting’
‘try to keep a balance between work and relaxation’
‘the way to some kind of peace and personal balance’
‘the balance of the voices is good’
‘the balance of opinion was that work was more important than leisure’
‘he accumulated a healthy balance with the savings bank’
‘the holiday balance must be paid by 8 weeks before departure’
‘a mug that she balanced on her knee’
‘Richard balanced on the ball of one foot’
‘the cost of obtaining such information needs to be balanced against its benefits’
‘he balanced his radical remarks with more familiar declarations’
‘they are struggling to balance work and family life’
‘the law requires the council to balance its books each year’
‘a surplus on the capital account to make the account balance’
--Word--
balancer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
balanced 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Keeping or showing a balance; in good proportions.
Taking everything into account; fairly judged or presented.
(especially of food) having different elements in the correct proportions.
(of a person or state of mind) having no emotion too strong or too weak; stable.
(of an electric circuit or signal) being symmetrical with respect to a reference point, usually earth.
--Examples--
‘she assembled a balanced team’
‘accurate and balanced information’
‘a healthy, balanced diet’
‘a balanced personality’

--Word--
Balanchine, George 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1904–83), Russian-born American ballet dancer and choreographer; born Georgi Melitonovich Balanchivadze. He was chief choreographer of Diaghilev's Ballets Russes during the 1920s, and in 1934 he co-founded the company which later became the New York City Ballet.
--Examples--

Balcon, Sir Michael 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1896–1977), English film producer associated chiefly with Ealing Studios. He produced such famous comedies as Kind Hearts and Coronets and Whisky Galore (both 1949).
--Examples--
--Word--
Balcones Escarpment 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The scarp marking the geologic fault that separates the plains of eastern Texas from highlands to the west. San Antonio, Austin, and Waco lie near or on it.
--Examples--

noun
--Meanings--

noun

--Word--
bald 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having a scalp wholly or partly lacking hair.
(of an animal) not covered by the usual fur, hair, or feathers.
(of a plant or an area of land) not covered by the usual leaves, bark, or vegetation.
(of a tyre) having the tread worn away.
Not having any extra detail or explanation; plain or blunt.
--Examples--
‘he was starting to go bald’
‘hedgehogs are born bald’
‘the bald trunks with their empty branches’
‘the Nissan had two bald tyres’
‘the bald statement in the preceding paragraph requires amplification’

--Word--
Balder 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A son of Odin and god of the summer sun. He was invulnerable to all things except mistletoe, with which the god Loki, by a trick, induced the blind god Hödur to kill him.

--Word--
Baldwin, Stanley 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
1st Earl Baldwin of Bewdley (1867–1947), British Conservative statesman, prime minister 1923–4, 1924–9, and 1935–7. Despite the German occupation of the Rhineland and the outbreak of the Spanish Civil War (both 1936), Baldwin opposed demands for rearmament, believing that the public would not support it.
--Examples--
--Word--
bale 
--Type--
proper noun, noun, verb, noun, verb
--Meanings--
A large wrapped or bound bundle of paper, hay, or cotton.
The quantity in a bale as a measure, specifically (in the US) 500 lb of cotton.
Make up into bales.
Evil considered as a destructive force.
Evil suffered; physical or mental torment.
--Examples--
‘the fire destroyed 500 bales of hay’
‘world cotton consumption was a record 86 m bales’
‘the straw is left on the field to be baled later’

Balenciaga, Cristóbal 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1895–1972), Spanish couturier. In the 1950s he contributed to the move away from the tight-waisted New Look originated by Christian Dior to a looser, semi-fitted style.

--Word--
Balfour, Arthur James 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
1st Earl of Balfour (1848–1930), British Conservative statesman, prime minister 1902–5. In 1917, in his capacity as Foreign Secretary, Balfour issued the declaration in favour of a Jewish national home in Palestine that came to be known as the Balfour Declaration.
--Examples--
--Word--
Bali 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A mountainous island of Indonesia, to the east of Java; chief city, Denpasar; population 3,470,700 (est. 2009).
--Examples--
--Word--
balibuntal 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A fine close-woven straw, used for making hats.
--Examples--
--Word--
Balinese 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to Bali or its people or language.
A native or inhabitant of Bali.
The Indonesian language of Bali, with around 4 million speakers.
--Examples--
--Word--
bale 
--Type--
proper noun, noun, verb, noun, verb
--Meanings--
A large wrapped or bound bundle of paper, hay, or cotton.
The quantity in a bale as a measure, specifically (in the US) 500 lb of cotton.
Make up into bales.
Evil considered as a destructive force.
Evil suffered; physical or mental torment.
--Examples--
‘the fire destroyed 500 bales of hay’
‘world cotton consumption was a record 86 m bales’
‘the straw is left on the field to be baled later’
--Word--
baler 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A machine for making up material such as paper, hay, or cotton into bales.
--Examples--
‘baler twine’
--Word--
balk 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Hesitate or be unwilling to accept an idea or undertaking.
Thwart or hinder (a plan or person)
Prevent a person or animal from having (something)
Miss or refuse (a chance or invitation)
(with reference to a horse) refuse or cause to refuse to go on.
A roughly squared timber beam.
The area on a billiard table between the balk line and the bottom cushion, within which in some circumstances a ball is protected from a direct stroke.
An unlawful action made by a pitcher that may deceive a base runner.
A ridge left unploughed between furrows.
--Examples--
‘he balked at such a drastic solution’
‘he raised every objection he could to balk this plan’
‘a tiger balked of its prey’
‘it's got to be done, so why balk it?’
‘he balked, both forefeet thrust stiffly in front of him’
‘most of the horses were balked and refused’
‘a balk of timber’
--Word--
Balkan 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to the Balkan Mountains or to the countries occupying the part of south-eastern Europe lying south of the Danube and Sava Rivers.
--Examples--
‘films from the Balkan countries’
‘a Balkan state’
--Word--
Balkanize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Divide (a region or body) into smaller mutually hostile states or groups.
--Examples--
‘ambitious neighbours would snatch pieces of territory, Balkanizing the country’
‘the balkanized world of the Senate Banking Committee’
