Balkanism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Balkan nature or character.
Also with lower-case initial. The action or fact of balkanizing or dividing.

--Word--
Balkans 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A range of mountains stretching eastwards across Bulgaria from the Serbian frontier to the Black Sea. The highest peak is Botev Peak (2,375 m; 7,793 ft).
The countries occupying the part of south-eastern Europe lying south of the Danube and Sava Rivers, forming a peninsula bounded by the Adriatic and Ionian Seas in the west, the Aegean and Black Seas in the east, and the Mediterranean in the south.
--Examples--
--Word--
balk 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Hesitate or be unwilling to accept an idea or undertaking.
Thwart or hinder (a plan or person)
Prevent a person or animal from having (something)
Miss or refuse (a chance or invitation)
(with reference to a horse) refuse or cause to refuse to go on.
A roughly squared timber beam.

An unlawful action made by a pitcher that may deceive a base runner.
A ridge left unploughed between furrows.

balk line 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A transverse line marked on a billiard table, extending the diameter of the D to the sides of the table.

--Word--
ball 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A solid or hollow spherical or egg-shaped object that is kicked, thrown, or hit in a game.
A spherical object or mass of material.
A solid non-explosive missile for a firearm.
A game played with a ball.
Baseball.
(in cricket) a delivery of the ball by the bowler to the batsman.
(in soccer) a pass of the ball in a specified direction or manner.
(in baseball) a pitch delivered outside the strike zone which the batter does not attempt to hit.
The rounded protuberant part of the foot at the base of the big toe.
The rounded protuberant part of the hand at the base of the thumb.
Squeeze or form (something) into a rounded shape.
Clench (one's fist) tightly.
Form a round shape.
Wrap the root ball of (a tree or shrub) to protect it during transportation.
Have sexual intercourse with.
(of a flower) fail to open properly, decaying in the half-open bud.
--Examples--
‘a cricket ball’
‘a ball of wool’
‘he crushed the card into a ball’
‘he comes across a group of kids playing ball’
‘kids have been playing ball in that lot for almost a hundred years’
‘young men would graduate from college and enter pro ball’
‘his half century came off only forty balls’
‘Whelan sent a long ball to Goddard’
‘he ignored it completely, and the umpire called it a ball’
‘Robert balled up his napkin and threw it on to his plate’
‘she balled her fist so that the nails dug into her palms’
‘the fishing nets eventually ball up and sink’
--Word--
ballas 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A tough aggregate of minute, concentrically arranged diamond crystals, occurring naturally in rounded masses especially in Brazil and South Africa, and mined or produced synthetically for industrial purposes.
--Examples--
--Word--
ballad 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A poem or song narrating a story in short stanzas. Traditional ballads are typically of unknown authorship, having been passed on orally from one generation to the next.
A slow sentimental or romantic song.
--Examples--
--Word--
ballade 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A poem consisting of one or more triplets of stanzas with a repeated refrain and an envoi.
A piece of music in romantic style with dramatic elements, typically for piano.

--Word--
baller 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A person or device that makes or forms something into balls.
A player of a ball game, especially a talented basketball player.
A successful person, typically one who has a lavish or self-indulgent lifestyle.
Extremely good or impressive; excellent.
--Examples--
‘a melon baller’
‘he's a baller who will take an open shot or create one’
‘who doesn't feel like a baller sipping whiskey out of a personalized glass?’
‘it was a pretty baller time, overall’
‘this place is baller!’
--Word--
Ballarat 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A mining and sheep-farming centre in Victoria, Australia; population 91,787 (2008). It is the site of the discovery in 1851 of the largest gold reserves in Australia.
--Examples--
--Word--
Ballard, J. G. 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1930–2009), British novelist and short-story writer; full name James Graham Ballard. He is known for dystopian science fiction such as his first novel, The Drowned World (1962), and Crash (1973).
--Examples--

--Word--
ballast 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
Heavy material, such as gravel, sand, or iron, placed in the bilge of a ship to ensure its stability.
A heavy substance carried in an airship or on a hot-air balloon to stabilize it and jettisoned when greater altitude is required.
Something providing stability or substance.
Gravel or coarse stone used to form the bed of a railway track or the substratum of a road.
A mixture of coarse and fine aggregate for making concrete.
A passive component used in an electric circuit to moderate changes in current.
Give stability to (a ship) by putting a heavy substance in its bilge.
Form (the bed of a railway line or the substratum of a road) with gravel or coarse stone.
--Examples--
‘the hull had insufficient ballast’
‘a forty kilo sandbag was used as ballast’
‘the film is an entertaining comedy with some serious ideas thrown in for ballast’
‘a thick layer of railway ballast’
‘ballasts are permanently wired into existing fixtures’
‘ballast resistors’
‘the vessel has been ballasted to give the necessary floating stability’
‘people insufficiently ballasted with factual information’
‘the track was laid with rails and ballasted with earth’
--Word--
cleaning 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of making something clean, especially the inside of a house.
--Examples--
‘the housekeeper will help with the cleaning’
--Word--
crushing 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Causing overwhelming disappointment or embarrassment.
--Examples--
‘the news came as a crushing blow’

--Word--
ballata 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A light song of Italian origin, typically on a romantic or moral theme, intended to accompany dancing, or with a dance-like rhythm.
--Examples--
--Word--
ball bearing 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A bearing in which the parts are separated by a ring of small freely rotating metal balls which reduce friction.
A metal ball used in a ball bearing.
--Examples--
--Word--
ball carrier 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A player in possession of the ball and attempting to advance it.
--Examples--
--Word--
ball carrier 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A player in possession of the ball and attempting to advance it.
--Examples--
--Word--
ball 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A solid or hollow spherical or egg-shaped object that is kicked, thrown, or hit in a game.
A spherical object or mass of material.
A solid non-explosive missile for a firearm.
A game played with a ball.
Baseball.
(in cricket) a delivery of the ball by the bowler to the batsman.
(in soccer) a pass of the ball in a specified direction or manner.
(in baseball) a pitch delivered outside the strike zone which the batter does not attempt to hit.
The rounded protuberant part of the foot at the base of the big toe.
The rounded protuberant part of the hand at the base of the thumb.
Squeeze or form (something) into a rounded shape.
Clench (one's fist) tightly.
Form a round shape.
Wrap the root ball of (a tree or shrub) to protect it during transportation.
Have sexual intercourse with.
(of a flower) fail to open properly, decaying in the half-open bud.
--Examples--
‘a cricket ball’
‘a ball of wool’
‘he crushed the card into a ball’
‘he comes across a group of kids playing ball’
‘kids have been playing ball in that lot for almost a hundred years’
‘young men would graduate from college and enter pro ball’
‘his half century came off only forty balls’
‘Whelan sent a long ball to Goddard’
‘he ignored it completely, and the umpire called it a ball’
‘Robert balled up his napkin and threw it on to his plate’
‘she balled her fist so that the nails dug into her palms’
‘the fishing nets eventually ball up and sink’
--Word--
balled up 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Formed into a ball.
Confused or frustrated.
--Examples--
‘I got slightly balled up in my facts’
--Word--
baller 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A person or device that makes or forms something into balls.
A player of a ball game, especially a talented basketball player.
A successful person, typically one who has a lavish or self-indulgent lifestyle.
Extremely good or impressive; excellent.
--Examples--
‘a melon baller’
‘he's a baller who will take an open shot or create one’
‘who doesn't feel like a baller sipping whiskey out of a personalized glass?’
‘it was a pretty baller time, overall’
‘this place is baller!’
--Word--
ballerina 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A female ballet dancer.
A ballet shoe.
--Examples--
‘wear ballerina pumps with a pretty day dress for a perfect spring/summer look’
‘New Yorkers walk a lot, so ballerinas make sense’
--Word--

--Type--

--Word--
ballet 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An artistic dance form performed to music, using precise and highly formalized set steps and gestures. Classical ballet, which originated in Renaissance Italy and established its present form during the 19th century, is characterized by light, graceful movements and the use of pointe shoes with reinforced toes.
A creative work or performance of ballet, or the music written for it.
A group of dancers who regularly perform ballets.
--Examples--
‘the Bolshoi Ballet’
--Word--
balletic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or characteristic of ballet.
--Examples--
‘a graceful, balletic movement’
--Word--
balletically 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
balletomane 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A ballet enthusiast.
--Examples--

balletomane 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A ballet enthusiast.
--Examples--
--Word--
balletomania 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--

ballyhoo 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--

‘a much-ballyhooed musical extravaganza’

--Word--
ball 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A solid or hollow spherical or egg-shaped object that is kicked, thrown, or hit in a game.
A spherical object or mass of material.
A solid non-explosive missile for a firearm.
A game played with a ball.
Baseball.
(in cricket) a delivery of the ball by the bowler to the batsman.
(in soccer) a pass of the ball in a specified direction or manner.
(in baseball) a pitch delivered outside the strike zone which the batter does not attempt to hit.
The rounded protuberant part of the foot at the base of the big toe.
The rounded protuberant part of the hand at the base of the thumb.
Squeeze or form (something) into a rounded shape.
Clench (one's fist) tightly.
Form a round shape.
Wrap the root ball of (a tree or shrub) to protect it during transportation.
Have sexual intercourse with.
(of a flower) fail to open properly, decaying in the half-open bud.
--Examples--
‘a cricket ball’
‘a ball of wool’
‘he crushed the card into a ball’
‘he comes across a group of kids playing ball’
‘kids have been playing ball in that lot for almost a hundred years’
‘young men would graduate from college and enter pro ball’
‘his half century came off only forty balls’
‘Whelan sent a long ball to Goddard’
‘he ignored it completely, and the umpire called it a ball’
‘Robert balled up his napkin and threw it on to his plate’
‘she balled her fist so that the nails dug into her palms’
‘the fishing nets eventually ball up and sink’

--Word--
Ballist 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of Balli Kombëtar, an Albanian nationalist and republican movement active during the Second World War (1939–45).
Of, relating to, or supporting Balli Kombëtar.

--Word--
ballistite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A smokeless explosive (propellant) invented by Alfred Nobel in 1887, consisting of nitroglycerine and soluble nitrocellulose in roughly equal proportions, stabilized with camphor or (later) diphenylamine.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Type--

--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
ballistocardiograph 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An instrument for recording the movements of the body caused by ejection of blood from the heart at each beat.
--Examples--

ballistocardiography

noun
--Meanings--
The use of a ballistocardiograph.
--Examples--
--Word--
ballistocardiographic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to a ballistocardiograph or ballistocardiography; (of movements of the body) caused by cardiovascular pulsation.

jasper 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An opaque reddish-brown semi-precious stone consisting of a variety of chalcedony.
A kind of fine hard porcelain developed by Josiah Wedgwood and used for Wedgwood cameos and other delicate work.

--Word--
ballo 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of various choreographed dances, or dance sequences, performed either at a social gathering or on the stage, often to a specific piece of music. Compare "dance". Now chiefly historical.
A piece of music intended for dancing, or composed in a dance rhythm.

--Word--
ballonné 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A bouncing step in dancing; specifically (Ballet) a jump in which the dancer stretches one leg to either the front, the back, or the side and lands on the other, before joining the feet in the cou-de-pied.
--Examples--
--Word--
ballonné 
--Type--

--Meanings--

ballon-sonde

noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
balloon 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A small coloured rubber bag which is inflated with air and then sealed at the neck, used as a child's toy or a decoration.
A large bag filled with hot air or gas to make it rise in the air, typically one carrying a basket for passengers.
A rounded outline in which the words or thoughts of characters in a comic strip or cartoon are written.
A large rounded drinking glass, used especially for brandy.
A stupid person.
Swell out in a spherical shape.
(of an amount of money spent or owed) increase rapidly.
(of a person) increase rapidly in weight.
(with reference to a ball) lob or be lobbed high in the air.
Travel by hot-air balloon.
--Examples--
‘the room was festooned with balloons and streamers’
‘his derision pricked the fragile balloon of her vanity’
‘he set his sights on crossing the Pacific by balloon’
‘a balloon reading ‘Ka-Pow!’’
‘a balloon of armagnac’
‘the trousers ballooned out below his waist’
‘the company's debt has ballooned in the last five years’
‘I ate out of boredom and I just ballooned up’
‘the ball ballooned into the air’
‘he is famous for ballooning across oceans’
--Word--
balloonism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The system, theory, or practice of ballooning.
--Examples--
--Word--
berry 
--Type--
noun, verb, proper noun
--Meanings--
A small roundish juicy fruit without a stone.
Any fruit that has its seeds enclosed in a fleshy pulp, for example a banana or tomato.
Any of various kernels or seeds, such as the coffee bean.
A fish egg or the roe of a lobster or similar creature.
Gather berries.
A former province of central France; chief town, Bourges.
--Examples--
‘juniper berries’
‘let's go berrying’

balloon 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A small coloured rubber bag which is inflated with air and then sealed at the neck, used as a child's toy or a decoration.

(of a person) increase rapidly in weight.

‘the room was festooned with balloons and streamers’

‘a balloon of armagnac’

--Word--
ballot 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A system of voting secretly and in writing on a particular issue.
The total number of votes cast in a ballot.
The piece of paper used to record a person's vote.
A lottery held to decide the allocation of tickets, shares, or other things among a number of applicants.
(of an organization) ask (members) to vote secretly on an issue.
Cast one's vote on an issue.
Decide the allocation of (something) to applicants by drawing lots.
--Examples--
‘a strike ballot’
‘the commissioners were elected by ballot’
‘he won 54 per cent of the ballot’
‘there were fifty-three abstentions and twenty-eight spoilt ballots’
‘a ballot decides which investors will be successful in buying the stock’
‘the union is preparing to ballot its members on industrial action’
‘ambulance crews balloted unanimously to reject the deal’
‘if the offer is oversubscribed acceptances will be balloted’
--Word--
Ballota 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A Eurasian genus of perennial herbs and shrubs of the family Lamiaceae (Labiatae), several kinds of which are grown ornamentally for their silvery-grey foliage; (also, in form ballota) a plant of this genus.
--Examples--
--Word--
ballotade 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A bouncing step or leap; (Dressage) a kind of leap in which a horse bends all four legs without kicking out the hind ones.
--Examples--
--Word--
ballotage 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In France: the second ballot, to decide between the two candidates who have come nearest to obtaining the majority.
--Examples--

‘ambulance crews balloted unanimously to reject the deal’
‘if the offer is oversubscribed acceptances will be balloted’
--Word--
ballotting 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
= ballottement.
--Examples--
--Word--
ballottable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Detectable by ballottement; moving in response to ballottement.
--Examples--
--Word--
ballottement 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: a method of diagnosing pregnancy in which the cervix is tapped by the examiner's finger (within the vagina), causing the fetus to strike against the walls of the uterus (now rare). Later also: a similar technique of physical examination, using sharp tapping blows to impart movement to an organ, especially in the ascitic abdomen.
--Examples--
--Word--
ballottine 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A dish of meat, poultry, or fish that is stuffed and rolled.
--Examples--

--Meanings--

ballpark 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A baseball ground.
An area or range within which an amount or estimate is likely to be correct.
(of a price or cost) approximate.
--Examples--
‘we can make a pretty good guess that this figure's in the ballpark’
‘the ballpark figure is $400–500’

balm 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A fragrant cream or liquid used to heal or soothe the skin.
Something that has a soothing or restorative effect.
A tree which yields a fragrant resinous substance, especially one used in medicine.
The resinous substance yielded by a balm.
A bushy herb of the mint family, with leaves smelling and tasting of lemon.
Used in names of other aromatic herbs of the mint family, e.g. bee balm.
--Examples--
‘a skin balm for use after shaving’
‘the murmur of the water can provide balm for troubled spirits’

proper noun
--Meanings--

A monetary unit of Romania, equal to one hundredth of a leu.

‘parking is banned around the harbour in summer’
‘her son was banned for life from the Centre’
‘a proposed ban on cigarette advertising’
‘a three-year driving ban’
‘a ban on dangerous jet-ski riders’
‘the Presbyterians were under the ban of the law’
‘the land might be smitten by the ban which once fell upon the Canaanites’
--Word--
Banaba 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An island in the western Pacific, just south of the equator to the west of the Gilbert Islands. Formerly within the Gilbert and Ellice Islands, the island has been part of Kiribati since 1979.

banana 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A long curved fruit which grows in clusters and has soft pulpy flesh and yellow skin when ripe.
The tropical and subtropical palmlike plant that bears bananas, having very large leaves but lacking a woody trunk.
Insane or extremely silly.
Extremely angry or excited.

bananaquit 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small songbird with a curved bill, typically with a white stripe over the eye, a sooty grey back, and yellow underparts. It is common in the Caribbean and Central and South America.

--Word--
Bancroft, Anne 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1931–2005), US actress; born Anna Maria Louisa Italiano. For her stage and film portrayal of Helen Keller's teacher Annie Sullivan in The Miracle Worker, she won a 1960 Tony Award and a 1962 Academy Award. Her role as Mrs. Robinson in the movie The Graduate (1967) is considered iconic.
--Examples--
--Word--
band 
--Type--
noun, verb, noun, verb
--Meanings--
A flat, thin strip or loop of material, used as a fastener, for reinforcement, or as decoration.
A plain ring for the finger, especially a gold wedding ring.
A ring of metal placed round a bird's leg to identify it.
A belt or strap transmitting motion between two wheels or pulleys.
A collar with two hanging strips, worn by certain lawyers, clerics, and academics as part of their formal dress.
A stripe, line, or elongated area of a different colour, texture, or composition from its surroundings.
A narrow stratum of rock or coal.
A range of values or a specified category within a series (used especially in financial contexts)
A range of frequencies or wavelengths in a spectrum.
Any of several groups into which school pupils of the same age are divided on the basis of broadly similar ability.
A thing that restrains, binds, or unites.
Provide or fit (an object) with something in the form of a strip or ring, for reinforcement or decoration.
Put a band on (a bird) for identification.
Mark (something) with a stripe or stripes of a different colour.
Allocate to a range or category (used especially in financial contexts)
Group (school pupils) into classes or sets for teaching purposes.
A group of people who have a common interest or purpose or who share a common feature.
A subgroup of a tribe.
(in Canada) a First Nations community that is officially recognized by the federal government, having an elected government with authority over internal affairs and acknowledged rights to a tract of land.
A small group of musicians and vocalists who play pop, jazz, or rock music.
A group of musicians who play brass, wind, or percussion instruments.
A herd or flock.
(of people or organizations) form a group to achieve a mutual objective.
--Examples--
‘wads of banknotes fastened with gummed paper bands’
‘Victoria settled the velvet band on her hair’
‘a narrow band of gold was her only jewellery’
‘look for a leg band on the osprey’
‘I'm wearing clerical bands, which are a sign of my office’
‘a long, narrow band of cloud’
‘the band of limestone continues north on the same contour’
‘your home was placed in one of eight valuation bands’
‘channels in the UHF band’
‘the top band of pupils’
‘must I fall, and die in bands?’
‘doors are banded with iron to make them stronger’
‘the map shows where starlings banded in Holland were later recovered’
‘the bird's bill is banded across the middle with black’
‘single adults in a property banded above D will pay more’
‘the infants are banded in terms of their ability’
‘a band of eminent British researchers’
‘Philip was born a Shushwap Indian, part of the Little Shushwap band’
‘the legislation requires aboriginal communities to post their band's financial statements online’
‘band members have an aboriginal right to fish in the river’
‘the band's last two albums’
‘a local band’
‘a military band’
‘moving bands of caribou’
‘local people banded together to fight the company’

Bandar Lampung 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city at the southern tip of Sumatra, in Indonesia; population 916,600 (est. 2009). It was created in the 1980s as a result of the amalgamation of the city of Tanjungkarang and the nearby port of Telukbetung.
--Examples--
--Word--
Bandaranaike, Sirimavo 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1916–2000), Sinhalese stateswoman, prime minister of Sri Lanka 1960–5, 1970–7, and 1994–2000; full name Sirimavo Ratwatte Dias Bandaranaike. The world's first woman prime minister, she succeeded her husband, S. W. R. D. Bandaranaike, after his assassination.

--Word--
band 
--Type--
noun, verb, noun, verb
--Meanings--
A flat, thin strip or loop of material, used as a fastener, for reinforcement, or as decoration.
A plain ring for the finger, especially a gold wedding ring.
A ring of metal placed round a bird's leg to identify it.
A belt or strap transmitting motion between two wheels or pulleys.
A collar with two hanging strips, worn by certain lawyers, clerics, and academics as part of their formal dress.
A stripe, line, or elongated area of a different colour, texture, or composition from its surroundings.
A narrow stratum of rock or coal.
A range of values or a specified category within a series (used especially in financial contexts)
A range of frequencies or wavelengths in a spectrum.
Any of several groups into which school pupils of the same age are divided on the basis of broadly similar ability.
A thing that restrains, binds, or unites.
Provide or fit (an object) with something in the form of a strip or ring, for reinforcement or decoration.
Put a band on (a bird) for identification.
Mark (something) with a stripe or stripes of a different colour.
Allocate to a range or category (used especially in financial contexts)
Group (school pupils) into classes or sets for teaching purposes.
A group of people who have a common interest or purpose or who share a common feature.
A subgroup of a tribe.
(in Canada) a First Nations community that is officially recognized by the federal government, having an elected government with authority over internal affairs and acknowledged rights to a tract of land.
A small group of musicians and vocalists who play pop, jazz, or rock music.
A group of musicians who play brass, wind, or percussion instruments.
A herd or flock.
(of people or organizations) form a group to achieve a mutual objective.
--Examples--
‘wads of banknotes fastened with gummed paper bands’
‘Victoria settled the velvet band on her hair’
‘a narrow band of gold was her only jewellery’
‘look for a leg band on the osprey’
‘I'm wearing clerical bands, which are a sign of my office’
‘a long, narrow band of cloud’
‘the band of limestone continues north on the same contour’
‘your home was placed in one of eight valuation bands’
‘channels in the UHF band’
‘the top band of pupils’
‘must I fall, and die in bands?’
‘doors are banded with iron to make them stronger’
‘the map shows where starlings banded in Holland were later recovered’
‘the bird's bill is banded across the middle with black’
‘single adults in a property banded above D will pay more’
‘the infants are banded in terms of their ability’
‘a band of eminent British researchers’
‘Philip was born a Shushwap Indian, part of the Little Shushwap band’
‘the legislation requires aboriginal communities to post their band's financial statements online’
‘band members have an aboriginal right to fish in the river’
‘the band's last two albums’
‘a local band’
‘a military band’
‘moving bands of caribou’
‘local people banded together to fight the company’
--Word--
bandsaw 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A saw consisting of an endless moving steel belt with a serrated edge.
--Examples--
--Word--
sawyer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who saws timber for a living.
An uprooted tree floating in a river but held fast at one end.
A large longhorn beetle whose larvae bore tunnels in the wood of injured or recently felled trees, producing an audible chewing sound.
A large wingless bush cricket whose larvae bore in wood.
--Examples--
--Word--
rift sawing 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(Originally) = "quarter sawing"; (now also North American) a method of sawing a log of wood into boards by quartering the log radially and making further cuts aligned to the centre of the tree and parallel to each other, producing boards with a uniform and straight grain pattern.
--Examples--
--Word--
shaped 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having a defined external form or outline.
--Examples--
‘an enclosed back garden with a shaped lawn’
‘her oval-shaped face’

Bandung 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--

noun
--Meanings--

bandwidth 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A range of frequencies within a given band, in particular that used for transmitting a signal.
The transmission capacity of a computer network or other telecommunication system.
The energy or mental capacity required to deal with a situation.
--Examples--

‘he lives alone, and says he doesn't have the bandwidth to handle a steady relationship’

--Word--
bang 
--Type--
noun, verb, adverb, exclamation
--Meanings--
A sudden loud, sharp noise.
A sharp blow causing a sudden, loud noise.
A sudden painful blow.
A fringe of hair cut straight across the forehead.
An act of sexual intercourse.
The character ‘!’.
Strike or put down (something) forcefully and noisily.
Cause (something) to strike something else unexpectedly and sharply.
(of a sports player) hit (a ball or a shot) forcefully and successfully.
Make a sudden loud noise, typically repeatedly.
(with reference to something such as a door) open or close noisily.
(of a person) move around or do something noisily.
Cut (hair) in a fringe.
(typically used of a man) have sexual intercourse with.
Exactly.
Completely.
Used to convey the sound of a sudden loud noise.
Used to convey the suddenness of an action.
--Examples--
‘the door slammed with a bang’
‘I went to answer a bang on the front door’
‘a nasty bang on the head’
‘she brushed back her wispy bangs’
‘he began to bang the table with his fist’
‘Sarah banged the phone down’
‘someone was banging on the door’
‘I banged my head on the low beams’
‘she banged into some shelves in the darkness’
‘he banged home four penalties in the opening twenty minutes’
‘the shutter was banging in the wind’
‘he banged the kitchen door shut behind him’
‘she was banging around the kitchen’
‘the train arrived bang on time’
‘bring your wardrobe bang up to date’
‘party poppers went bang’
‘the minute something becomes obsolete, bang, it's gone’

zither 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A musical instrument consisting of a flat wooden soundbox with numerous strings stretched across it, placed horizontally and played with the fingers and a plectrum. It is used especially in central European folk music.

--Word--
bank 
--Type--
noun, verb, noun, verb
--Meanings--
The land alongside or sloping down to a river or lake.
A long, high mass or mound of a particular substance.
An elevation in the seabed or a riverbed; a mudbank or sandbank.
A transverse slope given to a road, railway, or sports track to enable vehicles or runners to maintain speed round a curve.
The sideways tilt of an aircraft when turning in flight.
A set of similar things, especially electrical or electronic devices, grouped together in rows.
A tier of oars.
The cushion of a pool table.
Heap (a substance) into a mass or mound.
Form into a mass or mound.
Heap up (a fire) with tightly packed fuel so that it burns slowly.
Edge or surround with a ridge or row of something.
(with reference to an aircraft or vehicle) tilt or cause to tilt sideways in making a turn.
Build (a road, railway, or sports track) higher at the outer edge of a bend to facilitate fast cornering.
(of a locomotive) provide additional power for (a train) in ascending an incline.
(of an angler) succeed in landing (a fish)
(in pool) play (a ball) so that it rebounds off a surface such as a cushion.
A financial establishment that uses money deposited by customers for investment, pays it out when required, makes loans at interest, and exchanges currency.
A stock of something available for use when required.
A site or receptacle where something may be deposited for recycling.
The store of money or tokens held by the banker in some gambling or board games.
The person holding the bank in some gambling or board games; the banker.
A large amount of money.
Deposit (money or valuables) in a bank.
Have an account at a particular bank.
Win or earn (a sum of money)
Store (something, especially blood, tissue, or sperm) for future use.
--Examples--
‘willows lined the bank of the stream’
‘a grassy bank’
‘a bank of snow’
‘a rather steep angle of bank’
‘the DJ had big banks of lights and speakers on either side of his console’
‘the early ships had only twenty-five oars in each bank’
‘a bank shot’
‘the rain banked the soil up behind the gate’
‘snow was banked in humps at the roadside’
‘purple clouds banked up over the hills’
‘she banked up the fire’
‘steps banked with pots of chrysanthemums’
‘the plane banked as if to return to the airport’
‘I banked the aircraft steeply and turned’
‘the track was banked to allow a train to take curves faster while maintaining passenger comfort’
‘a banked racetrack’
‘it was the biggest rainbow trout that had ever been banked’
‘I banked the eight ball off two cushions’
‘a bank account’
‘a blood bank’
‘Britain has a bank of highly exportable skills’
‘a paper bank’
‘those entrepreneurs are raking in some serious bank’
‘the estate makes bank off the sale of merchandise’
‘she may have banked a cheque in the wrong account’
‘the family has banked with Coutts for generations’
‘he banked £100,000 for a hole-in-one’
‘the sperm is banked or held in storage for the following spring’

bankable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(especially in the entertainment industry) certain to bring profit and success.
Reliable.
--Examples--
‘he needed some bankable names to star in the film’
‘a bankable assurance’

--Word--
bank 
--Type--
noun, verb, noun, verb
--Meanings--
The land alongside or sloping down to a river or lake.
A long, high mass or mound of a particular substance.
An elevation in the seabed or a riverbed; a mudbank or sandbank.
A transverse slope given to a road, railway, or sports track to enable vehicles or runners to maintain speed round a curve.
The sideways tilt of an aircraft when turning in flight.
A set of similar things, especially electrical or electronic devices, grouped together in rows.
A tier of oars.
The cushion of a pool table.
Heap (a substance) into a mass or mound.
Form into a mass or mound.
Heap up (a fire) with tightly packed fuel so that it burns slowly.
Edge or surround with a ridge or row of something.
(with reference to an aircraft or vehicle) tilt or cause to tilt sideways in making a turn.
Build (a road, railway, or sports track) higher at the outer edge of a bend to facilitate fast cornering.
(of a locomotive) provide additional power for (a train) in ascending an incline.
(of an angler) succeed in landing (a fish)
(in pool) play (a ball) so that it rebounds off a surface such as a cushion.
A financial establishment that uses money deposited by customers for investment, pays it out when required, makes loans at interest, and exchanges currency.
A stock of something available for use when required.
A site or receptacle where something may be deposited for recycling.
The store of money or tokens held by the banker in some gambling or board games.
The person holding the bank in some gambling or board games; the banker.
A large amount of money.
Deposit (money or valuables) in a bank.
Have an account at a particular bank.
Win or earn (a sum of money)
Store (something, especially blood, tissue, or sperm) for future use.
--Examples--
‘willows lined the bank of the stream’
‘a grassy bank’
‘a bank of snow’
‘a rather steep angle of bank’
‘the DJ had big banks of lights and speakers on either side of his console’
‘the early ships had only twenty-five oars in each bank’
‘a bank shot’
‘the rain banked the soil up behind the gate’
‘snow was banked in humps at the roadside’
‘purple clouds banked up over the hills’
‘she banked up the fire’
‘steps banked with pots of chrysanthemums’
‘the plane banked as if to return to the airport’
‘I banked the aircraft steeply and turned’
‘the track was banked to allow a train to take curves faster while maintaining passenger comfort’
‘a banked racetrack’
‘it was the biggest rainbow trout that had ever been banked’
‘I banked the eight ball off two cushions’
‘a bank account’
‘a blood bank’
‘Britain has a bank of highly exportable skills’
‘a paper bank’
‘those entrepreneurs are raking in some serious bank’
‘the estate makes bank off the sale of merchandise’
‘she may have banked a cheque in the wrong account’
‘the family has banked with Coutts for generations’
‘he banked £100,000 for a hole-in-one’
‘the sperm is banked or held in storage for the following spring’
--Word--
banker 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
A person who manages or owns a bank or group of banks.
The person running the table, controlling play, or acting as dealer in some gambling or board games.
A supposedly certain bet.
A result forecast identically (while other forecasts differ) in several football-pool entries on one coupon.
A boat employed in cod fishing off Newfoundland.
A Newfoundland fisherman.
A river flooded to the top of its banks.
An additional locomotive used to assist a train in ascending an incline.
A bench at which a stonemason works.
--Examples--
‘the horse should be a banker for him in the Members' race’

--Word--
banket 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A gold-bearing conglomerate of quartz pebbles in a quartzitic matrix found in the Witwatersrand, South Africa (also with capital initial); (in extended use) any conglomerate of quartz pebbles in a quartzitic matrix visually similar to this. Usually as a mass noun; also "banket conglomerate".

--Word--
bankrupt 
--Type--
adjective, noun, verb
--Meanings--
(of a person or organization) declared in law as unable to pay their debts.
Impoverished or depleted.
Completely lacking in a particular good quality.
A person judged by a court to be insolvent, whose property is taken and disposed of for the benefit of their creditors.
Reduce (a person or organization) to bankruptcy.
--Examples--
‘his father went bankrupt and the family had to sell their home’
‘a bankrupt country with no natural resources’
‘their cause is morally bankrupt’
‘the strike nearly bankrupted the union’

‘a 7 per cent increase in bankruptcies’
‘the intellectual bankruptcy of the corporate media’

--Word--
ban 
--Type--
verb, noun, noun
--Meanings--
Officially or legally prohibit (something)
Officially prevent (someone) from doing something.
An official or legal prohibition.
An official exclusion of a person from an organization, country, or activity.
A sentence of outlawry.
A curse.
A monetary unit of Romania, equal to one hundredth of a leu.
--Examples--
‘parking is banned around the harbour in summer’
‘her son was banned for life from the Centre’
‘a proposed ban on cigarette advertising’
‘a three-year driving ban’
‘a ban on dangerous jet-ski riders’
‘the Presbyterians were under the ban of the law’
‘the land might be smitten by the ban which once fell upon the Canaanites’
--Word--
banner 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A long strip of cloth bearing a slogan or design, carried in a demonstration or procession or hung in a public place.
A flag on a pole used as the standard of a monarch, knight, or army.
Used in reference to support for a belief or principle.
A heading or advertisement appearing on a web page in the form of a bar, column, or box.
Excellent; outstanding.
--Examples--
‘a nuclear disarmament banner was carried round the war memorial’
‘students waved banners and chanted slogans’
‘the standard bearers followed, banners of bright red and yellow depicting dragons and stags’
‘the government is flying the free trade banner’
‘a banner ad’
‘the company was having a banner year’

Campbell-Bannerman, Sir Henry 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1836–1908), British Liberal statesman, prime minister 1905–8. His premiership saw the grant of self-government to the defeated Boer republics of Transvaal (1906) and the Orange River Colony (1907).

--Meanings--
The structure formed by the uprights and handrail at the side of a staircase.
A single upright at the side of a staircase.
--Examples--
‘he vaulted the banister’
‘she peered over the banisters’
‘I stuck my head between the banisters’
--Word--
bannock 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A round, flat loaf, typically unleavened, associated with Scotland and northern England.
--Examples--
--Word--
Bannockburn, Battle of 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A battle which took place near Stirling in central Scotland in 1314, in which the English army of Edward II, advancing to break the siege of Stirling Castle, was defeated by the Scots under Robert the Bruce.
--Examples--

ban 
--Type--
verb, noun, noun
--Meanings--
Officially or legally prohibit (something)
Officially prevent (someone) from doing something.
An official or legal prohibition.
An official exclusion of a person from an organization, country, or activity.
A sentence of outlawry.
A curse.
A monetary unit of Romania, equal to one hundredth of a leu.

‘parking is banned around the harbour in summer’
‘her son was banned for life from the Centre’
‘a proposed ban on cigarette advertising’
‘a three-year driving ban’
‘a ban on dangerous jet-ski riders’
‘the Presbyterians were under the ban of the law’
‘the land might be smitten by the ban which once fell upon the Canaanites’

--Word--
baptism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The Christian religious rite of sprinkling water on to a person's forehead or of immersing them in water, symbolizing purification or regeneration and admission to the Christian Church. In many denominations, baptism is performed on young children and is accompanied by name-giving.
A ceremony or occasion at which baptism takes place.
A person's initiation into a particular activity or role, typically one perceived as difficult.
--Examples--
‘the sacrament of baptism’
‘weddings, funerals, and baptisms are carried out in the parish church’
‘this event constituted his baptism as a politician’
--Word--
baptismal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to the Christian rite of baptism.
--Examples--
‘we will renew our baptismal vows’
‘baptismal rites’

baptismal

‘baptismal rites’

baptism

--Word--
baptist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of a Protestant Christian denomination advocating baptism only of adult believers by total immersion. Baptists form one of the largest Protestant bodies and are found throughout the world and especially in the US.
A person who baptizes someone.
--Examples--
--Word--
Helmont, Jan Baptista van 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1577–1644), Belgian chemist and physician. He made early studies on the conservation of matter, was the first to distinguish gases, and coined the word gas.
--Examples--
--Word--
Perrin, Jean Baptiste 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1870–1942), French physical chemist. He provided the definitive proof of the existence of atoms, proved that cathode rays are negatively charged, and investigated Brownian motion. Nobel Prize for Physics (1926).
--Examples--
--Word--

(in a Baptist chapel) a sunken receptacle used for baptism by total immersion.

--Word--
bar 
--Type--
noun, verb, preposition
--Meanings--
A long rigid piece of wood, metal, or similar material, typically used as an obstruction, fastening, or weapon.
An amount of food or another substance formed into a narrow block.
A band of colour or light.
The heating element of an electric fire.
The crossbar of a goal.
A metal strip below the clasp of a medal, awarded as an additional distinction.
A sandbank or shoal at the mouth of a harbour or an estuary.
A charge in the form of a narrow horizontal stripe across the shield.
A counter in a pub, restaurant, or cafe across which drinks or refreshments are served.
A room in a pub, restaurant, or hotel in which alcohol is served.
An establishment where alcohol and sometimes other refreshments are served.
A small shop, stall, or area in a department store that serves refreshments or provides a specified service.
A barrier or restriction to an action or advance.
A plea suspending an action or claim in a lawsuit.
Any of the short sections or measures, typically of equal time value, into which a piece of music is divided, shown on a score by vertical lines across the stave.
A partition in a court room, now usually notional, beyond which most people may not pass and at which an accused person stands.
A rail marking the end of each chamber in the Houses of Parliament.
The profession of barrister.
Barristers collectively.
Lawyers collectively.
A particular court of law.
Fasten (something, especially a door or window) with a bar or bars.
Prevent or prohibit (someone) from doing something or from going somewhere.
Forbid someone from undertaking (an activity)
Exclude (something) from consideration.
Prevent or delay (an action) by objection.
Mark (something) with bars or stripes.
Except for.
Except the horses indicated (used when stating the odds).
--Examples--
‘an iron bar’
‘bars on the windows’
‘a bar of chocolate’
‘gold bars’
‘bars of sunlight shafting through the windows’
‘Clark's shot hit the bar’
‘he was awarded a second bar to his DSO’
‘the bar to the estuary of the River Eske’
‘standing at the bar’
‘the oak-panelled bar of the Lion’
‘bar stools’
‘a small friendly bar open all day’
‘a sandwich bar’
‘political differences are not necessarily a bar to a good relationship’
‘the opening bars of the first hymn’
‘the prisoner at the bar’
‘he had to appear at the Bar of the House for a reprimand by the Speaker’
‘his dismissal from the Singapore Bar’
‘she bolted and barred the door’
‘journalists had been barred from covering the elections’
‘the job she loved had been barred to her’
‘nothing is barred in the crime novel’
‘his face was barred with light’
‘his kids were all gone now, bar one’
--Word--
bar 
--Type--
noun, verb, preposition
--Meanings--
A long rigid piece of wood, metal, or similar material, typically used as an obstruction, fastening, or weapon.
An amount of food or another substance formed into a narrow block.
A band of colour or light.

A barrier or restriction to an action or advance.
A plea suspending an action or claim in a lawsuit.

A rail marking the end of each chamber in the Houses of Parliament.
The profession of barrister.
Barristers collectively.
Lawyers collectively.
A particular court of law.

Prevent or prohibit (someone) from doing something or from going somewhere.
Forbid someone from undertaking (an activity)
Exclude (something) from consideration.
Prevent or delay (an action) by objection.
Mark (something) with bars or stripes.
Except for.
Except the horses indicated (used when stating the odds).

Obama, Barack 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(born 1961), US Democratic statesman, 44th president of the US 2009–17; full name Barack Hussein Obama. He was the first African American to be elected to the presidency, and was re-elected in 2012 for a second term. He was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 2009.

A fine woollen cloth, sometimes mixed with silk or cotton, used chiefly for coats and suits.
--Examples--
--Word--
baraza 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(in East Africa) a public meeting place.
--Examples--
--Word--
barb 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
A sharp projection near the end of an arrow, fish hook, or similar object, which is angled away from the main point so as to make extraction difficult.
A cluster of spikes on barbed wire.
A deliberately hurtful remark.
A beard-like filament at the mouth of some fish, such as barbel and catfish.
Each of the fine hair-like filaments growing from the shaft of a feather, forming the vane.
A freshwater fish with barbels around the mouth, popular in aquaria.
A small horse of a hardy breed originally from North Africa.
--Examples--
‘his barb hurt more than she cared to admit’
--Word--
barbacoa 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(in Mexican cooking) beef, lamb, or other meat that has been slowly cooked with seasonings, typically shredded as a filling in tacos, burritos, etc.
--Examples--
‘a fried tortilla filled with your choice of marinated chicken, barbacoa, or carnitas’
--Word--
Barbadian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or characteristic of Barbados or its inhabitants.
A native or inhabitant of Barbados.
--Examples--
‘a senior Barbadian player’
‘written literature by Barbadians received its first real debut in the 1940s and 1950s’
--Word--
Barbados 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An island country in the Caribbean, the most easterly of the Caribbean islands; population 284,000 (estimated 2015); official language, English; capital, Bridgetown. Barbados became a British colony in the 1630s and remained British until 1966, when it gained independence as a Commonwealth state.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Type--

--Word--
Santa Barbara 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A resort city in California, on the Pacific coast, north-west of Los Angeles; population 86,400 (est. 2008).
--Examples--
--Word--
Anne 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1665–1714), queen of England and Scotland (known as Great Britain from 1707) and Ireland 1702–14. The last of the Stuart monarchs, daughter of the Catholic James II (but herself a Protestant), she succeeded her brother-in-law William III to the throne. None of her children survived into adulthood, and by the Act of Settlement (1701) the throne passed to the House of Hanover on her death.
--Examples--
--Word--
Barbary 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A former name for the Saracen countries of north and north-western Africa, together with Moorish Spain. The area was noted between the 16th and 18th centuries as a haunt of pirates.
--Examples--
--Word--
barbarian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
(in ancient times) a member of a people not belonging to one of the great civilizations (Greek, Roman, Christian)
An uncultured or brutish person.
Relating to ancient barbarians.
Uncultured; brutish.
--Examples--
‘the city was besieged by the barbarians’
‘you arrogant barbarian!’
‘barbarian invasions’

--Word--
barbarism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Absence of culture and civilization.
A word or expression which is badly formed according to traditional philological rules, e.g. a word formed from elements of different languages, such as breathalyser (English and Greek) or television (Greek and Latin).
Extreme cruelty or brutality.
--Examples--
‘the collapse of civilization and the return to barbarism’
‘she called the execution an act of barbarism’

Barbarossa 
--Type--
proper noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
(c.1483–1546), Barbary pirate; born Khair ad-Din. He was notorious for his successes against Christian vessels in the eastern Mediterranean.

barbecue 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A meal or gathering at which meat, fish, or other food is cooked out of doors on a rack over an open fire or on a special appliance.
A rack or appliance used for the preparation of food at a barbecue.
Food cooked on a barbecue.
Cook (food) on a barbecue.
--Examples--
‘in the evening there was a barbecue’
‘a barbecue area’
‘food was placed to sizzle on the barbecue’
‘all the barbecue he could eat’
‘fish barbecued with herbs’
‘barbecued chicken’

--Meanings--

An African marine or freshwater fish with barbels round the mouth.

--Word--
barbet 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A large-headed, brightly coloured fruit-eating bird that has a stout bill with tufts of bristles at the base. Barbets are found on all continents, especially in the tropics.

--Word--
Barbizon School 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A mid 19th-century school of French landscape painters who reacted against classical conventions and based their art on direct study of nature. Led by Théodore Rousseau, the group included Charles Daubigny and Jean-François Millet.

Streisand, Barbra 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(born 1942), US singer, actress, and film director; born Barbara Joan Streisand. She won an Oscar for her performance in Funny Girl (1968). She later played the lead in A Star is Born (1976); the film's song ‘Evergreen’, composed by Streisand, won an Oscar.

--Meanings--
Relating to the remote inland area of Australia.
--Examples--
‘Barcoo sickness’
--Word--
bard 
--Type--
noun, noun, verb
--Meanings--
A poet, traditionally one reciting epics and associated with a particular oral tradition.
Shakespeare.
The winner of a prize for Welsh verse at an Eisteddfod.
A rasher of fat bacon placed on meat or game before roasting.
Cover (meat or game) with rashers of fat bacon.
--Examples--
‘our national bard, Robert Burns’
‘he was admitted as a Bard at the National Eisteddfod’
‘the venison was barded and marinated’

--Type--

--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
Bardeen, John 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1908–91), US physicist. With William Shockley and Walter Brattain, he developed a point-contact transistor, for which they shared the Nobel Prize for Physics in 1956. He also worked on the theory of superconductivity, for which he shared the prize in 1972 with colleagues Leon N. Cooper (born 1930) and John Robert Schrieffer (born 1931).
--Examples--

bardo 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(in Tibetan Buddhism) a state of existence between death and rebirth, varying in length according to a person's conduct in life and manner of, or age at, death.

Bardot, Brigitte 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(born 1934), French actress. The film And God Created Woman (1956) established her reputation as an international sex symbol.

--Word--
bare 
--Type--
adjective, verb, determiner, adverb
--Meanings--
(of a person or part of thtye body) not clothed or covered.
Without the appropriate, usual, or natural covering.
Without the appropriate or usual contents.
Devoid of; without.
Without addition; basic and simple.
Only just sufficient.
Surprisingly small in number or amount.
Uncover (a part of the body or other thing) and expose it to view.
A large amount or number of.
Very; really (used as an intensifier)
--Examples--
‘he was bare from the waist up’
‘she padded in bare feet towards the door’
‘leaf fall had left the trees bare’
‘bare floorboards’
‘a bare cell with just a mattress’
‘the interior was bare of plaster’
‘he outlined the bare essentials of the story’
‘the bare minimum of furniture’
‘all you need to get started with this program is a bare 10K bytes of memory’
‘he bared his chest to show his scar’
‘my birthday's on the 22nd—I'm gonna get bare cash’
‘I've got bare work to do’
‘you can't promote your party all over Twitter and then get mad when bare people show up’
‘you are bare lazy’
‘I'm in a bare good mood for once’
--Word--
ankled 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--

bareback 
--Type--
adverb, adjective
--Meanings--
On an unsaddled horse or other animal.
(in relation to sexual intercourse) without a condom.
Riding on an unsaddled horse or other animal.
Relating to or denoting sexual intercourse that is performed without a condom.
--Examples--
‘she rode bareback, without saddle or stirrups’
‘a bareback circus rider’

--Word--
Barebones Parliament 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The nickname of Cromwell's Parliament of 1653, from one of its members, Praise-God Barbon, an Anabaptist leather seller of Fleet Street. It replaced the Rump Parliament, but was itself dissolved within a few months.
--Examples--
--Word--
Barebones Parliament 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The nickname of Cromwell's Parliament of 1653, from one of its members, Praise-God Barbon, an Anabaptist leather seller of Fleet Street. It replaced the Rump Parliament, but was itself dissolved within a few months.
--Examples--
--Word--
boned 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of meat or fish) having had the bones removed before being sold, cooked, or served.
(of a person) having bones of the specified type.
(of a garment) stiffened with strips of plastic or whalebone to give shape to the wearer's figure or the garment.
--Examples--
‘boned turkey with cranberry stuffing’
‘she was fine-boned and boyishly slim’
‘the dress has a boned bodice’

--Word--
branched 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a tree or plant) having parts that grow out from the trunk or from a bough.
Having lateral extensions or subdivisions extending from the main part.
--Examples--
‘a tall, branched plant with flowers’
‘many trees are bare-branched already’
‘the elaborate branched antlers of the stag’
‘a branched network’

--Word--
Barenboim, Daniel 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(born 1942), Israeli pianist and conductor, musical director of the Orchestre de Paris 1975–88 and of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra 1991–2006. In 1967 he married the cellist Jacqueline du Pré.
--Examples--

Barents, Willem 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(died 1597), Dutch explorer. The leader of several expeditions in search of the North-East Passage to Asia, Barents discovered Spitsbergen and reached Novaya Zemlya, off the coast of which he died.
--Examples--

--Word--
bargain 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An agreement between two or more people or groups as to what each will do for the other.
A thing bought or offered for sale much more cheaply than is usual or expected.
Negotiate the terms and conditions of a transaction.
Part with something after negotiation but get little or nothing in return.
Be prepared for; expect.
--Examples--
‘bargains between political parties supporting the government’
‘the table was a real bargain’
‘a bargain price of 99p’
‘he bargained with the local council to rent the stadium’
‘his determination not to bargain away any of the province's economic powers’
‘I got more information than I'd bargained for’
‘he didn't bargain on this storm’
--Word--
bargainable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
That may be bargained with or about; open to negotiation.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Examples--
‘bargain-basement prices’

--Word--
barge 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A long flat-bottomed boat for carrying freight on canals and rivers, either under its own power or towed by another.
A long ornamental boat used for pleasure or ceremony.
A boat used by the chief officers of a warship.
Move forcefully or roughly.
Intrude or interrupt rudely or awkwardly.
(chiefly in a sporting context) run into and collide with (someone), typically intentionally.
Convey (freight) by barge.
--Examples--
‘we can't just barge into a private garden’
‘sorry to barge in on your cosy evening’
‘you can use this method to barge an opponent’
‘just barge the other skater off the ball’
--Word--

noun

--Word--
couple 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
Two people or things of the same sort considered together.
A pair of partners in a dance or game.
A pair of hunting dogs.
Two collars joined together and used for holding hounds together.
A pair of rafters.
A pair of equal and parallel forces acting in opposite directions, and tending to cause rotation about an axis perpendicular to the plane containing them.
Two people who are married or otherwise closely associated romantically or sexually.
An indefinite small number.
Link or combine (something) with something else.
Connect (a railway vehicle or a piece of equipment) to another.
Connect (two electrical components) using electromagnetic induction, electrostatic charge, or an optical link.
Join to form a pair.
Mate or have sexual intercourse.
--Examples--
‘a couple of girls were playing marbles’
‘in three weeks the couple fell in love and became engaged’
‘a honeymoon couple’
‘he hoped she'd be better in a couple of days’
‘we got some eggs—would you like a couple?’
‘just a couple more questions’
‘clean the stains with a couple squirts dishwashing liquid’
‘a sense of hope is coupled with a palpable sense of loss’
‘a cable is coupled up to one of the wheels’
‘resistors are used to couple the oscillators’
‘the beetles may couple up to form a pair’
‘as middle-class youth grew more tolerant of sex, they started to couple more often’

goose 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A large waterbird with a long neck, short legs, webbed feet, and a short broad bill. Generally geese are larger than ducks and have longer necks and shorter bills.
A female goose.
The flesh of a goose as food.
A foolish person.
A tailor's smoothing iron.
Poke (someone) in the bottom.
Give (something) a boost; invigorate.
--Examples--
‘‘Silly goose,’ he murmured fondly’
‘the government's desire to goose the tired housing market’

bare 
--Type--
adjective, verb, determiner, adverb
--Meanings--
(of a person or part of thtye body) not clothed or covered.
Without the appropriate, usual, or natural covering.
Without the appropriate or usual contents.
Devoid of; without.
Without addition; basic and simple.
Only just sufficient.
Surprisingly small in number or amount.
Uncover (a part of the body or other thing) and expose it to view.
A large amount or number of.
Very; really (used as an intensifier)
--Examples--
‘he was bare from the waist up’
‘she padded in bare feet towards the door’
‘leaf fall had left the trees bare’
‘bare floorboards’
‘a bare cell with just a mattress’
‘the interior was bare of plaster’
‘he outlined the bare essentials of the story’
‘the bare minimum of furniture’
‘all you need to get started with this program is a bare 10K bytes of memory’
‘he bared his chest to show his scar’
‘my birthday's on the 22nd—I'm gonna get bare cash’
‘I've got bare work to do’
‘you can't promote your party all over Twitter and then get mad when bare people show up’
‘you are bare lazy’
‘I'm in a bare good mood for once’

barium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The chemical element of atomic number 56, a soft white reactive metal of the alkaline earth group.
A mixture of barium sulphate and water, opaque to X-rays, which is swallowed to permit radiological examination of the stomach or intestines.
--Examples--
‘a barium meal’
--Word--
barium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The chemical element of atomic number 56, a soft white reactive metal of the alkaline earth group.
A mixture of barium sulphate and water, opaque to X-rays, which is swallowed to permit radiological examination of the stomach or intestines.
--Examples--
‘a barium meal’
--Word--
bark 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The sharp explosive cry of a dog, fox, or seal.
A sound resembling a bark, typically one made by someone laughing or coughing.
(of a dog, fox, or seal) give a bark.
(of a person) make a sound resembling a bark.
Utter (a command or question) abruptly or aggressively.
Call out in order to sell or advertise something.
--Examples--
‘a short bark of laughter’
‘a dog barked at her’
‘she barked with laughter’
‘he began barking out his orders’
‘‘Nobody is allowed up here,’ he barked’
‘doormen bark at passers-by, promising hot music and cold beer’

--Word--
Barkley, Charles 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(born 1963), US basketball player; full name Charles Wade Barkley. He played for the Philadelphia 76ers 1984–92, the Phoenix Suns 1992–96, and the Houston Rockets 1996–2000. He was also a member of the US Olympic “Dream Team” in 1992. Basketball Hall of Fame (2006).
--Examples--
--Word--
bark 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The sharp explosive cry of a dog, fox, or seal.
A sound resembling a bark, typically one made by someone laughing or coughing.
(of a dog, fox, or seal) give a bark.
(of a person) make a sound resembling a bark.
Utter (a command or question) abruptly or aggressively.
Call out in order to sell or advertise something.
--Examples--
‘a short bark of laughter’
‘a dog barked at her’
‘she barked with laughter’
‘he began barking out his orders’
‘‘Nobody is allowed up here,’ he barked’
‘doormen bark at passers-by, promising hot music and cold beer’
--Word--
bark 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The sharp explosive cry of a dog, fox, or seal.
A sound resembling a bark, typically one made by someone laughing or coughing.
(of a dog, fox, or seal) give a bark.
(of a person) make a sound resembling a bark.
Utter (a command or question) abruptly or aggressively.
Call out in order to sell or advertise something.
--Examples--
‘a short bark of laughter’
‘a dog barked at her’
‘she barked with laughter’
‘he began barking out his orders’
‘‘Nobody is allowed up here,’ he barked’
‘doormen bark at passers-by, promising hot music and cold beer’
--Word--
bark 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The sharp explosive cry of a dog, fox, or seal.
A sound resembling a bark, typically one made by someone laughing or coughing.
(of a dog, fox, or seal) give a bark.
(of a person) make a sound resembling a bark.
Utter (a command or question) abruptly or aggressively.
Call out in order to sell or advertise something.
--Examples--
‘a short bark of laughter’
‘a dog barked at her’
‘she barked with laughter’
‘he began barking out his orders’
‘‘Nobody is allowed up here,’ he barked’
‘doormen bark at passers-by, promising hot music and cold beer’
--Word--
-le 
--Type--
suffix, suffix, suffix, suffix
--Meanings--
Forming names of appliances or instruments.
Forming names of animals and plants.
Forming nouns having or originally having a diminutive sense.
(forming adjectives from an original verb) apt to; liable to.
Forming verbs, chiefly those expressing repeated action or movement (as in babble, dazzle), or having diminutive sense (as in nestle).
--Examples--
‘bridle’
‘thimble’
‘beetle’
‘mantle’
‘battle’
‘castle’
‘brittle’
‘nimble’

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

The grain of barley.

barn 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
A large farm building used for storing grain, hay, or straw or for housing livestock.
A large shed used for storing road or railway vehicles.
A large and uninviting building.
A unit of area, 10^-28 square metres, used especially in particle physics.
--Examples--
‘a great barn of a pub’
--Word--
Barnabas, St. 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(died c.61), a Cypriot Levite and apostle. The traditional founder of the Cypriot Church, he is said to have been martyred in Cyprus. Feast day, June 11.
--Examples--
--Word--
Brahman 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of the highest Hindu caste, originally that of the priesthood.
The ultimate reality underlying all phenomena in the Hindu scriptures.
--Examples--
‘a Brahman family’
‘Brahman is formless but is the birthplace of all forms in visible reality’
--Word--
barnacle 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A marine crustacean with an external shell, which attaches itself permanently to a surface and feeds by filtering particles from the water using its modified feathery legs.
Used in similes to describe a tenacious person or thing.
--Examples--
‘buses careered along with men hanging from their doors like barnacles’

Barnard, Christiaan 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1922–2001), South African surgeon; full name Christiaan Neethling Barnard. He pioneered human heart transplantation, performing the first operation of this kind in December 1967.
--Examples--
--Word--
Barnardo, Thomas John 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1845–1905), Irish-born doctor and philanthropist. He founded the East End Mission for destitute children in 1867, the first of many such homes. Now known as Dr Barnardo's Homes, they cater chiefly for those with physical and mental disabilities.
--Examples--
--Word--

The capital of Altai territory in Russia on the River Ob; population 597,200 (est. 2008).

Wallis, Sir Barnes Neville 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1887–1979), English inventor. His designs include the bouncing bomb used against the Ruhr dams in Germany in the Second World War.

Newman, Barnett 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1905–70), American painter. A seminal figure in colour-field painting, he juxtaposed large blocks of uniform colour with narrow marginal strips of contrasting colours.

barnstorm 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Tour rural districts giving theatrical performances, originally often in barns.
Make a rapid tour of an area as part of a political campaign.
Travel around giving exhibitions of flying and performing aeronautical stunts.
--Examples--
‘he barnstormed up and down both coasts and eventually played New York’
‘he was barnstorming down in Georgia’
‘the speech he gives as he barnstorms the country’
‘barnstorming had become a popular occupation among many trained pilots’

--Word--
Barnum effect 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The tendency to accept as true types of information such as character assessments or horoscopes, even when the information is so vague as to be worthless.
--Examples--

--Word--
baron 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of the lowest order of the British nobility. Baron is not used as a form of address, barons usually being referred to as ‘Lord’.
A member of a foreign nobility having a rank similar to that of a British baron.
A person who held lands or property from the sovereign or a powerful overlord.
An important or powerful person in a specified business or industry.
--Examples--
‘a press baron’
--Word--
baronage 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Barons or nobles collectively.
An annotated list of barons or peers.
--Examples--
‘he owed his position to his popularity with the baronage’

--Examples--

--Word--
baroness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The wife or widow of a baron. Baroness is not used as a form of address, baronesses usually being referred to as ‘Lady’.
A woman holding the rank of baron either as a life peerage or as a hereditary rank.
--Examples--

‘a press baron’
--Word--
baroque 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting a style of European architecture, music, and art of the 17th and 18th centuries that followed Mannerism and is characterized by ornate detail. In architecture the period is exemplified by the palace of Versailles and by the work of Wren in England. Major composers include Vivaldi, Bach, and Handel; Caravaggio and Rubens are important baroque artists.
Highly ornate and extravagant in style.
The baroque style or period.
--Examples--
‘the candles were positively baroque’
‘the interior of the church is in lavish baroque’
‘the sculptural group in Rome is a key work of the baroque’
--Word--
baroque 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or denoting a style of European architecture, music, and art of the 17th and 18th centuries that followed Mannerism and is characterized by ornate detail. The baroque style or period.
--Examples--
‘the candles were positively baroque’
‘the interior of the church is in lavish baroque’
‘the sculptural group in Rome is a key work of the baroque’

--Type--

--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
Vignola, Giacomo Barozzi da 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1507–73), Italian architect. His designs were mannerist in style and include the Palazzo Farnese near Viterbo (1559–73) and the church of Il Gesù in Rome (begun 1568).
--Examples--
--Word--
barque 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A sailing ship, typically with three masts, in which the foremast and mainmast are square-rigged and the mizzenmast is rigged fore and aft.
A boat.
--Examples--
--Word--
barquentine 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A sailing ship similar to a barque but with only the foremast square-rigged and the remaining masts rigged fore and aft.
--Examples--

--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--

barrack 
--Type--
verb, verb
--Meanings--
Provide (soldiers) with accommodation in a building or set of buildings.
Jeer loudly at (someone performing or speaking in public) in order to express disapproval or to distract them.
Give support and encouragement to.
--Examples--
‘the granary in which the platoons were barracked’
‘opponents barracked him when he addressed the opening parliamentary session’
‘the disgraceful barracking that came from the mob’
‘I take it you'll be barracking for Labour tonight?’

--Word--
barrage 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A concentrated artillery bombardment over a wide area.
An overwhelming number of questions, criticisms, complaints, etc. delivered simultaneously or in rapid succession.
An artificial barrier across a river or estuary to prevent flooding, aid irrigation or navigation, or to generate electricity by tidal power.
Bombard (someone) with questions, criticisms, complaints, etc.
--Examples--
‘his forces launched an artillery barrage on the city’
‘a barrage of questions’
‘they are considering a tidal barrage built across the Severn estuary’
‘his doctor was barraged with unsolicited advice’

Barranquilla 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
barratry 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Fraud or gross negligence of a ship's master or crew at the expense of its owners or users.
Vexatious litigation or incitement to it (abolished as an offence in Britain in 1967).
Trade in the sale of Church or state appointments.
--Examples--

noun, noun

--Word--
barrel 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A cylindrical container bulging out in the middle, traditionally made of wooden staves with metal hoops round them.
A barrel together with its contents.
A measure of capacity used for oil and beer, usually equal to 36 imperial gallons for beer and 35 imperial gallons or 42 US gallons (roughly 159 litres) for oil.
A tube forming part of an object such as a gun or a pen.
The belly and loins of a four-legged animal such as a horse.
Drive or move in a way that is so fast as to almost be out of control.
Put into a barrel or barrels.
--Examples--
‘the wine is then matured in old barrels’
‘a barrel of beer’
‘the well was producing 10,000 barrels a day’
‘a gun barrel’
‘a Welsh mountain pony with a barrel like a butt of wine’
‘we barrelled across the Everglades’
‘when the young spirit is barrelled, it absorbs some of this flavour’

--Examples--

--Word--
barren 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
(of land) too poor to produce much or any vegetation.
(of a tree or plant) not producing fruit or seed.
Showing no results or achievements; unproductive.
(of a woman) infertile.
(of a female animal) not pregnant or unable to become so.
(of a place or building) bleak and lifeless.
Empty of meaning or value.
Devoid of.
A barren tract or tracts of land.
A group or drove of mules.
--Examples--
‘the plains of Kyrenia were barren’
‘the barren, burnt-up countryside’
‘the barren fig tree’
‘he scored yesterday to end his barren spell’
‘the sports hall turned out to be a rather barren concrete building’
‘the flat feels too tidy, almost barren’
‘your life will be barren’
‘the room was barren of furniture’
‘the Newfoundland barrens’
‘the Greeks were seen to drive a barren of mules’
--Word--
barren 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
(of land) too poor to produce much or any vegetation.
(of a tree or plant) not producing fruit or seed.
Showing no results or achievements; unproductive.
(of a woman) infertile.
(of a female animal) not pregnant or unable to become so.
(of a place or building) bleak and lifeless.
Empty of meaning or value.
Devoid of.
A barren tract or tracts of land.
A group or drove of mules.
--Examples--
‘the plains of Kyrenia were barren’
‘the barren, burnt-up countryside’
‘the barren fig tree’
‘he scored yesterday to end his barren spell’
‘the sports hall turned out to be a rather barren concrete building’
‘the flat feels too tidy, almost barren’
‘your life will be barren’
‘the room was barren of furniture’
‘the Newfoundland barrens’
‘the Greeks were seen to drive a barren of mules’
--Word--
barren 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
(of land) too poor to produce much or any vegetation.
(of a tree or plant) not producing fruit or seed.
Showing no results or achievements; unproductive.
(of a woman) infertile.
(of a female animal) not pregnant or unable to become so.
(of a place or building) bleak and lifeless.
Empty of meaning or value.
Devoid of.
A barren tract or tracts of land.
A group or drove of mules.
--Examples--
‘the plains of Kyrenia were barren’
‘the barren, burnt-up countryside’
‘the barren fig tree’
‘he scored yesterday to end his barren spell’
‘the sports hall turned out to be a rather barren concrete building’
‘the flat feels too tidy, almost barren’
‘your life will be barren’
‘the room was barren of furniture’
‘the Newfoundland barrens’
‘the Greeks were seen to drive a barren of mules’

--Word--
barrenwort 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An Old World plant with cup-shaped spurred flowers, cultivated for its colourful foliage. It was formerly thought to cause infertility.

--Word--
barricade 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An improvised barrier erected across a street or other thoroughfare to prevent or delay the movement of opposing forces.
Block or defend with a barricade.
Shut (someone) into a place by blocking all the entrances.
--Examples--
‘the police action led to riots, with hundreds of demonstrators building barricades and burning vehicles’
‘they barricaded the building and occupied it all night’
‘detainees who barricaded themselves into their dormitory’

--Word--
bar 
--Type--
noun, verb, preposition
--Meanings--
A long rigid piece of wood, metal, or similar material, typically used as an obstruction, fastening, or weapon.
An amount of food or another substance formed into a narrow block.
A band of colour or light.
The heating element of an electric fire.
The crossbar of a goal.
A metal strip below the clasp of a medal, awarded as an additional distinction.
A sandbank or shoal at the mouth of a harbour or an estuary.
A charge in the form of a narrow horizontal stripe across the shield.
A counter in a pub, restaurant, or cafe across which drinks or refreshments are served.
A room in a pub, restaurant, or hotel in which alcohol is served.
An establishment where alcohol and sometimes other refreshments are served.
A small shop, stall, or area in a department store that serves refreshments or provides a specified service.
A barrier or restriction to an action or advance.
A plea suspending an action or claim in a lawsuit.
Any of the short sections or measures, typically of equal time value, into which a piece of music is divided, shown on a score by vertical lines across the stave.
A partition in a court room, now usually notional, beyond which most people may not pass and at which an accused person stands.
A rail marking the end of each chamber in the Houses of Parliament.
The profession of barrister.
Barristers collectively.
Lawyers collectively.
A particular court of law.
Fasten (something, especially a door or window) with a bar or bars.
Prevent or prohibit (someone) from doing something or from going somewhere.
Forbid someone from undertaking (an activity)
Exclude (something) from consideration.
Prevent or delay (an action) by objection.
Mark (something) with bars or stripes.
Except for.
Except the horses indicated (used when stating the odds).
--Examples--
‘an iron bar’
‘bars on the windows’
‘a bar of chocolate’
‘gold bars’
‘bars of sunlight shafting through the windows’
‘Clark's shot hit the bar’
‘he was awarded a second bar to his DSO’
‘the bar to the estuary of the River Eske’
‘standing at the bar’
‘the oak-panelled bar of the Lion’
‘bar stools’
‘a small friendly bar open all day’
‘a sandwich bar’
‘political differences are not necessarily a bar to a good relationship’
‘the opening bars of the first hymn’
‘the prisoner at the bar’
‘he had to appear at the Bar of the House for a reprimand by the Speaker’
‘his dismissal from the Singapore Bar’
‘she bolted and barred the door’
‘journalists had been barred from covering the elections’
‘the job she loved had been barred to her’
‘nothing is barred in the crime novel’
‘his face was barred with light’
‘his kids were all gone now, bar one’

--Word--
Barth, Karl 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1886–1968), Swiss Protestant theologian. His seminal work Epistle to the Romans (1919) established a neo-orthodox or theocentric approach to contemporary religious thought which remains influential on Protestant theology.

Vanzetti, Bartolomeo 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1888–1927), US political radical; born in Italy. In 1921, along with Nicola Sacco, he was accused and convicted of murder in a sensational trial. In 1927, both men were executed in the electric chair, in a still controversial outcome.
--Examples--
--Word--
Bartolommeo, Fra 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(c.1472–1517), Italian painter; born Baccio della Porta. He was a Dominican friar and worked chiefly in Florence, where he was impressed and influenced by the work of Raphael.
