verb
--Meanings--
Make a gesture with the hand, arm, or head to encourage or instruct someone to approach or follow.
Summon (someone) by beckoning to them.
Appear attractive or inviting.
--Examples--
‘Miranda beckoned to Adam’
‘he beckoned Cameron over’
‘he beckoned Duncan to follow’
‘the going is tough and soft options beckon’
--Word--
beck 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
A stream.
A gesture requesting attention, such as a nod or wave.
--Examples--
--Word--
beck 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
A stream.
A gesture requesting attention, such as a nod or wave.
--Examples--
--Word--
Becker, Boris 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(born 1967), German tennis player. In 1985 he became the youngest man and first unseeded player to win the men's singles championship at Wimbledon. He won it again in 1986 and 1989.
--Examples--
--Word--
becket 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A loop of rope or similar device for securing loose items on a ship.
--Examples--
--Word--
becket 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A loop of rope or similar device for securing loose items on a ship.
--Examples--
--Word--
Beckett, Samuel 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1906–89), Irish playwright, novelist, and poet; full name Samuel Barclay Beckett. He is best known for his plays, especially Waiting for Godot (1952), a seminal work in the Theatre of the Absurd. Nobel Prize for Literature (1969).
--Examples--
--Word--
Beckford, William 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1759–1844), English writer and collector. As an author he is remembered for the oriental romance Vathek (1786, originally written in French).
--Examples--
--Word--
beck 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
A stream.
A gesture requesting attention, such as a nod or wave.
--Examples--
--Word--
Beckmann, Max 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1884–1950), German painter and graphic artist. Beckmann's paintings reflect his first-hand experience of human evil during the First World War.
--Examples--

--Word--
become 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Begin to be.
Grow to be; develop into.
(of a person) qualify or be accepted as.
(in questions) happen to.
(of clothing) look good on or suit (someone)
Be appropriate to (someone)
--Examples--
‘she became angry and sulked all day’
‘it is becoming clear that we are in a new situation’
‘the child will become an adult’
‘she wanted to become a doctor’
‘what would become of her now?’
‘mourning regalia became her’
‘minor celebrity status did not become Potter’

noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
bed 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A piece of furniture for sleep or rest, typically a framework with a mattress.
A bed and associated facilities comprising a place for a patient in a hospital.
A bedroom.
A place or article used by a person or animal for sleep or rest.
Used with reference to a bed as the typical place for sexual activity.
The bottom of the sea or a lake or river.
A place on the seabed where shellfish, especially oysters or mussels, breed or are bred.
An area of ground, typically in a garden, where flowers and plants are grown.
A stratum or layer of rock.
A layer of food on which other foods are served.
A flat base or foundation on which something rests or is supported.
The foundation of a road or railway.
The open part of a truck, wagon, or cart, where goods are carried.
The flat surface beneath the baize of a billiard table.
Settle down to sleep or rest for the night in an improvised place.
Settle a person or animal down to sleep or rest for the night.
Have sexual intercourse with.
Transfer (a plant) from a pot or seed tray to a garden plot.
Fix firmly; embed.
Lay or arrange (something, especially stone) in a layer.
Settle down and become established.
--Examples--
‘a large double bed’
‘she was in bed by nine’
‘the unit has 20 geriatric beds’
‘a three-bed detached house’
‘a bed of straw’
‘he's incredibly good in bed’
‘she'd gone to bed with Tom’
‘the gravelly bed of the stream’
‘the Firth of Forth was once home to vast beds of oysters’
‘the lawns are flanked by rose beds’
‘a bed of tulips’
‘a bed of clay’
‘the salad is served on a bed of raw spinach’
‘place each paver on a bed of concrete’
‘the pavement consists of granite blocks set on a bed of cobblestones and cement’
‘the spare tyre in the forward bed of the truck’
‘you can bed down in the shed’
‘she is grooming the horses and bedding them down for the night’
‘I am quite picky when it comes to bedding someone’
‘I bedded out some houseplants’
‘the posts should be firmly bedded in concrete’
‘crazy paving has to be bedded on a solid base of hard core’
‘a period of calm will allow the changes to bed in’

--Word--
bedazzle 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Greatly impress (someone) with outstanding ability or striking appearance.
Decorate or personalize (clothing or accessories) using sequins, beads, glitter, etc.
--Examples--
‘bedazzled by him, they offered him a post in Paris’
‘Roberts is not bedazzled by the red carpet’
‘I'd bring a box of rhinestones so I could bedazzle our uniforms’
‘tiaras and beautiful bedazzled dresses’

--Word--
Bede, St. 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(c.673–735), English monk, theologian, and historian; known as the Venerable Bede. He wrote The Ecclesiastical History of the English People (written in Latin and completed in 731), a primary source for early English history. Feast day, May 27.
--Examples--

--Word--
bed 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A piece of furniture for sleep or rest, typically a framework with a mattress.
A bed and associated facilities comprising a place for a patient in a hospital.
A bedroom.
A place or article used by a person or animal for sleep or rest.
Used with reference to a bed as the typical place for sexual activity.
The bottom of the sea or a lake or river.
A place on the seabed where shellfish, especially oysters or mussels, breed or are bred.
An area of ground, typically in a garden, where flowers and plants are grown.
A stratum or layer of rock.
A layer of food on which other foods are served.
A flat base or foundation on which something rests or is supported.
The foundation of a road or railway.
The open part of a truck, wagon, or cart, where goods are carried.
The flat surface beneath the baize of a billiard table.
Settle down to sleep or rest for the night in an improvised place.
Settle a person or animal down to sleep or rest for the night.
Have sexual intercourse with.
Transfer (a plant) from a pot or seed tray to a garden plot.
Fix firmly; embed.
Lay or arrange (something, especially stone) in a layer.
Settle down and become established.
--Examples--
‘a large double bed’
‘she was in bed by nine’
‘the unit has 20 geriatric beds’
‘a three-bed detached house’
‘a bed of straw’
‘he's incredibly good in bed’
‘she'd gone to bed with Tom’
‘the gravelly bed of the stream’
‘the Firth of Forth was once home to vast beds of oysters’
‘the lawns are flanked by rose beds’
‘a bed of tulips’
‘a bed of clay’
‘the salad is served on a bed of raw spinach’
‘place each paver on a bed of concrete’
‘the pavement consists of granite blocks set on a bed of cobblestones and cement’
‘the spare tyre in the forward bed of the truck’
‘you can bed down in the shed’
‘she is grooming the horses and bedding them down for the night’
‘I am quite picky when it comes to bedding someone’
‘I bedded out some houseplants’
‘the posts should be firmly bedded in concrete’
‘crazy paving has to be bedded on a solid base of hard core’
‘a period of calm will allow the changes to bed in’
--Word--
Bedford 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A town in south central England, on the River Ouse, the county town of Bedfordshire; population 83,400 (est. 2009).
A city in north-eastern Texas, north-east of Fort Worth; population 49,155 (est. 2008).
--Examples--

proper noun
--Meanings--

bed 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A piece of furniture for sleep or rest, typically a framework with a mattress.
A bed and associated facilities comprising a place for a patient in a hospital.
A bedroom.
A place or article used by a person or animal for sleep or rest.
Used with reference to a bed as the typical place for sexual activity.
The bottom of the sea or a lake or river.
A place on the seabed where shellfish, especially oysters or mussels, breed or are bred.
An area of ground, typically in a garden, where flowers and plants are grown.
A stratum or layer of rock.
A layer of food on which other foods are served.
A flat base or foundation on which something rests or is supported.
The foundation of a road or railway.
The open part of a truck, wagon, or cart, where goods are carried.
The flat surface beneath the baize of a billiard table.
Settle down to sleep or rest for the night in an improvised place.
Settle a person or animal down to sleep or rest for the night.
Have sexual intercourse with.
Transfer (a plant) from a pot or seed tray to a garden plot.
Fix firmly; embed.
Lay or arrange (something, especially stone) in a layer.
Settle down and become established.
--Examples--
‘a large double bed’
‘she was in bed by nine’
‘the unit has 20 geriatric beds’
‘a three-bed detached house’
‘a bed of straw’
‘he's incredibly good in bed’
‘she'd gone to bed with Tom’
‘the gravelly bed of the stream’
‘the Firth of Forth was once home to vast beds of oysters’

‘a bed of tulips’
‘a bed of clay’
‘the salad is served on a bed of raw spinach’

‘the pavement consists of granite blocks set on a bed of cobblestones and cement’
‘the spare tyre in the forward bed of the truck’
‘you can bed down in the shed’
‘she is grooming the horses and bedding them down for the night’
‘I am quite picky when it comes to bedding someone’
‘I bedded out some houseplants’
‘the posts should be firmly bedded in concrete’
‘crazy paving has to be bedded on a solid base of hard core’
‘a period of calm will allow the changes to bed in’

--Word--
east 
--Type--
noun, adjective, adverb
--Meanings--
The direction towards the point of the horizon where the sun rises at the equinoxes, on the right-hand side of a person facing north, or the point on the horizon itself.
The compass point corresponding to east.
The eastern part of the world or of a specified country, region, or town.
The regions or countries lying to the east of Europe, especially China, Japan, and India.
The former communist states of eastern Europe.
The player sitting to the left of North and partnering West.
Lying towards, near, or facing the east.
(of a wind) blowing from the east.
Situated in the part of a church containing the altar or high altar, usually the actual east.
Of or denoting the eastern part of a specified region, town, or country.
To or towards the east.
--Examples--
‘a gale was blowing from the east’
‘the Atlantic Ocean to the east of Florida’
‘a factory in the east of the city’
‘the protection of trade routes to the East’
‘the centrally planned system of the East’
‘East passes and you respond one heart’
‘the hospital's east wing’
‘a biting east wind’
‘the liturgical east window is actually in the south wall’
‘East Fife’
‘East African’
‘travelling east, he met two men’
‘the river rises east of Brentford’

--Word--
Beecham, Sir Thomas 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1879–1961), English conductor and impresario, founder of the London Philharmonic (1932) and the Royal Philharmonic (1947). He did much to stimulate interest in new or neglected composers such as Sibelius, Delius, and Richard Strauss.
--Examples--

beechdrops 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A broomrape that is parasitic on the roots of beech trees. Unlike most broomrapes, it has branching stems.

Beecher, Catherine 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1800–78), US educator; full name Catherine Esther Beecher. She promoted educational rights for women and founded the American Women's Education Assocation in 1852. She was the sister of Henry Ward Beecher and Harriet Beecher Stowe.

beef 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The flesh of a cow, bull, or ox, used as food.
A cow, bull, or ox fattened for its meat.
Flesh with well-developed muscle.
Strength or power.
The substance of a matter.
A complaint or grievance.
A criminal charge.
Complain.
beef something up
Give more substance or strength to something.
--Examples--
‘there was the smell of roast beef’
‘beef cattle’
‘a beef sent to the abattoir’

‘he has a beef with education: it doesn't teach the basics of investing’
‘getting caught with pot in the sixties was a narco beef’
‘he was beefing about how the recession was killing the business’
‘cost-cutting measures are planned to beef up performance’

‘a beef sent to the abattoir’
‘he needs a little more beef on his bones’
‘he was brought in to give the team more beef’
‘it's more a sketch than a policy—where's the beef?’
‘he has a beef with education: it doesn't teach the basics of investing’
‘getting caught with pot in the sixties was a narco beef’
‘he was beefing about how the recession was killing the business’
‘cost-cutting measures are planned to beef up performance’
--Word--
beef something up 
--Type--
phrasal verb
--Meanings--
Give more substance or strength to something.
--Examples--
‘cost-cutting measures are planned to beef up performance’
--Word--
beef 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The flesh of a cow, bull, or ox, used as food.
A cow, bull, or ox fattened for its meat.
Flesh with well-developed muscle.
Strength or power.
The substance of a matter.
A complaint or grievance.
A criminal charge.
Complain.
beef something up
Give more substance or strength to something.
--Examples--
‘there was the smell of roast beef’
‘beef cattle’
‘a beef sent to the abattoir’
‘he needs a little more beef on his bones’
‘he was brought in to give the team more beef’
‘it's more a sketch than a policy—where's the beef?’
‘he has a beef with education: it doesn't teach the basics of investing’
‘getting caught with pot in the sixties was a narco beef’
‘he was beefing about how the recession was killing the business’
‘cost-cutting measures are planned to beef up performance’
--Word--
beefsteak 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A thick slice of lean beef, typically from the rump and eaten grilled or fried.
--Examples--
‘beefsteaks so large that one slice makes a sandwich’
‘high-quality beefsteak’

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A stinging winged insect which collects nectar and pollen, produces wax and honey, and lives in large communities.

beep 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A short, high-pitched sound emitted by electronic equipment or a vehicle horn.
(of a horn or electronic device) produce a beep.
Summon (someone) by means of a pager.
--Examples--
‘leave a message after the beep’
‘the machines were beeping and the tills humming’
‘they have themselves beeped in restaurants’

--Word--
Beerbohm, Sir Max 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1872–1956), English caricaturist, essayist, and critic; full name Sir Henry Maximilian Beerbohm. A central figure of the Aesthetic Movement, he is remembered chiefly for his novel, Zuleika Dobson (1911).

beet 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A herbaceous plant widely cultivated as a source of food for humans and livestock, and for processing into sugar. Some varieties are grown for their leaves and some for their large nutritious root.

Beethoven, Ludwig van 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1770–1827), German composer.
--Examples--
--Word--
Beethovenian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or characteristic of the German composer Ludwig van Beethoven, his music, or his theories of musical composition.
An admirer of the German composer Ludwig van Beethoven.
A performer of the music of the German composer Ludwig van Beethoven.
--Examples--
‘a compelling Beethovenian influence at work’
‘this is a most interesting CD which should commend itself to all true Beethovenians’
‘the pianist is currently one of the master Beethovenians’
--Word--
beetle 
--Type--
noun, verb, noun, verb, verb, adjective
--Meanings--
An insect of a large order distinguished by having forewings that are typically modified into hard wing cases (elytra), which cover and protect the hindwings and abdomen.
A dice game in which a picture of a beetle is drawn or assembled.
Make one's way hurriedly.
A very heavy mallet, typically with a wooden head, used for ramming, crushing, etc.
A machine used for heightening the lustre of cloth by pressure from rollers.
Ram or crush with a beetle.
Finish (cloth) with a beetle.
(of a rock or a person's eyebrows) project or overhang.
(of a person's eyebrows) shaggy and projecting.
--Examples--
‘the tourist beetled off’
‘she stood in a shed, beetling grain for the fowl’
‘his eyebrows beetled with irritation’
‘thick beetle brows’
--Word--
beetle-browed 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having shaggy and projecting eyebrows.
Sullen or unfriendly in appearance.
--Examples--
‘beetle-browed Neanderthals’
‘heavy, swarthy, beetle-browed features’
‘his taciturn beetle-browed image’
--Word--
beetle-crusher 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A large boot, shoe, or foot.
--Examples--

‘you befooled me on your first trip’
--Word--
befool 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Make a fool of.
--Examples--
‘you befooled me on your first trip’
--Word--
before 
--Type--
UnKnownKind
--Meanings--
During the period of time preceding (a particular event or time)
In front of.
In front of and required to answer to (a court of law, tribunal, or other authority)
In preference to; rather than.
--Examples--
‘she had to rest before dinner’
‘the day before yesterday’
‘they lived rough for four days before they were arrested’
‘his playing days had ended six years before’
‘it's never happened to me before’
‘Matilda stood before her, panting’
‘trotting through the city with guards running before and behind’
‘he could be taken before a magistrate for punishment’
‘a skilled warrior who places duty before all else’
‘they would die before they would cooperate with each other’
--Word--
above-cited 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Cited previously in the present text.
--Examples--

--Word--
known 
--Type--
verb, adjective
--Meanings--
Recognized, familiar, or within the scope of knowledge.
Publicly acknowledged to be.
(of a quantity or variable) having a value that can be stated.
--Examples--
‘plants little known to western science’
‘the known world’
‘a known criminal’

--Word--
beg 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Ask someone earnestly or humbly for something.
Ask for (something) earnestly or humbly.
Ask formally for (permission to do something)
Ask for food or money as charity.
Acquire (food or money) from someone by begging.
(of a dog) sit up with the front paws raised expectantly in the hope of a reward.
--Examples--
‘he begged his fellow passengers for help’
‘she begged me to say nothing to her father’
‘I must beg of you not to act impulsively’
‘he begged their forgiveness’
‘I will now beg leave to make some observations’
‘I beg to second the motion’
‘a young woman was begging in the street’
‘they had to beg for food’
‘a piece of bread which I begged from a farmer’

--Type--

--Meanings--

--Word--
beggar 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A person, typically a homeless one, who lives by asking for money or food.
A person of a specified type, especially one to be envied or pitied.
Reduce (someone) to poverty.
--Examples--
‘poor little beggars’
‘why should I beggar myself for you?’

--Word--
beggar-my-neighbour 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A card game for two players in which the object is to acquire one's opponent's cards. Players alternately turn cards up and if an honour is revealed, the other player must find an honour within a specified number of turns or else forfeit the cards already played.
(especially of national policy) self-aggrandizing at the expense of competitors.
--Examples--
‘the economic recession had been intensified by the adoption of beggar-my-neighbour policies’
--Word--
beggar-my-neighbour 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A card game for two players in which the object is to acquire one's opponent's cards. Players alternately turn cards up and if an honour is revealed, the other player must find an honour within a specified number of turns or else forfeit the cards already played.
(especially of national policy) self-aggrandizing at the expense of competitors.
--Examples--
‘the economic recession had been intensified by the adoption of beggar-my-neighbour policies’

--Word--
begin 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Perform or undergo the first part of (an action or activity)
Come into being or have its starting point at a certain time or place.
(of a person) hold a specified role before holding any other.
Have as a first element.
Set to work at.
Start speaking by saying.
(of an article) cost at least (a specified amount)
Not have any chance or likelihood of doing a specified thing.
--Examples--
‘Peter had just begun a life sentence for murder’
‘it was beginning to snow’
‘she began by rewriting the syllabus’
‘a new era had begun’
‘the cycleway begins at Livingston village’
‘he began as a drummer’
‘words beginning with a vowel’
‘Picasso began on a great canvas’
‘‘Mr Smith,’ he began’
‘rooms begin at £139’
‘I can't begin to tell you how much I hate that commercial’
--Word--
beginner 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person just starting to learn a skill or take part in an activity.
--Examples--
‘a beginner's guide’
‘language courses for beginners’
‘an absolute beginner’

beginner's luck

phrase
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
beginning 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The point in time or space at which something begins.
The first part or earliest stage of something.
The background or origins of a person or organization.
--Examples--
‘he left at the beginning of February’
‘they had reached the beginning of the wood’
‘the ending of one relationship and the beginning of another’
‘she had the beginnings of a headache’
‘he had risen from humble beginnings to great wealth’

--Word--
begonia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A herbaceous plant of warm climates, the flowers of which have brightly coloured sepals but no petals. Numerous cultivars are grown for their flowers or striking foliage.
--Examples--
--Word--
begonia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A herbaceous plant of warm climates, the flowers of which have brightly coloured sepals but no petals. Numerous cultivars are grown for their flowers or striking foliage.
--Examples--

begorra 
--Type--
exclamation
--Meanings--
An exclamation of surprise traditionally attributed to the Irish.

--Word--
beg 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Ask someone earnestly or humbly for something.
Ask for (something) earnestly or humbly.
Ask formally for (permission to do something)
Ask for food or money as charity.
Acquire (food or money) from someone by begging.
(of a dog) sit up with the front paws raised expectantly in the hope of a reward.
--Examples--
‘he begged his fellow passengers for help’
‘she begged me to say nothing to her father’
‘I must beg of you not to act impulsively’
‘he begged their forgiveness’
‘I will now beg leave to make some observations’
‘I beg to second the motion’
‘a young woman was begging in the street’
‘they had to beg for food’
‘a piece of bread which I begged from a farmer’
--Word--
beguile 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Charm or enchant (someone), often in a deceptive way.
Trick (someone) into doing something.
Help (time) pass pleasantly.
--Examples--
‘he beguiled the voters with his good looks’
‘they were beguiled into signing a peace treaty’
‘to beguile some of the time they went to the cinema’

--Word--
beguine 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
A popular dance of Caribbean origin, similar to the foxtrot.
(in the Roman Catholic Church) a member of a lay sisterhood in the Low Countries, not bound by vows.

behalf 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In the interests of a person, group, or principle.
As a representative of.
On the part of; done by.
--Examples--
‘he campaigned on behalf of the wrongly convicted four’
‘he had to attend the funeral on Mama's behalf’
‘this wasn't simply a philanthropic gesture on his behalf’
--Word--
Behan, Brendan 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1923–64), Irish playwright and poet; full name Brendan Francis Behan. A committed supporter of Irish nationalism, he is noted for the novel Borstal Boy (1958), which describes his punishment for involvement in terrorist activities, and the play The Quare Fellow (1956).
--Examples--
--Word--
behave 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Act or conduct oneself in a specified way, especially towards others.
(of a machine or natural phenomenon) work or function in a specified way.
Conduct oneself in accordance with the accepted norms of a society or group.
--Examples--
‘he always behaved like a gentleman’
‘it is not acceptable for a student to behave like that towards a teacher’
‘each car behaves differently’
‘‘Just behave, Tom,’ he said’
‘they were expected to behave themselves’

--Examples--
‘a well-behaved child’
‘some of the boys had been badly behaved’

--Word--
behaviour 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The way in which one acts or conducts oneself, especially towards others.
The way in which an animal or person behaves in response to a particular situation or stimulus.
The way in which a machine or natural phenomenon works or functions.
--Examples--
‘he will vouch for her good behaviour’
‘his insulting behaviour towards me’
‘behaviour patterns’
‘management is a set of techniques and behaviours for getting things done’
‘the feeding behaviour of predators’
‘the erratic behaviour of the old car’
--Word--
behavioural 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Involving, relating to, or emphasizing behaviour.
--Examples--
‘closely related species have similar behavioural patterns’
‘a behavioural approach to children's language’
--Word--
behaviourally 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
behavior modification 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The alteration of behavioral patterns through the use of such learning techniques as biofeedback and positive or negative reinforcement.
--Examples--
--Word--
behaviourism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The theory that human and animal behaviour can be explained in terms of conditioning, without appeal to thoughts or feelings, and that psychological disorders are best treated by altering behaviour patterns.
Treatment involving the practical application of the theory of behaviourism.
--Examples--

--Word--
behind 
--Type--
preposition, adverb, noun
--Meanings--
At or to the far side of (something), typically so as to be hidden by it.
Underlying (something) but not apparent to the observer.
Following or further back than (another member of a moving group)
At the back of (someone), after they have passed through a door.
In support of or giving guidance to (someone else)
Controlling or responsible for (an event or plan)
After the departure or death of (someone)
Less advanced than (someone or something) in achievement or development.
Having a lower score than (another competitor)
At or to the far side of something.
In a particular place after leaving or after others have moved on.
Further back than other members of a moving group.
(in a contest or match) having a score lower than that of the opposing team.
Late in accomplishing a task.
In arrears.
A person's buttocks.
A kick that sends the ball over a behind line, or a touch that sends it between the inner posts, scoring one point.
--Examples--
‘the recording machinery was kept behind screens’
‘the sun came out from behind a cloud’
‘the agony behind his decision to retire’
‘we were stuck behind a slow-moving tractor’
‘she ran out of the room, slamming the door behind her’
‘whatever you decide to do, I'll be behind you’
‘the power behind the throne’
‘I began to believe that he was behind the whole plot’
‘the meticulous organization behind the coup’
‘he left behind him a manuscript which was subsequently published’
‘the government admitted it is ten years behind the West in PC technology’
‘Woosnam moved to ten under par, five shots behind Fred Couples’
‘Campbell grabbed him from behind’
‘don't leave me behind’
‘Ben led the way, with Joe a short distance behind’
‘England were still 382 runs behind’
‘I'm getting behind with my work’
‘she was behind with her rent’
‘she slid inelegantly down a few steps on her behind’
--Word--
behind 
--Type--
preposition, adverb, noun
--Meanings--
At or to the far side of (something), typically so as to be hidden by it.
Underlying (something) but not apparent to the observer.

At or to the far side of something.
In a particular place after leaving or after others have moved on.
Further back than other members of a moving group.
(in a contest or match) having a score lower than that of the opposing team.
Late in accomplishing a task.
In arrears.
A person's buttocks.

--Word--
behindhand 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Late or slow in doing something.
Unaware of recent events.
--Examples--
‘the Yoruba have not been behindhand in economic activity’
‘you are miserably behindhand—Mr Cole gave me a hint of it six weeks ago’

--Word--
Behn, Aphra 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1640–89), English novelist and playwright, regarded as the first professional woman writer in England. Notable works: The Rover (comic play, 1678) and Oroonoko, or the History of the Royal Slave (novel, 1688).
--Examples--

behove 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
It is a duty or responsibility for someone to do something.

--Examples--
‘it behoves the House to assure itself that there is no conceivable alternative’
‘it ill behoves Opposition Members to decry the sale of arms to friendly countries’

Behrens, Peter 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1868–1940), German architect and designer. He trained Walter Gropius and Le Corbusier.
--Examples--
--Word--
Behring, Emil Adolf von 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1854–1917), German bacteriologist and one of the founders of immunology. Nobel Prize for Physiology or Medicine (1901).
--Examples--
--Word--
bey 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The governor of a district or province in the Ottoman Empire.
Formerly used in Turkey and Egypt as a courtesy title.
--Examples--
--Word--
Beiderbecke, Bix 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1903–31), American jazz musician and composer; born Leon Bismarck Beiderbecke. A self-taught cornetist and pianist, he was one of a handful of white musicians who profoundly influenced the development of jazz.
--Examples--

--Word--
Beijing 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The capital of China, in the north-east of the country; population 8,580,400 (est. 2006). Beijing became the country's capital in 1421, at the start of the Ming period, and survived as the capital of the Republic of China after the revolution of 1912.

--Word--
beyond 
--Type--
UnKnownKind, noun
--Meanings--
At or to the further side of.
Outside the physical limits or range of.
More extensive or extreme than; further-reaching than.
Happening or continuing after (a specified time, stage, or event)
Having progressed or achieved more than (a specified stage or level)
Above or greater than (a specified amount)
To or in a degree or condition where a specified action is impossible.
Too much for (someone) to achieve or understand.
Apart from; except.
The unknown, especially in references to life after death.
--Examples--
‘he pointed to a spot beyond the concealing trees’
‘from south of Dortmund as far as Essen and beyond’
‘the hook which held the chandelier was beyond her reach’
‘what these children go through is far beyond what most adults endure in a lifetime’
‘the authority of the inspectors goes beyond ordinary police powers’
‘pushing the laws to their limits and beyond’
‘training beyond the age of 14’
‘music going on into the night and beyond’
‘we need to get beyond square one’
‘his failure to rise beyond the rank of Undersecretary’
‘raising its stake beyond 15%’
‘he could count up to a hundred thousand million now, and beyond’
‘the landscape has changed beyond recognition’
‘their integrity is beyond question’
‘the questions were well beyond the average adult’
‘beyond telling us that she was well educated, he has nothing to say about her’
‘there was little vegetation beyond brush-growth’
‘messages from the beyond’

belay 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Fix (a running rope) round a cleat, rock, pin, or other object, to secure it.
Secure (a climber) with a belayed rope.
Stop; desist from.
An act of belaying.
A spike of rock or other object used for belaying.
--Examples--
‘he belayed his partner across the ice’
‘‘Belay that, mister. Man your post.’’
‘the leader may require belays to tackle more difficult sections’
‘the trees along the top are used as belays’

--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--

An act of belching.
--Examples--

‘a factory chimney belches out smoke’
‘flames belch from the wreckage’

‘with a triumphant belch the train came to a stop’

--Word--
belly 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The front part of the human trunk below the ribs, containing the stomach and bowels.
The stomach, especially as representing the body's need for food.
The underside of a bird or other animal.
A cut of pork from the underside between the legs.
A pig's belly as food, especially as a traded commodity.
The rounded underside of a ship or aircraft.
The top surface of an instrument of the violin family, over which the strings are placed.
Swell or cause to swell.
Move or sit close to (a bar or table)
--Examples--
‘his fat belly stuck out over his trousers’
‘they'll fight all the better on empty bellies’
‘grasses were said to have been tall enough to brush the bellies of horses’
‘as she leaned forward her pullover bellied out’
‘the wind bellied the sail out’
‘regulars who first bellied up to the bar years before’

--Word--
belief 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An acceptance that something exists or is true, especially one without proof.
Something one accepts as true or real; a firmly held opinion.
A religious conviction.
Trust, faith, or confidence in (someone or something)
--Examples--
‘his belief in extraterrestrial life’
‘a belief that climate can be modified beneficially’
‘we're prepared to fight for our beliefs’
‘contrary to popular belief existing safety regulations were adequate’
‘Christian beliefs’
‘the medieval system of fervent religious belief’
‘a belief in democratic politics’

--Examples--
--Word--
belier 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who belies someone or something; especially: (a) one who gives a false representation or account; a slanderer or libeller; (b) a denier. Usually with of.
--Examples--
--Word--
belie 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
(of an appearance) fail to give a true impression of (something)
Fail to fulfil or justify (a claim or expectation)
--Examples--
‘his lively, alert manner belied his years’
‘the quality of the music seems to belie the criticism’

believability 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
believable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Able to be believed; credible.
(of a fictional character or situation) convincing or realistic.
--Examples--
‘she felt that Dawn's story was not quite believable’
‘a drama that lacks believable characters’

--Word--
believe 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Accept that (something) is true, especially without proof.
Accept the statement of (someone) as true.
Have religious faith.
Feel sure that (someone) is capable of doing something.
Hold (something) as an opinion; think.
--Examples--
‘the superintendent believed Lancaster's story’
‘some 23 per cent believe that smoking keeps down weight’
‘he didn't believe her’
‘there are those on the fringes of the Church who do not really believe’
‘I wouldn't have believed it of Lavinia—what an extraordinary woman!’
‘I believe we've already met’
‘four men were believed to be trapped’

--Word--
believer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who believes in the truth or existence of something.
A person who believes that a specified thing is right, effective, or acceptable.
An adherent of a particular religion; someone with religious faith.
--Examples--
‘a firm believer that party politics has no place in local government’
‘I'm a great believer in community policing’
‘the relationship into which God invites believers’

Belize 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
bell 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A hollow metal object, typically in the shape of a deep inverted cup widening at the lip, that sounds a clear musical note when struck, especially by means of a clapper inside.
A device that includes or sounds like a bell, used to give a signal or warning.
(in boxing and other sports) a bell rung to mark the start or end of a round.
A bell-shaped object or part of something.
The end of a trumpet or other brass instrument.
The corolla of a bell-shaped flower.
The umbrella of a jellyfish.
A musical instrument consisting of a set of metal tubes of different lengths, suspended in a frame and played by being struck with a hammer.
(preceded by a numeral) the time as indicated every half hour of a watch by the striking of the ship's bell one to eight times.
Provide with a bell or bells.
Make a ringing sound likened to that of a bell.
Telephone (someone)
Spread outwards like the lip of a bell.
--Examples--
‘the church bells tolled’
‘a bell tinkled as he went in the shop’
‘the bell chamber of the church spire’
‘a bicycle bell’
‘they were dragged off each other at the final bell’
‘the acoustic properties of a trumpet's bell’
‘a flower with small pale blue bells’
‘the tiny jellyfish has a bell measuring five to ten millimetres wide’
‘at five bells in the forenoon of June 11’
‘the young men were belling and hobbling the horses before releasing them’
‘the organ was belling away’
‘no problem, I'll bell her tomorrow’
‘her shirt belled out behind’
--Word--
Bella Coola 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of a grouping of four North American Indian peoples of the central British Columbia coast, Canada, having a common culture and language and now consolidated at the mouth of the Bella Coola River.
The Salishan language of the Bella Coola.
--Examples--
--Word--
Bella Coola 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of a grouping of four North American Indian peoples of the central British Columbia coast, Canada, having a common culture and language and now consolidated at the mouth of the Bella Coola River.
The Salishan language of the Bella Coola.

bearer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person or thing that carries or holds something.
A carrier of equipment on an expedition.
A domestic servant or other menial worker.
A waiter.
A person who carries the coffin at a funeral.
A person who presents a cheque or other order to pay money.
Payable to the possessor.
--Examples--
‘a flag-bearer’
‘I'm sorry to be the bearer of bad tidings’
‘promissory notes payable to the bearer’
‘bearer bonds’

--Word--
bell 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A hollow metal object, typically in the shape of a deep inverted cup widening at the lip, that sounds a clear musical note when struck, especially by means of a clapper inside.
A device that includes or sounds like a bell, used to give a signal or warning.
(in boxing and other sports) a bell rung to mark the start or end of a round.
A bell-shaped object or part of something.
The end of a trumpet or other brass instrument.
The corolla of a bell-shaped flower.
The umbrella of a jellyfish.
A musical instrument consisting of a set of metal tubes of different lengths, suspended in a frame and played by being struck with a hammer.
(preceded by a numeral) the time as indicated every half hour of a watch by the striking of the ship's bell one to eight times.
Provide with a bell or bells.
Make a ringing sound likened to that of a bell.
Telephone (someone)
Spread outwards like the lip of a bell.
--Examples--
‘the church bells tolled’
‘a bell tinkled as he went in the shop’
‘the bell chamber of the church spire’
‘a bicycle bell’
‘they were dragged off each other at the final bell’
‘the acoustic properties of a trumpet's bell’
‘a flower with small pale blue bells’
‘the tiny jellyfish has a bell measuring five to ten millimetres wide’
‘at five bells in the forenoon of June 11’
‘the young men were belling and hobbling the horses before releasing them’
‘the organ was belling away’
‘no problem, I'll bell her tomorrow’
‘her shirt belled out behind’

faced 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having a face or expression of a specified kind.
Having a surface or front of a specified kind.
(of a solid) having a specified number of surfaces.
(of a piece of stone or other material) having a smoothed or polished surface.
(of a playing card) turned face up.
--Examples--
‘a pimply-faced teenager’
‘a burly, square-faced doorman’
‘sad-faced children’
‘a heavy, square-faced hammer’
‘a stone-faced building’
‘a twelve-faced solid’
‘walls and pillars had faced stone on the outer surfaces’
‘he gets the faced card as his first card’

--Word--
belly 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The front part of the human trunk below the ribs, containing the stomach and bowels.
The stomach, especially as representing the body's need for food.
The underside of a bird or other animal.
A cut of pork from the underside between the legs.
A pig's belly as food, especially as a traded commodity.
The rounded underside of a ship or aircraft.
The top surface of an instrument of the violin family, over which the strings are placed.
Swell or cause to swell.
Move or sit close to (a bar or table)
--Examples--
‘his fat belly stuck out over his trousers’
‘they'll fight all the better on empty bellies’
‘grasses were said to have been tall enough to brush the bellies of horses’
‘as she leaned forward her pullover bellied out’
‘the wind bellied the sail out’
‘regulars who first bellied up to the bar years before’
--Word--

--Meanings--

Complain noisily or persistently.
--Examples--
‘Heads of Department bellyaching about lack of resources’

beaten 
--Type--
UnKnownKind, adjective
--Meanings--
Having been defeated.
Exhausted and dejected.
Having been beaten or struck.
(of food) stirred vigorously to a uniform consistency.
(of metal) shaped by hammering, typically so as to give the surface a dimpled texture.
(of precious metal) hammered to form thin foil for ornamental use.
(of a path) well trodden; much used.
--Examples--
‘last year's beaten finalist’
‘he sat feeling old and beaten’
‘he trudged home like a beaten cur’
‘beaten egg’
‘beaten copper coffee tables’
‘magnificent howdahs covered with beaten gold and silver’

--Word--
bumper 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A horizontal bar fixed across the front or back of a motor vehicle to reduce damage in a collision.
A shock-absorbing piston projecting from a cross-beam at the end of a railway track or at the end of a railway vehicle.
A flat race for inexperienced horses which are intended for future racing in hurdles or steeplechases.
A generous glassful of an alcoholic drink, typically one drunk as a toast.
Exceptionally large, fine, or successful.
--Examples--
‘she started the car with a jerk and hit the bumper of the car in front’
‘a bumper crop’
‘everyone in the business predicts a bumper year’

bell 
--Type--

(preceded by a numeral) the time as indicated every half hour of a watch by the striking of the ship's bell one to eight times.
Provide with a bell or bells.
Make a ringing sound likened to that of a bell.

Spread outwards like the lip of a bell.

--Word--

Give comfort or support to.
Make or become less miserable.
A shout of encouragement, praise, or joy.
Cheerfulness, optimism, or confidence.
Food and drink provided for a festive occasion.
--Examples--
‘she cheered from the sidelines’
‘MPs rose to cheer the Chancellor’
‘the cyclists were cheered on by the crowds’

‘I asked her out to lunch to cheer her up’

‘an attempt to inject a little cheer into this gloomy season’
‘they had partaken heartily of the Christmas cheer’
--Word--
belly 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The front part of the human trunk below the ribs, containing the stomach and bowels.
The stomach, especially as representing the body's need for food.
The underside of a bird or other animal.
A cut of pork from the underside between the legs.
A pig's belly as food, especially as a traded commodity.
The rounded underside of a ship or aircraft.
The top surface of an instrument of the violin family, over which the strings are placed.
Swell or cause to swell.
Move or sit close to (a bar or table)
--Examples--
‘his fat belly stuck out over his trousers’
‘they'll fight all the better on empty bellies’
‘grasses were said to have been tall enough to brush the bellies of horses’
‘as she leaned forward her pullover bellied out’
‘the wind bellied the sail out’
‘regulars who first bellied up to the bar years before’

--Word--
bell 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A hollow metal object, typically in the shape of a deep inverted cup widening at the lip, that sounds a clear musical note when struck, especially by means of a clapper inside.
A device that includes or sounds like a bell, used to give a signal or warning.
(in boxing and other sports) a bell rung to mark the start or end of a round.
A bell-shaped object or part of something.
The end of a trumpet or other brass instrument.
The corolla of a bell-shaped flower.
The umbrella of a jellyfish.
A musical instrument consisting of a set of metal tubes of different lengths, suspended in a frame and played by being struck with a hammer.
(preceded by a numeral) the time as indicated every half hour of a watch by the striking of the ship's bell one to eight times.
Provide with a bell or bells.
Make a ringing sound likened to that of a bell.
Telephone (someone)
Spread outwards like the lip of a bell.
--Examples--
‘the church bells tolled’
‘a bell tinkled as he went in the shop’
‘the bell chamber of the church spire’
‘a bicycle bell’
‘they were dragged off each other at the final bell’
‘the acoustic properties of a trumpet's bell’
‘a flower with small pale blue bells’
‘the tiny jellyfish has a bell measuring five to ten millimetres wide’
‘at five bells in the forenoon of June 11’
‘the young men were belling and hobbling the horses before releasing them’
‘the organ was belling away’
‘no problem, I'll bell her tomorrow’
‘her shirt belled out behind’

--Word--
bellows 
--Type--
plural noun
--Meanings--

‘they were dragged off each other at the final bell’
‘the acoustic properties of a trumpet's bell’
‘a flower with small pale blue bells’
‘the tiny jellyfish has a bell measuring five to ten millimetres wide’
‘at five bells in the forenoon of June 11’
‘the young men were belling and hobbling the horses before releasing them’
‘the organ was belling away’
‘no problem, I'll bell her tomorrow’
‘her shirt belled out behind’

bell-shaped 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having a shape that resembles that of a bell.
--Examples--
‘a small wild flower with purple bell-shaped blossoms’
--Word--
tongue 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The fleshy muscular organ in the mouth of a mammal, used for tasting, licking, swallowing, and (in humans) articulating speech.
The equivalent organ in other vertebrates, sometimes used (in snakes) as a scent organ or (in chameleons) for catching food.
An analogous organ in insects, formed from some of the mouthparts and used in feeding.
The tongue of an ox or lamb as food.
Used in reference to a person's style or manner of speaking.
A particular language.
A strip of leather or fabric under the laces in a shoe, attached only at the front end.
The pin of a buckle.
The free-swinging metal piece inside a bell which is made to strike the bell to produce the sound.
A long, low promontory of land.
A projecting strip on a wooden board fitting into a groove on another.
The vibrating reed of a musical instrument or organ pipe.
A jet of flame.
Sound (a note) distinctly on a wind instrument by interrupting the air flow with the tongue.
Lick or caress with the tongue.
--Examples--
‘a galantine of tongue’
‘he was a redoubtable debater with a caustic tongue’
‘the girls were singing in their native tongue’
‘a tongue of flame flashed from the gun’
‘Eugene has worked out the correct tonguing’
‘the other horse tongued every part of the colt's mane’

--Examples--
‘that post-bellum decade’
‘the post-bellum southern states’
--Word--
bell 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A hollow metal object, typically in the shape of a deep inverted cup widening at the lip, that sounds a clear musical note when struck, especially by means of a clapper inside.
A device that includes or sounds like a bell, used to give a signal or warning.
(in boxing and other sports) a bell rung to mark the start or end of a round.
A bell-shaped object or part of something.
The end of a trumpet or other brass instrument.
The corolla of a bell-shaped flower.
The umbrella of a jellyfish.
A musical instrument consisting of a set of metal tubes of different lengths, suspended in a frame and played by being struck with a hammer.
(preceded by a numeral) the time as indicated every half hour of a watch by the striking of the ship's bell one to eight times.
Provide with a bell or bells.
Make a ringing sound likened to that of a bell.
Telephone (someone)
Spread outwards like the lip of a bell.
--Examples--
‘the church bells tolled’
‘a bell tinkled as he went in the shop’
‘the bell chamber of the church spire’
‘a bicycle bell’
‘they were dragged off each other at the final bell’
‘the acoustic properties of a trumpet's bell’
‘a flower with small pale blue bells’
‘the tiny jellyfish has a bell measuring five to ten millimetres wide’
‘at five bells in the forenoon of June 11’
‘the young men were belling and hobbling the horses before releasing them’
‘the organ was belling away’
‘no problem, I'll bell her tomorrow’
‘her shirt belled out behind’

--Word--
belong 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Be the property of.
Be due to.
(of a contest or period of time) be dominated by.
Be a member of (a particular group or organization)
(of a person) have an affinity for a specified place or situation.
Have the right personal or social qualities to be a member of a particular group.
(of a thing) be rightly placed in a specified position.
Be rightly assigned to a specified category.
--Examples--
‘the vehicle did not belong to him’
‘most of the credit belongs to Paul’
‘the race belonged completely to Fogarty’
‘he belonged to the local cricket club’
‘she is a stranger, and doesn't belong here’
‘you and me, we belong together’
‘young people are generally very anxious to belong’
‘he put the rifle back in the locker where it belonged’
‘such statements do not belong in a modern student textbook’
‘these compounds belong to a class of chemical mediators called kairomones’

--Word--
belt 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A strip of leather or other material worn, typically round the waist, to support or hold in clothes or to carry weapons.
A belt worn as a sign of rank or achievement.
A belt of a specified colour, marking the attainment of a particular level in judo, karate, or similar sports.
A person who is qualified to wear a belt of a specified colour in judo, karate, etc.
The punishment of being struck with a belt.
A continuous band of material used in machinery for transferring motion from one wheel to another.
A conveyor belt.
A flexible strip carrying machine-gun cartridges.
A strip or encircling area that is different in nature or composition from its surroundings.
A heavy blow.
Fasten with a belt.
Be fastened with a belt.
Attach or secure with a belt.
Beat or strike (someone), especially with a belt as a punishment.
Hit (something) hard.
Rush or dash in a specified direction.
(of rain) fall hard.
--Examples--
‘he tightened his leather belt an extra notch’
‘a sword belt’
‘a belt buckle’
‘he was awarded the victor's belt’
‘brown-belt level’
‘Shaun became a brown belt in judo’
‘be quiet, or it's the belt’
‘a great wheel driven by a leather belt’
‘the asteroid belt’
‘a belt of trees’
‘she administered a good belt with her stick’
‘she belted her raincoat firmly’
‘the jacket belts at the waist’
‘he was securely belted into the passenger seat’
‘I was belted and sent to my room’
‘he belted the ball downfield’
‘he belted out of the side door’
‘the rain belted down on the tin roof’

‘her bemused expression’
‘he was bemused by what was happening’

ben

--Word--
bench 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A long seat for several people, typically made of wood or stone.
A long work table in a workshop or laboratory.
A judge's seat in a law court.
The office of judge or magistrate.
A judge or magistrate presiding over a particular case.
A long seat in Parliament for politicians of a specified party.
The politicians occupying a specified bench in Parliament.
A seat at the side of a sports field for coaches, substitutes, and players not taking part in a game.
A flat ledge in masonry or on sloping ground.
Exhibit (a dog) at a show.
Withdraw (a sports player) from play.
--Examples--
‘a park bench’
‘a 19th-century wheelwright's bench’
‘his appointment to the civil bench’
‘the Conservative benches’
‘the pledge that was given by the Opposition benches yesterday’
‘he must settle for a place on the substitute's bench’
‘Affenpinschers and Afghans were benched side by side’
‘the coach benched quarterback Cunningham in favour of McMahon’
‘he benched almost 500 pounds’

--Word--
Benchley 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The name of a family of US writers.
Robert Charles (1889–1945), drama critic, actor, and humorist. He was a theater critic for Life magazine (1920–29) and The New Yorker(1929–40).
Nathaniel (1915–81), son of Robert. He was the author of such humorous novels as Lassiter's Folly (1971).
Peter (1940–2006), son of Nathaniel. He wrote Jaws (1974), The Deep (1976), and White Shark (1994).
--Examples--

‘handmade chocolates’
--Word--
benchmark 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A standard or point of reference against which things may be compared.
A test designed to evaluate or compare the performance of computer hardware or software.
A surveyor's mark cut in a wall, pillar, or building and used as a reference point in measuring altitudes.
Evaluate (something) by comparison with a standard.
Give particular results during a benchmark test.
--Examples--
‘the pay settlement will set a benchmark for other employers and workers’
‘we thought we'd run some benchmarks on the smartphone’
‘we are benchmarking our performance against external criteria’
‘the device should benchmark at between 100 and 150 MHz’

--Word--
bend 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Shape or force (something straight) into a curve or angle.
(of something straight) be shaped or forced into a curve or angle.
(of a road, river, or path) deviate from a straight line in a specified direction.
(of a person) incline the body downwards from the vertical.
Move (a jointed part of the body) to an angled position.
Force or be forced to submit.
Interpret or modify (a rule) to suit someone.
Direct (one's attention or energies) to a task.
Attach (a sail or cable) by means of a knot.
A curve in a road, river, path, or racing circuit.
A curved or angled part of something.
A kind of knot used to join two ropes together, or to tie a rope to another object, e.g. a carrick bend.
Decompression sickness, especially in divers.
--Examples--
‘the wire has to be bent back tightly’
‘poppies bending in the wind’
‘the road bent left and then right’
‘she bent down and yanked out the flex’
‘I bent over my plate’
‘extend your left leg and bend your right’
‘they want to bend me to their will’
‘a refusal to bend to mob rule’
‘we cannot bend the rules, even for Darren’
‘Eric bent all his efforts to persuading them to donate some blankets’
‘she bent once more to the task of diverting her guests’
‘sailors were bending sails to the spars’
‘the van screeched round a bend’
‘a bend in the river’
‘make a bend in the wire’

--Word--
beneath 
--Type--
preposition, adverb
--Meanings--
Extending or directly underneath.
Underneath so as to be hidden, covered, or protected.
At a lower level or layer than.
Lower in grade or rank than.
Considered of lower status or worth than.
Behind (a physical surface)
Hidden behind (an appearance)
Extending or directly underneath something.
At a lower level or layer.
Hidden behind an appearance.
--Examples--
‘a 2.5-mile tunnel beneath the Alps’
‘the ancient city has lain hidden beneath the sea for 2,000 years’
‘beneath this floor there's a cellar’
‘her eyes had dark shadows beneath them’
‘he was relegated to the rank beneath theirs’
‘she's in love with a man who is rather beneath her’
‘they found another layer beneath the stucco’
‘beneath the gloss of success was a tragic private life’
‘a house built on stilts to allow air to circulate beneath’
‘upper layers can be removed to reveal internal parts beneath’
‘the smile revealed the evil beneath’
--Word--
Croce, Benedetto 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1866–1952), Italian philosopher and politician. In his ‘Philosophy of Spirit’ he denied the physical reality of a work of art and identified philosophical endeavour with a methodological approach to history. A former Minister of Education, he helped to rebuild democracy in Italy after the fall of Mussolini.
--Examples--
--Word--
benedicite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A blessing, especially a grace said at table in religious communities.
The canticle used in the Anglican service of matins beginning ‘O all ye works of the Lord, bless ye the Lord’, the text being taken from the Apocrypha.
--Examples--
--Word--
Arnold, Benedict 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1741–1801), American general and traitor. During the American Revolution, he was instrumental, with Ethan Allan, in the capture of Fort Ticonderoga but later planned to betray West Point to the British. He fled behind British lines and lived the rest of his life in Britain. His name became synonymous with 'traitor.'.
--Examples--
--Word--
Benedictine 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A monk or nun of a Christian religious order following the rule of St Benedict and established c.540.
A liqueur based on brandy, originally made by Benedictine monks in France.
Relating to St Benedict or the Benedictines.
--Examples--

‘he eventually wins benediction’

‘daisies that are highly attractive to five key kinds of beneficials (ladybugs, lacewings, hover flies, tachinid flies, and miniwasps)’

--Word--
benefit 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An advantage or profit gained from something.
A payment made by the state or an insurance scheme to someone entitled to receive it.
An event such as a concert or game, intended to raise money for a particular player or charity.
Receive an advantage; profit.
Bring advantage to.
--Examples--
‘enjoy the benefits of being a member’
‘the changes are of benefit to commerce’
‘part-time jobs supplemented by means-tested benefits’
‘families on benefit’
‘the social season was highlighted by debutante balls and charity benefits’
‘a benefit gig’
‘areas that would benefit from regeneration’
‘the bill will benefit Britain’

Beneš, Edvard 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1884–1948), Czechoslovak statesman, prime minister 1921–2, president 1935–8 and 1945–8. During the Second World War he served in London as head of the Czechoslovakian government in exile. In 1945 he regained the presidency but resigned after the 1948 communist coup.

Israel 
--Type--
proper noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
A country in the Middle East, on the Mediterranean Sea; population 8,100,000 (estimated 2015); languages, Hebrew (official), English, Arabic; capital (not recognized as such by the United Nations), Jerusalem.
The Hebrew nation or people. According to tradition they are descended from the twelve sons of the patriarch Jacob (also named Israel).
The northern kingdom of the Hebrews (c.930–721 BC), formed after the reign of Solomon, whose inhabitants were carried away to captivity in Assyria.
--Examples--
--Word--
Benin 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A country of West Africa, immediately west of Nigeria; population 10,900,000 (estimated 2015); languages, French (official), West African languages; capital, Porto Novo. The country was conquered by the French in 1893 and became part of French West Africa. In 1960 it became fully independent.

Benioff zone

noun
--Meanings--
An inclined zone in which many deep earthquakes occur, situated beneath a destructive plate boundary where oceanic crust is being subducted.

--Word--
Mussolini, Benito 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1883–1945), Italian Fascist statesman, prime minister 1922–43; known as Il Duce (‘the leader’); full name Benito Amilcare Andrea Mussolini. He founded the Italian Fascist Party in 1921. He annexed Abyssinia in 1936 and entered the Second World War on Germany's side in 1940. Forced to resign after the Allied invasion of Sicily, he was rescued from imprisonment by German paratroopers, but was captured and executed by Italian communist partisans.

Benn, Tony 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1925–2014), British Labour politician; full name Anthony Neil Wedgwood Benn. A Labour MP from 1950, he was debarred from the House of Commons on succeeding to the title of Viscount Stansgate in 1960. He renounced his title in 1963 and was re-elected. He held several cabinet posts and gained a reputation as an orator on the left of the party.

proper noun

--Type--
adjective, noun

Relating to or consistent with the philosophical system of utilitarianism proposed by the English philosopher and jurist Jeremy Bentham.

Benton, Thomas Hart 
--Type--
proper noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
(1782–1858), US politician. A Democratic member of the US Senate from Missouri (1821–51), he supported frontier explorations and opposed extending slavery to the territories.
(1889–1975), US painter, a grand-nephew of Senator Thomas Hart Benton. His paintings, of the American naturalist school, represent life in the Midwest.

--Word--
Berber 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of the indigenous people of North Africa, among whom are the nomadic Tuareg.
The Afro-Asiatic language of the Berber peoples, spoken by about 11 million people. There are several different dialects; some of them, e.g. Tamashek, are regarded by some scholars as separate languages.
Relating to the Berber peoples or their language.

Coma Berenices 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A small inconspicuous northern constellation (Berenice's Hair), said to represent the tresses of Queen Berenice. It contains a large number of galaxies.
Used with preceding letter or numeral to designate a star in the constellation Coma Berenices.
--Examples--
‘the star Beta Comae Berenices’

noun, noun
--Meanings--

A dessert pear of a rich and sweet variety.

--Word--
Bergson, Henri 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1859–1941), French philosopher; full name Henri Louis Bergson. Dividing the world into life (or consciousness) and matter, he rejected Darwinian evolution and argued that life possesses an inherent creative impulse (élan vital) which creates new forms as life seeks to impose itself on matter. Nobel Prize for Literature (1927).
--Examples--
--Word--
Bergsonian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or characteristic of the French philosopher Henri Bergson or his ideas.
A follower of the ideas of the French philosopher Henri Bergson.
--Examples--
‘a Bergsonian division between intuition and intellect’
‘half of the most excitable authors of our time have been Bergsonians’
--Word--
Bergson, Henri 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1859–1941), French philosopher; full name Henri Louis Bergson. Dividing the world into life (or consciousness) and matter, he rejected Darwinian evolution and argued that life possesses an inherent creative impulse (élan vital) which creates new forms as life seeks to impose itself on matter. Nobel Prize for Literature (1927).

Beria, Lavrenti 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1899–1953), Soviet politician and head of the secret police 1938–53; full name Lavrenti Pavlovich Beria. He was involved in the elimination or deportation of Stalin's opponents, but after Stalin's death he was arrested and executed.

berkelium 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The chemical element of atomic number 97, a radioactive metal of the actinide series. Berkelium does not occur naturally and was first made by bombarding americium with helium ions.

Berlioz, Hector 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1803–69), French composer; full name Louis-Hector Berlioz. He wrote for large orchestras and choirs and employed dramatic, descriptive orchestral effects. Notable works: Les Troyens (opera, 1856–9), Symphonie fantastique (1830), and La Damnation de Faust (cantata, 1846).

Bernadette, St. 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1844–79), French peasant girl; born Marie Bernarde Soubirous. Her visions of the Virgin Mary at Lourdes in 1858 led to the town's establishment as a center of pilgrimage. Feast day, February 18.

Bernadotte, Jean 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1763–1844), French soldier; king of Sweden (as Charles XIV) 1818–44; full name Jean Baptiste Jules Bernadotte. One of Napoleon's marshals, he was adopted by Charles XIII of Sweden in 1810 and later became king, thus founding Sweden's present royal house.

O'Higgins, Bernardo 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(c.1778–1842), Chilean revolutionary leader and statesman, head of state 1817–23. With the help of José de San Martín he led the army which defeated Spanish forces in 1817 and paved the way for Chilean independence the following year.

--Word--
Riemann, Bernhard 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1826–66), German mathematician; full name Georg Friedrich Bernhard Riemann. He founded Riemannian geometry, which is of fundamental importance to both mathematics and physics. The Riemann hypothesis, about the complex numbers which are roots of a certain transcendental equation, remains an unsolved problem.
--Examples--
--Word--
Bernhardt, Sarah 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1844–1923), French actress; born Henriette Rosine Bernard. She was best known for her portrayal of Marguerite in La Dame aux Camélias and Cordelia in King Lear.

Bernini, Gian Lorenzo 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1598–1680), Italian baroque sculptor, painter, and architect. His work includes the great canopy over the altar and the colonnade round the piazza at St Peter's, Rome.
--Examples--
--Word--
Bernoulli 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A Swiss family that produced many eminent mathematicians and scientists.
Jakob (1654–1705); also known as Jacques or James Bernoulli. He made discoveries in calculus and contributed to geometry and the theory of probabilities.
Johann (1667–1748), the brother of Jakob, who contributed to differential and integral calculus; also known as Jean or John Bernoulli.
Daniel (1700–82), son of Johann. His greatest contributions were to hydrodynamics and mathematical physics.
--Examples--
--Word--
New Bern

--Meanings--
A historic commercial city in eastern North Carolina; population 28,586 (est. 2008).

proper noun
--Meanings--
(1918–90), American composer, conductor, and pianist. Notable works: Candide (operetta, 1954–6), West Side Story (musical, 1957), Chichester Psalms (1965), and film music for On the Waterfront (1954).
--Examples--
--Word--
Berra, Yogi 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1925–2015), American baseball player; born Lawrence Peter Berra. He was especially famous as a catcher with the New York Yankees.
--Examples--
--Word--
berry 
--Type--
noun, verb, proper noun
--Meanings--
A small roundish juicy fruit without a stone.
Any fruit that has its seeds enclosed in a fleshy pulp, for example a banana or tomato.
Any of various kernels or seeds, such as the coffee bean.
A fish egg or the roe of a lobster or similar creature.
Gather berries.
A former province of central France; chief town, Bourges.
--Examples--
‘juniper berries’
‘let's go berrying’
--Word--
bearing 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person's way of standing or moving.
The way a person behaves or conducts themselves.
Relation; relevance.
The ability to tolerate something bad or to be tolerated.
A part of a machine that allows one part to rotate or move in contact with another part with as little friction as possible.
The direction or position of something, or the direction of movement, relative to a fixed point. It is usually measured in degrees, typically with magnetic north as zero.
Awareness of one's position relative to one's surroundings.
A device or charge.
--Examples--
‘a man of precise military bearing’
‘she has the bearing of a First Lady’
‘the case has no direct bearing on the issues being considered’
‘school was bad enough, but now it's past bearing’
‘the Point is on a bearing of 015°’
‘there were no steeples or bridges from which to take a bearing’
‘he flashed the torch around, trying to get his bearings’
‘armorial bearings’
--Word--
(as) brown as a berry 
--Type--
phrase
--Meanings--
(of a person) very suntanned.
--Examples--
‘she'd lost her pale, city complexion and become as brown as a berry’
--Word--
berried 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Bearing or covered with berries.
Like a berry or berries, as in flavour or shape.
(of crustaceans or fish) bearing eggs.
--Examples--
‘red-berried elder trees’

Berryman, John 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1914–72), US poet and educator. His notable works include the Pulitzer Prize-winning 77 Dream Songs (1964).
--Examples--
--Word--
off (or on) the bone 
--Type--
phrase
--Meanings--
(of meat or fish) having had the bone or bones removed (or left in) before being cooked, served, or sold.
--Examples--
‘they supply hams in the traditional way, on the bone’

Lahr, Bert 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1895–1967) US comedian and actor; born Irving Lahrheim. He starred in The Wizard of Oz (1939) as the Cowardly Lion. His other movies include Ship Ahoy (1942) and The Night They Raided Minsky's (1968).
--Examples--
--Word--
Hummel, Berta 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1909–46), German artist and nun; also known as Sister Maria Innocentia. She created the sketches upon which M. I. Hummel figurines, made by the Franz Goebel Company, are based.
--Examples--
--Word--
berth 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A ship's allotted place at a wharf or dock.
A fixed bunk on a ship, train, or other means of transport.
(often in a sporting context) a position in an organization or event.
Moor (a ship) in its allotted place.
(of a ship) dock.
(of a passenger ship) provide a sleeping place for (someone).
--Examples--
‘the vessel had left its berth’
‘I'll sleep in the upper berth’
‘a four-berth caravan’
‘he looked at home in an unfamiliar right-back berth’
‘they planned to berth HMS Impregnable at Portsmouth’
‘the ship berthed at Plymouth’
--Word--
bertha 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A deep collar, typically made of lace, attached to the top of a dress that has a low neckline.
--Examples--

--Word--
Morisot, Berthe 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1841–95), French painter, the first woman to join the impressionists; full name Berthe Marie Pauline Morisot. Her works typically depict women and children and waterside scenes.
--Examples--

--Word--
berthing 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action or process of mooring a ship in its allotted place.
Accommodation for ships in berths.
--Examples--
‘as soon as the berthing was complete, they went ashore’
‘there were more than 12 miles of berthing’

Ahern, Bertie 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(born 1951), Irish Fianna Fáil statesman, Taoiseach (prime minister) 1997–2008; full name Patrick Bartholomew Ahern.
--Examples--
--Word--
Bertillon, Alphonse 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1853–1914), French criminologist. He devised a system of body measurements for the identification of criminals, which was widely used until superseded by fingerprinting at the beginning of the 20th century.
--Examples--
--Word--
Brecht, Bertolt 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1898–1956), German playwright, producer, and poet; full name Eugen Bertolt Friedrich Brecht. His interest in combining music and drama led to collaboration with Kurt Weill, for example in The Threepenny Opera (1928), an adaptation of John Gay's The Beggar's Opera. Brecht's later drama, written in exile after Hitler's rise to power, uses techniques of theatrical alienation and includes Mother Courage (1941) and The Caucasian Chalk Circle (1948).
--Examples--
--Word--
Bertolucci, Bernardo 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(born 1940), Italian film director. Notable works: The Spider's Stratagem (1970), Last Tango in Paris (1972), The Last Emperor (1987), and The Dreamers (2003).
--Examples--
--Word--
Russell, Bertrand 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
3rd Earl Russell (1872–1970), British philosopher, mathematician, and social reformer; full name Bertrand Arthur William Russell. In Principia Mathematica (1910–13) he and A. N. Whitehead attempted to express all of mathematics in formal logic terms. He expounded logical atomism in Our Knowledge of the External World (1914) and neutral monism in The Analysis of Mind (1921). A conscientious objector during the First World War, he also campaigned for women's suffrage and against nuclear arms. Nobel Prize for Literature (1950).
--Examples--
--Word--
Berwick-upon-Tweed 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A town at the mouth of the River Tweed in north-eastern England, close to the Scottish border; population 13,000 (est. 2009). Having been held alternately by England and Scotland, it was ceded by Scotland to England in 1482.
--Examples--
--Word--
Berwickshire 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A former county of south-eastern Scotland, on the border with England. It became a part of Borders region (now Scottish Borders) in 1975.
--Examples--

Berzelius, Jöns Jakob 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1779–1848), Swedish analytical chemist. He determined the atomic weights of many elements and discovered cerium, selenium, and thorium.

--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A grotesque god depicted as having short legs, an obese body, and an almost bestial face, who dispelled evil spirits.

Besant, Annie 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1847–1933), English theosophist, writer, and politician, president of the Theosophical Society. She settled in Madras (Chennai), where she worked for Indian self-government.

--Word--
beset 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
(of a problem or difficulty) trouble (someone or something) persistently.
Surround and harass.
Hem in.
Be covered or studded with.
--Examples--
‘the social problems that beset the UK’
‘she was beset with self-doubt’
‘I was beset by clouds of flies’
‘the ship was beset by ice and finally sank’
‘springy grass all beset with tiny jewel-like flowers’

--Word--
beside 
--Type--
preposition
--Meanings--
At the side of; next to.
Compared with.
In addition to; apart from.
--Examples--
‘he sat beside me in the front seat’
‘the table beside the bed’
‘beside Paula she always felt clumsy’
‘he commissioned work from other artists beside Minton’
--Word--
besides 
--Type--
preposition, adverb
--Meanings--
In addition to; apart from.
In addition; as well.
Used to introduce an additional idea or explanation.
--Examples--
‘I have no other family besides my parents’
‘besides being a player, he was my friend’
‘I'm capable of doing the work, and a lot more besides’
‘I had no time to warn you. Besides, I wasn't sure’
--Word--
besiege 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Surround (a place) with armed forces in order to capture it or force its surrender.
Surround and harass.
Be inundated by large numbers of requests or complaints.
--Examples--
‘the king marched north to besiege Berwick’
‘she spent the whole day besieged by newsmen’
‘the television station was besieged with calls’
--Word--
besieged 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a place) surrounded by armed forces aiming to capture it or force surrender.
--Examples--
‘the besieged city’
--Word--
besiegement 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Aggressive pressure or intimidation.
--Examples--
‘the policy of political besiegement’

--Word--
smut 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A small flake of soot or other dirt or a mark left by one.
A fungal disease of cereals in which parts of the ear change to black powder.
Obscene or lascivious talk, writing, or pictures.
Mark with flakes or soot or other dirt.
Infect (a plant) with smut.
--Examples--
‘all those black smuts from the engine’
‘a few bad crop years with smut and drought and frost’
‘fungal infections such as the smuts’
‘porn, in his view, is far from being harmless smut’
‘the smutted sky’
‘smutted wheat’
--Word--
be- 
--Type--
prefix
--Meanings--
(forming verbs) all over; all round.
(forming verbs) thoroughly; excessively.
(added to intransitive verbs) expressing transitive action.
(added to adjectives and nouns) expressing transitive action.
(added to nouns) affect with.
(added to adjectives) cause to be.
(forming adjectives ending in -ed) having; covered with.
--Examples--
‘bespatter’
‘bewilder’
‘bemoan’
‘befool’
‘befriend’
‘befog’
‘befoul’
‘bejewelled’
--Word--
besom 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A broom made of twigs tied round a stick.
A woman or girl.

verb

--Word--
Bessarabia 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A region in eastern Europe between the Dniester and Prut Rivers. It was part of Romania 1918–40, but now lies in Moldova and Ukraine.
--Examples--
--Word--
Bessarabian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or characteristic of the former European region of Bessarabia or its inhabitants.
A native or inhabitant of the former European region of Bessarabia.
--Examples--
‘a Bulgarian of Bessarabian descent’
‘he was a Bessarabian of noble birth’
--Word--
Bessel, Friedrich Wilhelm 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1784–1846), German astronomer and mathematician. He determined the positions of some 75,000 stars, obtained accurate measurements of stellar distances, and following a study of the orbit of Uranus, predicted the existence of an eighth planet.
--Examples--
--Word--
Bessemer 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city in north central Alabama, a steel and industrial center southwest of Birmingham; population 28,542 (est. 2008).
--Examples--
--Word--
bezzie 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Denoting a person's best or closest friend.
A person's best or closest friend.
--Examples--
‘we're practically bezzie mates’
‘Fiona's my bezzy pal’
‘she and Nadine used to be bezzies and even shared a flat’
‘find out how well you know your bessie’
--Word--
best 
--Type--
adjective, adverb, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Of the most excellent or desirable type or quality.
Most enjoyable.
Most appropriate, advantageous, or well advised.
To the highest degree; most (used with verbs suggesting a desirable action or state or a successful outcome)
To the highest standard.
Most appropriately or usefully.
That which is the most excellent, outstanding, or desirable.
The finest aspect of a person or thing.
The highest standard or level that someone or something can reach.
One's smartest or most formal clothes.
(in sport) a record performance.
Written at the end of a letter to wish a person well.
Outwit or get the better of (someone)
--Examples--
‘the best midfielder in the country’
‘how to obtain the best results from your machine’
‘her best black suit’
‘some of the best times of my life’
‘do whatever you think best’
‘it's best if we both go’
‘they named the pictures they liked best’
‘you knew him best’
‘well-drained soil suits this plant best’
‘the best-dressed man in Britain’
‘the things we do best’
‘pruning is best done in spring’
‘jokes are best avoided in essays’
‘buy the best you can afford’
‘Sarah always had to be the best at everything’
‘this film represents the best of mainstream popular cinema’
‘he brought out the best in people’
‘this is jazz at its best’
‘try to look your best’
‘she dressed in her best’
‘a lifetime best of 12.0 seconds’
‘See you soon, best, Michael’
‘she refused to allow herself to be bested’
--Word--
-able 
--Type--
suffix
--Meanings--
(forming adjectives) able to be.
(forming adjectives) to be.
(forming adjectives) subject to.
(forming adjectives) relevant to or in accordance with.
(forming adjectives) having the quality to.
--Examples--
‘calculable’
‘payable’
‘taxable’
‘fashionable’
‘suitable’
‘comfortable’

‘food can be an abused substance’
