--Word--
well-conditioned 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of good disposition, morals, or behaviour; having good qualities; right-minded. Now rare (chiefly archaic).
In good physical condition; in a sound, healthy, or satisfactory state.
Surveying and Computing. Such that a small error in measurement or change in data gives rise to only a small change in the calculated result or outcome; such that an answer can be obtained to an acceptable degree of accuracy.
--Examples--
--Word--
conducted 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Led by a guide; managed.
--Examples--
‘a conducted tour’

considered 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having been thought about carefully.
--Examples--
‘I may not have time to give a considered reply to suggestions’
--Word--
consult 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Seek information or advice from (someone, especially an expert or professional)
Have discussions with (someone), typically before undertaking a course of action.
Refer for information to (a book, diary, or watch)
An act of consulting a professional; a consultation.
--Examples--
‘if you consult a solicitor, making a will is a simple procedure’
‘patients are entitled to be consulted about their treatment’
‘the government must consult with interested bodies’
‘she consulted a large desk diary’
‘after a consult with his attorneys, he retracted his previous statement’
--Word--
cultivated 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Refined and well educated.
--Examples--
‘he was a remarkably cultivated and educated man’
--Word--
dressed 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of food, especially poultry or shellfish) cleaned and prepared for cooking or eating.
(of a salad) having a dressing added.
(of stone) having had the surface smoothed.
(of an artificial fly) made for use in fishing.
--Examples--
‘dressed crab’
‘serve with dressed salad leaves’
‘a fine frontage in red brick with dressed white stone on the facings’
‘dressed Cotswold stone’
‘a dressed wet fly’

--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having existed or done something for a long time and therefore recognized and generally accepted.

‘an established artist’
‘thick, established plants can be pruned by cutting out about one third of all stems’
‘America had no established Church’

--Word--
best-laid 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
That has been laid in the best manner or to the highest standard.
Of a plan, scheme, etc.: formulated most carefully or meticulously. Now chiefly in "best-laid plans" with allusion to quot. 1786.
--Examples--
--Word--
learned 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a person) having acquired much knowledge through study.
Showing, requiring, or characterized by learning; scholarly.
Used as a courteous description of a lawyer in certain formal contexts.
--Examples--
‘a learned, generous, and notoriously absent-minded man’
‘an article in a learned journal’
‘my learned friend’

Outwit or get the better of (someone)
--Examples--
‘the best midfielder in the country’
‘how to obtain the best results from your machine’
‘her best black suit’
‘some of the best times of my life’
‘do whatever you think best’
‘it's best if we both go’
‘they named the pictures they liked best’
‘you knew him best’
‘well-drained soil suits this plant best’
‘the best-dressed man in Britain’
‘the things we do best’
‘pruning is best done in spring’
‘jokes are best avoided in essays’
‘buy the best you can afford’
‘Sarah always had to be the best at everything’
‘this film represents the best of mainstream popular cinema’
‘he brought out the best in people’
‘this is jazz at its best’
‘try to look your best’
‘she dressed in her best’
‘a lifetime best of 12.0 seconds’
‘See you soon, best, Michael’
‘she refused to allow herself to be bested’

--Word--
best 
--Type--
adjective, adverb, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Of the most excellent or desirable type or quality.
Most enjoyable.
Most appropriate, advantageous, or well advised.
To the highest degree; most (used with verbs suggesting a desirable action or state or a successful outcome)
To the highest standard.
Most appropriately or usefully.
That which is the most excellent, outstanding, or desirable.
The finest aspect of a person or thing.
The highest standard or level that someone or something can reach.
One's smartest or most formal clothes.
(in sport) a record performance.
Written at the end of a letter to wish a person well.
Outwit or get the better of (someone)
--Examples--
‘the best midfielder in the country’
‘how to obtain the best results from your machine’
‘her best black suit’
‘some of the best times of my life’
‘do whatever you think best’
‘it's best if we both go’
‘they named the pictures they liked best’
‘you knew him best’
‘well-drained soil suits this plant best’
‘the best-dressed man in Britain’
‘the things we do best’
‘pruning is best done in spring’
‘jokes are best avoided in essays’
‘buy the best you can afford’
‘Sarah always had to be the best at everything’
‘this film represents the best of mainstream popular cinema’
‘he brought out the best in people’
‘this is jazz at its best’
‘try to look your best’
‘she dressed in her best’
‘a lifetime best of 12.0 seconds’
‘See you soon, best, Michael’
‘she refused to allow herself to be bested’

verb
--Meanings--

‘creatures that bestride the dividing line between amphibians and reptiles’

--Word--
bet 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Risk a sum of money or valued item against someone else's on the basis of the outcome of an unpredictable event such as a race or game.
Risk a sum of money against (someone) on the outcome or likelihood of a future event.
Used to express certainty.
An act of betting a sum of money.
A sum of money staked.
A candidate or option offering a specified likelihood of success.
One's opinion about a future event.
--Examples--
‘he bet on baseball games’
‘I would be prepared to bet that he wanted to leave’
‘most people would bet their life savings on the prospect’
‘I bet you £15 you won't chat her up’
‘I bet this place is really spooky late at night’
‘he'll be surprised to see me, I'll bet’
‘she had a bet on the Derby’
‘for a bet he once rode 200 miles in nine hours’
‘the bookies are taking bets on his possible successor’
‘City looked a good bet for victory’
‘your best bet is to call the official liquidators’
‘my bet is that Arsenal won't win anything’

--Word--
beta 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The second letter of the Greek alphabet (Β, β), transliterated as ‘b’.
Denoting the second of a series of items, categories, forms of a chemical compound, etc.
A second-class mark given for a piece of work or an examination paper.
The second (typically second-brightest) star in a constellation.
Relating to beta decay or beta particles.
A measure of the movement in price of a security relative to the stock market as a whole, used to indicate possible risk.
--Examples--
‘beta carotene’
‘beta blocker’
‘Beta Virginis’
‘beta emitters’
‘a fund with a beta of 0.58 is less volatile’
--Word--
amylase 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An enzyme, found chiefly in saliva and pancreatic fluid, that converts starch and glycogen into simple sugars.

Betelgeuse 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The tenth-brightest star in the sky, in the constellation Orion. It is a red supergiant, and variations in its brightness are associated with pulsations in its outer envelope.

Bethlehem 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A small town 8 km (5 miles) south of Jerusalem, in the West Bank; population 43,100 (est. 2009). It was the native city of King David and is the reputed birthplace of Jesus.

--Word--
Bethune, Mary McLeod 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(1875–1955), US educator; full name Mary Jane McLeod Bethune. In 1904, she founded the Daytona Normal and Industrial Institute for Negro Girls, which, with the Cookman Institute, became Bethune-Cookman College in 1923. Bethune was founder and first president 1935–49 of the National Council of Negro Women.
--Examples--
--Word--
betide 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Happen.
Happen to (someone)
--Examples--
‘I waited with beating heart, not knowing what would betide’
‘she was trembling with fear lest worse might betide her’

--Word--
Betjeman, Sir John 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1906–84), English poet, noted for his self-deprecating, witty, and gently satirical poems. He was appointed Poet Laureate in 1972.
--Examples--
--Word--
betoken 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--

Be a warning or indication of (a future event)
--Examples--
‘she wondered if his cold, level gaze betokened indifference or anger’
‘the falling comet betokened the true end of Merlin's powers’

‘she wondered if his cold, level gaze betokened indifference or anger’
‘the falling comet betokened the true end of Merlin's powers’
--Word--
betoken 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Be a sign of.
Be a warning or indication of (a future event)
--Examples--
‘she wondered if his cold, level gaze betokened indifference or anger’
‘the falling comet betokened the true end of Merlin's powers’

--Word--
betony 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A Eurasian plant of the mint family, which bears spikes of showy purple flowers.
Used in names of plants that resemble the betony, e.g. water betony.
--Examples--

--Word--
betray 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Expose (one's country, a group, or a person) to danger by treacherously giving information to an enemy.
Treacherously reveal (information)
Be gravely disloyal to.
Unintentionally reveal; be evidence of.
--Examples--
‘a double agent who betrayed some 400 British and French agents to the Germans’
‘many of those employed by diplomats betrayed secrets’
‘the men who have betrayed British people's trust’
‘she drew a deep breath that betrayed her indignation’
--Word--
betrayal 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of betraying one's country, a group, or a person; treachery.
--Examples--
‘the betrayal by the king by his daughter’
‘these developments represented a betrayal of democracy’

--Word--
bet 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Risk a sum of money or valued item against someone else's on the basis of the outcome of an unpredictable event such as a race or game.
Risk a sum of money against (someone) on the outcome or likelihood of a future event.
Used to express certainty.
An act of betting a sum of money.
A sum of money staked.
A candidate or option offering a specified likelihood of success.
One's opinion about a future event.
--Examples--
‘he bet on baseball games’
‘I would be prepared to bet that he wanted to leave’
‘most people would bet their life savings on the prospect’
‘I bet you £15 you won't chat her up’
‘I bet this place is really spooky late at night’
‘he'll be surprised to see me, I'll bet’
‘she had a bet on the Derby’
‘for a bet he once rode 200 miles in nine hours’
‘the bookies are taking bets on his possible successor’
‘City looked a good bet for victory’
‘your best bet is to call the official liquidators’
‘my bet is that Arsenal won't win anything’
--Word--
betting 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of gambling money on the outcome of a race, game, or other unpredictable event.
The odds offered by bookmakers on the outcome of races, games, etc.
--Examples--
‘football pools and other forms of betting’
‘Atlantic Way headed the betting at 2-1’
--Word--
Ross, Betsy 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1752–1836), US patriot and seamstress; full name Elizabeth Griscom Ross. She is traditionally credited with having made the first flag of the US in June 1776.
--Examples--
--Word--
Davis, Bette 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1908–89), American actress; born Ruth Elizabeth Davis. She established her Hollywood career playing a number of strong, independent female characters in such films as Dangerous (1935). Her flair for suggesting the macabre and menacing emerged in later films, such as What Ever Happened to Baby Jane? (1962).
--Examples--
--Word--
Davis, Bette 
--Type--

--Meanings--

--Word--
Bettendorf 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An industrial city in southeastern Iowa, on the Mississippi River; population 32,584 (est. 2008). It is one of the Quad Cities.
--Examples--
--Word--
better 
--Type--
adjective, adverb, noun, verb
--Meanings--
More desirable, satisfactory, or effective.
More appropriate, advantageous, or well advised.
Partly or fully recovered from illness, injury, or mental stress.
More excellently or effectively.
To a greater degree; more (used in connection with success or with desirable actions or conditions)
More suitably, appropriately, or usefully.
The better one; that which is better.
One's superiors in social class or ability.
Improve on or surpass (an existing or previous level or achievement)
Make (something) better; improve.
Achieve a higher social position or status.
Overcome or defeat (someone)
--Examples--
‘we're hoping for better weather tomorrow’
‘the new facilities were far better’
‘I'm better at doing sums than Alice’
‘there couldn't be a better time to take up this job’
‘it might be better to borrow the money’
‘his leg was getting better’
‘Jonathon could do better if he tried’
‘sound travels better in water than in air’
‘instruments are generally better made these days’
‘I liked it better when we lived in the country’
‘well-fed people are better able to fight off infection’
‘the money could be better spent on more urgent cases’
‘the Natural History Museum book is by far the better of the two’
‘you've a right to expect better than that’
‘a change for the better’
‘educating the young to respect their elders and betters’
‘his account can hardly be bettered’
‘bettering his previous time by ten minutes’
‘his ideas for bettering the lot of the millhands’
‘the residents are mostly Londoners who have bettered themselves’
‘she had almost bettered him at archery’

advised 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Acting in a way that would be recommended; sensible; wise.
--Examples--
‘you would be advised to check on increases to your pension’
--Word--
affected 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Influenced or touched by an external factor.
Artificial, pretentious, and designed to impress.
Disposed or inclined in a specified way.
--Examples--
‘affected areas’
‘the gesture appeared both affected and stagy’
‘you might become differently affected towards him’
--Word--
balanced 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Keeping or showing a balance; in good proportions.
Taking everything into account; fairly judged or presented.
(especially of food) having different elements in the correct proportions.
(of a person or state of mind) having no emotion too strong or too weak; stable.
(of an electric circuit or signal) being symmetrical with respect to a reference point, usually earth.
--Examples--
‘she assembled a balanced team’
‘accurate and balanced information’
‘a healthy, balanced diet’
‘a balanced personality’

becoming

adjective

(of clothing) looking good on someone.
Suitable or appropriate.
--Examples--
‘what a becoming dress!’
‘do not talk too much to your cousins, it's not becoming’

behaved

adjective
--Meanings--
Conducting oneself in a specified way.
--Examples--
‘a well-behaved child’
‘some of the boys had been badly behaved’

--Meanings--
A short-nosed rat-kangaroo found in Australia.

--Word--

--Word--
between 
--Type--
preposition, adverb
--Meanings--
At, into, or across the space separating (two objects or regions)
In the period separating (two points in time)
In the interval separating (two points on a scale)
Indicating a connection or relationship involving two or more parties.
With reference to a collision or conflict.
With reference to a contrast or failure to correspond.
With reference to a choice or differentiation involving two or more things being considered together.
By combining the resources or actions of (two or more people or other entities)
Shared by (two or more people or things)
In or along the space separating two objects or regions.
In the period separating two points in time.
--Examples--
‘the border between Mexico and the United States’
‘the dog crawled between us and lay down at our feet’
‘those who travel by train between London and Paris’
‘they snack between meals’
‘the long, cold nights between autumn and spring’
‘a man aged between 18 and 30’
‘between 25 and 40 per cent off children's clothes’
‘links between science and industry’
‘negotiations between the two companies are continuing’
‘a collision in mid-air between two light aircraft’
‘the 14th- and 15th-century wars between England and France’
‘the difference between income and expenditure’
‘you have to choose between two or three different options’
‘we have created something between us’
‘oxygen and nitrogen between them account for 99 per cent of air’
‘they had drunk between them a bottle of Chianti’
‘layers of paper with tar in between’
‘from Leipzig to Dresden, with the gentle Elbe flowing between’
‘sets of exercises with no rest in between’

--Word--
bevel 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A slope from the horizontal or vertical in carpentry and stonework; a sloping surface or edge.
A tool for marking angles in carpentry and stonework.
Reduce (a square edge on an object) to a sloping edge.
--Examples--
‘a very small 45° bevel is ground on the top surface’
‘a bevelled mirror’

Beveridge, William Henry 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
1st Baron (1879–1963), British economist and social reformer, born in India. He was chairman of the committee which prepared the Beveridge Report, which formed the basis of much of the social legislation on which the welfare state in the UK is founded.
--Examples--

Bevin, Ernest 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1881–1951), British Labour statesman and trade unionist. He was one of the founders of the Transport and General Workers' Union and a leading organizer of the General Strike (1926).

--Word--
antler 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Each of the branched horns on the head of an adult deer (typically a male one), which are made of bone and are grown and cast annually.
Each of the branches on an antler.
--Examples--
‘a stag's antlers’
‘combs made of antler’

--Word--
bezique 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A trick-taking card game for two, played with a double pack of 64 cards, including the seven to ace only in each suit.
The holding of the queen of spades and the jack of diamonds in bezique.
--Examples--
--Word--
bezique 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A trick-taking card game for two, played with a double pack of 64 cards, including the seven to ace only in each suit.
The holding of the queen of spades and the jack of diamonds in bezique.
--Examples--
--Word--
bezoar 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small stony concretion which may form in the stomachs of certain animals, especially ruminants, and which was once used as an antidote for various ailments.
A wild goat with flat scimitar-shaped horns, found from Greece to Pakistan. The ancestor of the domestic goat, it was the best-known source of bezoars.
--Examples--
--Word--
bezoar 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small stony concretion which may form in the stomachs of certain animals, especially ruminants, and which was once used as an antidote for various ailments.
A wild goat with flat scimitar-shaped horns, found from Greece to Pakistan. The ancestor of the domestic goat, it was the best-known source of bezoars.
--Examples--
--Word--
BF

--Meanings--

--Examples--
‘I've been dating my BF since January’
‘Lottie is my absolute BF’

--Examples--
--Word--
b 
--Type--
abbreviation, noun, abbreviation
UnKnownKind
--Meanings--
Barn(s).
Born (used to indicate a date of birth)
(on scorecards) bowled by.
(on scorecards) bye(s)
The second letter of the alphabet.
Denoting the second in a set of items, categories, sizes, etc.
The second highest class of academic mark.
(in the UK) denoting a secondary road.
Denoting the second-highest-earning socio-economic category for marketing purposes, including intermediate management and professional personnel.
Denoting the second file from the left, as viewed from White's side of the board.
The second fixed constant to appear in an algebraic equation.
Denoting a soil horizon of intermediate depth, typically the subsoil.
The human blood type (in the ABO system) containing the B antigen and lacking the A.
(with numeral) denoting a series of international standard paper sizes each twice the area of the next, as B0, B1, B2, B3, B4, etc., B4 being 250 × 353 mm.
The seventh note of the diatonic scale of C major.
A key based on a scale with B as its keynote.
Belgium (international vehicle registration).
Bishop (used in recording moves in chess)
Black (used in describing grades of pencil lead)
Bomber (in designations of US aircraft types)
The chemical element boron.
Magnetic flux density.

--Word--
Bhagavadgita 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A poem composed between the 2nd century BC and the 2nd century AD and incorporated into the Mahabharata. Presented as a dialogue between the Kshatriya prince Arjuna and his divine charioteer Krishna, it stresses the importance of doing one's duty and of faith in God.

--Word--
bhakti 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Devotional worship directed to one supreme deity, usually Vishnu (especially in his incarnations as Rama and Krishna) or Shiva, by whose grace salvation may be attained by all regardless of sex, caste, or class. It is followed by the majority of Hindus today.

--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city in central India, the capital of the state of Madhya Pradesh; population 1,752,200 (est. 2009). In December 1984 leakage of poisonous gas from an American-owned pesticide factory in the city caused the death of about 2,500 people.

horizon 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The line at which the earth's surface and the sky appear to meet.
The circular boundary of the part of the earth's surface visible from a particular point, ignoring irregularities and obstructions.
A great circle of the celestial sphere, the plane of which passes through the centre of the earth and is parallel to that of the apparent horizon of a place.
The limit of a person's knowledge, experience, or interest.
A layer of soil or rock, or a set of strata, with particular characteristics.
A level of an excavated site representing a particular period.
--Examples--

--Word--
Bhutto, Benazir 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1953–2007), Pakistani stateswoman, prime minister 1988–90 and 1993–6, daughter of Zulfikar Ali Bhutto. She was the first woman prime minister of a Muslim country. Defeated in elections in 1997, she was later charged with corruption offences and banned from public office; the conviction was subsequently overturned. She was assassinated after returning to Pakistan to campaign for re-election.

--Word--
by 
--Type--
preposition, adverb, noun
--Meanings--
Identifying the agent performing an action.
After a passive verb.
After a noun denoting an action.
Identifying the author of a text, idea, or work of art.
Indicating the means of achieving something.
Indicating a term to which an interpretation is to be assigned.
Indicating a name according to which a person is known.
Indicating the means of transport selected for a journey.
Indicating the other parent of someone's child or children.
Indicating the sire of a pedigree animal, especially a horse.
(followed by a noun without a determiner) in various phrases indicating how something happens.
Indicating the amount or size of a margin.
Indicating a quantity or amount.
In phrases indicating something happening repeatedly or progressively, typically with repetition of a unit of time.
Identifying a parameter.
Expressing multiplication, especially in dimensions.
Indicating a deadline or the end of a particular time period.
Indicating location of a physical object beside a place or object.
Past and beyond.
Indicating the period in which something happens.
Concerning; according to.
Used in mild oaths.
So as to go past.
--Examples--
‘the door was opened by my cousin Annie’
‘damage caused by fire’
‘a clear decision by the electorate’
‘years of hard fund-raising work by local people’
‘a book by Ernest Hemingway’
‘malaria can be controlled by attacking the parasite’

‘they plan to provide further working capital by means of borrowing’

‘I travelled to Folkestone by rail’

‘a black filly by Goldfuerst’

‘the shot missed her by miles’

‘billing is by the minute’
‘the drunken yobbos who turned up by the cartload’
‘colours changing minute by minute’
‘the risk becomes worse by the day’

‘by now Kelly needed extensive physiotherapy’

‘the pram was by the dresser’
‘I drove by our house’
‘this animal always hunts by night’

‘a car flashed by on the other side of the road’
‘he let only a moment go by’

--Word--
Biafra 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A state that was proclaimed in 1967 when part of south-eastern Nigeria, inhabited chiefly by the Igbo people, sought independence from the rest of the country. In the ensuing civil war the new state's troops were overwhelmed by numerically superior forces, and by 1970 it had ceased to exist.

bias 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
Inclination or prejudice for or against one person or group, especially in a way considered to be unfair.
A concentration on or interest in one particular area or subject.
A systematic distortion of a statistical result due to a factor not allowed for in its derivation.
A direction diagonal to the weave of a fabric.
(in bowls) the irregular shape given to one side of a bowl.
The oblique course taken by a bowl as a result of its irregular shape.
A steady voltage, magnetic field, or other factor applied to a system or device to cause it to operate over a predetermined range.
Cause to feel or show inclination or prejudice for or against someone or something.
Give a bias to.
--Examples--
‘there was evidence of bias against foreign applicants’
‘the bias towards younger people in recruitment’
‘his work showed a discernible bias towards philosophy’
‘a turquoise silk dress cut on the bias’
‘readers said the paper was biased towards the Conservatives’
‘editors were biased against authors from provincial universities’
‘bias the valve so that the anode current is normally zero or small’

bid 
--Type--
verb, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Offer (a certain price) for something, especially at an auction.
(of a contractor) offer to do (work) for a stated price; tender for.
Make a statement during the auction undertaking to make (a certain number of tricks with a stated suit as trumps) if the bid is successful and one becomes the declarer.
Make an effort or attempt to achieve.
An offer of a price, especially at an auction.
An offer to buy the shares of a company in order to gain control of it.
An offer to do work or supply goods at a stated price; a tender.
An undertaking by a player in the auction to make a stated number of tricks with a stated suit as trumps.
An attempt or effort to achieve something.
Utter (a greeting or farewell) to.
Command or order (someone) to do something.
Invite (someone) to do something.
--Examples--
‘a consortium of dealers bid a world record price for a snuff box’
‘guests will bid for pieces of fine jewellery’
‘nineteen companies have indicated their intention to bid for the contract’
‘North bids four hearts’
‘she's now bidding to become a top female model’
‘the two forwards are bidding for places in the England side’
‘at the fur tables, several buyers make bids for the pelts’
‘a takeover bid’
‘a number of businessmen were keen to make a bid for the £75 million contract’
‘a bid of three spades’
‘he made a bid for power in 1984’
‘an investigation would be carried out in a bid to establish what had happened’

‘I did as he bade me’

--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
bibl. 
--Type--
abbreviation
--Meanings--
Biblical.
--Examples--
--Word--
Bible 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The Christian scriptures, consisting of the Old and New Testaments.
The Jewish scriptures, consisting of the Torah or Law, the Prophets, and the Hagiographa or Writings.
A copy of the Christian or Jewish scriptures.
A book regarded as authoritative in a particular sphere.
--Examples--
‘verses from the Bible’
‘Bible stories’
‘Bible study’
‘clutching a large black Bible under his arm’
‘the New English Bible’
‘a brand-new edition of this filmgoers' bible’
--Word--
Bible-basher 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who expounds or follows the teachings of the Bible in an aggressively evangelical way.
--Examples--
--Word--

noun

biblicism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
biblical 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or contained in the Bible.
Resembling the language or style of the Bible.
Very great; on a very large scale.
--Examples--
‘the biblical account of creation’
‘biblical times’
‘there is a biblical cadence in the last words he utters’
‘we need rainfall of biblical proportions to bring us back to normal’
--Word--
biblicism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
biblically 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In a way that accords with or relates to the Bible.
To a great extent.
--Examples--
‘a biblically grounded objection’
‘teach them to think biblically’
‘a biblically idiotic haircut’

--Word--
bibliography 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A list of the books referred to in a scholarly work, typically printed as an appendix.
A list of the books of a specific author or publisher, or on a specific subject.
The history or systematic description of books, their authorship, printing, publication, editions, etc.
--Examples--
‘a bibliography of his publications’
--Word--
bibliographic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to bibliography.
--Examples--
‘researchers can now search the bibliographic records’
‘detailed bibliographical references’

--Word--
bibliolater 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who is passionately enthusiastic about books.
A person who interprets the Bible on an extremely literal level.
--Examples--
‘maybe literature doesn't really have the power that bibliolaters like to claim’
‘bibliolaters would point to this passage as an amazing example of prophecy’
--Word--
bibliolatry 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An excessive adherence to the literal interpretation of the Bible.
An excessive love of books.
--Examples--

bibliolatrous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
bibliomancy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The practice of foretelling the future by interpreting a randomly chosen passage from a book, especially the Bible.
--Examples--
--Word--
bibliomane 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person with a passionate enthusiasm for collecting and possessing books.

‘aren't bibliomanes supposed to collect books indiscriminately and wantonly?’

Bibliothèque nationale 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
Byblos 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An ancient Mediterranean seaport, situated on the site of modern Jebeil, to the north of Beirut in Lebanon. It became a thriving Phoenician city in the 2nd millennium BC.
--Examples--
--Word--
by-blow 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A side-blow not at the main target.
A man's illegitimate child.
--Examples--
‘he was, he declared, a by-blow of the prince’
--Word--
boat 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A small vessel for travelling over water, propelled by oars, sails, or an engine.
A vessel of any size, especially a large one.
A serving dish in the shape of a boat.
Travel in a boat for pleasure.
Transport (someone or something) in a boat.
(of an angler) draw (a hooked fish) into a boat.
--Examples--
‘a fishing boat’
‘a boat trip’
‘those newly arriving here by boat or plane’
‘a gravy boat’
‘they boated through fjords’
‘she likes to go boating’
‘they boated the timber down the lake’
‘he boated a 2 lb 14oz Dover sole’
--Word--
bib 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A piece of cloth or plastic fastened round a child's neck to keep its clothes clean while eating.
A loose-fitting sleeveless garment worn on the upper body for identification, especially by competitors and officials at sporting events.
The part above the waist of the front of an apron or pair of dungarees.
A patch of colour on the throat of a bird or other animal.
A common European inshore fish of the cod family.
--Examples--
‘the sponsor's name printed on our bibs’
‘a black bird with a white bib’

--Word--
biceps 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of several muscles having two points of attachment at one end.
A large muscle in the upper arm which turns the hand to face palm uppermost and flexes the arm and forearm.
A muscle in the back of the thigh which helps to flex the leg.
--Examples--
‘he clenched his fist and exhibited his bulging biceps’
--Word--
biceps 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of several muscles having two points of attachment at one end.
A large muscle in the upper arm which turns the hand to face palm uppermost and flexes the arm and forearm.
A muscle in the back of the thigh which helps to flex the leg.
--Examples--
‘he clenched his fist and exhibited his bulging biceps’

--Word--
channel 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A length of water wider than a strait, joining two larger areas of water, especially two seas.
The English Channel.
A navigable passage in a stretch of water otherwise unsafe for vessels.
A hollow bed for a natural or artificial waterway.
A band of frequencies used in radio and television transmission, especially as used by a particular station.
A service or station using a channel of frequencies.
A method or system for communication or distribution.
An electric circuit which acts as a path for a signal.
The semiconductor region in a field-effect transistor that forms the main current path between the source and the drain.
A tubular passage or duct for liquid.
Direct towards a particular end or object.
Cause to pass along or through a specified route or medium.
(of a person) serve as a medium for (a spirit)
Emulate or seem to be inspired by.
Form channels or grooves in.
--Examples--
‘the movement has spread across the Channel’
‘buoys marked the safe limits of the channel’
‘the river is confined in a narrow channel’
‘a new television channel’
‘they didn't apply through the proper channels’
‘some companies have a variety of sales channels’
‘an audio channel’
‘fish eggs have a small channel called the micropyle’
‘the council is to channel public funds into training schemes’
‘many countries channel their aid through charities’
‘she was channelling the spirit of Billie Holiday’
‘Meg Ryan plays Avery as if she's channelling Nicole Kidman’
‘pottery with a distinctive channelled decoration’
--Word--
Beach-la-mar 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
child 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A young human being below the age of puberty or below the legal age of majority.
A son or daughter of any age.
An immature or irresponsible person.
A person who has little or no experience in a particular area.
The descendants of a family or people.
A person regarded as the product of (a specified influence or environment)
--Examples--
‘she'd been playing tennis since she was a child’
‘the film is not suitable for children’
‘when children leave home, parents can feel somewhat redundant’
‘she's such a child!’
‘he's a child in financial matters’
‘the children of Abraham’
‘a child of the Sixties’
--Word--
bichir 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An elongated African freshwater fish with an armour of hard shiny scales and a series of separate fins along its back.
--Examples--
--Word--
chop 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Cut (something) into pieces with repeated sharp blows of an axe or knife.
Remove something by cutting.
Cut through the base of (a tree or similar plant) with blows from an axe or other implement, in order to fell it.
Strike (something) with a short heavy blow, as if cutting at something.
Abolish or reduce the size of (something) in a way regarded as ruthless.
A downward cutting blow or movement, typically with the hand.
A thick slice of meat, especially pork or lamb, adjacent to and often including a rib.
A person's share of something.
Crushed or ground grain used as animal feed.
The broken motion of water, owing to the action of the wind against the tide.
--Examples--
‘they chopped up the pulpit for firewood’
‘finely chop the parsley’
‘they chopped off all her hair’
‘the boy chopped down eight trees’
‘Benson chopped the ball on to the stumps’
‘their training courses are to be chopped’
‘an effective chop to the back of the neck’
‘he lived on liver or chops’
‘the pile of chop was dropped into the calves' feeder’
‘we started our run into a two-foot chop’

bicycle 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A vehicle consisting of two wheels held in a frame one behind the other, propelled by pedals and steered with handlebars attached to the front wheel.
Ride a bicycle.
--Examples--
‘they spent the holidays bicycling around the beautiful Devonshire countryside’

--Word--
bicker 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Argue about petty and trivial matters.
(of water) flow or fall with a gentle repetitive noise; patter.
(of a flame or light) flash, gleam, or flicker.
--Examples--
‘couples who bicker over who gets what from the divorce’
‘against the glass the rain did beat and bicker’
‘the restless wheels whose flashing spokes bicker and burn’

--Word--
iron 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A strong, hard magnetic silvery-grey metal, the chemical element of atomic number 26, much used as a material for construction and manufacturing, especially in the form of steel.
Used figuratively as a symbol or type of firmness, strength, or resistance.
A tool or implement now or originally made of iron.
Metal supports for a malformed leg.
Fetters or handcuffs.
Stirrups.
A handheld implement, typically an electrical one, with a heated flat steel base, used to smooth clothes, sheets, etc.
A golf club with a metal head (typically with a numeral indicating the degree to which the head is angled in order to loft the ball)
A shot made with an iron.
A meteorite containing a high proportion of iron.
Smooth (clothes, sheets, etc.) with an iron.
--Examples--
‘her father had a will of iron’
‘the iron grip of the president on every aspect of foreign policy’
‘a caulking iron’
‘a four-iron’
‘his long irons were majestic’
--Word--
bicker 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Argue about petty and trivial matters.
(of water) flow or fall with a gentle repetitive noise; patter.
(of a flame or light) flash, gleam, or flicker.
--Examples--
‘couples who bicker over who gets what from the divorce’
‘against the glass the rain did beat and bicker’
‘the restless wheels whose flashing spokes bicker and burn’

--Word--
iron 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A strong, hard magnetic silvery-grey metal, the chemical element of atomic number 26, much used as a material for construction and manufacturing, especially in the form of steel.
Used figuratively as a symbol or type of firmness, strength, or resistance.
A tool or implement now or originally made of iron.
Metal supports for a malformed leg.
Fetters or handcuffs.
Stirrups.
A handheld implement, typically an electrical one, with a heated flat steel base, used to smooth clothes, sheets, etc.
A golf club with a metal head (typically with a numeral indicating the degree to which the head is angled in order to loft the ball)
A shot made with an iron.
A meteorite containing a high proportion of iron.
Smooth (clothes, sheets, etc.) with an iron.
--Examples--
‘her father had a will of iron’
‘the iron grip of the president on every aspect of foreign policy’
‘a caulking iron’
‘a four-iron’
‘his long irons were majestic’
--Word--
cock 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A male bird, especially of a domestic fowl.
Used in names of birds, especially game birds, e.g. watercock.
A male lobster, crab, or salmon.
A friendly form of address among men.
A man's penis.
Nonsense.
A firing lever in a gun which can be raised to be released by the trigger.
A stopcock.
Tilt (something) in a particular direction.
Bend a (limb or joint) at an angle.
(of a male dog) lift (a back leg) in order to urinate.
Raise the cock of (a gun) in order to make it ready for firing.
Ruin something as a result of incompetence or inefficiency.
--Examples--
‘the biggest salmon I ever had was a 45 lb cock’
‘please yourself, cock’
‘that's all a lot of cock’
‘she cocked her head slightly to one side’
‘Madge threw herself into the armchair and cocked her legs over the side’
‘a greyhound cocked its leg against the tree’
‘he took the loaded pistol from his belt and cocked it’
‘the party cocked up the Euro-elections’
--Word--
bicker 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Argue about petty and trivial matters.
(of water) flow or fall with a gentle repetitive noise; patter.
(of a flame or light) flash, gleam, or flicker.
--Examples--
‘couples who bicker over who gets what from the divorce’
‘against the glass the rain did beat and bicker’
‘the restless wheels whose flashing spokes bicker and burn’

--Word--
iron 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A strong, hard magnetic silvery-grey metal, the chemical element of atomic number 26, much used as a material for construction and manufacturing, especially in the form of steel.
Used figuratively as a symbol or type of firmness, strength, or resistance.
A tool or implement now or originally made of iron.
Metal supports for a malformed leg.
Fetters or handcuffs.
Stirrups.
A handheld implement, typically an electrical one, with a heated flat steel base, used to smooth clothes, sheets, etc.
A golf club with a metal head (typically with a numeral indicating the degree to which the head is angled in order to loft the ball)
A shot made with an iron.
A meteorite containing a high proportion of iron.
Smooth (clothes, sheets, etc.) with an iron.
--Examples--
‘her father had a will of iron’
‘the iron grip of the president on every aspect of foreign policy’
‘a caulking iron’
‘a four-iron’
‘his long irons were majestic’

--Word--
corner 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A place or angle where two sides or edges meet.
The area inside a room or other space near the place where two walls or other surfaces meet.
A place where two or more streets meet.
A sharp bend in a road.
A place where two planes of rock meet at an angle of between 60° and 120°.
A location or area, especially one regarded as secluded or remote.
A position in which one dominates the supply of a particular commodity.
A difficult or awkward situation.
A place kick taken by the attacking side from a corner of the field after the ball has been sent over the byline by a defender.
A free hit in field hockey, taken from the corner of the field.
Each of the diagonally opposite ends of the ring, where a contestant rests between rounds.
A contestant's supporters or seconds.
A triangular cut from the hind end of a side of bacon.
Force (a person or animal) into a place or situation from which it is hard to escape.
Detain (someone) in conversation.
Control (a market) by dominating the supply of a particular commodity.
Establish a corner in (a commodity)
(of a vehicle or driver) go round a bend in a road.
--Examples--
‘Jan sat at one corner of the table’
‘the colour TV in the corner of the room’
‘the huge bookshop on the corner’
‘they took the corner in a skidding turn’
‘fountains are discovered in quiet corners and sleepy squares’
‘dance professionals from all corners of the globe attended the five-day festival’
‘she couldn't bear journalists prying into every corner of her life’
‘London doesn't have a corner on film festivals’
‘I didn't wait for the prosecutor to try to get me in a corner’
‘he put a corner kick deep into the heart of the Southampton penalty area’
‘when the bell sounded he turned to go back to his corner’
‘Hodkinson was encouraged by his corner’
‘the man was eventually cornered by police dogs’
‘I managed to corner Gary for fifteen minutes’
‘whether they will corner the market in graphics software remains to be seen’
‘you cornered vanadium and made a killing’
‘no squeal is evident from the tyres when cornering fast’

--Word--
bid 
--Type--
verb, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Offer (a certain price) for something, especially at an auction.
(of a contractor) offer to do (work) for a stated price; tender for.
Make a statement during the auction undertaking to make (a certain number of tricks with a stated suit as trumps) if the bid is successful and one becomes the declarer.
Make an effort or attempt to achieve.
An offer of a price, especially at an auction.
An offer to buy the shares of a company in order to gain control of it.
An offer to do work or supply goods at a stated price; a tender.
An undertaking by a player in the auction to make a stated number of tricks with a stated suit as trumps.
An attempt or effort to achieve something.
Utter (a greeting or farewell) to.
Command or order (someone) to do something.
Invite (someone) to do something.
--Examples--
‘a consortium of dealers bid a world record price for a snuff box’
‘guests will bid for pieces of fine jewellery’
‘nineteen companies have indicated their intention to bid for the contract’
‘North bids four hearts’
‘she's now bidding to become a top female model’
‘the two forwards are bidding for places in the England side’
‘at the fur tables, several buyers make bids for the pelts’
‘a takeover bid’
‘a number of businessmen were keen to make a bid for the £75 million contract’
‘a bid of three spades’
‘he made a bid for power in 1984’
‘an investigation would be carried out in a bid to establish what had happened’
‘James bade a tearful farewell to his parents’
‘I did as he bade me’
‘he bade his companions enter’

effect 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A change which is a result or consequence of an action or other cause.
The state of being or becoming operative.
The extent to which something succeeds or is operative.
A physical phenomenon, typically named after its discoverer.
An impression produced in the mind of a person.
The lighting, sound, or scenery used in a play, film, or broadcast.
Personal belongings.
Cause (something) to happen; bring about.
--Examples--
‘the lethal effects of hard drugs’
‘politicians have some effect on the lives of ordinary people’
‘wind power can be used to great effect’
‘the Renner effect’
‘gentle music can have a soothing effect’
‘the production relied too much on spectacular effects’
‘the insurance covers personal effects’
‘the prime minister effected many policy changes’

Conventional or orthodox in attitude.
A conventional or orthodox person.
--Examples--

--Word--
biennial 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Taking place every other year.
(of a plant) taking two years to grow from seed to fruition and die.
A biennial plant.
An event celebrated or taking place every two years.
--Examples--
‘the first of a series of biennial exhibitions’
‘the top antiques fairs are the Milan and Florence biennials’
--Word--
biennially 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
--Examples--

bier 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A movable frame on which a coffin or a corpse is placed before burial or cremation or on which they are carried to the grave.
--Examples--
--Word--
Bierce, Ambrose 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1842–c.1914), American writer, best known for his sardonic short stories and The Devil's Dictionary (1911); full name Ambrose Gwinnett Bierce. In 1913 he travelled to Mexico and mysteriously disappeared.
--Examples--
--Word--
bierkeller 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A bar or pub in Austria or Germany, especially one in a basement.
--Examples--
‘Munich's bierkellers were quite the splendid place to spend a day’

--Word--
bye 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The transfer of a competitor directly to the next round of a competition in the absence of an assigned opponent.
A run scored from a ball that passes the batsman without being hit (recorded as an extra, not credited to the individual batsman).
One or more holes remaining unplayed after a match has been decided.
--Examples--
‘he has a bye into the second round’

--Word--
bifacial 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having two faces, surfaces, or sides.
(of a leaf) having upper and lower surfaces that are structurally different.
(of a flint or other artefact) worked on both faces.
--Examples--
‘bifacial solar panels’
--Word--
fellow 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A man or boy.
A person in the same position, involved in the same activity, or otherwise associated with another.
A thing of the same kind as or otherwise associated with another.
A member of a learned society.
An incorporated senior member of a college.
An elected graduate receiving a stipend for a period of research.
A member of the governing body in some universities.
Sharing a particular activity, quality, or condition with someone or something.
--Examples--
‘he was an extremely obliging fellow’
‘he was learning with a rapidity unique among his fellows’
‘the page has been torn away from its fellows’
‘a fellow of the Geological Society’
‘a tutorial fellow’
‘they urged the troops not to fire on their fellow citizens’
--Word--
fellowship 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Friendly association, especially with people who share one's interests.
A group of people meeting to pursue a shared interest or aim.
A guild or corporation.
The status of a fellow of a college or society.
--Examples--
‘they valued fun and good fellowship as the cement of the community’
‘a fellowship in mathematics’

--Word--
big 
--Type--
adjective, verb, noun
--Meanings--
Of considerable size or extent.
Larger than other items of the same kind.
Grown-up.
Elder.
On an ambitiously large scale.
Doing a specified action very often or on a very large scale.
Showing great enthusiasm.
Of considerable importance or seriousness.
Very popular or successful.
Holding an important position or playing an influential role.
Generous.
Praise or recommend something highly.
The major league in a professional sport.
--Examples--
‘her big hazel eyes’
‘big buildings’
‘big staff cuts’
‘my big toe’
‘I'm a big girl now’
‘my big sister’
‘a small company with big plans’
‘a big eater’
‘a big gambler’
‘a big tennis fan’
‘it's a big decision’
‘his biggest problem is money’
‘he made a big mistake’
‘African bands which are big in Britain’
‘as a senior in college, he was a big man on campus’
‘‘I'm inclined to take pity on you.’ ‘That's big of you!’’
‘the record's been on the streets a while now, but it's still worth bigging up’
‘the day he made it to the bigs, he forgot every minor league ballpark he ever played in’

--Word--
bigarade 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
More fully "bigarade orange". The Seville orange, a variety of the sour orange, Citrus aurantium.
Attributive and as postpositive. Designating a sauce made with bigarade oranges, and dishes, especially roast duck, served with this sauce.
--Examples--
--Word--
bigarade 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
More fully "bigarade orange". The Seville orange, a variety of the sour orange, Citrus aurantium.
Attributive and as postpositive. Designating a sauce made with bigarade oranges, and dishes, especially roast duck, served with this sauce.
--Examples--

‘a lion rampant argent, armed and langued azure’
--Word--
bigarreau 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
More fully "bigarreau cherry". Any of a group of cultivated varieties of sweet cherry, Prunus avium (also "bigarreau cherry tree"); the fruit of such trees, which is typically large and heart-shaped with mottled pale and red skin and very firm flesh.
--Examples--

bigeye 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
bigeminate 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Botany. Of a leaf: having a petiole that branches dichotomously, especially with a single pair of leaflets on each secondary petiole; biconjugate. Now rare.
Consisting of or occurring in pairs or two pairs; consisting of two similar parts; (Zoology) (in echinoderms) designating ambulacral pores arranged in two pairs; having such pores.
--Examples--
--Word--
bigeminated 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Medicine. Designating or forming part of a bigeminal rhythm.
--Examples--
--Word--
bigeminy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A cardiac rhythm in which each normal beat is followed by an abnormal one.

--Meanings--

endian 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Denoting or relating to a system of ordering bytes in a word, or bits in a byte, in which the most significant (or least significant) item is put first.
--Examples--
‘big-endian vs. little-endian representation of data’
‘a lot of communications and networking hardware is little-endian’

Bigfoot 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A large, hairy, ape-like creature resembling a yeti, supposedly found in north-western America.
A prominent or well-known journalist.
Dominate or upstage.
--Examples--
‘the media bigfeet who mock him’
‘she was never tempted to bigfoot the project’
‘these moves are early efforts at bigfooting potential challengers’

--Word--
bigg 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A hardy variety of barley grown mainly in northern England and Scotland. [Now considered to be one of the cultivated varieties of Hordeum vulgare subsp. vulgare, this type of barley was previously known as H. tetrastichum because it appears to have four rows of grains in the ear. barley-bigg, Scotch bigg: see the first elements. Recorded earliest in compounds.]
--Examples--
--Word--
rough-gaited

--Meanings--
(Of a horse, etc.) having an uneven gait that jars the rider.
--Examples--

biggit

adjective
--Meanings--

verb
--Meanings--

--Word--
biggity 
--Type--
adjective, adverb
--Meanings--

Rudely; impudently.
--Examples--

‘so that's why you talked to him so biggity’

--Word--
biggin 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
A cap, a hood, especially a nightcap (now historical and rare).
More fully "coffee biggin". A type of coffee pot containing a strainer, through which coffee infuses without mixing with the water.
--Examples--
--Word--
big 
--Type--
adjective, verb, noun
--Meanings--
Of considerable size or extent.
Larger than other items of the same kind.
Grown-up.
Elder.
On an ambitiously large scale.
Doing a specified action very often or on a very large scale.
Showing great enthusiasm.
Of considerable importance or seriousness.
Very popular or successful.
Holding an important position or playing an influential role.
Generous.
Praise or recommend something highly.
The major league in a professional sport.
--Examples--
‘her big hazel eyes’
‘big buildings’
‘big staff cuts’
‘my big toe’
‘I'm a big girl now’
‘my big sister’
‘a small company with big plans’
‘a big eater’
‘a big gambler’
‘a big tennis fan’

‘his biggest problem is money’
‘he made a big mistake’

--Word--
bigg 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A hardy variety of barley grown mainly in northern England and Scotland. [Now considered to be one of the cultivated varieties of Hordeum vulgare subsp. vulgare, this type of barley was previously known as H. tetrastichum because it appears to have four rows of grains in the ear. barley-bigg, Scotch bigg: see the first elements. Recorded earliest in compounds.]
--Examples--

--Word--
bignonia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of numerous plants of the genus Bignonia or family Bignoniaceae, comprising mainly tropical and subtropical American trees, shrubs, and lianes; especially any of those popular in cultivation for their brightly coloured, trumpet-shaped flowers. Also (in form Bignonia): the genus itself.
--Examples--
--Word--
bignoniaceous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Belonging to or characteristic of the family Bignoniaceae of dicotyledonous plants (comprising mainly tropical and subtropical American lianes, trees, and shrubs), of which Bignonia is the type genus.
--Examples--
--Word--
bignonia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of numerous plants of the genus Bignonia or family Bignoniaceae, comprising mainly tropical and subtropical American trees, shrubs, and lianes; especially any of those popular in cultivation for their brightly coloured, trumpet-shaped flowers. Also (in form Bignonia): the genus itself.

gold 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A yellow precious metal, the chemical element of atomic number 79, used especially in jewellery and decoration and to guarantee the value of currencies.
An alloy of gold.
A deep lustrous yellow or yellow-brown colour.
Coins or other articles made of gold.
Money in large sums; wealth.
Something considered to be precious, beautiful, or of the most superior quality.
The bullseye of an archery target.

--Word--
hour 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A period of time equal to a twenty-fourth part of a day and night and divided into 60 minutes.
A more indefinite period of time.
The distance travelled in one hour.
A time of day specified as an exact number of hours from midnight or midday.
A time specified on the twenty-four-hour clock.
The time as formerly reckoned from sunrise.
A fixed period of time for an activity, such as work, use of a building, etc.
A particular point in time.
(in the Western (Latin) Church) a short service of psalms and prayers to be said at a particular time of day, especially in religious communities.
15° of longitude or right ascension (one twenty-fourth part of a circle).
--Examples--
‘an extra hour of daylight in the winter evenings’
‘rates of pay were low, starting at £3.20 an hour’
‘a two-hour operation’
‘during the early hours of the morning’
‘Ocean City is less than an hour away’
‘the clock in the sitting room struck the hour’
‘the first bomb fell at 0051 hours’
‘it was about the ninth hour’
‘the dinner hour’
‘licensing hours’
‘opening hours’
‘I wondered if my last hour had come’
‘you can't turn him away at this hour’
‘an organized life of prayer including the canonical hours’

noun, verb
--Meanings--
The feeling of wanting to know or learn about something or someone.
The quality of exciting curiosity or holding the attention.
An activity or subject which one enjoys doing or studying.
Money paid regularly at a particular rate for the use of money lent, or for delaying the repayment of a debt.
The advantage or benefit of a person or group.
The selfish pursuit of one's own welfare; self-interest.
A stake or involvement in an undertaking, especially a financial one.
A legal concern, title, or right in property.
A group or organization having a common concern, especially in politics or business.
Excite the curiosity or attention of (someone)
Persuade someone to undertake or acquire (something)
--Examples--
‘she looked about her with interest’
‘he developed an interest in art’
‘a tale full of interest’
‘their sole interests are soccer, drink, and cars’

noun, verb
--Meanings--

Problems or difficulties, especially with a service or facility.

‘the minister issued a statement’
‘exotic smells issued from a nearby building’
‘the struggles of history issue from the divided heart of humanity’
--Word--
bijection 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A mapping that is both one-to-one (an injection) and onto (a surjection), i.e. a function which relates each member of a set S (the domain) to a separate and distinct member of another set T (the range), where each member in T also has a corresponding member in S.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Word--
job 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A paid position of regular employment.
A task or piece of work, especially one that is paid.
A responsibility or duty.
A difficult task.
A procedure to improve the appearance of something.
A crime, especially a robbery.
An operation or group of operations treated as a single and distinct unit.
A thing of a specified kind.
Do casual or occasional work.
Buy and sell (stocks) as a broker-dealer, especially on a small scale.
Cheat; betray.
Turn a public office or a position of trust to private advantage.
--Examples--
‘the scheme could create 200 jobs’
‘a part-time job’
‘she wants to be left alone to get on with the job’
‘it's our job to find things out’
‘we thought you'd have a job getting there’
‘someone had done a skilful paint job’
‘a series of daring bank jobs’
‘this feature allows your computer to queue print jobs’
‘the oven is one of those fancy-pants jobs with a convection fan’
‘a jobbing builder’
‘his game plan is to buy in then job the shares on at a profit’
‘he was jobbed by the Justice Department’
‘if left unfettered he would job’

--Word--
biker 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A motorcyclist, especially one who is a member of a gang or group.
A cyclist.
--Examples--

‘a mountain biker’
--Word--
bike 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A bicycle or motorcycle.
Ride a bicycle or motorcycle.
Cause (a letter or package) to be delivered by bicycle or motorcycle.
--Examples--
‘my friends and I would ride our bikes’
‘I'm going by bike’
‘a bike ride’
‘Danny bikes to the park and back every day’
‘I'll get them to bike the scripts over’

--Word--
bilayer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A film two molecules thick (formed e.g. by lipids), in which each molecule is arranged with its hydrophobic end directed inwards towards the opposite side of the film and its hydrophilic end directed outwards.
--Examples--
--Word--
bilayer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A film two molecules thick (formed e.g. by lipids), in which each molecule is arranged with its hydrophobic end directed inwards towards the opposite side of the film and its hydrophilic end directed outwards.

--Word--
lane 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A narrow road, especially in a rural area.
An urban street.
A division of a road marked off with painted lines and intended to separate single lines of traffic according to speed or direction.
Each of a number of parallel strips of track or water for runners, rowers, or swimmers in a race.
A route prescribed for or regularly followed by ships or aircraft.
(in tenpin bowling) a long, narrow strip of floor down which the ball is bowled.
Each of a number of notional parallel strips in the gel of an electrophoresis plate, occupied by a single sample.
A dark streak or band which shows up against a bright background, especially in a spiral galaxy.
--Examples--
‘she drove along the winding lane’
‘Park Lane’
‘the car moved into the outside lane’
‘a bus lane’
‘she went into the final in lane three’
‘the shipping lanes of the South Atlantic’
‘a maximum of six people can play on a lane at any one time’
‘DNA from various sources is placed in separate lanes on an electrophoretic gel’
‘the innermost dust lane is dense enough to absorb some infrared’

--Word--
bilge 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The area on the outer surface of a ship's hull where the bottom curves to meet the vertical sides.
The lowest internal portion of the hull.
Dirty water that collects inside the bilges.
Nonsense; rubbish.
Break a hole in the bilge of (a ship).
--Examples--
‘romantic bilge dreamed up by journalists’

--Word--
bilge keel 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Each of a pair of plates or timbers fastened under the sides of the hull of a ship to provide lateral resistance to the water, prevent rolling, and support its weight in dry dock.

--Word--
bill 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A printed or written statement of the money owed for goods or services.
A draft of a proposed law presented to parliament for discussion.
A programme of entertainment at a theatre or cinema.
A banknote.
A poster or handbill.
List (a person or event) in a programme.
Describe or advertise someone or something in a particular way.
Send a bill to (someone)
Charge (a sum of money)
--Examples--
‘the bill for their meal came to £17’
‘a debate over the civil rights bill’
‘she was top of the bill at America's leading vaudeville house’
‘a ten-dollar bill’
‘he has been hard at work bill posting in a poster and sticker campaign’
‘they were billed to appear but did not show up’
‘he was billed as ‘the new Sean Connery’’
‘we shall be billing them for the damage caused’
‘he had been billed £3,000 for his licence’
‘we billed £400,000’

--Word--
billet 
--Type--
noun, verb, noun
--Meanings--
A place, especially a civilian's house, where soldiers are lodged temporarily.
A place to stop or stay.
Lodge (soldiers) in a particular place, especially a civilian's house.
Assign temporary accommodation to.
A thick piece of wood.
A small bar of metal for further processing.
Each of a series of short cylindrical pieces inserted at intervals in Norman decorative mouldings.
A rectangle placed vertically as a charge.
--Examples--
‘the sergeant gave them leave to rest while officers went in search of billets’
‘the young people's stay at each of their billets was short’
‘most of the army was billeted within the town’
‘the American team was billeted at Uxbridge’

--Examples--
--Word--
billiards 
--Type--
plural noun
--Meanings--
A game for two people, played on a billiard table, in which three balls are struck with cues into pockets round the edge of the tabl, with points scored by cannons, pocketing an object ball, or cannoning the cue ball into a pocket. In North America the game is known as English billiards.
--Examples--
‘guests can play billiards or table tennis’
‘a billiard ball’
--Word--
billy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A tin or enamel cooking pot with a lid and a wire handle, for use when camping.
--Examples--
‘Roger had our fire going and the billy boiling’

--Word--
Holiday, Billie 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1915–59), American jazz singer; born Eleanora Fagan. She began her recording career with Benny Goodman's band in 1933, going on to perform with many small jazz groups.

billing 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The fact of being advertised or described in a particular way.
The process of preparing or sending invoices.
The total amount of business conducted in a given time, especially that of an advertising agency.
--Examples--

‘he shared top billing with his wife’
‘faster, more accurate order fulfilment and billing’
‘the account was worth about $2 million a year in billings’

Billings

--Meanings--
A commercial city in south central Montana, the state's largest city; population 103,994 (est. 2008).

Billingsgate 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A London fish market dating from the 16th century. In 1982 the market moved to the Isle of Dogs in the East End.

--Word--
billion 
--Type--
cardinal number
--Meanings--
The number equivalent to the product of a thousand and a million; 1,000,000,000 or 10⁹
A very large number or amount of something.
A billion pounds or dollars.
A million million (1,000,000,000,000 or 10¹²).
--Examples--
‘a world population of nearly 5 billion’
‘half a billion dollars’
‘our immune systems are killing billions of germs right now’
‘the problem persists despite the billions spent on it’

--Word--
billionth 
--Type--
ordinal number
--Meanings--
Constituting number one billion in a sequence; 1,000,000,000th.
Constituting an unspecified but very large number in a sequence.
Each of one billion equal parts into which something is or may be divided.
--Examples--
‘the birth of India's billionth citizen’
‘I was late again for the billionth time’
‘particles so small they're measured in billionths of a metre’

--Word--
bill 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A printed or written statement of the money owed for goods or services.
A draft of a proposed law presented to parliament for discussion.
A programme of entertainment at a theatre or cinema.
A banknote.
A poster or handbill.
List (a person or event) in a programme.
Describe or advertise someone or something in a particular way.
Send a bill to (someone)
Charge (a sum of money)
--Examples--
‘the bill for their meal came to £17’
‘a debate over the civil rights bill’
‘she was top of the bill at America's leading vaudeville house’
‘a ten-dollar bill’
‘he has been hard at work bill posting in a poster and sticker campaign’
‘they were billed to appear but did not show up’
‘he was billed as ‘the new Sean Connery’’
‘we shall be billing them for the damage caused’
‘he had been billed £3,000 for his licence’
‘we billed £400,000’

billon

billow 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A large undulating mass of something, typically cloud, smoke, or steam.
A large sea wave.

(of smoke, cloud, or steam) move or flow outward with an undulating motion.
--Examples--
‘her dress billowed out around her’
‘smoke was billowing from the chimney’

--Word--
matter 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
Physical substance in general, as distinct from mind and spirit; (in physics) that which occupies space and possesses rest mass, especially as distinct from energy.
A particular substance.
Written or printed material.
A subject or situation under consideration.
Something which is to be tried or proved in court; a case.
The present state of affairs.
The reason for distress or a problem.
The substance or content of a text as distinct from its style or form.
The body of a printed work, as distinct from titles, headings, etc.
The particular content of a proposition, as distinct from its form.
Be important or significant.
(of a person) be important or influential.
(of a wound) secrete or discharge pus.
--Examples--
‘the structure and properties of matter’
‘organic matter’
‘faecal matter’
‘reading matter’
‘a great deal of work was done on this matter’
‘financial matters’
‘we can do nothing to change matters’
‘what's the matter?’
‘it doesn't matter what the guests wear’
‘what did it matter to them?’
‘she was trying to get known by the people who matter’

bimedialism

noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
bin 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A receptacle in which to deposit rubbish.
A capacious receptacle for storing a specified substance.
A partitioned stand for storing bottles of wine.
Each of a series of ranges of numerical value into which data are sorted in statistical analysis.
Throw (something) away by putting it in a bin.
Discard or reject.
End a relationship with someone.
Store (something, especially wine) in a bin.
Group together (data) in bins.
--Examples--
‘a compost bin’
‘piles of junk that should have been binned years ago’
‘the whole idea had to be binned’
‘she was a bit weird so I binned her off’
‘paint on the bottles indicated which way up they should be binned’

--Examples--
--Word--
bind 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Tie or fasten (something) tightly together.
Restrain (someone) by tying their hands and feet.
Wrap (something) tightly.
Bandage (a wound)
(of an object) be encircled by something, typically metal bands, so as to have greater strength.
Stick together or cause to stick together in a single mass.
Cause (painting pigments) to form a smooth medium by mixing them with oil.
Hold by chemical bonding.
Combine with (a substance) through chemical bonding.
(of a food or medicine) make (someone) constipated.
Cause (people) to feel united.
Cause someone to feel strongly attached to (a person or place)
Impose a legal or contractual obligation on.
Indenture (someone) as an apprentice.
Make a contractual or enforceable undertaking.
(of a court of law) require (someone) to fulfil an obligation, typically by paying a sum of money as surety.
Be hampered or constrained by.
Fix together and enclose (the pages of a book) in a cover.
Trim (the edge of a piece of material) with a decorative strip.
(of a quantifier) be applied to (a given variable) so that the variable falls within its scope. For example, in an expression of the form ‘For every x, if x is a dog, x is an animal’, the universal quantifier is binding the variable x.
(of a rule or set of grammatical conditions) determine the relationship between (coreferential noun phrases).
A problematical situation.
A nuisance.
A statutory constraint.
bind off
Cast off in knitting.
--Examples--
‘logs bound together with ropes’
‘they bound her hands and feet’
‘the raider then bound and gagged Mr Glenn’
‘her hair was bound up in a towel’
‘Shelley cleaned the wound and bound it up with a clean dressing’
‘an ancient oak chest bound with brass braces’
‘mix the flour with the coconut and enough egg white to bind them’
‘a protein in a form that can bind DNA’
‘these proteins have been reported to bind to calmodulin’
‘the comradeship that had bound such a disparate bunch of lads together’
‘touches like that had bound men to him for life’
‘a party who signs a document will normally be bound by its terms’
‘he was bound apprentice at the age of sixteen’
‘the government cannot bind itself as to the form of subsequent legislation’
‘he was bound over to keep the peace by magistrates’
‘Sarah did not want to be bound by a rigid timetable’
‘a small, fat volume, bound in red morocco’
‘a frill with the edges bound in a contrasting colour’
‘he is in a bind that gets worse with every passing minute’
‘the travelling can be a bit of a bind’
‘I know being disturbed on Christmas Day is a bind’
‘the moral bind of the law’

bind 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Tie or fasten (something) tightly together.

Be hampered or constrained by.
Fix together and enclose (the pages of a book) in a cover.

(of a quantifier) be applied to (a given variable) so that the variable falls within its scope. For example, in an expression of the form ‘For every x, if x is a dog, x is an animal’, the universal quantifier is binding the variable x.

A nuisance.

‘the travelling can be a bit of a bind’
‘I know being disturbed on Christmas Day is a bind’

--Word--
bind 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Tie or fasten (something) tightly together.
Restrain (someone) by tying their hands and feet.
Wrap (something) tightly.
Bandage (a wound)
(of an object) be encircled by something, typically metal bands, so as to have greater strength.
Stick together or cause to stick together in a single mass.
Cause (painting pigments) to form a smooth medium by mixing them with oil.
Hold by chemical bonding.
Combine with (a substance) through chemical bonding.
(of a food or medicine) make (someone) constipated.
Cause (people) to feel united.
Cause someone to feel strongly attached to (a person or place)
Impose a legal or contractual obligation on.
Indenture (someone) as an apprentice.
Make a contractual or enforceable undertaking.
(of a court of law) require (someone) to fulfil an obligation, typically by paying a sum of money as surety.
Be hampered or constrained by.
Fix together and enclose (the pages of a book) in a cover.
Trim (the edge of a piece of material) with a decorative strip.
(of a quantifier) be applied to (a given variable) so that the variable falls within its scope. For example, in an expression of the form ‘For every x, if x is a dog, x is an animal’, the universal quantifier is binding the variable x.
(of a rule or set of grammatical conditions) determine the relationship between (coreferential noun phrases).
A problematical situation.
A nuisance.
A statutory constraint.
bind off
Cast off in knitting.
--Examples--
‘logs bound together with ropes’
‘they bound her hands and feet’
‘the raider then bound and gagged Mr Glenn’
‘her hair was bound up in a towel’
‘Shelley cleaned the wound and bound it up with a clean dressing’
‘an ancient oak chest bound with brass braces’
‘mix the flour with the coconut and enough egg white to bind them’
‘a protein in a form that can bind DNA’
‘these proteins have been reported to bind to calmodulin’
‘the comradeship that had bound such a disparate bunch of lads together’
‘touches like that had bound men to him for life’
‘a party who signs a document will normally be bound by its terms’
‘he was bound apprentice at the age of sixteen’
‘the government cannot bind itself as to the form of subsequent legislation’
‘he was bound over to keep the peace by magistrates’
‘Sarah did not want to be bound by a rigid timetable’
‘a small, fat volume, bound in red morocco’
‘a frill with the edges bound in a contrasting colour’
‘he is in a bind that gets worse with every passing minute’
‘the travelling can be a bit of a bind’
‘I know being disturbed on Christmas Day is a bind’
‘the moral bind of the law’
--Word--
binder 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A cover for holding magazines or loose sheets of paper together.
A substance used to make other substances or materials stick or mix together.
A reaping machine that binds grain into sheaves.
A bookbinder.
--Examples--

bindery 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A workshop or factory in which books are bound.

--Meanings--

bindi 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A decorative mark worn in the middle of the forehead by Indian women, especially Hindus.
--Examples--
--Word--
bindi-eye 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small perennial Australian plant of the daisy family, with a spiky fruit similar to a burr.
--Examples--
--Word--
binding 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A strong covering holding the pages of a book together.
Fabric cut or woven in a strip, used for binding the edges of a piece of material.
A mechanical device fixed to a ski to grip a ski boot, especially either of a pair used for downhill skiing which hold the toe and heel of the boot and release it automatically in a fall.
The action of fastening or holding together, or of being linked by chemical bonds.
(in Chomskyan linguistics) the relationship between a referentially dependent noun (such as a reflexive) and the independent noun phrase which determines its reference.
(of an agreement or promise) involving an obligation that cannot be broken.
--Examples--
‘the binding of antibodies to cell surfaces’
‘business agreements are intended to be legally binding’
--Word--
binding 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A strong covering holding the pages of a book together.
Fabric cut or woven in a strip, used for binding the edges of a piece of material.

The action of fastening or holding together, or of being linked by chemical bonds.
(in Chomskyan linguistics) the relationship between a referentially dependent noun (such as a reflexive) and the independent noun phrase which determines its reference.
(of an agreement or promise) involving an obligation that cannot be broken.
--Examples--
‘the binding of antibodies to cell surfaces’
‘business agreements are intended to be legally binding’

binding

noun, adjective

--Word--
bindweed 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A twining plant with trumpet-shaped flowers, several kinds of which are invasive weeds.
Used in names of twining plants similar to bindweed, e.g. black bindweed.
--Examples--

--Word--
Binet, Alfred 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1857–1911), French psychologist. He devised a mental age scale which described performance in relation to the average performance of students of the same physical age, and with the psychiatrist Théodore Simon (1873–1961) pioneered a system of intelligence tests.
--Examples--
--Word--
bing 
--Type--
noun, exclamation
--Meanings--
A heap, especially of metallic ore or of waste from a mine.
Indicating a sudden action or event.
--Examples--
‘then, bing, the lights went on’
--Word--
binge 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A period of excessive indulgence in an activity, especially drinking alcohol or eating.
Indulge in an activity, especially eating, to excess.
--Examples--
‘he went on a binge and was in no shape to drive’
‘she binged on ice cream’

--Word--
Hildegard of Bingen, St. 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1098–1179), German abbess, scholar, composer, and mystic. A nun of the Benedictine order, she wrote scientific works, poetry, and music, and described her mystical experiences in Scivias.

--Word--
Bingham, George Caleb 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1811–79), US artist. His paintings of the US frontier include The Fur Traders Descending the Missouri (1845), The Trappers Return (1851), and The County Election (1851–52).
--Examples--
--Word--
Binghamton 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An industrial city in south central New York, on the Susquehanna River, near the Pennsylvania border; population 44,729 (est. 2008).

bingo 
--Type--
noun, exclamation
--Meanings--
A game in which players mark off numbers on cards as the numbers are drawn randomly by a caller, the winner being the first person to mark off all their numbers.
A call by someone who wins a game of bingo.
Used to express satisfaction at a sudden positive event or outcome.
--Examples--
‘a bingo hall’
‘Just swipe the pen over a bar code and bingo! The recorder's programmed itself’
