bin 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A receptacle in which to deposit rubbish.
A capacious receptacle for storing a specified substance.
A partitioned stand for storing bottles of wine.
Each of a series of ranges of numerical value into which data are sorted in statistical analysis.
Throw (something) away by putting it in a bin.
Discard or reject.
End a relationship with someone.
Store (something, especially wine) in a bin.
Group together (data) in bins.
--Examples--
‘a compost bin’
‘piles of junk that should have been binned years ago’
‘the whole idea had to be binned’
‘she was a bit weird so I binned her off’
‘paint on the bottles indicated which way up they should be binned’

binomial 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
An algebraic expression of the sum or the difference of two terms.
A two-part name, especially the Latin name of a species of living organism (consisting of the genus followed by the specific epithet).
A noun phrase with two heads joined by a conjunction, in which the order is relatively fixed (as in knife and fork).
Consisting of two terms.
Relating to a binomial or to the binomial theorem.
Having or using two names (used especially of the Latin name of a species of living organism).

--Meanings--

Biological.

‘dogs are used at the airport to sniff out plant and other bio materials’
‘he's never met his bio dad’

bioblast 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

biochemic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to biochemistry; biochemical.

--Word--
biochemistry 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The branch of science concerned with the chemical and physico-chemical processes and substances that occur within living organisms.
The processes and substances with which the science of biochemistry is concerned.
--Examples--
‘abnormal brain biochemistry’

noun

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
biodegradable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a substance or object) capable of being decomposed by bacteria or other living organisms and thereby avoiding pollution.
--Examples--
‘consumers have forced a shift to more biodegradable products’
--Word--
biodegradable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a substance or object) capable of being decomposed by bacteria or other living organisms and thereby avoiding pollution.
--Examples--
‘consumers have forced a shift to more biodegradable products’

bioecology 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The ecology of organisms and their interactions with each other; the branch of science concerned with this.
--Examples--
--Word--
bioecological 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Biology. Of or relating to the ecology of organisms and their interactions with each other.
Psychology. Designating or relating to a model of the development of individual human behaviour and personality which posits that inherited tendencies manifest only as a result of continuing interaction with the environment.

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

biofeedback 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A process whereby electronic monitoring of a normally automatic bodily function is used to train someone to acquire voluntary control of that function.
--Examples--
--Word--
office 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A room, set of rooms, or building used as a place for commercial, professional, or bureaucratic work.
The local centre of a large business.
A room, department, or building used to provide a particular service.
The consulting room of a professional person.
A position of authority or service, typically one of a public nature.
Tenure of an official position, especially that of a Minister of State or of the party forming the government.
The quarters, staff, or collective authority of a particular government department or agency.
A service done for another or others.
A duty attaching to one's position.
The series of services of prayers and psalms said (or chanted) daily by Catholic priests, members of religious orders, and other clergy.
A service conducted daily as part of the office.
The parts of a house given over to household work or to storage.
A toilet.
--Examples--
‘an office job’
‘a company which has four US and four European offices’
‘a ticket office’
‘a Post Office’
‘a patient walks in to a doctor's office’
‘the office of chief constable’
‘a year ago, when the President took office’
‘he was ejected from office in 1988’
‘the Foreign Office’
‘rescued through the good offices of the Italian Ambassador, he was returned safely to England’
‘the offices of a nurse’
‘the noon office’

noun

Any of a group of compounds occurring mainly in citrus fruits and blackcurrants, formerly regarded as vitamins.

noun
--Meanings--
With singular concord. = "recapitulation"; compare "biogenesis". Chiefly in "law of biogenetics"noun = "biogenetic law". Now historical.

--Word--
biograph 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A biography or biographical article; especially a short profile of a public figure. Now rare.
Originally US. An early form of motion-picture camera and projector combined. Compare "bioscope". Now historical.
To write a biography or biographical profile of (a person, especially a historical or public figure); (also) to record (historical information) in a biographical account. Occasionally without object.

--Word--
biokinetics 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Biochemistry. With singular concord. The study of the way in which particular substances move through the body and are metabolized, following ingestion. Also (treated as plural): the properties of a substance in this connection.
With singular concord. The study of the way different parts of the body move in different situations.

--Type--

--Word--
biolith 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: a rock of organic origin; specifically one composed of the remains of living organisms or produced by the activity of such organisms. In later use also: a mineralized particle of animal or plant origin, found in soil, rock, etc.
--Examples--
--Word--
biolytic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Designating the decomposition of organic matter by microbial or enzymic action, especially as part of a sewage treatment process where solids and liquids are treated separately; of or relating to such a treatment process.
--Examples--
--Word--
biology 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The study of living organisms, divided into many specialized fields that cover their morphology, physiology, anatomy, behaviour, origin, and distribution.
The plants and animals of a particular area.
The physiology, behaviour, and other qualities of a particular organism or class of organisms.
--Examples--
‘the biology of the Chesapeake Bay’
‘human biology’
--Word--
biologic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to biology; biological.
--Examples--
‘there is growing interest in the biologic activities of plant extracts in the treatment of disease’
‘these natural biologics can be as potent as manufactured drugs’
--Word--
biological 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to biology or living organisms.
(of a detergent or other cleaning product) containing enzymes to assist the process of cleaning.
Relating to or involving the use of microorganisms or toxins of biological origin as weapons of war.
(of a member of a person's family) genetically related; related by blood.
A substance of biological origin used as a drug, vaccine, pesticide, etc.
--Examples--
‘his biological mother’
‘a wide spectrum of biologicals are produced from animal cells in culture’
--Word--
biologically 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In a way that concerns biology or living organisms.
In an inherited or innate way.
--Examples--
‘the world's most biologically diverse ecosystems’
‘biologically rooted instincts’

--Word--
biophysiology 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: the scientific study of functions found exclusively in living organisms (now rare or disused). In later use: (Psychology) the study of emotion, mental functioning, and behaviour in terms of biology and physiology.
--Examples--
--Word--
biophysiologist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An expert or specialist in biophysiology.
--Examples--
--Word--
biophor 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In the terminology of A. Weismann: a group of molecules believed to constitute a fundamental unit of living protoplasm.
--Examples--
--Word--
biopic 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A biographical film.
--Examples--
--Word--
bioplasm 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In the terminology of L. S. Beale: living protoplasm (as opposed to its non-living portions or constituents).
--Examples--
--Word--
bioplasm 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In the terminology of L. S. Beale: living protoplasm (as opposed to its non-living portions or constituents).
--Examples--
--Word--
bioplast 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In the terminology of L. S. Beale: a unit of bioplasm as an independently existing entity capable of growth and reproduction; the living part of a cell.
--Examples--
--Word--
bioplastic 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
biopsy 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An examination of tissue removed from a living body to discover the presence, cause, or extent of a disease.
Conduct a biopsy on (tissue removed from a living body)
--Examples--
‘a bone marrow biopsy’
‘cirrhosis was confirmed by biopsy’
‘the lesions may be malignant and should be biopsied’

biorhythm 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A recurring cycle in the physiology or functioning of an organism, such as the daily cycle of sleeping and waking.
A cyclic pattern of physical, emotional, or mental activity believed to occur in a person's life.
--Examples--
‘I found that the music suited my biorhythms’

--Word--
bypass 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A road passing round a town or its centre to provide an alternative route for through traffic.
A secondary channel, pipe, or connection to allow a flow when the main one is closed or blocked.
A surgical operation in which an alternative channel is created, especially to improve blood flow to the heart when a coronary artery is blocked.
An alternative channel created during a bypass operation.
Go past or round.
Provide (a town) with a route diverting traffic from its centre.
Avoid or circumvent (an obstacle or problem)
--Examples--
‘I had a bypass last year so have been building up my strength’
‘he's just had a triple bypass operation’
‘bypass the farm and continue to the road’
‘the town has been bypassed’
‘a manager might bypass formal channels of communication’
--Word--
bypass 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--

‘he's just had a triple bypass operation’

‘the town has been bypassed’
‘a manager might bypass formal channels of communication’
--Word--
passage 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The action or process of moving through or past somewhere on the way from one place to another.
The action or process of moving forward.
The right to pass through somewhere.
A journey by sea or air.
(of a migrating bird) the action of passing through a place en route to its final destination.
A narrow way allowing access between buildings or to different rooms within a building; a passageway.
A duct, vessel, or other channel in the body.
The process of transition from one state to another.
The passing of a bill into law.
A short extract from a book or other printed material.
A section of a piece of music.
An episode in a spell of longer activity such as a sporting event.
The propagation of microorganisms or cells in a series of host organisms or culture media, so as to maintain them or modify their virulence.
Subject (a strain of microorganisms or cells) to a passage.
--Examples--
‘there were moorings for boats wanting passage through the lock’
‘despite the passage of time she still loved him’
‘we obtained a permit for safe passage from the embassy’
‘I booked a passage on the next ship’
‘the species occurs regularly on passage’
‘a passage migrant’
‘the larger bedroom was at the end of the passage’
‘an allegory on the theme of the passage from ignorance to knowledge’
‘a catalyst for the unrest was the passage of a privatization law’
‘he picked up the newspaper and read the passage again’
‘an orchestral passage’
‘a neat passage of midfield play’
‘cultured cells can replicate on serial passage for predictable periods of time’
‘each recombinant virus was passaged nine times successively’

--Word--
place 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A particular position, point, or area in space; a location.
A particular area on a larger surface.
A building or area used for a specified purpose or activity.
A person's home.
A point in a book or other text reached by a reader at a particular time.
A portion of space designated or available for or being used by someone.
A vacancy or available position.
The regular or proper position of something.
A person's rank or status.
A right or privilege resulting from someone's role or position.
The role played by or importance attached to someone or something in a particular context.
A position in a sequence or series, typically one ordered on the basis of merit.
Any of the first three or sometimes four positions in a race (used especially of the second, third, or fourth positions).
The second position, especially in a horse race.
The degree of priority given to something.
The position of a figure in a series indicated in decimal or similar notation, especially one after the decimal point.
A square or short street.
A country house with its grounds.
Put in a particular position.
Cause to be in a particular situation.
Allocate or assign (an abstract quality) to something.
Have a specified degree of advantage or convenience as a result of one's position or circumstances.
Find a home or employment for.
Dispose of (something, especially shares) by selling to a customer.
Arrange for the recognition and implementation of (an order, bet, etc.)
Order or obtain a connection for (a telephone call) through an operator.
Identify or classify as being of a specified type or as holding a specified position in a sequence or hierarchy.
Be able to remember or identify (someone or something)
Achieve a specified position in a race.
Be among the first three or four in a race (or the first three in the US)
Score (a goal) by a place kick.
--Examples--
‘I can't be in two places at once’
‘the monastery was a peaceful place’
‘that street was no place for a lady’
‘he would always have a special place in her heart’
‘he lashed out and cut the policeman's hand in three places’
‘the town has many excellent eating places’
‘a place of worship’
‘what about dinner at my place?’
‘I must have lost my place in the script’
‘they hurried to their places at the table’
‘Jackie had saved her a place’
‘he was offered a place at Liverpool University’
‘she put the book back in its place’
‘occupation structures a person's place in society’
‘I'm sure she has a story to tell, but it's not my place to ask’
‘the place of computers in improving office efficiency’
‘his score left him in ninth place’
‘accurate reportage takes second place to lurid detail’
‘calculate the ratios to one decimal place’
‘the lecture theatre is in New Burlington Place’
‘a newspaper had been placed beside my plate’
‘enemy officers were placed under arrest’
‘you are not placing yourself under any obligation’
‘they place a great deal of emphasis on positive thought’
‘the company is well placed to seize the opportunity’
‘the children were placed with foster-parents’
‘the shares were placed last November’
‘they placed a contract for three boats’
‘she placed a call to her husband to break the news’
‘a survey placed the company 13th for achievement’
‘she eventually said she couldn't place him’
‘he was placed eleventh in the long individual race’
‘he won three times and placed three times’
‘the horse, Bahuddin, was not placed at Lingfield’

An early type of aircraft with two pairs of wings, one above the other.

--Word--
plot 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A plan made in secret by a group of people to do something illegal or harmful.
The main events of a play, novel, film, or similar work, devised and presented by the writer as an interrelated sequence.
A small piece of ground marked out for a purpose such as building or gardening.
A graph showing the relation between two variables.
A diagram, chart, or map.
Secretly make plans to carry out (an illegal or harmful action)
Devise the sequence of events in (a play, novel, film, or similar work)
Mark (a route or position) on a chart.
Mark out or allocate (points) on a graph.
Make (a curve) by marking out a number of points on a graph.
Illustrate by use of a graph.
--Examples--
‘there's a plot to overthrow the government’
‘the plot consists almost entirely of a man and woman falling in love’
‘he outlined his idea for a movie plot’
‘a vegetable plot’
‘the two men are serving sentences for plotting a bomb campaign’
‘brother plots against brother’
‘she would plot a chapter as she drove’
‘in a crime story you have to plot carefully to achieve the surprise at the end’
‘he started to plot lines of ancient sites’
‘the dependent variable's points are plotted on the Y axis’
‘a cooling curve is plotted and the freezing point determined’
‘it is possible to plot fairly closely the rate at which recruitment of girls increased’

bipolar 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having or relating to two poles or extremities.
Relating to or occurring in both North and South polar regions.
(of psychiatric illness) characterized by both manic and depressive episodes, or manic ones only.
(of a person) suffering from bipolar disorder.
(of a nerve cell) having two axons, one either side of the cell body.
(of a transistor or other device) using both positive and negative charge carriers.
--Examples--
‘a sharply bipolar division of affluent and underclass’
‘bipolar species’

--Word--
byproduct 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An incidental or secondary product made in the manufacture or synthesis of something else.
A secondary result, unintended but inevitably produced in doing or producing something else.
--Examples--
‘zinc is a byproduct of the glazing process’
‘he saw poverty as the byproduct of colonial prosperity’
--Word--
by-product 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An incidental or secondary product made in the manufacture or synthesis of something else.
An unintended but inevitable secondary result.
--Examples--
‘zinc is a by-product of the glazing process’
‘he saw poverty as the by-product of colonial prosperity’

--Word--
purpose 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The reason for which something is done or created or for which something exists.
A particular requirement or consideration, typically one that is temporary or restricted in scope or extent.
A person's sense of resolve or determination.
Have as one's intention or objective.
--Examples--
‘the purpose of the meeting is to appoint a trustee’
‘the building is no longer needed for its original purpose’
‘state pensions are considered as earned income for tax purposes’
‘there was a new sense of purpose in her step as she set off’
‘God has allowed suffering, even purposed it’

--Word--
birch 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A slender hardy tree which has thin peeling bark and bears catkins. Birch trees grow chiefly in northern temperate regions and yield hard, pale, fine-grained timber.
The hard fine-grained pale wood of birch trees.
A formal punishment in which a person is flogged with a bundle of birch twigs.
Beat (someone) with a bundle of birch twigs as a formal punishment.
--Examples--
‘there were calls to bring back the birch’
‘the school would attempt to birch them into submission’
--Word--
birchbark 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The impervious bark of the North American paper birch, formerly used by North American Indians to make canoes and other items.
--Examples--
‘stretch the birchbark over a cedar frame’
‘birchbark baskets’

--Word--
Byrd, William 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1543–1623), English composer. He was joint organist of the Chapel Royal with Tallis and is famous for his Latin masses and his Anglican Great Service.

--Word--
watch 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Look at or observe attentively over a period of time.
Keep under careful, protective, or secret observation.
Observe and guard in a protective way.
Follow closely or maintain an interest in.
Exercise care, caution, or restraint about.
Look out or be on the alert for.
Be careful.
Be careful (used as a warning or threat)
Remain awake for the purpose of religious observance.
A small timepiece worn typically on a strap on one's wrist.
An act or instance of carefully observing someone or something over a period of time.
A period during which a person is stationed to look out for danger or trouble, typically at night.
A fixed period of duty on a ship, usually lasting four hours.
The officers and crew on duty during a watch.
A shift worked by firefighters or police officers.
A watchman or group of watchmen who patrolled and guarded the streets of a town before the introduction of the police force.
A film or programme considered in terms of its appeal to the public.
A flock of nightingales.
--Examples--
‘Lucy watched him go’
‘as she watched, two women came into the garden’
‘everyone stopped to watch what was going on’
‘there aren't enough staff to watch him properly’
‘he told me my telephones were tapped and that I was being watched’
‘I guess I can rest a while, with you here to watch over me’
‘the girls watched the development of this relationship with incredulity’
‘most women watch their diet during pregnancy’
‘you should watch what you say!’
‘in spring and summer, watch for kingfishers’
‘watch out for broken glass’
‘credit-card fraud is on the increase, so watch out’
‘if anyone finds out, you're dead meat, so watch it’
‘she watched whole nights in the church’
‘my watch had stopped’
‘the security forces have been keeping a close watch on our activities’
‘Murray took the last watch before dawn’
‘sea air, lots of exercise, and four-hour watches give everyone a healthy appetite’
‘the men of Red Watch at Kingsland Fire Station’
‘the woman, with a piercing shriek, called the watch’
‘this movie's an engrossing watch’
‘a watch of nightingales began flying south’

--Word--
reaction 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Something done, felt, or thought in response to a situation or event.
A person's ability to respond physically and mentally to external stimuli.
An adverse physiological response to a substance that has been breathed in, ingested, or touched.
A mode of thinking or behaving that is deliberately different from previous modes of thought and behaviour.
Opposition to political or social progress or reform.
A chemical process in which substances act mutually on each other and are changed into different substances, or one substance changes into other substances.
An analogous transformation of atomic nuclei or other particles.
A force exerted in opposition to an applied force.
--Examples--
‘my immediate reaction was one of relief’
‘prices fell in reaction to intense competition’
‘a skilled driver with quick reactions’
‘such allergic reactions as hay fever and asthma’
‘the work of these painters was a reaction against Fauvism’
‘the institution is under threat from the forces of reaction’
‘a chemical reaction caused by a build-up of particular sodium salts’
‘reactions between photons and electrically charged atomic particles’
‘the law of action and reaction’

--Word--
respect 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A feeling of deep admiration for someone or something elicited by their abilities, qualities, or achievements.
The state of being admired or respected.
A person's polite greetings.
Used to express the speaker's approval of someone or something.
Due regard for the feelings, wishes, or rights of others.
A particular aspect, point, or detail.
Admire (someone or something) deeply, as a result of their abilities, qualities, or achievements.
Have due regard for (someone's feelings, wishes, or rights)
Avoid harming or interfering with.
Agree to recognize and abide by (a legal requirement)
--Examples--
‘the director had a lot of respect for Douglas as an actor’
‘his first chance in over fifteen years to regain respect in the business’
‘give my respects to their Excellencies’
‘respect to Hill for a truly non-superficial piece on the techno scene’
‘young people's lack of respect for their parents’
‘the government's record in this respect is a mixed one’
‘she was respected by everyone she worked with’
‘I respected his views’
‘it is incumbent upon all hill users to respect the environment’
‘the crown and its ministers ought to respect the ordinary law’
--Word--
result 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A thing that is caused or produced by something else; a consequence or outcome.
A favourable outcome of an undertaking or contest.
The outcome of a business's trading over a given period, expressed as a statement of profit or loss.
A final score, mark, or placing in a sporting event or examination.
An item of information obtained by experiment or some other scientific method; a quantity or formula obtained by calculation.
Occur or follow as the consequence of something.
Have (a specified outcome)
--Examples--
‘the tower collapsed as a result of safety violations’
‘different approaches have been tried with somewhat mixed results’
‘determination and persistence guarantee results’
‘if we can get a result in that game we might qualify’
‘oil companies have reported better results’
‘exam results’
‘it was a great result for us’
‘the results are evaluated by the researcher’
‘anger may result from an argument’
‘talks in July had resulted in stalemate’

Nilsson, Birgit 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1918–2005), Swedish operatic soprano; full name Märta Birgit Nilsson. She gained international success in the 1950s, being particularly noted for her interpretation of Wagnerian roles.
--Examples--
--Word--
Bridget, St. 
--Type--
proper noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
(6th century), Irish abbess; also known as St. Bridget of Ireland. She was venerated in Ireland as a virgin saint and noted in miracle stories for her compassion. Feast day, July 23.
(c.1303–73), Swedish nun and visionary; also known as St. Bridget of Sweden. She experienced her first vision of the Virgin Mary at the age of seven. Feast day, February 1.

--Word--
Byrnes, James Francis 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1879–1972), US Supreme Court associate justice 1941–42. A Democrat from South Carolina, he was a member of the US House of Representatives 1911–25 and the US Senate 1931–41 before being appointed to the Court by President Franklin D. Roosevelt. He resigned a year later to take several federal positions in the war effort, and from 1945 to 1947 was US secretary of state.
--Examples--
--Word--
Byrnes, James Francis 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1879–1972), US Supreme Court associate justice 1941–42. A Democrat from South Carolina, he was a member of the US House of Representatives 1911–25 and the US Senate 1931–41 before being appointed to the Court by President Franklin D. Roosevelt. He resigned a year later to take several federal positions in the war effort, and from 1945 to 1947 was US secretary of state.

proper noun
--Meanings--

room 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
Space that can be occupied or where something can be done.
Opportunity or scope for something to happen or be done.
A part or division of a building enclosed by walls, floor, and ceiling.
The people present in a room.
A set of rooms, typically rented, in which a person, couple, or family live.
Share a room, house, or flat, especially a rented one at a college or similar institution.
Provide with a shared room or lodging.
--Examples--
‘there's only room for a single bed in there’
‘she made room for Josh on the sofa’
‘he was trapped without room to move’
‘there's room for improvement in the way the programme is managed’
‘a policy which left the government with very little room to manoeuvre’
‘he wandered from room to room’
‘the whole room burst into an uproar of approval’
‘my rooms at Mrs Jenks's house’
‘I was rooming with my cousin’
‘they roomed us together’

birthwort 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A climbing or herbaceous plant that typically has heart-shaped leaves and deep-throated, pipe-shaped flowers. It was formerly used as an aid to childbirth and to induce abortion.

--Word--
Bisbee 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A town in southeastern Arizona, near the Mexican border; population 5,991 (est. 2008). An artists' colony, it was a copper mining center in the early 1900s and is noted as the source of Bisbee turquoise, an incidental byproduct of the copper mining.
--Examples--
--Word--
Biscay, Bay of 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A part of the North Atlantic between the north coast of Spain and the west coast of France, noted for its strong currents and storms. The shipping forecast area Biscay extends approximately as far west as the longitude of Gijón in Spain.
--Examples--

--Word--
bishop 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A senior member of the Christian clergy, usually in charge of a diocese and empowered to confer holy orders.
An African weaver bird, the male of which has red, orange, yellow, or black plumage.
A chess piece, typically with its top shaped like a mitre, that can move in any direction along a diagonal on which it stands. Each player starts the game with two bishops, one moving on white squares and the other on black.
Mulled and spiced wine.

--Word--
Bismarck 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The state capital of North Dakota; population 60,389 (est. 2008). A terminus of the Northern Pacific Railway, it took the name of the German Chancellor in order to attract German capital for railroad-building.

A humpbacked shaggy-haired wild ox native to North America and Europe.

--Word--
speech 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The expression of or the ability to express thoughts and feelings by articulate sounds.
A person's style of speaking.
A formal address or discourse delivered to an audience.
A sequence of lines written for one character in a play.
--Examples--
‘he was born deaf and without the power of speech’
‘she wouldn't accept his correction of her speech’
‘he gave a speech about the company’
‘Antony's speech over Caesar's body’
--Word--
by- 
--Type--
prefix
--Meanings--
Subordinate; incidental; secondary.
--Examples--
‘by-election’
‘by-product’

--Word--
bissextile 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a year) having the extra day (29 February) of a leap year.
--Examples--
‘in a bissextile year, any fixed festival after February leaps forward’
‘the year 1904 was bissextile’
--Word--
Shelley, Percy Bysshe 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1792–1822), English poet. He was a leading figure of the romantic movement with radical political views. Notable works include Queen Mab (political poems, 1813), Prometheus Unbound (lyrical drama, 1820), The Defence of Poetry (essay, 1821), and Adonais (1821), an elegy on the death of Keats.
--Examples--
--Word--
byssus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A fine textile fibre and fabric of flax.
A tuft of tough silky filaments by which mussels and some other bivalves adhere to rocks and other objects.
--Examples--
‘byssus threads’

--Word--
stake 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A strong wooden or metal post with a point at one end, driven into the ground to support a plant, form part of a fence, mark a boundary, etc.
A wooden post to which a person was tied before being burned alive as a punishment.
A long vertical rod used in basket-making.
A metalworker's small anvil, typically with a projection for fitting into a socket on a bench.
A territorial division of the Mormon Church under the jurisdiction of a president.
Support (a plant) with a stake or stakes.
Mark an area with stakes so as to claim ownership of it.
Be assertive in defining and defending a position or policy.
--Examples--
‘Bishop Ridley was burned at the stake’
‘the gladioli were staked in gaudy ranks’
‘vigorous plants need staking’
‘the boundary between the two manors was properly staked out’
‘Elena was staking out a role for herself as a formidable political force’

--Word--
stroke 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An act of hitting or striking someone or something; a blow.
A method of striking the ball in sports or games.
An act of hitting the ball with a club, as a unit of scoring.
The sound made by a striking clock.
A mark made by drawing a pen, pencil, or paintbrush in one direction across paper or canvas.
A line forming part of a written or printed character.
A short printed or written diagonal line typically separating characters or figures.
An act of moving one's hand across a surface with gentle pressure.
Each of a series of movements in which something moves out of its position and back into it.
The whole motion of a piston in either direction.
The rhythm to which a series of repeated movements is performed.
A movement of the arms and legs forming one of a series in swimming.
A particular style of moving the arms and legs in swimming.
(in rowing) the mode or action of moving the oar.
The oar or oarsman nearest the stern of a boat, setting the timing for the other rowers.
A sudden disabling attack or loss of consciousness caused by an interruption in the flow of blood to the brain, especially through thrombosis.
Move one's hand with gentle pressure over (a surface), typically repeatedly; caress.
Apply (something) to a surface using a gentle movement.
Reassure or flatter (someone), especially in order to gain their cooperation.
Act as the stroke of (a boat or crew)
Hit or kick (a ball) smoothly and deliberately.
--Examples--
‘he received three strokes of the cane’
‘he won by two strokes’
‘the first stroke would belt out from the clock’
‘the paint had been applied in careful, regular strokes’
‘massage the cream into your skin using light upward strokes’
‘the ray swam with effortless strokes of its huge wings’
‘the rowers sing to keep their stroke’
‘I slipped into the water and swam a few strokes’
‘front crawl is a popular stroke’
‘he was left disabled by a stroke’
‘smoking increases the risk of stroke’
‘he put his hand on her hair and stroked it’
‘she strokes blue eyeshadow on her eyelids’
‘production executives were expert at stroking stars and brokering talent’
‘he stroked the coxed four to victory’
‘Markwick stroked the ball home’

--Word--
bit 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small piece, part, or quantity of something.
A short time or distance.
A fairly large amount.
A set of actions or ideas associated with a specific group or activity.
A girl or young woman.
A person's genitals.
A unit of 12 1/2 cents (used only in even multiples).
--Examples--
‘give the duck a bit of bread’
‘he read bits of his work to me’
‘I fell asleep for a bit’
‘can you move over a bit?’
‘working in a foreign country took quite a bit of getting used to’
‘Miranda could go off and do her theatrical bit’
‘he went and married some young bit half his age’
‘You could see everything! All her bits!’

--Word--
talk 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Speak in order to give information or express ideas or feelings; converse or communicate by spoken words.
Have the power of speech.
Discuss personal or intimate feelings.
Persuade or cause (someone) to do something by talking.
Used to emphasize the seriousness, importance, or extent of the thing one is discussing.
Reveal secret or confidential information.
Gossip.
Have formal dealings or discussions; negotiate.
Use (a particular language) in speech.
Communication by spoken words; conversation or discussion.
A period of conversation or discussion, especially a relatively serious one.
Rumour, gossip, or speculation.
Empty promises or boasting.
A current subject of widespread gossip or speculation in (a particular place)
Formal discussions or negotiations over a period.
An informal address or lecture.
--Examples--
‘the two men talked’
‘we'd sit and talk about jazz’
‘it was no use talking to Anthony’
‘you're talking rubbish’
‘he can talk as well as you or I can’
‘we need to talk, Maggie’
‘keep on walking and talk your way out of it’
‘we're talking big money’
‘dead men can't talk’
‘you'll have the whole school talking’
‘they won't talk to the regime that killed their families’
‘we were talking German’
‘there was a slight but noticeable lull in the talk’
‘my mother had a talk with Louis’
‘there is talk of an armistice’
‘he's all talk’
‘within days I was the talk of the town’
‘peace talks’
‘a thirty-minute illustrated talk’
‘a talk on a day in the life of an actor’

--Word--
bitch 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A female dog, wolf, fox, or otter.
A spiteful or unpleasant woman.
A woman.
A person who is completely subservient to another.
Used as a form of address.
A difficult or unpleasant situation or thing.
A complaint.
Make spitefully critical comments.
--Examples--
‘I'm free, bitches!’
‘working the night shift is a bitch’
‘my big bitch is that there's nothing new here’
‘everybody was bitching about their colleagues’

--Word--
bite 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
(of a person or animal) use the teeth to cut into something.
Use the teeth in order to inflict injury on.
(of a snake, insect, or spider) wound with fangs, pincers, or a sting.
(of an acid) corrode a surface.
(of a fish) take the bait or lure on the end of a fishing line into the mouth.
Be persuaded to accept a deal or offer.
Annoy or worry.
(of a tool, tyre, boot, etc.) grip or take hold on a surface.
(of an object) press into a part of the body, causing pain.
Cause emotional pain.
(of a policy or situation) take effect, with unpleasant consequences.
Be very bad, unpleasant, or unfortunate.
An act of biting something in order to eat it.
A wound inflicted by an animal's or a person's teeth.
A wound inflicted by a snake, insect, or spider.
An instance of bait being taken by a fish.
The bringing together of the teeth so that the jaws are closed.
An imprint of the position of the teeth when the jaws are closed, made in a plastic material.
A piece cut off by biting.
A quick snack.
A small morsel of prepared food, intended to constitute one mouthful.
A short piece of information.
A sharp or pungent flavour.
Incisiveness or cogency of style.
A feeling of cold in the air or wind.
--Examples--
‘she was biting a slice of bread’
‘the woman's arm was bitten off by an alligator’
‘Rosa bit into a cupcake’
‘babies learn to bite and chew about halfway through their first year’
‘he was chased and bitten by a police dog’
‘she had bitten, scratched, and kicked her assailant’
‘it is not unusual for a dog to bite at its owner's hand’
‘while on holiday she was bitten by an adder’
‘chemicals have bitten deep into the stone’
‘I marvel at how easily and eagerly a chub will bite’
‘a hundred or so retailers should bite’
‘what's biting you today?’
‘once on the slab, my boots failed to bite’
‘the handcuffs bit into his wrists’
‘Cheryl's betrayal had bitten deep’
‘the cuts in art education were starting to bite’
‘it bites that your mom won't let you go’
‘Stephen ate a hot dog in three big bites’
‘Percy's dog had given her a nasty bite’
‘my legs were covered in mosquito bites’
‘by four o'clock he still hadn't had a single bite’
‘Robyn took a large bite out of her sandwich’
‘I plan to stop off in the village and have a bite to eat’
‘bacon bites with cheese’
‘a fresh, lemony bite’
‘the tale has added bite if its characters appear to be real’
‘by early October there's a bite in the air’
--Word--
byte 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A group of binary digits or bits (usually eight) operated on as a unit.
A byte considered as a unit of memory size.

--Word--
thing 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An object that one need not, cannot, or does not wish to give a specific name to.
Personal belongings or clothing.
Equipment, utensils, or other objects used for a particular purpose.
Anything (used for emphasis)
Used to express one's disapproval of or contempt for something.
All that can be described in the specified way.
Used euphemistically to refer to a man's penis.
An inanimate material object as distinct from a living sentient being.
A living creature or plant.
Used to express one's feelings of pity, affection, approval, or contempt for a person or animal.
An action, event, thought, or utterance.
Circumstances or matters that are unspecified.
An abstract entity, quality, or concept.
An example or type of something.
A situation or activity of a specified type or quality.
A romantic or sexual relationship.
An established or genuine phenomenon or practice (typically used in expressions registering surprise or incredulity)
What is needed or required.
What is socially acceptable or fashionable.
One's special interest or inclination.
Used to introduce or emphasize an important point.
--Examples--
‘look at that metal rail thing over there’
‘there are lots of things I'd like to buy’
‘she began to unpack her things’
‘they cleared away the lunch things’
‘she couldn't find a thing to wear’
‘you won't find me smoking those filthy things’
‘his love for all things English’
‘I'm not a thing, not a work of art to be cherished’
‘the sea is the primal source of all living things on earth’
‘have a nice weekend in the country, you lucky thing!’
‘the lamb was a puny little thing’
‘she said the first thing that came into her head’
‘the only thing I could do well was cook’
‘things haven't gone entirely to plan’
‘how are things with you?’
‘mourning and depression are not the same thing’
‘they had one thing in common—they were men of action’
‘the game is the latest thing in family fun’
‘your being here is just a friendship thing, OK?’
‘Phil and Lisa had been having a thing’
‘according to media reports, sleep texting is now a thing among serious smartphone addicts’
‘he looks like he's wearing boxers underneath his trunks (is that a thing?)’
‘you need a tonic—and here's just the thing’
‘it wouldn't be quite the thing to go to a royal garden party in wellies’
‘reading isn't my thing’
‘the thing is, I am going to sell this house’
‘here's the thing: this is a story, not a piece of hard news’
‘that's the thing about style—no two people are completely alike’
--Word--
Bithynia 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The ancient name for the region of north-western Asia Minor west of ancient Paphlagonia, bordering the Black Sea and the Sea of Marmara.

--Word--
throw 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Propel (something) with force through the air by a movement of the arm and hand.
Push or force (someone or something) violently and suddenly into a particular physical position or state.
Put in place or erect quickly.
Move (a part of the body) quickly or suddenly in a particular direction.
Project or cast (light or shadow) in a particular direction.
Deliver (a punch)
Direct a particular kind of look or facial expression.
Project (one's voice) so that it appears to come from someone or something else, as in ventriloquism.
Put on or take off (a garment) hastily.
Move (a switch or lever) so as to operate a device.
Roll (dice)
Obtain (a specified number) by rolling dice.
Lose (a race or contest) intentionally, especially in return for a bribe.
Bowl (the ball) with an unlawful bent arm action.
(of a horse) lose (a shoe).
Send suddenly into a particular state or condition.
Put (someone) in a particular place or state in a rough, abrupt, or summary fashion.
Disconcert; confuse.
Send (one's opponent) to the ground in wrestling, judo, or similar activity.
(of a horse) unseat (its rider)
Form (ceramic ware) on a potter's wheel.
Turn (wood or other material) on a lathe.
Twist (silk or other fabrics) into thread or yarn.
Have (a fit or tantrum)
Give or hold (a party)
(of an animal) give birth to (young, especially of a specified kind)
An act of throwing something.
An act of throwing one's opponent in wrestling, judo, or a similar sport.
An illegitimate delivery considered to have been thrown rather than properly bowled.
A light cover for furniture.
Used to indicate how much a single item, turn, or attempt costs.
The extent of vertical displacement in a fault.
A machine or device by or on which an object is turned while being shaped.
The action or motion of a slide valve or of a crank, eccentric wheel, or cam.
The distance moved by the pointer of an instrument.
--Examples--
‘I threw a brick through the window’
‘the pilot and one passenger were thrown clear and survived’
‘the door was thrown open and a uniformed guard entered the room’
‘the stewards had thrown a cordon across the fairway’
‘she threw her head back and laughed’
‘a chandelier threw its bright light over the walls’
‘Cheryl drew back her fist and threw another punch’
‘she threw a withering glance at him’
‘I can throw my voice—I could make a fortune as a medium’
‘I tumbled out of bed, threw on my tracksuit, and joined the others’
‘at the trolley portal the operator had to manually throw the switch using a switch iron’
‘he reached out and put the dice in the shaker and threw them’
‘the man who throws a race is a crook for life’
‘he threw all her emotions into turmoil’
‘the bond market was thrown into confusion’
‘these guys should be thrown in jail’
‘she frowned, thrown by this apparent change of tack’
‘in the final Arnaud was too strong, and threw Hughes twice’
‘their horse threw its jockey before the race had started’
‘further on a potter was throwing pots’
‘occasionally a small child will throw a tantrum when denied something’
‘he threw a huge farewell party for them’
‘sometimes a completely black calf is thrown’
‘Holding's throw hit the stumps’
‘a shoulder throw’
‘this decision represents something of a final throw’
‘people who hazard their entire company on one major throw’
‘he was offering to draw on-the-spot portraits at £25 a throw’

--Type--
verb, noun

Push suddenly or violently in a specified direction.

A reverse fault of low angle, with older strata displaced horizontally over newer.

--Word--
tone 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A musical or vocal sound with reference to its pitch, quality, and strength.
A modulation of the voice expressing a particular feeling or mood.
A musical note or other sound used as a signal on a telephone or answering machine.
The general character or attitude of a place, piece of writing, situation, etc.
An atmosphere of respectability or class.
A basic interval in classical Western music, equal to two semitones and separating, for example, the first and second notes of an ordinary scale (such as C and D, or E and F sharp); a major second.
The particular quality of brightness, deepness, or hue of a shade of a colour.
The general effect of colour or of light and shade in a picture.
A slight degree of difference in the intensity of a colour.
(in some languages, such as Chinese) a particular pitch pattern on a syllable used to make semantic distinctions.
(in some languages, such as English) intonation on a word or phrase used to add functional meaning.
The normal level of firmness or slight contraction in a resting muscle.
The normal level of activity in a nerve fibre.
Give greater strength or firmness to (the body or a muscle)
(of a muscle or other bodily part) became stronger or firmer.
Harmonize with (something) in terms of colour.
Give (a monochrome picture) an altered colour in finishing by means of a chemical solution.
tone something down
Make something less harsh in sound or colour.
Make something less extreme or intense.
--Examples--
‘they were speaking in hushed tones’
‘the piano tone appears lacking in warmth’
‘a firm tone of voice’
‘my friend and I lowered the tone with our oafish ways’
‘there was a general tone of ill-concealed glee in the reporting’
‘they don't feel he gives the place tone’
‘the B flat clarinet's part is written one tone higher than the pitch required’
‘stained glass in vivid tones of red and blue’
‘an attractive colour which is even in tone and texture’
‘a reduction of muscle tone’
‘a certain amount of daily exercise is essential to maintain proper body tone and function’
‘vagal tone’
‘exercise tones up the muscles’
‘his leg muscles had toned up’
‘the rich orange colour of the wood tones beautifully with the yellow roses’
‘it's a good idea to sepia tone the whole print first’
‘a green-tinged moisturizer helps to tone down a ruddy complexion’
‘I just hope we can now begin to tone down the rhetoric’

--Word--
track 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A rough path or road, typically one beaten by use rather than constructed.
A prepared course or circuit for athletes, horses, motor vehicles, bicycles, or dogs to race on.
The sport of running on a track.
A mark or line of marks left by a person, animal, or vehicle in passing.
The course or route followed by someone or something (used especially in talking about their pursuit by others)
A course of action or line of thought.
A continuous line of rails on a railway.
A metal or plastic strip or rail along which a curtain or spotlight may be moved.
A strip on the mast, boom, or floor of a yacht along which a slide attached to a sail can be moved, used to adjust the position of the sail.
A recording of one song or piece of music.
A lengthwise strip of magnetic tape containing one sequence of signals.
The soundtrack of a film or video.
A continuous articulated metal band around the wheels of a heavy vehicle such as a tank, intended to facilitate movement over rough or soft ground.
A continuous line of copper or other conductive material on a printed circuit board, used to connect parts of a circuit.
The transverse distance between a vehicle's wheels.
A group in which schoolchildren of the same age and ability are taught.
Follow the trail or movements of (someone or something), typically in order to find them or note their course.
Note the progress or course of.
Follow a particular course.
(of a stylus) follow (a groove in a record)
(of a film or television camera) move in relation to the subject being filmed.
(of wheels) run so that the back ones are exactly in the track of the front ones.
(of a tunable circuit or component) vary in frequency in the same way as another circuit or component, so that the frequency difference between them remains constant.
--Examples--
‘follow the track to the farm’
‘a Formula One Grand Prix track’
‘the four running disciplines of track, road, country, and fell’
‘he followed the tracks made by the cars in the snow’
‘I didn't want them on my track’
‘in terms of social arrangements, you are not too far off the track’
‘commuters had to leave trains to walk along the tracks’
‘130 kilometres of track’
‘the CD contains early Elvis Presley tracks’
‘extremely thin tracks are not able to withstand much heat when soldering’
‘the undercarriage was fully retractable inwards into the wing, with a 90 inch track’
‘secondary radars that track the aircraft in flight’
‘he tracked Anna to her room’
‘City have been tracking the striker since the summer’
‘the storm was tracking across the ground at 30 mph’
‘the pickup's stylus must faithfully track undulations’
‘the DT1 tracks exceptionally well’
‘the camera eventually tracked away’
--Word--
trail 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A mark or a series of signs or objects left behind by the passage of someone or something.
A track, scent, or other indication used in following someone or hunting an animal.
A long thin part or line stretching behind or hanging down from something.
A beaten path through the countryside.
A route followed for a particular purpose.
A downhill ski run or cross-country ski route.
A trailer for a film or broadcast.
The rear end of a gun carriage, resting or sliding on the ground when the gun is unlimbered.
Draw or be drawn along behind someone or something.
(typically of a plant) grow or hang over the edge of something or along the ground.
Walk or move slowly or wearily.
(of the voice or a speaker) fade gradually before stopping.
Follow (a person or animal) by using marks or scent left behind.
Be losing to an opponent in a game or contest.
Give advance publicity to (a film, broadcast, or proposal)
Apply (slip) through a nozzle or spout to decorate ceramic ware.
--Examples--

‘the torrential rain left a trail of devastation’

‘her robe trailed along the ground’
‘the roses grew wild, their stems trailing over the banks’

‘her voice trailed away’

‘the defending champions were trailing 10—5 at half-time’
‘the bank's plans have been extensively trailed’

--Word--
bitter 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Having a sharp, pungent taste or smell; not sweet.
(of chocolate) dark and unsweetened.
Feeling or showing anger, hurt, or resentment because of bad experiences or a sense of unjust treatment.
(of a conflict, argument, or opponent) full of anger and acrimony.
Painful or unpleasant to accept or contemplate.
(of wind or weather) intensely cold.
Beer that is strongly flavoured with hops and has a bitter taste, brewed by top fermentation.
Alcohol flavoured with bitter plant extracts, used as an additive in cocktails or as a medicinal substance to promote appetite or digestion.
--Examples--
‘raw berries have an intensely bitter flavour’
‘I don't feel jealous or bitter’
‘she wept bitter tears of self-reproach’
‘a bitter five-year legal battle’
‘today's decision has come as a bitter blow’
‘she knew from bitter experience how treacherous such feelings could be’
‘a bitter February night’
‘a pint of bitter’
‘the company brews a range of bitters’
‘a dash of bitters’

--Word--
bittering agent 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A substance added to a toxic product, e.g. antifreeze, to make it taste or smell extremely bitter and thus discourage inhalation or ingestion.
--Examples--
--Word--
bitterly 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In an angry, hurt, or resentful way.

--Examples--

--Word--
bitterling 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small brightly coloured freshwater fish of central Europe. The eggs are deposited inside a mussel, in which they are fertilized and the young eventually hatch.
--Examples--
--Word--
bittern 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
A large marshbird of the heron family, which is typically smaller than a heron, with brown streaked plumage. The larger kinds are noted for the deep booming call of the male in the breeding season.
A concentrated solution of various salts remaining after the crystallization of salt from seawater.

‘bittersweet memories of his time in London’
--Word--
bittersweet 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
(of food or drink) sweet with a bitter aftertaste.
Arousing pleasure tinged with sadness or pain.
An American climbing plant that bears clusters of bright orange pods.
A widely distributed bivalve mollusc which has a pale rounded shell that is typically marked with wavy lines.
--Examples--
‘she sipped the bittersweet drink’
‘the ale has a fine bittersweet nutty taste’
‘bittersweet memories of his time in London’

--Word--
bit 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small piece, part, or quantity of something.
A short time or distance.
A fairly large amount.
A set of actions or ideas associated with a specific group or activity.
A girl or young woman.
A person's genitals.
A unit of 12 1/2 cents (used only in even multiples).
--Examples--
‘give the duck a bit of bread’
‘he read bits of his work to me’
‘I fell asleep for a bit’
‘can you move over a bit?’
‘working in a foreign country took quite a bit of getting used to’
‘Miranda could go off and do her theatrical bit’
‘he went and married some young bit half his age’
‘You could see everything! All her bits!’

bitumen 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A black viscous mixture of hydrocarbons obtained naturally or as a residue from petroleum distillation. It is used for road surfacing and roofing.
A tarred road surface.
--Examples--
‘a kilometre and a half of bitumen’
--Word--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A black viscous mixture of hydrocarbons obtained naturally or as a residue from petroleum distillation. It is used for road surfacing and roofing.
A tarred road surface.

--Word--
walk 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Move at a regular pace by lifting and setting down each foot in turn, never having both feet off the ground at once.
Go on foot for recreation and exercise.
Travel over (a route or area) on foot.
Used to suggest that someone has achieved a state or position easily or undeservedly.
Move in a similar way to walking, but using one's hands or a support such as stilts.
(of a quadruped) proceed with the slowest gait, always having at least two feet on the ground at once.
Ride (a horse) at the slowest pace.
Guide, accompany, or escort (someone) on foot.
Take (a dog) out for exercise.
Train and look after (a hound puppy).
(of a thing) go missing or be stolen.
Abandon or suddenly withdraw from a job or commitment.
Be released from suspicion or from a charge.
(of a batsman) leave the field without waiting to be given out by the umpire.
Reach first base automatically after not hitting at four balls pitched outside the strike zone.
Allow or enable (a batter) to walk.
(of a ghost) be visible; appear.
Live or behave in a particular way.
An act of travelling or an outing on foot.
Used to indicate the time that it will take to reach a place on foot or the distance to be travelled.
A route recommended or marked out for recreational walking.
A path.
The round followed by a postman.
An unhurried rate of movement on foot.
The slowest gait of an animal.
A person's manner of walking.
A part of a forest under one keeper.
The place where a gamecock is kept.
A farm where a hound puppy is trained.
An instance of reaching first base automatically after not hitting at four balls pitched outside the strike zone.
A flock of snipe.
--Examples--
‘I walked across the lawn’
‘she turned and walked a few paces’
‘you can walk in 21,000 acres of moorland’
‘the police department has encouraged officers to walk the beat’
‘no one has the right to walk straight into a well-paid job for life’
‘he could walk on his hands carrying a plate on one foot’
‘he walked his horse towards her’
‘he walked her home to her door’
‘a meeting to walk parents through the complaint process’
‘she spotted a man walking his retriever’
‘customers have to leave a deposit to ensure the beer glasses don't walk’
‘he was in place as the male lead but walked at the eleventh hour’
‘had any of the others come clean during the trial, he might have walked’
‘the ghosts of Bannockburn walked abroad’
‘walk humbly with your God’
‘he was too restless to sleep, so he went out for a walk’
‘the library is within five minutes' walk’
‘there are picnic places and waymarked walks’
‘the street lamps illuminated the riverside walk’
‘the first job is to sort the mail into routes or walks’
‘they crossed the field at a leisurely walk’
‘she reined her horse to a slow walk’
‘the spring was back in his walk’

wipe 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Clean or dry (something) by rubbing with a cloth, a piece of paper, or one's hand.
Remove (dirt or moisture) from something by wiping.
Clean (something) by rubbing it against a surface.
Spread (a liquid) over a surface by rubbing.
Remove or eliminate (something) completely.
Erase (data) from a tape, computer, etc.
Reject or dismiss (a person or idea)
Pass (a swipe card) over an electronic reader.
An act of wiping.
A disposable cloth treated with a cleansing agent, for wiping things clean.
A cinematographic effect in which an existing picture seems to be wiped out by a new one as the boundary between them moves across the screen.
--Examples--
‘Paulie wiped his face with a handkerchief’
‘he wiped down the kitchen wall’
‘she wiped away a tear’
‘the man wiped his hands on his hips’
‘gently wipe the lotion over the eyelids’
‘their life savings were wiped out’
‘things have happened to wipe the smile off Kate's face’
‘a virus that can wipe information from computer hard disks’
‘the tapes have been wiped’
‘you can wipe that idea, if that's what you're thinking’
‘a customer wipes the card across the reader and enters his/her identification number’
‘Bert was giving the machine a final wipe over with an oily rag’

wood 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The hard fibrous material that forms the main substance of the trunk or branches of a tree or shrub, used for fuel or timber.
Wooden barrels used for storing alcoholic drinks.
A golf club with a wooden or other head that is relatively broad from face to back (often with a numeral indicating the degree to which the face is angled to loft the ball)
A shot made with a wood.
An area of land, smaller than a forest, that is covered with growing trees.

‘best quality woods were used for joinery’
‘wines from the wood’
‘he hit the ball with a three-wood’
‘he's hitting a wood for his second shot’
‘a thick hedge divided the wood from the field’
‘a long walk in the woods’

--Word--
Beiderbecke, Bix 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1903–31), American jazz musician and composer; born Leon Bismarck Beiderbecke. A self-taught cornetist and pianist, he was one of a handful of white musicians who profoundly influenced the development of jazz.

--Word--
Byzantine 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to Byzantium (now Istanbul), the Byzantine Empire, or the Eastern Orthodox Church.
Of an ornate artistic and architectural style which developed in the Byzantine Empire and spread to Italy, Russia, and elsewhere. The art is typified by religious wall paintings and icons and the architecture by many-domed churches.
(of a system or situation) excessively complicated, and typically involving a great deal of administrative detail.
Characterized by deviousness or underhand procedure.
A citizen of Byzantium or the Byzantine Empire.
--Examples--
‘Byzantine insurance regulations’
‘he has the most Byzantine mind in politics’

--Type--

--Word--
Byzantium 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An ancient Greek city, founded in the 7th century BC, at the southern end of the Bosporus, site of the modern city of Istanbul. It was rebuilt by Constantine the Great in AD 324–30 as Constantinople.
--Examples--

--Word--
black 
--Type--
adjective, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Of the very darkest colour owing to the absence of or complete absorption of light; the opposite of white.
(of the sky or night) completely dark owing to the sun, moon, or stars not being visible.
Deeply stained with dirt.
(of a plant or animal) dark in colour as distinguished from a lighter variety.
(of coffee or tea) served without milk.
Of or denoting the suits spades and clubs in a pack of cards.
(of a ski run) of the highest level of difficulty, as indicated by black markers positioned along it.
Belonging to or denoting any human group having dark-coloured skin, especially of African or Australian Aboriginal ancestry.
Relating to black people.
Characterized by tragic or disastrous events; causing despair or pessimism.
(of a person's state of mind) full of gloom or misery; very depressed.
(of humour) presenting tragic or harrowing situations in comic terms.
Full of anger or hatred.
Very evil or wicked.
Denoting a covert military procedure.
(of goods or work) not to be handled or undertaken by trade union members, especially so as to express support for an industrial dispute elsewhere.
Black colour or pigment.
Black clothes or material, typically worn as a sign of mourning.
Darkness, especially of night or an overcast sky.
The player of the black pieces in chess or draughts.
A black thing, in particular the black ball in snooker.
A member of a dark-skinned people, especially one of African or Australian Aboriginal ancestry.
The situation of not owing money to a bank or of making a profit in a business operation.
Blackcurrant cordial.
Make (something) black, especially with polish.
Make (one's face and other visible parts) black with polish or make-up so as not to be seen at night or to play the role of a black person in a play or film.
Refuse to handle (goods), undertake (work), or have dealings with (a person or business) as a way of taking industrial action.
--Examples--
‘black smoke’
‘her long black hair’
‘the sky was moonless and black’
‘the walls were black with age and dirt’
‘Japanese black pine’
‘a mug of black coffee’
‘Doyle took his coffee black’
‘black adolescents of Jamaican descent’
‘black culture’
‘five thousand men were killed on the blackest day of the war’
‘the future looks black’
‘Jean had disappeared and Mary was in a black mood’
‘‘Good place to bury the bodies,’ she joked with black humour’
‘Rory shot her a black look’
‘my soul is steeped in the blackest sin’
‘clearance for black operations came from the highest political level’
‘the union declared the ship black’
‘a tray decorated in black and green’
‘only one or two of the mourners were in black’
‘the only thing visible in the black was the light of the torch’
‘Black's king's defences are somewhat weakened’
‘they tend to identify strongly with other blacks’
‘it is hoped the club will be back in the black by the end of the season’
‘I managed to break even in the first six months—quite a short time for a small business to get into the black’
‘an insurance company operating in the black will be able to pay for further growth’
‘a rum and black’
‘the steps of the house were neatly blacked’
‘white extras blacking up their faces to play Ethiopians’
‘the union blacked the film because overtime was not being paid’

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A black African or a very dark-skinned person.

adjective
--Meanings--

noun

--Word--
black-and-white colobus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(In full "black-and-white colobus monkey") any of several black and white monkeys of the African genus Colobus (family Cercopithecidae (or Colobidae)), which are long-haired and long-tailed, and lack thumbs.
--Examples--

blackarm 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A bacterial disease of cotton plants caused by the pathogen Xanthomonas malvacearum, characterized by angular black lesions on the stem and fruiting branches.

blackback 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A black-backed gull; specifically (more fully "great blackback", "greater blackback") the great black-backed gull, Larus marinus.
Any of various other animals with black or dark backs; (in later use especially) a subordinate male gorilla.

--Word--
Blackbeard 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(died 1718), English pirate; real name Edward Teach. Originally a privateer during the War of the Spanish Succession 1701–14, he turned to piracy and concentrated on the West Indies and the Virginia–North Carolina coast of America.
--Examples--

blackberry 
--Type--
noun, verb, noun, verb
--Meanings--
An edible soft fruit consisting of a cluster of soft purple-black drupelets.
The prickly climbing shrub of the rose family that bears blackberries.
Gather blackberries in the wild.
A handheld mobile device that provides Internet access and email, telephone, and text-messaging facilities.
Communicate with (someone) using a BlackBerry device.
--Examples--
‘she asked me to go blackberrying with her’
‘I was BlackBerrying them while the speech was going on’
‘they blogged, BlackBerried, and texted—sometimes contacting someone only a few feet away’

--Word--
blackbird 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An Old World thrush with mainly black plumage.
A New World songbird with a strong pointed bill. The male has black plumage that is iridescent or has patches of red or yellow.
A black or Polynesian captive on a slave ship.
--Examples--
--Word--
blackbirder 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person engaged in press-ganging or kidnapping labourers in the south Pacific region for work on the sugar plantations.
A ship engaged in this trade.
--Examples--
--Word--
blackbirding 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The practice of kidnapping Pacific Islanders and using them as forced labour, in particular on sugar and cotton plantations in Australia.
--Examples--
‘the island's population was severely depleted by blackbirding’

brown 
--Type--
adjective, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Of a colour produced by mixing red, yellow, and blue, as of dark wood or rich soil.
(of bread) light brown in colour and typically made with unbleached or unrefined wholemeal flour.
Dark-skinned or suntanned.
Relating or belonging to a human group characterized as having relatively dark-coloured skin (chiefly used of peoples of ancestry other than European or African)
Brown colour or pigment.
Brown clothes or material.
A brown thing, in particular the brown ball in snooker.
A satyrid butterfly, which typically has brown wings with small eyespots.
Make or become brown, typically by cooking.
--Examples--
‘an old brown coat’
‘she had warm brown eyes’
‘a slice of brown toast with low fat spread’
‘his face was brown from the sun’

‘a pair of boots in brown’
‘the print is rich with velvety browns’
‘a woman all in brown’
‘a skillet in which food has been browned’
‘grill the pizza until the cheese has browned’

--Word--
black 
--Type--
adjective, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Of the very darkest colour owing to the absence of or complete absorption of light; the opposite of white.
(of the sky or night) completely dark owing to the sun, moon, or stars not being visible.
Deeply stained with dirt.
(of a plant or animal) dark in colour as distinguished from a lighter variety.
(of coffee or tea) served without milk.
Of or denoting the suits spades and clubs in a pack of cards.
(of a ski run) of the highest level of difficulty, as indicated by black markers positioned along it.
Belonging to or denoting any human group having dark-coloured skin, especially of African or Australian Aboriginal ancestry.
Relating to black people.
Characterized by tragic or disastrous events; causing despair or pessimism.
(of a person's state of mind) full of gloom or misery; very depressed.
(of humour) presenting tragic or harrowing situations in comic terms.
Full of anger or hatred.
Very evil or wicked.
Denoting a covert military procedure.
(of goods or work) not to be handled or undertaken by trade union members, especially so as to express support for an industrial dispute elsewhere.
Black colour or pigment.
Black clothes or material, typically worn as a sign of mourning.
Darkness, especially of night or an overcast sky.
The player of the black pieces in chess or draughts.
A black thing, in particular the black ball in snooker.
A member of a dark-skinned people, especially one of African or Australian Aboriginal ancestry.
The situation of not owing money to a bank or of making a profit in a business operation.
Blackcurrant cordial.
Make (something) black, especially with polish.
Make (one's face and other visible parts) black with polish or make-up so as not to be seen at night or to play the role of a black person in a play or film.
Refuse to handle (goods), undertake (work), or have dealings with (a person or business) as a way of taking industrial action.
--Examples--
‘black smoke’
‘her long black hair’
‘the sky was moonless and black’
‘the walls were black with age and dirt’
‘Japanese black pine’
‘a mug of black coffee’
‘Doyle took his coffee black’
‘black adolescents of Jamaican descent’
‘black culture’
‘five thousand men were killed on the blackest day of the war’
‘the future looks black’
‘Jean had disappeared and Mary was in a black mood’
‘‘Good place to bury the bodies,’ she joked with black humour’
‘Rory shot her a black look’
‘my soul is steeped in the blackest sin’
‘clearance for black operations came from the highest political level’
‘the union declared the ship black’
‘a tray decorated in black and green’
‘only one or two of the mourners were in black’
‘the only thing visible in the black was the light of the torch’
‘Black's king's defences are somewhat weakened’
‘they tend to identify strongly with other blacks’
‘it is hoped the club will be back in the black by the end of the season’
‘I managed to break even in the first six months—quite a short time for a small business to get into the black’
‘an insurance company operating in the black will be able to pay for further growth’
‘a rum and black’
‘the steps of the house were neatly blacked’
‘white extras blacking up their faces to play Ethiopians’
‘the union blacked the film because overtime was not being paid’

--Word--
black-eyed 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having black eyes (often regarded as a mark of beauty).
Designating any of several varieties of pea or bean having a black spot or mark on the seed. In later use: specifically a variety of the cowpea, Vigna unguiculata.
--Examples--
--Word--
blacken 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Make or become black or dark, especially as a result of burning, decay, or bruising.
Dye or colour (the face or hair) black for camouflage or cosmetic effect.
Damage or destroy (someone's reputation) by speaking badly of them.
--Examples--
‘stone blackened by the soot of ages’
‘he set light to the paper, watching the end blacken as it burned’
‘paras in full combat gear with blackened faces’
‘she won't thank you for blackening her husband's name’

black 
--Type--
adjective, noun, verb

Of the very darkest colour owing to the absence of or complete absorption of light; the opposite of white.

(of a plant or animal) dark in colour as distinguished from a lighter variety.
(of coffee or tea) served without milk.
Of or denoting the suits spades and clubs in a pack of cards.
(of a ski run) of the highest level of difficulty, as indicated by black markers positioned along it.
Belonging to or denoting any human group having dark-coloured skin, especially of African or Australian Aboriginal ancestry.
Relating to black people.
Characterized by tragic or disastrous events; causing despair or pessimism.
(of a person's state of mind) full of gloom or misery; very depressed.
(of humour) presenting tragic or harrowing situations in comic terms.
Full of anger or hatred.
Very evil or wicked.
Denoting a covert military procedure.
(of goods or work) not to be handled or undertaken by trade union members, especially so as to express support for an industrial dispute elsewhere.
Black colour or pigment.
Black clothes or material, typically worn as a sign of mourning.
Darkness, especially of night or an overcast sky.
The player of the black pieces in chess or draughts.
A black thing, in particular the black ball in snooker.
A member of a dark-skinned people, especially one of African or Australian Aboriginal ancestry.
The situation of not owing money to a bank or of making a profit in a business operation.
Blackcurrant cordial.
Make (something) black, especially with polish.
Make (one's face and other visible parts) black with polish or make-up so as not to be seen at night or to play the role of a black person in a play or film.
Refuse to handle (goods), undertake (work), or have dealings with (a person or business) as a way of taking industrial action.
--Examples--
‘black smoke’
‘her long black hair’
‘the sky was moonless and black’
‘the walls were black with age and dirt’
‘Japanese black pine’
‘a mug of black coffee’
‘Doyle took his coffee black’
‘black adolescents of Jamaican descent’
‘black culture’
‘five thousand men were killed on the blackest day of the war’
‘the future looks black’
‘Jean had disappeared and Mary was in a black mood’
‘‘Good place to bury the bodies,’ she joked with black humour’
‘Rory shot her a black look’
‘my soul is steeped in the blackest sin’
‘clearance for black operations came from the highest political level’
‘the union declared the ship black’
‘a tray decorated in black and green’
‘only one or two of the mourners were in black’
‘the only thing visible in the black was the light of the torch’
‘Black's king's defences are somewhat weakened’
‘they tend to identify strongly with other blacks’
‘it is hoped the club will be back in the black by the end of the season’
‘I managed to break even in the first six months—quite a short time for a small business to get into the black’
‘an insurance company operating in the black will be able to pay for further growth’
‘a rum and black’
‘the steps of the house were neatly blacked’
‘white extras blacking up their faces to play Ethiopians’
‘the union blacked the film because overtime was not being paid’
--Word--
blacketeer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A trader in black-market goods; = "black marketeer".
--Examples--
--Word--
Blackett, Patrick 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
Baron (1897–1974), English physicist; full name Patrick Maynard Stuart Blackett. Blackett was a member of the Maud Committee, which dealt with the development of the atom bomb. He also modified the cloud chamber for the study of cosmic rays. Nobel Prize for Physics (1948).
--Examples--
--Word--
blackface 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A sheep of a breed with a black face.
Make-up used by a non-black performer playing a black role.
--Examples--
--Word--
black-faced 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of a thing (also with personification): dark, dismal, gloomy.
Of a person: having a dark-coloured or blackened face.
Of an animal: having a black or dark-coloured face.
Typography. Designating or printed in blackface type; bold.

--Word--
black 
--Type--
adjective, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Of the very darkest colour owing to the absence of or complete absorption of light; the opposite of white.
(of the sky or night) completely dark owing to the sun, moon, or stars not being visible.
Deeply stained with dirt.
(of a plant or animal) dark in colour as distinguished from a lighter variety.
(of coffee or tea) served without milk.
Of or denoting the suits spades and clubs in a pack of cards.
(of a ski run) of the highest level of difficulty, as indicated by black markers positioned along it.
Belonging to or denoting any human group having dark-coloured skin, especially of African or Australian Aboriginal ancestry.
Relating to black people.
Characterized by tragic or disastrous events; causing despair or pessimism.
(of a person's state of mind) full of gloom or misery; very depressed.
(of humour) presenting tragic or harrowing situations in comic terms.
Full of anger or hatred.
Very evil or wicked.
Denoting a covert military procedure.
(of goods or work) not to be handled or undertaken by trade union members, especially so as to express support for an industrial dispute elsewhere.

Black clothes or material, typically worn as a sign of mourning.
Darkness, especially of night or an overcast sky.
The player of the black pieces in chess or draughts.
A black thing, in particular the black ball in snooker.
A member of a dark-skinned people, especially one of African or Australian Aboriginal ancestry.
The situation of not owing money to a bank or of making a profit in a business operation.
Blackcurrant cordial.
Make (something) black, especially with polish.
Make (one's face and other visible parts) black with polish or make-up so as not to be seen at night or to play the role of a black person in a play or film.
Refuse to handle (goods), undertake (work), or have dealings with (a person or business) as a way of taking industrial action.

--Word--
Blackfoot 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a confederacy of North American peoples of the north-western plains. The Blackfoot confederacy was made up of three closely related tribes: the Blackfoot proper or Siksika, the Bloods, and the Peigan.
The Algonquian language of the Blackfoot, with about 6,000 speakers.
Relating to the Blackfoot or their language.
--Examples--

--Word--
black-figure 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A type of ancient Greek pottery, originating in Corinth in the 7th century BC, in which figures are painted in black, details being added by incising through to the red clay background.
--Examples--
‘a black-figure amphora’
--Word--

--Word--
blackfin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of various dark-finned fishes; especially (more fully "blackfin tuna") a small tuna of the western Atlantic, Thunnus atlanticus, having the second dorsal fin and the dorsal finlets all dark.
--Examples--
--Word--
blackfin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of various dark-finned fishes; especially (more fully "blackfin tuna") a small tuna of the western Atlantic, Thunnus atlanticus, having the second dorsal fin and the dorsal finlets all dark.

blackfly 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A black or dark green aphid which is a common pest of crops and gardens.
A small black fly, the female of which sucks blood and can transmit a number of serious human and animal diseases.

blacky
