noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A black person. Frequently without article, as though a proper name. Now offensive.

--Word--
blackleg 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A person who continues working when fellow workers are on strike; a strike-breaker.
An acute infectious bacterial disease of cattle and sheep, causing necrosis in one or more legs.
Any of a number of plant diseases in which part of the stem blackens and decays.
Continue working when one's fellow workers are on strike.
--Examples--
‘the blacklegs who had arrived by rail were harassed by crowds of workers’
‘blackleg labour’

--Word--
blackmail 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The action, treated as a criminal offence, of demanding money from someone in return for not revealing compromising information which one has about them.
Money demanded by a person or group engaged in blackmail.
The use of threats or the manipulation of someone's feelings to force them to do something.
Demand money from (someone) in return for not revealing compromising information about them.
Force (someone) to do something by using threats or manipulating their feelings.
--Examples--
‘they were acquitted of charges of blackmail’
‘she recounted the blackmail threats’
‘we do not pay blackmail’
‘some people use emotional blackmail’
‘they use this fact to blackmail him, trying to force him to vote for their candidate’
‘he had blackmailed her into sailing with him’

black marketeer

noun
--Meanings--
A person who trades illegally in officially controlled commodities.
--Examples--
‘most of the tickets had been sold to black marketeers’
--Word--
Blackmore, R. D. 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1825–1900), English novelist and poet; full name Richard Doddridge Blackmore. He is known for his romantic novel Lorna Doone (1869), set on 17th-century Exmoor.
--Examples--
--Word--
blackmouth 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A foul-mouthed person; a slanderer. Now rare.
Attributive Designating the black-mouthed dogfish, Galeus melastomus.
United States regional. The chinook salmon, Oncorhynchus tshawytscha; specifically an immature one.
--Examples--
--Word--
black-mouthed 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having a black mouth; (figurative) slanderous; foul-mouthed.
--Examples--
--Word--
Blackmun, Harry 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1908–99), US Supreme Court associate justice 1970–94; full name Harry Andrew Blackmun. He is noted as the author of Roe v. Wade, which ruled on the right to legal abortion in 1973.
--Examples--
--Word--
blackneb 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
English regional (northern) and Scottish. Any of various (chiefly black-billed) birds; especially the carrion crow, Corvus corone. Now historical.
Scottish depreciative. A blackleg, a strike-breaker; = "blacknob". Now historical.
--Examples--
--Word--
blackneb 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
English regional (northern) and Scottish. Any of various (chiefly black-billed) birds; especially the carrion crow, Corvus corone. Now historical.
Scottish depreciative. A blackleg, a strike-breaker; = "blacknob". Now historical.

--Word--
blackness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The property or quality of being black in colour.
Complete darkness; the absence of any light.
The fact or state of belonging to any human group having dark-coloured skin.
The quality or character associated with black people.
A state characterized by despair or depression.
A state or condition of being evil or wicked.
--Examples--
‘it restores grey hair to blackness’
‘the entire house was plunged into pitch blackness’
‘my experiences have made me far more aware of my blackness than ever before’
‘she holds that position not because of her blackness, but her effectiveness’
‘the blackness of his poetry is an inextricable aspect of his subject matter’
‘there is a little hope amid the blackness of his life’
‘the absolute depths of blackness and morbidity’
‘the blackness of the human heart through the atrocities of war’

--Word--
blackout 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A period when all lights must be turned out or covered to prevent them being seen by the enemy during an air raid.
Dark curtains put up in windows to cover lights during an air raid.
A failure of an electrical power supply.
A moment in the theatre when the lights on stage are suddenly dimmed.
A suppression of information, especially one imposed on the media by government.
A temporary loss of consciousness.
--Examples--
‘people found it difficult to travel in the blackout’
‘she peered out through the blackout curtains’
‘due to a power blackout their hotel was in total darkness’
‘the total information blackout on the series of meetings’
‘she was suffering from blackouts’

red-bellied black snake 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A venomous snake, Pseudechis porphyriacus (family Elapidae), which is glossy black with a reddish underside, found in eastern Australia; also called common black snake.

--Word--
black 
--Type--
adjective, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Of the very darkest colour owing to the absence of or complete absorption of light; the opposite of white.
(of the sky or night) completely dark owing to the sun, moon, or stars not being visible.
Deeply stained with dirt.
(of a plant or animal) dark in colour as distinguished from a lighter variety.
(of coffee or tea) served without milk.
Of or denoting the suits spades and clubs in a pack of cards.
(of a ski run) of the highest level of difficulty, as indicated by black markers positioned along it.
Belonging to or denoting any human group having dark-coloured skin, especially of African or Australian Aboriginal ancestry.
Relating to black people.
Characterized by tragic or disastrous events; causing despair or pessimism.
(of a person's state of mind) full of gloom or misery; very depressed.
(of humour) presenting tragic or harrowing situations in comic terms.
Full of anger or hatred.
Very evil or wicked.
Denoting a covert military procedure.
(of goods or work) not to be handled or undertaken by trade union members, especially so as to express support for an industrial dispute elsewhere.
Black colour or pigment.
Black clothes or material, typically worn as a sign of mourning.
Darkness, especially of night or an overcast sky.
The player of the black pieces in chess or draughts.
A black thing, in particular the black ball in snooker.
A member of a dark-skinned people, especially one of African or Australian Aboriginal ancestry.
The situation of not owing money to a bank or of making a profit in a business operation.
Blackcurrant cordial.
Make (something) black, especially with polish.
Make (one's face and other visible parts) black with polish or make-up so as not to be seen at night or to play the role of a black person in a play or film.
Refuse to handle (goods), undertake (work), or have dealings with (a person or business) as a way of taking industrial action.
--Examples--
‘black smoke’
‘her long black hair’
‘the sky was moonless and black’
‘the walls were black with age and dirt’
‘Japanese black pine’
‘a mug of black coffee’
‘Doyle took his coffee black’
‘black adolescents of Jamaican descent’
‘black culture’
‘five thousand men were killed on the blackest day of the war’
‘the future looks black’
‘Jean had disappeared and Mary was in a black mood’
‘‘Good place to bury the bodies,’ she joked with black humour’
‘Rory shot her a black look’
‘my soul is steeped in the blackest sin’
‘clearance for black operations came from the highest political level’
‘the union declared the ship black’
‘a tray decorated in black and green’
‘only one or two of the mourners were in black’
‘the only thing visible in the black was the light of the torch’
‘Black's king's defences are somewhat weakened’
‘they tend to identify strongly with other blacks’
‘it is hoped the club will be back in the black by the end of the season’
‘I managed to break even in the first six months—quite a short time for a small business to get into the black’
‘an insurance company operating in the black will be able to pay for further growth’
‘a rum and black’
‘the steps of the house were neatly blacked’
‘white extras blacking up their faces to play Ethiopians’
‘the union blacked the film because overtime was not being paid’

--Word--
Blackstone River 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A river that flows south for 50 miles (80 km) through Worcester, Massachusetts, to Pawtucket, Rhode Island, below which it is called the Seekonk River. The Blackstone Valley was a site of early US industrial development.
--Examples--
--Word--
blackstrap 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A dark, viscous molasses, the byproduct of the final extraction phase of sugar refining, used chiefly in cattle feed and in the industrial production of citric acid and vinegar.
--Examples--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
South African. A white sea bream (genus Diplodus, family Sparidae); especially the dassie, D. capensis.
North American. The black-tailed or mule deer, Odocoileus hemionus, of western North America.

--Word--
black 
--Type--
adjective, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Of the very darkest colour owing to the absence of or complete absorption of light; the opposite of white.
(of the sky or night) completely dark owing to the sun, moon, or stars not being visible.
Deeply stained with dirt.
(of a plant or animal) dark in colour as distinguished from a lighter variety.
(of coffee or tea) served without milk.

Relating to black people.
Characterized by tragic or disastrous events; causing despair or pessimism.
(of a person's state of mind) full of gloom or misery; very depressed.
(of humour) presenting tragic or harrowing situations in comic terms.
Full of anger or hatred.
Very evil or wicked.
Denoting a covert military procedure.
(of goods or work) not to be handled or undertaken by trade union members, especially so as to express support for an industrial dispute elsewhere.
Black colour or pigment.
Black clothes or material, typically worn as a sign of mourning.
Darkness, especially of night or an overcast sky.

A black thing, in particular the black ball in snooker.
A member of a dark-skinned people, especially one of African or Australian Aboriginal ancestry.
The situation of not owing money to a bank or of making a profit in a business operation.
Blackcurrant cordial.
Make (something) black, especially with polish.
Make (one's face and other visible parts) black with polish or make-up so as not to be seen at night or to play the role of a black person in a play or film.
Refuse to handle (goods), undertake (work), or have dealings with (a person or business) as a way of taking industrial action.

Blackwell, Elizabeth 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1821–1910), US physician, born in England. She was the first woman to receive a medical degree in the US (1849) and the first woman listed in the Medical Register of the United Kingdom (1859).

bladderwort

noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
blade 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The flat cutting edge of a knife, saw, or other tool or weapon.
A sword.
Hand shears used in sheep shearing.
A long, narrow flake.
The flat, wide section of an implement or device such as an oar or a propeller.
A thin, flat metal runner on an ice skate.
A prosthetic lower limb designed for athletes, consisting of a flattened length of carbon fibre with a long, curved section at the base.
A shoulder bone in a joint of meat, or the joint itself.
The flat part of the tongue behind the tip.
A long, narrow leaf of grass or another similar plant.
The broad, thin part of a leaf apart from the stalk.
A dashing or energetic young man.
Skate using Rollerblades.
--Examples--
‘cut cleanly using a sharp blade’
‘Lydia is being taught to run on blades’
‘the Paralympics brought prosthetics such as running blades into the limelight’
‘a blade of grass’
‘the director, a young blade in an oversized suit’
‘she loves to run, bike, blade, and explore the city’
‘blading with the wind in your face…that's really nice’

--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
blade 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The flat cutting edge of a knife, saw, or other tool or weapon.
A sword.
Hand shears used in sheep shearing.
A long, narrow flake.
The flat, wide section of an implement or device such as an oar or a propeller.
A thin, flat metal runner on an ice skate.
A prosthetic lower limb designed for athletes, consisting of a flattened length of carbon fibre with a long, curved section at the base.
A shoulder bone in a joint of meat, or the joint itself.
The flat part of the tongue behind the tip.
A long, narrow leaf of grass or another similar plant.
The broad, thin part of a leaf apart from the stalk.
A dashing or energetic young man.
Skate using Rollerblades.
--Examples--
‘cut cleanly using a sharp blade’
‘Lydia is being taught to run on blades’
‘the Paralympics brought prosthetics such as running blades into the limelight’
‘a blade of grass’
‘the director, a young blade in an oversized suit’
‘she loves to run, bike, blade, and explore the city’
‘blading with the wind in your face…that's really nice’

--Meanings--
--Examples--

--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
blagging 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of obtaining something by using persuasion or guile.
The action of obtaining private or confidential information by impersonation or another method of deception.
--Examples--
‘most people are comfortable with some level of blagging’
‘blagging is an offence under the Data Protection Act’
--Word--
blague 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A joke or piece of nonsense.
--Examples--
--Word--
blagueur 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who talks nonsense.
--Examples--
--Word--
blah 
--Type--
noun, adjective, exclamation
--Meanings--
Used to refer to something which is boring or without meaningful content.
Depression.
Dull or unexciting.
Used to substitute for actual words in contexts where they are felt to be too tedious or lengthy to give in full.
--Examples--
‘the first 20 pages are a lot of blah about budgets and stuff like that’
‘a case of the blahs’
‘the game has been very blah’
‘he said nations great and small could come together to blah blah blah’

--Word--
Port Blair 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A port on the southern tip of South Andaman Island in the Bay of Bengal; population 127,100 (est. 2009). It is the capital of the Andaman and Nicobar Islands.
--Examples--
--Word--
Blairism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The policies and principles advocated by former British Prime Minister Tony Blair.
--Examples--
‘the rise of Blairism’
--Word--
Pascal, Blaise 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1623–62), French mathematician, physicist, and religious philosopher. He founded the theory of probabilities and developed a forerunner of integral calculus, but is best known for deriving the principle that the pressure of a fluid at rest is transmitted equally in all directions. His Lettres Provinciales (1656–7) and Pensées (1670) argue for his Jansenist Christianity.
--Examples--
--Word--
Blake, William 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1757–1827), English artist and poet. Blake's poems mark the beginning of romanticism and a rejection of the Age of Enlightenment. His watercolours and engravings, like his writings, were only fully appreciated after his death. Notable collections of poems: Songs of Innocence (1789) and Songs of Experience (1794).
--Examples--
--Word--
Blake, William 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1757–1827), English artist and poet. Blake's poems mark the beginning of romanticism and a rejection of the Age of Enlightenment. His watercolours and engravings, like his writings, were only fully appreciated after his death. Notable collections of poems: Songs of Innocence (1789) and Songs of Experience (1794).
--Examples--

blam 
--Type--
exclamation
--Meanings--
Used to represent a loud sharp sound, as of a gunshot or explosion.
--Examples--
‘Blam! There is an explosion and nothing is the same’

--Word--
blame 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Feel or declare that (someone or something) is responsible for a fault or wrong.
Assign the responsibility for a bad or unfortunate situation or phenomenon to (someone or something)
Responsibility for a fault or wrong.
--Examples--
‘the inquiry blamed the train driver for the accident’
‘they blame youth crime on unemployment’
‘his players had to take the blame for the defeat’
‘they are trying to put the blame on us’

--Word--
blanch 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Make white or pale by extracting colour.
Whiten (a plant) by depriving it of light.
Flinch or grow pale from shock, fear, or a similar emotion.
Prepare (vegetables) for freezing or further cooking by immersing briefly in boiling water.
Peel (almonds) by scalding them.
--Examples--
‘the cold light blanched her face’
‘blanch endive by covering plants with large flowerpots’
‘he visibly blanched at this reminder of mortality’
‘blanch corn in boiling water for one minute’
‘blanched almonds’
--Word--
Blanchard, Jean-Pierre 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1753–1809), French balloonist; full name Jean-Pierre François Blanchard. He made the first crossing of the English Channel by air, flying by balloon, on 7 January 1785.
--Examples--

--Word--
bland 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Lacking strong features or characteristics and therefore uninteresting.
(of food or drink) unseasoned, mild-tasting, or insipid.
Showing no strong emotion.
--Examples--
‘bland, mass-produced pop music’
‘a bland and unadventurous vegetarian dish’
‘standardized bland beers of mediocre quality’
‘his expression was bland and unreadable’
--Word--
Blanda, George 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(born 1927), US football player; full name George Frederick Blanda. He scored 2,002 points in professional football, chiefly as a placekicker. He played the most games (340) for the most seasons (26). Football Hall of Fame (1981).
--Examples--
--Word--
blandness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Lack of strong emotions, features, or characteristics.
(with reference to food or drink) the quality of being unseasoned, mild-tasting, or insipid.
--Examples--
‘the overall blandness of his performance’
‘the boneless chops were underseasoned to the point of blandness’

--Word--
blank 
--Type--
adjective, noun, verb
--Meanings--
(of a surface or background) unrelieved by decorative or other features; bare, empty, or plain.
Not written or printed on.
(of a document) with spaces left for a signature or details.
(of a tape) with nothing recorded on it.
Showing a lack of comprehension or reaction.
Temporarily having no knowledge or understanding.
Lacking incident or result.
Complete; absolute (used emphatically with negative force)
Used euphemistically in place of an adjective regarded as obscene, profane, or abusive.
A space left to be filled in a document.
A document with blank spaces to be filled.
A domino with one or both halves blank.
A cartridge containing gunpowder but no bullet, used for training or as a signal.
An empty space or period of time, especially in terms of a lack of knowledge or understanding.
A piece of metal or wood intended for further shaping or finishing.
A plain metal disc from which a coin is made by stamping a design on it.
A dash written instead of a word or letter, especially instead of an obscenity or profanity.
Used euphemistically in place of a noun regarded as obscene, profane, or abusive.
Make (something) blank or empty.
Become blank or empty.
Cut (a metal blank)
Defeat (a sports team) without allowing them to score.
Deliberately ignore (someone)
--Examples--
‘a blank wall’
‘the screen went blank’
‘a blank sheet of paper’
‘blank tax-return forms’
‘blank cassettes’
‘we were met by blank looks’
‘her mind went blank’
‘those blank moments aboard airplanes’
‘he was met with a blank refusal to discuss the issue’
‘show the miserable blank-blank Englishman how to fight this war’
‘leave blanks to type in the appropriate names’
‘my mind was a total blank’
‘electronic countermeasures blanked out the radar signals’
‘the picture blanked out’
‘the complete core disc can be blanked out in one piece’
‘Baltimore blanked Toronto in a 7–0 victory’
‘I just blanked them and walked out’

‘he was met with a blank refusal to discuss the issue’
‘show the miserable blank-blank Englishman how to fight this war’
‘leave blanks to type in the appropriate names’
‘my mind was a total blank’
‘electronic countermeasures blanked out the radar signals’
‘the picture blanked out’
‘the complete core disc can be blanked out in one piece’
‘Baltimore blanked Toronto in a 7–0 victory’
‘I just blanked them and walked out’
--Word--
blank 
--Type--
adjective, noun, verb
--Meanings--
(of a surface or background) unrelieved by decorative or other features; bare, empty, or plain.
Not written or printed on.
(of a document) with spaces left for a signature or details.
(of a tape) with nothing recorded on it.
Showing a lack of comprehension or reaction.
Temporarily having no knowledge or understanding.
Lacking incident or result.
Complete; absolute (used emphatically with negative force)
Used euphemistically in place of an adjective regarded as obscene, profane, or abusive.
A space left to be filled in a document.
A document with blank spaces to be filled.
A domino with one or both halves blank.
A cartridge containing gunpowder but no bullet, used for training or as a signal.
An empty space or period of time, especially in terms of a lack of knowledge or understanding.
A piece of metal or wood intended for further shaping or finishing.
A plain metal disc from which a coin is made by stamping a design on it.
A dash written instead of a word or letter, especially instead of an obscenity or profanity.
Used euphemistically in place of a noun regarded as obscene, profane, or abusive.
Make (something) blank or empty.
Become blank or empty.
Cut (a metal blank)
Defeat (a sports team) without allowing them to score.
Deliberately ignore (someone)
--Examples--
‘a blank wall’
‘the screen went blank’
‘a blank sheet of paper’
‘blank tax-return forms’
‘blank cassettes’
‘we were met by blank looks’
‘her mind went blank’
‘those blank moments aboard airplanes’
‘he was met with a blank refusal to discuss the issue’
‘show the miserable blank-blank Englishman how to fight this war’
‘leave blanks to type in the appropriate names’
‘my mind was a total blank’
‘electronic countermeasures blanked out the radar signals’
‘the picture blanked out’
‘the complete core disc can be blanked out in one piece’
‘Baltimore blanked Toronto in a 7–0 victory’
‘I just blanked them and walked out’
--Word--
blanket 
--Type--
noun, adjective, verb
--Meanings--
A large piece of woollen or similar material used as a covering on a bed or elsewhere for warmth.
A thick covering mass or layer.
A rubber surface used for transferring the image in ink from the plate to the paper in offset printing.
Covering all cases or instances; total and inclusive.
Cover completely with a thick layer of something.
Stifle or keep quiet (sound)
Take wind from the sails of (another craft) by passing to windward.
--Examples--
‘I slept on the ground covered by my blanket’
‘a dense grey blanket of cloud’
‘a blanket ban on tobacco advertising’
‘the countryside was blanketed in snow’
‘the double glazing blankets the noise a bit’

--Word--
blankly 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In a way that is plain and characterized by a lack of decorative or other features.
In a way that shows a lack of interest or engagement.
In a way that temporarily shows no emotion or understanding, especially as a result of shock.
In an absolute or blunt manner.
--Examples--
‘the suburbs that stretch blankly along the routes out from the city’
‘his clothes are blankly white’
‘the class looked back blankly’
‘my home life consists of staring blankly at the television’
‘he stared blankly at the freshly dug grave and new tombstone’
‘the policeman's jaw had dropped in bewilderment and he was eyeing him blankly’
‘the hospital has blankly refused to carry out tests’
‘officials have stated blankly that they will never extradite the operatives’

--Word--
blarney 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
Talk which aims to charm, flatter, or persuade (often considered typical of Irish people)

Influence or persuade (someone) using charm and pleasant flattery.
--Examples--

‘this story is perhaps just a bit of blarney’
‘he went overboard in blarneying him into thinking that Joe considered him a nice guy’

--Word--
blast 
--Type--
noun, verb, exclamation
--Meanings--
A destructive wave of highly compressed air spreading outwards from an explosion.
An explosion or explosive firing.
A forceful attack or assault.
A strong gust of wind or air.
A strong current of air used in smelting.
A single loud note of a horn, whistle, or similar.
A severe reprimand.
An enjoyable experience or lively party.
Blow up or break apart (something solid) with explosives.
Produce (damage) by means of an explosion.
Force or throw (something) in a specified direction by impact or explosion.
Shoot with a gun.
Move very quickly and loudly in a specified direction.
Produce or cause to produce loud continuous music or other noise.
Kick or strike (a ball) hard.
Criticize fiercely.
(of a wind or other natural force) wither, shrivel, or blight (a plant)
Strike with divine anger (used to express annoyance or dislike)
Destroy or ruin.
Expressing annoyance.
--Examples--
‘they were thrown backwards by the blast’
‘a bomb blast’
‘a shotgun blast’
‘United's four-goal blast’
‘the icy blast hit them’
‘a blast of the ship's siren’
‘I braced myself for the inevitable blast’
‘it could turn out to be a real blast’
‘the school was blasted by an explosion’
‘the force of the collision blasted out a tremendous crater’
‘the car was blasted thirty feet into the sky’
‘Fowler was blasted with an air rifle’
‘four low-flying jets blasted down the glen’
‘music blasted out at full volume’
‘an impatient motorist blasted his horn’
‘the striker blasted the free kick into the net’
‘the school was blasted by government inspectors’
‘corn blasted before it be grown up’
‘damn and blast this awful place!’
‘your reputation is blasted already in the village’
‘‘Blast! The car won't start!’’

blaster 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person or thing that emits or uses blasts.
(in science fiction) a weapon like a gun that is able to destroy something solid, typically using light or sound energy.
A move in which a ball is kicked or struck forcefully.
A type of physical exercise intended to strengthen specific muscle groups.
--Examples--
‘blasters were paid according to how much rock they broke’
‘don't try to stand in the way of laser blasters’
‘where was a super sonic death ray blaster gun when you needed one?’
‘he let fly with a 35-yard blaster’
‘the glute blaster’
‘squats represent a total blaster for quads’

--Word--
freeze 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
(with reference to a liquid) turn or be turned into ice or another solid as a result of extreme cold.
Become or cause to become blocked, covered, or rigid with ice.
Be so cold that one feels near death (often used hyperbolically)
(of the weather) be at or below freezing.
Deprive (a part of the body) of feeling, especially by the application of a chilled anaesthetic substance.
Stare coldly at (someone); treat coldly.
Store (something) at a very low temperature in order to preserve it.
(of food) be able to be preserved at a very low temperature.
Become suddenly motionless or paralysed with fear or shock.
Stop moving when ordered.
Hold (something) at a fixed level or in a fixed state for a period of time.
Prevent (assets) from being used for a period of time.
Stop (a moving image) at a particular frame when filming or viewing.
(of a computer screen) become temporarily locked because of system problems.
An act of holding or being held at a fixed level or in a fixed state.
A period of frost or very cold weather.
--Examples--
‘in the winter the milk froze’
‘frost freezes water that has seeped into joints’
‘the pipes had frozen’
‘the ground was frozen hard’
‘you'll freeze to death standing there’
‘at night it froze again’
‘she would freeze him with a look when he tried to talk to her’
‘the cake can be frozen’
‘this soup freezes well’
‘she froze in horror’
‘she came out with a revolver and told the boys to freeze’
‘new spending on defence was to be frozen’
‘the charity's bank account has been frozen’
‘the camera will set fast shutter speeds to freeze the action’
‘workers faced a pay freeze’
‘the big freeze surprised the weathermen’
--Word--
blast freezing 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The freezing of something, especially food, by means of a rapid current of chilled air.
--Examples--
--Word--
frozen 
--Type--
UnKnownKind, adjective
--Meanings--
(of a liquid) having turned into ice as a result of extreme cold.
Covered or rigid with ice.
(of food) stored at a very low temperature in order to preserve it.
(used hyperbolically) very cold.
--Examples--
‘frozen wastes’
‘frozen fish’
‘the wind whistled in my hair, and I was absolutely frozen’
--Word--
blast furnace 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A smelting furnace in the form of a tower into which a blast of hot compressed air can be introduced from below. Such furnaces are used chiefly to make iron from a mixture of iron ore, coke, and limestone.
--Examples--
--Word--
blaster 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person or thing that emits or uses blasts.
(in science fiction) a weapon like a gun that is able to destroy something solid, typically using light or sound energy.
A move in which a ball is kicked or struck forcefully.
A type of physical exercise intended to strengthen specific muscle groups.
--Examples--
‘blasters were paid according to how much rock they broke’
‘don't try to stand in the way of laser blasters’
‘where was a super sonic death ray blaster gun when you needed one?’
‘he let fly with a 35-yard blaster’
‘the glute blaster’
‘squats represent a total blaster for quads’
--Word--
blast 
--Type--
noun, verb, exclamation
--Meanings--
A destructive wave of highly compressed air spreading outwards from an explosion.
An explosion or explosive firing.
A forceful attack or assault.
A strong gust of wind or air.
A strong current of air used in smelting.
A single loud note of a horn, whistle, or similar.
A severe reprimand.
An enjoyable experience or lively party.
Blow up or break apart (something solid) with explosives.
Produce (damage) by means of an explosion.
Force or throw (something) in a specified direction by impact or explosion.
Shoot with a gun.
Move very quickly and loudly in a specified direction.
Produce or cause to produce loud continuous music or other noise.
Kick or strike (a ball) hard.
Criticize fiercely.
(of a wind or other natural force) wither, shrivel, or blight (a plant)
Strike with divine anger (used to express annoyance or dislike)
Destroy or ruin.
Expressing annoyance.
--Examples--
‘they were thrown backwards by the blast’
‘a bomb blast’
‘a shotgun blast’
‘United's four-goal blast’
‘the icy blast hit them’
‘a blast of the ship's siren’
‘I braced myself for the inevitable blast’
‘it could turn out to be a real blast’
‘the school was blasted by an explosion’
‘the force of the collision blasted out a tremendous crater’
‘the car was blasted thirty feet into the sky’
‘Fowler was blasted with an air rifle’
‘four low-flying jets blasted down the glen’
‘music blasted out at full volume’
‘an impatient motorist blasted his horn’
‘the striker blasted the free kick into the net’
‘the school was blasted by government inspectors’
‘corn blasted before it be grown up’
‘damn and blast this awful place!’
‘your reputation is blasted already in the village’
‘‘Blast! The car won't start!’’

blastogenesis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The theory of the transmission of inherited characteristics by germ plasm.

The development of lymphocytes into larger undifferentiated cells that can undergo mitosis.

blatant 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of bad behaviour) done openly and unashamedly.

‘despite their blatant attraction to each other they try to stay just friends’
‘incredibly blatant product placement’

adverb

‘she didn't want to be blatantly rude’
‘it's blatantly her first kiss’

--Word--
Blavatsky, Helena 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1831–91), Russian spiritualist, born in Ukraine; born Helena Petrovna Hahn; known as Madame Blavatsky; full name Helena Petrovna Blavatsky. In 1875 she co-founded the Theosophical Society in New York.
--Examples--
--Word--
blaze 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A very large or fiercely burning fire.
A very bright display of light or colour.
A conspicuous display or outburst of something.
Used in various expressions of anger, bewilderment, or surprise as a euphemism for ‘hell’
Burn fiercely or brightly.
Burst into flame.
Shine brightly or powerfully.
Fire a gun repeatedly or indiscriminately.
Achieve something in an impressive manner.
Hit (a ball) with impressive strength.
Smoke cannabis.
--Examples--
‘twenty firemen fought the blaze’
‘the gardens in summer are a blaze of colour’
‘White ended the season in a blaze of glory, with seven goals in as many games’
‘their relationship broke up in a blaze of publicity’
‘‘Go to blazes!’ he shouted’
‘what the blazes are you all talking about?’
‘the fire blazed merrily’
‘he attacked the fire with poker and tongs until it blazed up’
‘the sun blazed down’
‘Barbara's eyes were blazing with anger’
‘they stormed with main entrance with guns blazing’
‘she blazed to a gold medal in the 200-metre sprint’
‘he blazed a drive into the rough’

blazon 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Display prominently or vividly.
Report (news), especially in a sensational manner.
Describe or depict (armorial bearings) in a correct heraldic manner.
Inscribe or paint (an object) with arms or a name.
A correct description of armorial bearings.
A coat of arms.
--Examples--
‘they saw their company name blazoned all over the media’
‘accounts of their ordeal were blazoned to the entire nation’
‘the book contains tens of thousands of blazons of arms held by English families’
‘his knowledge of medieval blazon was unrivalled’

--Word--
bleach 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Cause (a material such as cloth, paper, or hair) to become white or much lighter by a chemical process or by exposure to sunlight.
Deprive of vitality or substance.
Clean or sterilize (a drain, sink, etc.) with bleach.
A chemical (typically a solution of sodium hypochlorite or hydrogen peroxide) used to make materials whiter or for sterilizing drains, sinks, etc.
--Examples--
‘a new formula to bleach and brighten clothing’
‘his contributions to the album are bleached of personality’
‘how can I get all those stains out of my wash without bleach?’
--Word--
bleacher 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person or thing that bleaches.
A cheap bench seat at a sports ground, typically in an outdoor uncovered stand.
--Examples--
‘there's a pudgy man in the bleachers pacing the aisles’

--Meanings--
(of an area of land) lacking vegetation and exposed to the elements.
(of a building or room) charmless and inhospitable; dreary.
(of the weather) cold and miserable.
(of a situation) not hopeful or encouraging; unlikely to have a favourable outcome.
(of a person's expression) cold and forbidding.
A small silvery shoaling fish of the carp family, found in Eurasian rivers.
--Examples--
‘a bleak and barren moor’
‘he looked round the bleak little room in despair’
‘a bleak midwinter's day’
‘he paints a bleak picture of a company that has lost its way’
‘the future looks bleak’
‘his mouth was set and his eyes were bleak’
--Word--
bleak 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
bleakness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The quality or state of being bare and inhospitable.
The quality or state of cold and miserable weather.
The quality or state of being hopeless, discouraging, or unlikely to have a favourable outcome.
--Examples--
‘the bleakness of that destroyed landscape’
‘the grim concrete bleakness’
‘the bleakness of winter’
‘the evening's rainy bleakness’
‘this story is marked by unrelenting bleakness’
‘the atrocities and bleakness of war’

--Word--
bleat 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
(of a sheep, goat, or calf) make a characteristic weak, wavering cry.
Speak or complain in a weak, querulous, or foolish way.
The weak, wavering cry made by a sheep, goat, or calf.
A person's weak or plaintive cry.
A complaint.
--Examples--
‘the lamb was bleating weakly’
‘it's no good just bleating on about the rising tide of crime’
‘the distant bleat of sheep’
‘his despairing bleat touched her heart’
‘they're hoping that I'll bow to their idiotic arrangements without a bleat’

--Word--
bleed 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Lose blood from the body as a result of injury or illness.
Draw blood from (someone), especially as a former method of treatment in medicine.
Drain (someone) of money or resources.
Allow (fluid or gas) to escape from a closed system through a valve.
Release fluid or gas from (a closed system) by allowing air to escape through a valve.
(of a liquid substance such as dye or colour) seep into an adjacent colour or area.
(with reference to an illustration or design) print or be printed so that it runs off the page after trimming.
An instance of bleeding.
The escape of fluid or gas from a closed system through a valve.
An instance of printing an illustration or design so as to leave no margin after the page has been trimmed.
The seeping of a dye or colour into an adjacent colour or area.
--Examples--
‘the cut was bleeding steadily’
‘some casualties were left to bleed to death’
‘the bleeding has stopped now’
‘he didn't bleed his patients with leeches’
‘his policy of attempting to bleed British unions of funds’
‘open the isolating valves and bleed air from the pump chamber’
‘air can be got rid of by bleeding the radiator at the vent’
‘I worked loosely with the oils, allowing colours to bleed into one another’
‘the picture bleeds on three sides’
‘a lot of blood was lost from the placental bleed’
‘check the amount of air bleed from the compressor’
‘open the bleed valve’
‘the picture has an unfortunate bleed’
‘colour bleed is apparent on brighter hues’

--Word--
bleeder 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person regarded with contempt or pity.
A person who bleeds easily, especially a haemophiliac.
A ground ball hit that barely passes between two infielders.
--Examples--
‘the poor bleeder split his head open’

--Word--
bleep 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A short high-pitched sound made by an electronic device as a signal or to attract attention.
A short high-pitched electronic sound used in broadcasting as a substitute for a censored word or phrase.
(of an electronic device) make a short high-pitched sound or sounds as a signal or to attract attention.
Summon (someone) with a bleeper.
Substitute a bleep or bleeps for (a censored word or phrase)
--Examples--
‘when your food was ready for eating, the microwave told you so with five bleeps’
‘the screen flickered for a few moments and bleeped’
‘I'll get Jan to bleep you if I need transport’
‘I may have to bleep a few words in his testimony’

--Word--
blemish 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A small mark or flaw which spoils the appearance of something.
A moral defect or fault.
Spoil the appearance or quality of (something)
--Examples--
‘the girl's hands were without a blemish’
‘the offences were an uncharacteristic blemish on an otherwise clean record’
‘local government is not without blemish’
‘my main problem was a blemished skin’
‘his reign as world champion has been blemished by controversy’

--Word--
blend 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Mix (a substance) with another substance so that they combine together.
Mix (different types of the same substance, such as tea, coffee, spirits, etc.) together so as to make a product of the desired quality.
Put or combine (abstract things) together.
Merge (a colour) with another so that one is not clearly distinguishable from the other.
Form a harmonious combination.
Be an unobtrusive or harmonious part of a greater whole by being similar in appearance or behaviour.
A mixture of different substances or other things.
A mixture of different types of the same substance.
A word made up of parts of two other words and combining their meanings, for example motel from motor and hotel.
--Examples--
‘blend the cornflour with a tablespoon of water’
‘add the grated cheese and blend well’
‘a blended whisky’
‘I blend basic information for the novice with some scientific gardening for the more experienced’
‘blend and smudge the darker colours under the bottom lashes’
‘costumes, music, and lighting all blend together beautifully’
‘she would have to employ a permanent bodyguard in the house, someone who would blend in’
‘the chutney is a blend of bananas, raisins, and ginger’
‘Ontario offers a cultural blend you'll find nowhere else on earth’
‘nearly all Scotch whiskies are blends’
--Word--
blende 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--

‘Ontario offers a cultural blend you'll find nowhere else on earth’
‘nearly all Scotch whiskies are blends’
--Word--
Blenheim 
--Type--
proper noun, noun
--Meanings--
A battle in 1704 in Bavaria, near the village of Blindheim, in which the English, under the Duke of Marlborough, defeated the French and the Bavarians.
The Duke of Marlborough's seat at Woodstock near Oxford, a stately home designed by Vanbrugh (1705). The house and its estate were given to the first Duke of Marlborough in honour of his victory at Blenheim.
A dog of a small red and white breed of spaniel.
--Examples--
--Word--
blenny 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small spiny-finned marine fish with scaleless skin and a blunt head, typically living in shallow inshore or intertidal waters.
Used in names of other small fishes that resemble or are related to the true blennies, e.g. eel blenny.
--Examples--
--Word--
blenny 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small spiny-finned marine fish with scaleless skin and a blunt head, typically living in shallow inshore or intertidal waters.
Used in names of other small fishes that resemble or are related to the true blennies, e.g. eel blenny.

Blériot, Louis 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1872–1936), French aviation pioneer. On 25 July 1909 he became the first to fly the English Channel (Calais to Dover), in a monoplane of his own design.
--Examples--
--Word--
blesbok 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An antelope with a mainly reddish-brown coat and white face, found in south-western South Africa. It belongs to the same species as the bontebok.

--Word--
bless 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Pronounce words in a religious rite in order to confer or invoke divine favour upon; ask God to look favourably on.
(especially in Christian church services) call (God) holy; praise (God).
(of God or some notional higher power) endow someone with (a particular cherished thing or attribute)
Express or feel gratitude to; thank.
Make the sign of the cross.
Used in expressions of surprise, endearment, gratitude, etc.
--Examples--
‘he blessed the dying man and anointed him’
‘we have been blessed with a beautiful baby boy’
‘a beautiful city blessed with huge sandy beaches’
‘she silently blessed the premonition which had made her pack her best dress’
‘the poor parson, blessing himself, brought up the rear’
‘bless my soul, Alan, what are you doing?’
‘Nurse Jones, bless her, had made a pot of tea’
‘she even bought me a little present—bless!’
--Word--
blessed 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Made holy; consecrated.
A title preceding the name of a dead person considered to have led a holy life, especially a person formally beatified by the Roman Catholic Church.
Endowed with divine favour and protection.
Those who live with God in heaven.
Bringing pleasure or relief as a welcome contrast to what one has previously experienced.
Used in mild expressions of annoyance or exasperation.
--Examples--
‘the Blessed Sacrament’
‘the Convent of the Blessed Agnes’
‘blessed are the meek’
‘he felt blessed, fortunate to be in her company’
‘he half stumbled out of the room up to his bed and blessed, blessed sleep’
‘he'll want to go and see his blessed allotment’

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

A prayer asking for divine favour and protection.

A beneficial thing for which one is grateful.
A person's sanction or support.

‘a priest gave a blessing as the ship was launched’
‘great intelligence can be a curse as well as a blessing’
‘it's a blessing we're alive’
‘he gave the plan his blessing even before it was announced’

blether 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Talk in a long-winded way without making very much sense.
Long-winded talk with no real substance.
A chat or conversation.
A person who likes to chat or talk at length.
--Examples--
‘there's plenty of stuff I could blether about from today’
‘some stupid blether about puns surrounding the Beatles’
‘we sat there for two hours having a blether’
‘he knows he can be a blether sometimes’

Bly, Nellie 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1867–1922), US journalist and social reformer; pseudonym of Elizabeth Jane Cochrane. As a reporter for the Pittsburgh Dispatch, she wrote about child labor and unsafe working conditions in factories.

--Word--
Bligh, William 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1754–1817), British naval officer, captain of HMS Bounty. In 1789 part of his crew, led by the first mate Fletcher Christian, mutinied and Bligh was set adrift in an open boat, arriving safely at Timor, nearly 6,400 km (4,000 miles) away, a few weeks later.
--Examples--
--Word--
blight 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A plant disease, typically one caused by fungi such as mildews, rusts, and smuts.
A thing that spoils or damages something.
The degeneration of a landscape or urban area as a result of neglect.
Infect (plants) with blight.
Spoil, harm, or destroy.
Subject (an urban area) to neglect.
--Examples--
‘the vines suffered blight and disease’
‘potato blight’
‘her remorse could be a blight on that happiness’
‘the city's high-rise social housing had become synonymous with urban blight’
‘a peach tree blighted by leaf curl’
‘the scandal blighted the careers of several leading politicians’
‘plans to establish enterprise zones in blighted areas’

--Word--
Blighty 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An informal term for Britain or England, used by soldiers of the First and Second World Wars.
A wound suffered by a soldier in the First World War which was sufficiently serious to merit being shipped home to Britain.
--Examples--
‘he had copped a Blighty and was on his way home’

--Word--
blind 
--Type--
adjective, verb, noun, adverb
--Meanings--
Unable to see because of injury, disease, or a congenital condition.
(of an action, especially a test or experiment) done without being able to see or without having relevant information.
(of flying) using instruments only.
Lacking perception, awareness, or judgement.
Not controlled by reason.
Not governed by purpose.
(of a corner or bend in a road) impossible to see round.
(of a door or window) walled up.
Closed at one end.
Not the slightest (used in emphatic expressions)
(of a plant) without buds, eyes, or terminal flowers.
Cause (someone) to be unable to see, permanently or temporarily.
Deprive (someone) of understanding, judgement, or perception.
Confuse or overawe someone with (something they do not understand)
Move very fast and dangerously.
A screen for a window, especially one on a roller or made of slats.
An awning over a shop window.
Something designed to conceal one's real intentions.
A camouflaged shelter used for observing or hunting wildlife.
A heavy drinking bout.
Without being able to see clearly.
Without having all the relevant information; unprepared.
(of a stake in poker or brag) put up by a player before the cards dealt are seen.
--Examples--
‘a blind man with a stick’
‘he was blind in one eye’
‘guide dogs for the blind’
‘a blind tasting of eight wines’
‘blind landings during foggy conditions’
‘a blind acceptance of the status quo’
‘she was blind to the realities of her position’
‘they left in blind panic’
‘a world of blind chance’
‘two trucks collided on a blind curve in the road’
‘fresco paintings on the blind windows’
‘a blind pipe’
‘this declaration is not a blind bit of good to the workers’
‘planting too shallowly is the most common cause of bulbs coming up blind’
‘the injury temporarily blinded him’
‘her eyes were blinded with scalding tears’
‘he was blinded by his faith’
‘somehow Clare and I were blinded to the truth’
‘they try to blind you with science’
‘I could see the bombs blinding along above the roof tops’
‘she pulled down the blinds’
‘he phoned again from his own home: that was just a blind for his wife’
‘a duck blind’
‘he's off on a blind again’
‘he was the first pilot in history to fly blind’
‘wines were tasted blind’
‘he was going into the interview blind’

A course of action leading nowhere.
--Examples--
‘many technologies that show early promise lead up blind alleys’

--Word--
blindfold 
--Type--
noun, verb, adjective, adverb
--Meanings--
A piece of cloth tied round the head to cover someone's eyes.
Deprive (someone) of sight by tying a piece of cloth round the head so as to cover the eyes.
Wearing a blindfold.
(of a game of chess) conducted without sight of board and pieces.
With a blindfold covering the eyes.
Used to convey that something is done with great ease and confidence.
--Examples--
‘he was blindfolded and trussed up in a cupboard’
‘the reporter was driven blindfold to meet the gangster’
‘he missed putts that he would normally hole blindfold’

A screen for a window, especially one on a roller or made of slats.
An awning over a shop window.
Something designed to conceal one's real intentions.
A camouflaged shelter used for observing or hunting wildlife.
A heavy drinking bout.
Without being able to see clearly.
Without having all the relevant information; unprepared.
(of a stake in poker or brag) put up by a player before the cards dealt are seen.
--Examples--
‘a blind man with a stick’
‘he was blind in one eye’
‘guide dogs for the blind’
‘a blind tasting of eight wines’
‘blind landings during foggy conditions’
‘a blind acceptance of the status quo’
‘she was blind to the realities of her position’

‘a world of blind chance’
‘two trucks collided on a blind curve in the road’
‘fresco paintings on the blind windows’
‘a blind pipe’
‘this declaration is not a blind bit of good to the workers’
‘planting too shallowly is the most common cause of bulbs coming up blind’

‘her eyes were blinded with scalding tears’
‘he was blinded by his faith’
‘somehow Clare and I were blinded to the truth’
‘they try to blind you with science’
‘I could see the bombs blinding along above the roof tops’
‘she pulled down the blinds’
‘he phoned again from his own home: that was just a blind for his wife’
‘a duck blind’
‘he's off on a blind again’
‘he was the first pilot in history to fly blind’
‘wines were tasted blind’
‘he was going into the interview blind’
--Word--
blinding 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
(of light) very bright and likely to dazzle or cause temporary blindness.
Temporarily obstructing the vision.
(especially of pain) very intense.
(of an action) remarkably skilful and exciting.
The process of covering a newly made road with grit to fill cracks.
Grit used to cover a newly made road.
A thin bed of concrete laid down over an area before the main mass of concrete is put in place.
--Examples--
‘the sunlight outside was blinding’
‘a blinding flash of inspiration’
‘blinding rain’
‘I've got a blinding headache’
‘he denied Norwich victory with two blinding saves’
--Word--
blindingly 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In a very bright and dazzling way that is likely to cause temporary loss of vision.
Very intensely; extremely.
--Examples--
‘blindingly white beams of light’
‘it started out blindingly sunny on Sunday morning’
‘the reason is blindingly obvious’
--Word--
for your (or his, her, etc.) eyes only 
--Type--
phrase
--Meanings--
Intended to be seen by a particular person or group of people only; confidential.
--Examples--
‘a secret coded message for your eyes only’
--Word--
blindness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The state or condition of being unable to see because of injury, disease, or a congenital condition.
Lack of perception, awareness, or judgement; ignorance.
--Examples--
‘a leading cause of blindness in the elderly’
‘the field of vision gradually narrows and blindness can result’
‘this policy is based on willful blindness to economic reality’
--Word--
blindly 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
Without being able to see; unseeingly.
Without understanding or using one's judgement; unthinkingly.
--Examples--
‘she began groping blindly in the dark’
‘don't blindly accept dogma as justification’
--Word--
loaded 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Carrying or bearing a load, especially a large one.
(of a firearm) charged with ammunition.
Having a lot of money; wealthy.
Drunk.
(of a car) equipped with many optional extras; deluxe.
Weighted or biased towards a particular outcome.
(of a word, statement, or question) charged with an underlying meaning or implication.
--Examples--
‘a heavily loaded freight train’
‘a loaded gun’
‘she doesn't really have to work—they're loaded’
‘it's Friday night, and we want to get loaded’
‘1989 Ford 250 LXT: low miles, loaded’
‘a trick like the one with the loaded dice’
‘avoid politically loaded terms like ‘nation’’
‘‘Anything else?’ It was a loaded question and Kelly knew it’

--Word--
blink 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Shut and open the eyes quickly.
Try to control or prevent tears by blinking.
React to (something) with surprise or disapproval.
Back down from a confrontation.
(of a light) flash on and off in a regular or intermittent way.
An act of shutting and opening the eyes very quickly.
A moment's hesitation.
A momentary gleam of light.
--Examples--
‘I blinked in astonishment’
‘he blinked his eyes nervously’
‘she blinked away her tears’
‘Elizabeth blinked back tears’
‘he doesn't blink at the unsavoury aspects of his subject’
‘the government blinked only after losing 46 of the first 48 hearings’
‘the car's right-hand indicator was blinking’
‘he was observing her every blink’
‘Feargal would have given her all this without a blink’
‘out on the marshes there was a blink of light’

--Word--
blinker 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A pair of small leather screens attached to a horse's bridle to prevent it seeing sideways and behind and being startled.
Something which prevents someone from gaining a full understanding of a situation.
A vehicle indicator or other device that gives out an intermittent light.
Put blinkers on (a horse)
Cause (someone) to have a narrow or limited outlook on a situation.
--Examples--
‘we are having a fresh look at ourselves without blinkers’
‘the cars queued up with blinkers flashing’
‘Brown Boy will be blinkered for the first time at York’
‘university education blinkers researchers so that they see poverty in terms of their own specialization’

blip 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An unexpected, minor, and typically temporary deviation from a general trend.
A very short high-pitched sound made by an electronic device.
A small flashing point of light on a radar screen representing an object.
(of an electronic device) make a very short high-pitched sound or succession of sounds.
Open (the throttle of a motor vehicle) momentarily.
--Examples--
‘the Chancellor dismissed rising inflation as a blip’
‘computer games can drive you crazy with their blips and bleeps’
‘air traffic controllers watching the blips on their radars’
‘big boxes of esoteric electronics hummed and blipped’
‘he straddled the bike and blipped the throttle’

blister 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A small bubble on the skin filled with serum and caused by friction, burning, or other damage.

--Examples--
‘his heels were covered in blisters’
‘check for cracks and blisters in sheet roofing felt’
‘the child is a disgusting little blister’
‘the surface of the door began to blister’
‘a caustic liquid that blisters the skin’
--Word--
blistered 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having blisters on the skin or another surface.
--Examples--
‘he had blistered feet’
‘blistered paintwork’
--Word--
blistering 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of heat) intense.
(of criticism) expressed with great vehemence.
Extremely fast, forceful, or impressive.
--Examples--
‘the blistering heat of the desert’
‘a blistering attack on the government's transport policy’
‘Burke set a blistering pace’
--Word--
blisteringly 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
blister 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A small bubble on the skin filled with serum and caused by friction, burning, or other damage.
A swelling filled with air or fluid on the surface of a plant, heated metal, painted wood, etc.
A preparation applied to the skin to form a blister.
An annoying person.
Form blisters on the skin or other surface.
Cause blisters to form on the surface of.
--Examples--
‘his heels were covered in blisters’
‘check for cracks and blisters in sheet roofing felt’
‘the child is a disgusting little blister’
‘the surface of the door began to blister’
‘a caustic liquid that blisters the skin’

--Word--
blitz 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An intensive or sudden military attack.
The German air raids on Britain in 1940–1.
A sudden concerted effort to deal with something.
A play in which one or more defensive backs charge the quarterback of the opposing team.
Attack or seriously damage (a place) in a blitz.
Process (food) in an electric mixing machine.
Charge (the opposing team's quarterback) in a blitz.
--Examples--
‘a heavy artillery blitz’
‘Katrina and I had a blitz on the cleaning’
‘news came that Rotterdam had been blitzed’
‘she blitzed her own world record in the 400m freestyle’
‘add the eggs and blitz the mixture until it becomes granular’
--Word--
blitzed 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

--Examples--
‘we're all hanging out getting blitzed as usual’

--Word--
Blixen, Karen 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
Baroness Blixen-Finecke (1885–1962), Danish novelist and short-story writer; born Karen Dinesen; also known by the pseudonym of Isak Dinesen. She is best known for Seven Gothic Tales (1934) and her autobiography Out of Africa (1937), which she wrote after living in Kenya from 1914 to 1931.

noun, verb

--Word--
Bloch, Ernest 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1880–1959), Swiss-born American composer, of Jewish descent. His work reflects the influence of the late 19th-century romanticism of Liszt and Richard Strauss and Jewish musical forms. Notable works: the Israel Symphony (1912–16) and Solomon (1916).
--Examples--
--Word--
block 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A large solid piece of hard material, especially rock, stone, or wood, typically with flat surfaces on each side.
A sturdy flat-topped piece of wood used as a work surface.
A packaged rectangular portion of butter, ice cream, chocolate, etc.
A set of sheets of paper glued along one edge, used for drawing or writing on.
A starting block.
A piece of wood or metal engraved for printing on paper or fabric.
A large metal moulding containing the cylinders of an internal combustion engine.
A head-shaped mould for shaping hats or wigs.
A large single building subdivided into separate rooms, flats, or offices.
A building or part of a complex used for a particular purpose.
A group of buildings bounded by four streets.
Any urban or suburban area bounded by four streets.
The length of one side of a block, especially as a measure of distance.
A large quantity or allocation of things regarded as a unit.
A large piece of text processed as a unit.
An obstacle to the normal progress or functioning of something.
An act of blocking someone or something.
A chock for stopping the motion of a wheel.
The spot on which a batsman rests the end of the bat while waiting to receive a ball.
A flat area of something, especially a solid area of colour.
An area of land, in particular a tract offered to an individual settler by a government.
An urban or suburban building plot.
A pulley or system of pulleys mounted in a case.
Make the movement or flow in (a passage, pipe, road, etc.) difficult or impossible.
Put an obstacle in the way of (something proposed or attempted)
Prevent access to or the use of (email or a website or mobile phone)
Restrict the use or conversion of (currency or any other asset).
Impede the progress of (a tackler) with one's body.
(in sport) stop (a ball or blow) from finding its mark.
Stop (a ball) with the bat defensively.
Play in such a way that opponents are prevented from establishing (a long suit).
Impress text or a design on (a book cover).
Shape or reshape (a hat) on a mould.
--Examples--
‘a block of marble’
‘a chopping block’
‘a family block of ice cream’
‘a sketching block’
‘Jackson jetted out of his blocks’
‘a block of flats’
‘a shower block’
‘she went for a run round the block’
‘ours was the ugliest house on the block’
‘he lives a few blocks away from the museum’
‘a block of shares’
‘final examinations will be taken in a block at the end of the course’
‘substantial demands for time off may constitute a block to career advancement’
‘an emotional block’
‘Marshall's shot drew a fine block from the goalkeeper’
‘cover the eyelid with a neutral block of colour’
‘a simple pulley block’
‘block up the holes with sticky tape’
‘the narrow roads were blocked by cars’
‘he stood up, blocking her escape’
‘the government tried to block an agreement on farm subsidies’
‘some companies use these IMEI numbers to block stolen phones’
‘Knight did well to block Soloman's shot’
‘nobody cleans and blocks old felt hats any more’
--Word--
blockade 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An act or means of sealing off a place to prevent goods or people from entering or leaving.
An obstruction of a physiological or mental function, especially of a biochemical receptor.
Seal off (a place) to prevent goods or people from entering or leaving.
--Examples--
‘they voted to lift the blockade of major railway junctions’
‘the authorities blockaded roads in and out of the capital’

--Word--
blockbusting 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Very successful commercially.
The practice of persuading owners to sell property cheaply because of the fear of people of another race or class moving into the neighbourhood, and then profiting by reselling at a higher price.
--Examples--
‘his blockbusting novel’

--Meanings--

The impeding of an opponent in a game, especially (in ball games) one who does not have control of the ball.
The sudden halting of the flow of thought or speech, as a symptom of schizophrenia or other mental disorder.
Failure to recall or consider an unpleasant memory or train of thought.
The grouping or treatment of things (e.g. shades of colour) in blocks.
The physical arrangement of actors on a stage or film set.
--Examples--
‘the issue led to the disruption of classes and the blocking of the Kakata highway by angry students’
--Word--
blockish 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Big, bulky, or crude in form or appearance.
Unintelligent.
--Examples--
‘his blockish architecture is ugly if functional’
‘the blockish Ajax will meet the challenge of Hector’
--Word--

--Type--

--Meanings--

--Word--
blockish 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Big, bulky, or crude in form or appearance.
Unintelligent.
--Examples--
‘his blockish architecture is ugly if functional’
‘the blockish Ajax will meet the challenge of Hector’
--Word--
block 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A large solid piece of hard material, especially rock, stone, or wood, typically with flat surfaces on each side.
A sturdy flat-topped piece of wood used as a work surface.
A packaged rectangular portion of butter, ice cream, chocolate, etc.
A set of sheets of paper glued along one edge, used for drawing or writing on.
A starting block.
A piece of wood or metal engraved for printing on paper or fabric.
A large metal moulding containing the cylinders of an internal combustion engine.
A head-shaped mould for shaping hats or wigs.
A large single building subdivided into separate rooms, flats, or offices.
A building or part of a complex used for a particular purpose.
A group of buildings bounded by four streets.
Any urban or suburban area bounded by four streets.
The length of one side of a block, especially as a measure of distance.
A large quantity or allocation of things regarded as a unit.
A large piece of text processed as a unit.
An obstacle to the normal progress or functioning of something.
An act of blocking someone or something.
A chock for stopping the motion of a wheel.
The spot on which a batsman rests the end of the bat while waiting to receive a ball.
A flat area of something, especially a solid area of colour.
An area of land, in particular a tract offered to an individual settler by a government.
An urban or suburban building plot.
A pulley or system of pulleys mounted in a case.
Make the movement or flow in (a passage, pipe, road, etc.) difficult or impossible.
Put an obstacle in the way of (something proposed or attempted)
Prevent access to or the use of (email or a website or mobile phone)
Restrict the use or conversion of (currency or any other asset).
Impede the progress of (a tackler) with one's body.
(in sport) stop (a ball or blow) from finding its mark.
Stop (a ball) with the bat defensively.
Play in such a way that opponents are prevented from establishing (a long suit).
Impress text or a design on (a book cover).
Shape or reshape (a hat) on a mould.
--Examples--
‘a block of marble’
‘a chopping block’
‘a family block of ice cream’
‘a sketching block’
‘Jackson jetted out of his blocks’
‘a block of flats’
‘a shower block’
‘she went for a run round the block’
‘ours was the ugliest house on the block’
‘he lives a few blocks away from the museum’
‘a block of shares’
‘final examinations will be taken in a block at the end of the course’
‘substantial demands for time off may constitute a block to career advancement’
‘an emotional block’
‘Marshall's shot drew a fine block from the goalkeeper’
‘cover the eyelid with a neutral block of colour’
‘a simple pulley block’
‘block up the holes with sticky tape’
‘the narrow roads were blocked by cars’
‘he stood up, blocking her escape’
‘the government tried to block an agreement on farm subsidies’
‘some companies use these IMEI numbers to block stolen phones’
‘Knight did well to block Soloman's shot’
‘nobody cleans and blocks old felt hats any more’
--Word--
block 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A large solid piece of hard material, especially rock, stone, or wood, typically with flat surfaces on each side.
A sturdy flat-topped piece of wood used as a work surface.
A packaged rectangular portion of butter, ice cream, chocolate, etc.

Any urban or suburban area bounded by four streets.

A large piece of text processed as a unit.

An act of blocking someone or something.

Prevent access to or the use of (email or a website or mobile phone)
Restrict the use or conversion of (currency or any other asset).

(in sport) stop (a ball or blow) from finding its mark.
Stop (a ball) with the bat defensively.
Play in such a way that opponents are prevented from establishing (a long suit).
Impress text or a design on (a book cover).
Shape or reshape (a hat) on a mould.

‘a chopping block’

blocking 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action or fact of blocking or obstructing someone or something.

--Word--
saw 
--Type--
noun, verb
UnKnownKind, noun
--Meanings--
A hand tool for cutting wood or other hard materials, typically with a long, thin serrated blade and operated using a backwards and forwards movement.
A mechanical power-driven tool for cutting which has a toothed rotating disc or moving band.
A serrated organ or part, such as the toothed snout of a sawfish.
Cut (something) using a saw.
Make or form (something) using a saw.
Cut (something) as if with a saw, especially roughly or so as to leave rough or unfinished edges.
Make rapid sawlike motions in cutting, or in playing a stringed instrument.
(of two or more people) compromise by making concessions to one another.
A proverb or maxim.
--Examples--
‘the top of each post is sawn off at railing height’
‘thieves escaped after sawing through iron bars on a window’
‘the seats are sawn from well-seasoned elm planks’
‘the woman who sawed off all my lovely hair’
‘he was sawing away energetically at the loaf’
‘they sawed off over wages and concluded the deal’
‘it is worth bearing in mind another old saw: ‘oppositions do not win elections; governments lose them’’

serifed

--Word--
Langmuir, Irving 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1881–1957), American chemist and physicist. His principal work was in surface chemistry, especially applied to catalysis. He also worked on high-temperature electrical discharges in gases and studied atomic structure.
--Examples--

proper noun
--Meanings--
The capital of Free State province and judicial capital of South Africa; population 583,300 (est. 2009).

blonde

adjective, noun
--Meanings--

Having hair of a fair or pale yellow colour.
Having fair hair and a light complexion (especially when regarded as a racial characteristic)
(of wood or another substance) light in colour.
A person with fair or pale yellow hair (typically used of a woman).
The colour of blonde hair.

‘I had my hair dyed blonde’
‘a tall blonde woman’
‘she was blonde and blue-eyed’
‘a New York office full of blonde wood’
‘her hair was yellow—not any shade of blonde, but yellow’

--Word--
blood 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The red liquid that circulates in the arteries and veins of humans and other vertebrate animals, carrying oxygen to and carbon dioxide from the tissues of the body.
An internal bodily fluid in invertebates which performs a similar function to blood in humans and other vertebrates.
Blood samples or tests.
Violence involving bloodshed.
Fiery or passionate temperament.
Family background; descent or lineage.
A person of specified descent.
A fellow black person.
A fashionable and dashing young man.
Initiate (someone) in a particular activity.
Smear the face of (a novice) with the blood of the kill.
Give (a hound) a first taste of blood.
--Examples--
‘drops of blood’
‘his bloods were normal’
‘a nurse was out on the corridor taking bloods from the patients’
‘a commando operation full of blood and danger’
‘a ritual that fires up his blood’
‘she must have Irish blood in her’
‘a mixed blood’
‘any blood who opted out was ostracized’
‘a group of young bloods’
‘clubs are too slow to blood young players’
--Word--
blood and guts

phrase
--Meanings--
Violence and bloodshed, especially in fiction.
--Examples--
‘I like blood and guts, adventure, that kind of thing’

phrase
--Meanings--
Unrestrained and violent action or behaviour.
--Examples--
‘a typical blood-and-thunder cup tie’
--Word--
bloodbath 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An event or situation in which many people are killed in an extremely violent way.
--Examples--
‘he allowed the protest to go ahead despite warnings that it would spark a bloodbath’

--Meanings--

bloodberry 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A berry of a blood-red colour.
A perennial shrub, Rivina humilis (family Phytolaccaceae), of the southern United States and tropical America, which bears pale pink flowers and blood-red berries.

noun, verb

Involving or characterized by bloodshed or cruelty.
Cover or stain with blood.
--Examples--
‘his bloody hands’
‘a bloody discharge’
‘a bloody coup’
‘the bloody tyrannies of Europe’
‘he ended the fight with his face bloodied and battered’

--Word--
blood 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The red liquid that circulates in the arteries and veins of humans and other vertebrate animals, carrying oxygen to and carbon dioxide from the tissues of the body.
An internal bodily fluid in invertebates which performs a similar function to blood in humans and other vertebrates.
Blood samples or tests.
Violence involving bloodshed.
Fiery or passionate temperament.
Family background; descent or lineage.
A person of specified descent.
A fellow black person.
A fashionable and dashing young man.
Initiate (someone) in a particular activity.
Smear the face of (a novice) with the blood of the kill.
Give (a hound) a first taste of blood.
--Examples--
‘drops of blood’
‘his bloods were normal’
‘a nurse was out on the corridor taking bloods from the patients’
‘a commando operation full of blood and danger’
‘a ritual that fires up his blood’
‘she must have Irish blood in her’
‘a mixed blood’
‘any blood who opted out was ostracized’
‘a group of young bloods’
‘clubs are too slow to blood young players’

--Meanings--

--Examples--

‘another myth is that Scorpios are sex-mad’

‘this author has mad skills with the written word’

‘had I but seen thy picture in this plight, it would have madded me’

bloodsucker 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An insect or other animal that sucks blood, especially a leech or a mosquito.
A long-tailed arboreal Asian lizard which carries its head in a raised position. The head and shoulders of the male become bright red when it is excited.
A person who extorts money or otherwise lives off other people.

--Word--
bloodwite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Feudal Law. A fine payable for the offence of shedding blood; (also) a legal action for this offence; (occasionally) †the offence itself (obsolete). Also: the right of levying this fine; (occasionally) †the privilege of exemption from it (obsolete). Now historical.
Generally. A penalty for murder, especially (usually in form bloodwit) in Islamic jurisprudence.
--Examples--
--Word--
bloodwite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Feudal Law. A fine payable for the offence of shedding blood; (also) a legal action for this offence; (occasionally) †the offence itself (obsolete). Also: the right of levying this fine; (occasionally) †the privilege of exemption from it (obsolete). Now historical.
Generally. A penalty for murder, especially (usually in form bloodwit) in Islamic jurisprudence.

--Word--
bloom 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A flower, especially one cultivated for its beauty.
The state or period of flowering.
The state or period of greatest beauty, freshness, or vigour.
A youthful or healthy glow in a person's complexion.
A delicate powdery surface deposit on certain fresh fruits, leaves, or stems.
A greyish-white appearance on chocolate caused by cocoa butter rising to the surface.
A full, bright sound in a recording.
Produce flowers; be in flower.
Come into or be in full beauty or health; flourish.
(of fire, colour, or light) become radiant and glowing.
Coat (a lens) with a special surface layer so as to reduce reflection from its surface.
--Examples--
‘an exotic bloom’
‘the apple trees were in bloom’
‘I am no longer in the bloom of youth’
‘her face had lost its usual bloom’
‘the bloom on a plum’
‘the remastering has lost some of the bloom of the strings’
‘a chalk pit where cowslips bloomed’
‘the children had bloomed in the soft Devonshire air’
‘colour bloomed in her cheeks’
--Word--
bloom 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A flower, especially one cultivated for its beauty.
The state or period of flowering.
The state or period of greatest beauty, freshness, or vigour.
A youthful or healthy glow in a person's complexion.
A delicate powdery surface deposit on certain fresh fruits, leaves, or stems.
A greyish-white appearance on chocolate caused by cocoa butter rising to the surface.
A full, bright sound in a recording.
Produce flowers; be in flower.
Come into or be in full beauty or health; flourish.
(of fire, colour, or light) become radiant and glowing.
Coat (a lens) with a special surface layer so as to reduce reflection from its surface.
--Examples--
‘an exotic bloom’
‘the apple trees were in bloom’
‘I am no longer in the bloom of youth’
‘her face had lost its usual bloom’
‘the bloom on a plum’
‘the remastering has lost some of the bloom of the strings’
‘a chalk pit where cowslips bloomed’
‘the children had bloomed in the soft Devonshire air’
‘colour bloomed in her cheeks’
