--Word--
down 
--Type--
adverb, preposition, adjective, verb, noun
--Meanings--
Towards or in a lower place or position, especially to or on the ground or another surface.
At or to a specified distance below.
Downstairs.
Expressing movement or position away from the north.
To or at a place perceived as lower (often expressing casualness or lack of hurry)
Away from the capital or major city.
Away from a university, especially Oxford or Cambridge.
(with reference to food or drink swallowed) in or into the stomach.
So as to lie or be fixed flush or flat.
Used as a command to a person or animal to sit or lie down.
Referring to a crossword answer which reads vertically.
To or at a lower level of intensity, volume, or activity.
To or at a lower price, value, or rank.
To a finer consistency, a smaller amount or size, or a simpler or more basic state.
From an earlier to a later point in time or order.
In or into a weaker or worse position, mood, or condition.
Losing or at a disadvantage by a specified amount.
Used to express progress through a series of tasks or items.
(of a computer system) out of action or unavailable for use.
Shouted to express strong dislike of a specified person or thing.
In or into writing.
On or on to a list, schedule, or record.
(with reference to partial payment of a sum of money) made initially or on the spot.
(of sailing) with the current or the wind.
(of a ship's helm) moved round to leeward so that the rudder is to windward and the vessel swings toward the wind.
(of the ball or a player in possession) not in play, typically through progress being stopped.
From a higher to a lower point of (something)
At or to the part of (a river or stream) that is nearer the sea.
Moving or at a point further along the course of (something)
At or to (a place)
Throughout (a period of time)
Directed or moving towards a lower place or position.
Relating to or denoting trains travelling away from the main terminus.
Denoting a flavour of quark having a charge of −1/3. Protons and neutrons are thought to be composed of combinations of up and down quarks.
Unhappy; depressed.
(of a computer system) temporarily out of action or unavailable.
Supporting or going along with someone or something.
Aware of and following the latest fashion.
Knock or bring to the ground.
Put (the ball) out of play deliberately by touching one's knee to the ground while holding the ball or touching the ball itself to the ground.
Consume (something, typically a drink)
Sink (a putt)
A chance for a team to advance the ball, ending when the ball carrier is tackled or the ball becomes out of play. A team must advance at least ten yards in a series of four downs in order to keep possession.
Unwelcome experiences or events.
A feeling or period of unhappiness or depression.
--Examples--
‘she looked down’
‘the sun started to go down’
‘he put his glass down’
‘he swung the axe to chop down the tree’
‘you can plainly see the bottom 35 feet down’
‘I went down to put the kettle on’
‘they're living down south’
‘I'd rather be down at the villa’
‘I'm going down to the pub’
‘there are eight trains a day, four up and four down’
‘he was down from Oxford’
‘she couldn't keep anything down’
‘she stuck down a Christmas label’
‘down, boy!’
‘how many letters in fifteen down?’
‘keep the noise down’
‘the panic was dying down’
‘at night it would cool down’
‘output was down by 20 per cent’
‘soup is down from 59p to 49p’
‘I must slim down a bit’
‘a formal statement that can't be edited down’
‘thin down an oil-based paint with spirits’
‘buildings in England down to 1540’
‘everyone, from the President down to the bloke selling hot dogs, wants her dead’
‘the scandal brought down the government’
‘he was down with the flu’
‘United were 3–0 down’
‘one down and only six more to go’
‘the system went down yesterday’
‘crowds chanted ‘Down with America!’’
‘Graham noted the numbers down carefully’
‘taking down notes’
‘I'll put you down for the evening shift’
‘pay £5 down and the rest at the end of the month’
‘up and down the stairs’
‘tears streaming down her face’
‘a dozen miles or so down the Thames’
‘he lived down the street’
‘I wandered down the road’
‘she was tired of going down the pub every night’
‘astrologers down the ages’
‘the down escalator’
‘click on the down arrow’
‘we travelled on the first down train’
‘he's been so down lately’
‘sorry, but the computer's down’
‘you got to be down with me’
‘she was totally down for a selfie’
‘‘You going to the movies?’ ‘Yo, I'm down.’’
‘a seriously down, hip-hop homie’
‘175 enemy aircraft had been downed’
‘he struck Slater on the face, downing him’
‘Jones downed the ball in the end zone’
‘he downed five pints of cider’
‘he downed a 20-foot putt for victory’
‘there had been more downs than ups during his years at Ferrari’
‘everyone gets their downs, their depressive periods’

Bloomington 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A commercial city in central Illinois; population 73,026 (est. 2008).
A city in south central Indiana, noted for its limestone industry and home to Indiana University; population 71,819 (est. 2008).
A city in southeastern Minnesota, south of Minneapolis. It is home to the huge Mall of America; population 81,280 (est. 2008).

bloop 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
(of an electronic device) emit a short low-pitched noise.
Make a mistake.
Hit (a ball) weakly or make (a hit) that lands just beyond the reach of the infielders.
A short low-pitched noise emitted by an electronic device.
A mistake.
--Examples--
‘a fruit machine blooping in the corner’
‘the company admitted it had blooped’
‘he blooped a single over the fielder in the third inning’
‘a few bleeps and bloops’
‘a typical beginner's bloop’
‘seven hits which were bloops for the most part’
‘a bloop single’

--Word--
blot 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A dark mark or stain made by ink, paint, dirt, etc.
A shameful act or quality that damages an otherwise good character or reputation.
A thing that mars the appearance of something.
A procedure in which proteins or nucleic acids separated on a gel are transferred directly to an immobilizing medium for identification.
Dry (a wet surface or substance) using an absorbent material.
Mark or stain (something)
Damage the good character or reputation of.
Cover writing or pictures with ink or paint so that they cannot be seen.
Obscure a view.
Obliterate or disregard something painful in one's memory or existence.
Transfer by means of a blot.
--Examples--
‘a blot of ink’
‘the only blot on an otherwise clean campaign’
‘wind power turbines are a blot on the landscape’
‘Henry blotted the page’
‘dark patches of dirt blotted the grey dress’
‘the turmoil blotted his memory of the school’
‘Mary dug her brush into black paint and blotted out her picture’
‘a dust shield blotting out the sun’
‘the concentration necessary to her job blotted out all the feelings’
--Word--

‘red blotches on her face’
‘her face was blotched and swollen with crying’

Cover writing or pictures with ink or paint so that they cannot be seen.
Obscure a view.
Obliterate or disregard something painful in one's memory or existence.
Transfer by means of a blot.
--Examples--
‘a blot of ink’
‘the only blot on an otherwise clean campaign’
‘wind power turbines are a blot on the landscape’
‘Henry blotted the page’
‘dark patches of dirt blotted the grey dress’
‘the turmoil blotted his memory of the school’
‘Mary dug her brush into black paint and blotted out her picture’
‘a dust shield blotting out the sun’
‘the concentration necessary to her job blotted out all the feelings’
--Word--
blotto 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Extremely drunk.
--Examples--
‘we got blotto’
--Word--
Rutledge, Wiley Blount 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1894–1949), US Supreme Court associate justice 1943–49. Appointed to the Court by President Franklin D. Roosevelt, he tended toward liberalism.
--Examples--
--Word--
blouse 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A woman's upper garment resembling a shirt, typically with a collar, buttons, and sleeves.
A loose linen or cotton garment formerly worn by peasants and manual workers, typically belted at the waist.
A type of jacket worn as part of military uniform.
Make (a garment) hang in loose folds.
--Examples--
‘I bloused my trousers over my boots’

--Word--
blow 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
(of wind) move creating an air current.
(of wind) cause (something) to move; propel.
Be carried, driven, or moved by the wind or an air current.
Leave.
(of a person) expel air through pursed lips.
Use one's breath to propel (something)
Breathe hard; pant.
Out of breath; panting.
Force air through the mouth into (an instrument) in order to make a sound.
(of an instrument) make a sound when air is forced into it.
Sound (the horn of a vehicle)
Play jazz or rock music in an unrestrained style.
Force air through a tube into (molten glass) in order to create an artefact.
Remove the contents of (an egg) by forcing air through it.
(of a whale) eject air and vapour through the blowhole.
(of an explosion or explosive device) displace violently or send flying.
(of a vehicle tyre) burst suddenly while the vehicle is in motion.
Burst or cause to burst due to pressure or overheating.
(with reference to an electric circuit) burn out through overloading.
Spend recklessly.
Completely bungle (an opportunity)
Expose (a stratagem)
Damn.
Perform fellatio on (a man).
Be extremely bad or unwelcome.
(of flies) lay eggs in or on (something).
A strong wind.
An act of getting some fresh air.
An act of blowing an instrument.
A spell of playing jazz or rock music.
An act of blowing one's nose.
(in steel-making) an act of sending an air or oxygen blast through molten metal in a converter.
Cannabis or cocaine.
--Examples--
‘a cold breeze was blowing in off the sea’
‘a gust of wind blew a cloud of smoke into his face’
‘the spire was blown down during a gale’
‘it was so windy that the tent nearly blew away’
‘cotton curtains blowing in the breeze’
‘I'd better blow’
‘Willie took a deep breath, and blew’
‘he blew on his tea to cool it’
‘he blew cigar smoke in her face’
‘Uncle Albert was soon puffing and blowing’
‘an exhausted, blown horse’
‘the umpire blew his whistle’
‘police whistles blew’
‘angry motorists blew their horns’
‘it took him maybe five choruses to warm up, but then he could really blow’
‘factory showrooms where you can see glass being blown and painted’
‘teaching children to blow an egg by placing holes in either end with a pin’
‘the blast had blown the windows out of the van’
‘a rear tyre had blown’
‘the engines sounded as if their exhausts had blown’
‘the fuse had blown’
‘the floodlights blew a fuse’
‘they blew £100,000 in just eighteen months’
‘he'd been given a second chance and he'd blown it’
‘they blew a 4–2 lead’
‘a man whose cover was blown’
‘‘Well, blow me’, he said, ‘I never knew that.’’
‘I'm blowed if I want to see him again’
‘‘This blows,’ she sighs, ‘I want it to be next week already’’
‘we're in for a bit of a blow’
‘I'll go down to the sea and get a blow before supper’
‘a number of blows on the whistle’
‘give your nose a good blow’

--Word--
blowback 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A process in which gases expand or travel in a direction opposite to the usual one, especially through escape of pressure or delayed combustion.
The unintended adverse results of a political action or situation.
--Examples--
‘this is the blowback from all those aggressive public health campaigns’

noun
--Meanings--
Trees that have been blown down by the wind.

‘designs had to withstand blowdown conditions’

blower 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

A telephone.
--Examples--
‘the shower will stop automatically and warm air blowers will dry you off’
‘I've been trying to get hold of you on the blower’

‘I'm blowed if I want to see him again’
‘‘This blows,’ she sighs, ‘I want it to be next week already’’
‘we're in for a bit of a blow’
‘I'll go down to the sea and get a blow before supper’
‘a number of blows on the whistle’
‘give your nose a good blow’

--Word--
blow 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
(of wind) move creating an air current.
(of wind) cause (something) to move; propel.
Be carried, driven, or moved by the wind or an air current.
Leave.
(of a person) expel air through pursed lips.
Use one's breath to propel (something)
Breathe hard; pant.
Out of breath; panting.
Force air through the mouth into (an instrument) in order to make a sound.
(of an instrument) make a sound when air is forced into it.
Sound (the horn of a vehicle)
Play jazz or rock music in an unrestrained style.
Force air through a tube into (molten glass) in order to create an artefact.
Remove the contents of (an egg) by forcing air through it.
(of a whale) eject air and vapour through the blowhole.
(of an explosion or explosive device) displace violently or send flying.
(of a vehicle tyre) burst suddenly while the vehicle is in motion.
Burst or cause to burst due to pressure or overheating.
(with reference to an electric circuit) burn out through overloading.
Spend recklessly.
Completely bungle (an opportunity)
Expose (a stratagem)
Damn.
Perform fellatio on (a man).
Be extremely bad or unwelcome.
(of flies) lay eggs in or on (something).
A strong wind.
An act of getting some fresh air.
An act of blowing an instrument.
A spell of playing jazz or rock music.
An act of blowing one's nose.
(in steel-making) an act of sending an air or oxygen blast through molten metal in a converter.
Cannabis or cocaine.
--Examples--
‘a cold breeze was blowing in off the sea’
‘a gust of wind blew a cloud of smoke into his face’
‘the spire was blown down during a gale’
‘it was so windy that the tent nearly blew away’
‘cotton curtains blowing in the breeze’
‘I'd better blow’
‘Willie took a deep breath, and blew’
‘he blew on his tea to cool it’
‘he blew cigar smoke in her face’
‘Uncle Albert was soon puffing and blowing’
‘an exhausted, blown horse’
‘the umpire blew his whistle’
‘police whistles blew’
‘angry motorists blew their horns’
‘it took him maybe five choruses to warm up, but then he could really blow’
‘factory showrooms where you can see glass being blown and painted’
‘teaching children to blow an egg by placing holes in either end with a pin’
‘the blast had blown the windows out of the van’
‘a rear tyre had blown’
‘the engines sounded as if their exhausts had blown’
‘the fuse had blown’
‘the floodlights blew a fuse’
‘they blew £100,000 in just eighteen months’
‘he'd been given a second chance and he'd blown it’
‘they blew a 4–2 lead’
‘a man whose cover was blown’
‘‘Well, blow me’, he said, ‘I never knew that.’’
‘I'm blowed if I want to see him again’
‘‘This blows,’ she sighs, ‘I want it to be next week already’’
‘we're in for a bit of a blow’
‘I'll go down to the sea and get a blow before supper’
‘a number of blows on the whistle’
‘give your nose a good blow’

--Word--
blowout 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An occasion when a tyre on a vehicle bursts or an electric fuse melts.
An uprush of oil or gas from a well.
An outburst of anger or an argument.
A large or lavish meal or social gathering.
An event at which goods are sold at heavily discounted prices.
An easy victory in a sporting contest or election.
An act or instance of blow-drying hair.
A hollow eroded by the wind.
--Examples--
‘a blowout preventer’
‘that exchange led to a big blowout five years ago’
‘it is difficult to imagine the slim person going for a real blowout’
‘the purpose of the blowout is to motivate new customers to visit’
‘the local store is having a big blowout sale—everything 65 per cent off’
‘the game had been a blowout’
‘you can't do a blowout with super wet hair’

--Word--
blowpipe 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A primitive weapon consisting of a long tube through which an arrow or dart is propelled by force of the breath.
A long tube by means of which molten glass is blown into the required shape.
A tube used to intensify the heat of a flame by blowing air or other gas through it at high pressure.

--Word--
blue 
--Type--
adjective, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Of a colour intermediate between green and violet, as of the sky or sea on a sunny day.
(of a person's skin) having turned blue as a result of cold or breathing difficulties.
(of a bird or other animal) having blue markings.
(of a cat, fox, or rabbit) having fur of a smoky grey colour.
(of a ski run) of the second-lowest level of difficulty, as indicated by blue markers positioned along it.
Denoting one of three colours of quark.
(of a person or mood) melancholy, sad, or depressed.
(of a film, joke, or story) having sexual or pornographic content.
Politically conservative.
Blue colour or pigment.
Blue clothes or material.
The blue ball in snooker, billiards, and similar games.
The sky or sea, or the unknown.
A small butterfly, the male of which is predominantly blue while the female is typically brown.
A person who has represented Cambridge University (a Cambridge blue) or Oxford University (an Oxford blue) at a particular sport in a match between the two universities.
A distinction awarded to a Cambridge blue or an Oxford blue.
An argument or fight.
A mistake.
A nickname for a red-headed person.
A supporter of the Conservative Party.
Make or become blue.
Heat (metal) so as to give it a greyish-blue finish.
Wash (white clothes) with bluing.
--Examples--
‘the clear blue sky’
‘a blue silk shirt’
‘deep blue eyes’
‘Ashley went blue and I panicked’
‘a blue jay’
‘the blue fox’
‘he's feeling blue’
‘a blue movie’
‘the successful blue candidate’
‘she was dressed in blue’
‘the dark blue of his eyes’
‘armchairs in pastel blues and greens’
‘Susan wore blue’
‘far out upon the blue were many sails’
‘a flyweight boxing blue’
‘Adrian's brother won a rugby blue in December’
‘did you have a blue or what?’
‘his tactical blue in saying the opposition wasn't ready to govern’
‘only an Aussie could make a red-headed man ‘Blue.’’
‘the light dims, bluing the retina’
‘blued paper’
‘the day would haze, the air bluing with afternoon’
‘nickel-plated or blued hooks’
‘they blued the shirts and starched the uniforms’

--Meanings--

blueback 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
Bluebeard 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A character in a tale by Charles Perrault, who killed several wives in turn for disobeying his order to avoid a locked room, which contained the bodies of his previous wives. Local tradition in Brittany identifies him with Gilles de Rais (c.1400–40), a perpetrator of atrocities, although he had only one wife (who left him).
A man who murders his wives.
--Examples--
‘you seem to imply I'm some sort of Bluebeard who keeps her incarcerated’
--Word--
Bluebeard 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A character in a tale by Charles Perrault, who killed several wives in turn for disobeying his order to avoid a locked room, which contained the bodies of his previous wives. Local tradition in Brittany identifies him with Gilles de Rais (c.1400–40), a perpetrator of atrocities, although he had only one wife (who left him).
A man who murders his wives.
--Examples--
‘you seem to imply I'm some sort of Bluebeard who keeps her incarcerated’
--Word--
bluebell 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A European woodland plant of the lily family that produces clusters of blue bell-shaped flowers in spring.
Any of a number of other plants with blue bell-shaped flowers.

--Word--
blue-bellied 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Derogatory (chiefly United States regional (southern)). Designating a person regarded as low, cowardly, or contemptible, especially (in the southern United States) a northerner (sometimes specifically a New Englander).
Especially in the names of animals: having a distinctive blue belly.
--Examples--

--Word--
belt 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A strip of leather or other material worn, typically round the waist, to support or hold in clothes or to carry weapons.
A belt worn as a sign of rank or achievement.
A belt of a specified colour, marking the attainment of a particular level in judo, karate, or similar sports.
A person who is qualified to wear a belt of a specified colour in judo, karate, etc.
The punishment of being struck with a belt.
A continuous band of material used in machinery for transferring motion from one wheel to another.
A conveyor belt.
A flexible strip carrying machine-gun cartridges.
A strip or encircling area that is different in nature or composition from its surroundings.
A heavy blow.
Fasten with a belt.
Be fastened with a belt.
Attach or secure with a belt.
Beat or strike (someone), especially with a belt as a punishment.
Hit (something) hard.
Rush or dash in a specified direction.
(of rain) fall hard.
--Examples--
‘he tightened his leather belt an extra notch’
‘a sword belt’
‘a belt buckle’
‘he was awarded the victor's belt’
‘brown-belt level’
‘Shaun became a brown belt in judo’
‘be quiet, or it's the belt’
‘a great wheel driven by a leather belt’
‘the asteroid belt’
‘a belt of trees’
‘she administered a good belt with her stick’
‘she belted her raincoat firmly’
‘the jacket belts at the waist’
‘he was securely belted into the passenger seat’
‘I was belted and sent to my room’
‘he belted the ball downfield’
‘he belted out of the side door’
‘the rain belted down on the tin roof’
--Word--
blueberry 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small sweet blue-black edible berry which grows in clusters on North American shrubs related to the bilberry.
One of the dwarf shrubs that produces blueberries, some kinds being cultivated for their fruit or as ornamentals.
--Examples--

bluebird 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
An American songbird of the thrush family, the male of which has a blue head, back, and wings.
Denoting or relating to a period of time characterized by sunny, cloudless weather, typically after a night of snowfall.
--Examples--
‘on beautiful bluebird days the girls rode snowmobiles’
‘a week of bluebird skies’
‘the clouds broke, the sun shone down, and the day was bluebird’

blackness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The property or quality of being black in colour.
Complete darkness; the absence of any light.
The fact or state of belonging to any human group having dark-coloured skin.
The quality or character associated with black people.
A state characterized by despair or depression.
A state or condition of being evil or wicked.
--Examples--
‘it restores grey hair to blackness’
‘the entire house was plunged into pitch blackness’
‘my experiences have made me far more aware of my blackness than ever before’
‘she holds that position not because of her blackness, but her effectiveness’
‘the blackness of his poetry is an inextricable aspect of his subject matter’
‘there is a little hope amid the blackness of his life’
‘the absolute depths of blackness and morbidity’
‘the blackness of the human heart through the atrocities of war’

bluebuck 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
South African. The blue duiker, Cephalophus (or Philantomba) monticola. Now rare.
Historical. A large extinct antelope, Hippotragus leucophaeus, with a dark bluish coat and long curved horns, found in south-western South Africa until about 1800.
The nilgai, Boselaphus tragocamelus, a large Indian antelope.
--Examples--
--Word--
blue cap 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Military slang (now historical). Originally: a soldier belonging to the Royal Madras Fusiliers; (later) a soldier belonging to the Royal Dublin Fusiliers.
Chiefly English regional. The cornflower, Centaurea cyanus. Now rare.
A bluish layer in a flame; specifically (Mining) a circle of bluish flame appearing above and around the wick of a safety lamp, indicating the presence of explosive gases. Compare "cap". Now rare.

--Word--
blue 
--Type--
adjective, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Of a colour intermediate between green and violet, as of the sky or sea on a sunny day.
(of a person's skin) having turned blue as a result of cold or breathing difficulties.
(of a bird or other animal) having blue markings.
(of a cat, fox, or rabbit) having fur of a smoky grey colour.
(of a ski run) of the second-lowest level of difficulty, as indicated by blue markers positioned along it.
Denoting one of three colours of quark.
(of a person or mood) melancholy, sad, or depressed.
(of a film, joke, or story) having sexual or pornographic content.
Politically conservative.
Blue colour or pigment.
Blue clothes or material.
The blue ball in snooker, billiards, and similar games.
The sky or sea, or the unknown.
A small butterfly, the male of which is predominantly blue while the female is typically brown.
A person who has represented Cambridge University (a Cambridge blue) or Oxford University (an Oxford blue) at a particular sport in a match between the two universities.
A distinction awarded to a Cambridge blue or an Oxford blue.
An argument or fight.
A mistake.
A nickname for a red-headed person.
A supporter of the Conservative Party.
Make or become blue.
Heat (metal) so as to give it a greyish-blue finish.
Wash (white clothes) with bluing.
--Examples--
‘the clear blue sky’
‘a blue silk shirt’
‘deep blue eyes’
‘Ashley went blue and I panicked’
‘a blue jay’
‘the blue fox’
‘he's feeling blue’
‘a blue movie’
‘the successful blue candidate’
‘she was dressed in blue’
‘the dark blue of his eyes’
‘armchairs in pastel blues and greens’
‘Susan wore blue’
‘far out upon the blue were many sails’
‘a flyweight boxing blue’
‘Adrian's brother won a rugby blue in December’
‘did you have a blue or what?’
‘his tactical blue in saying the opposition wasn't ready to govern’
‘only an Aussie could make a red-headed man ‘Blue.’’
‘the light dims, bluing the retina’
‘blued paper’
‘the day would haze, the air bluing with afternoon’
‘nickel-plated or blued hooks’
‘they blued the shirts and starched the uniforms’

--Word--
hot 
--Type--
adjective, verb
--Meanings--
Having a high degree of heat or a high temperature.
Feeling or producing an uncomfortable sensation of heat.
(of food or drink) prepared by heating and served without cooling.
(of an electric circuit) live or at a high voltage.
Radioactive.
(of food) containing or consisting of pungent spices or peppers which produce a burning sensation when tasted.
Filled with passionate excitement, anger, or other strong emotion.
Lustful or erotic.
(of popular music) strongly rhythmical and excitingly played.
Involving much activity, debate, or interest.
(of news) fresh and of great interest.
Currently popular, fashionable, or in demand.
(of a person) sexually attractive.
(of the scent) fresh and strong, indicating that the quarry has passed recently.
(in children's games) very close to finding or guessing something.
Very knowledgeable or skilful.
Good.
Regarding (something) as very important; strict about.
Difficult to deal with.
(of goods) stolen and difficult to dispose of because easily identifiable.
(of a person) wanted by the police.
Make or become hot.
Become or make more lively or exciting.
--Examples--
‘it was hot inside the hall’
‘a hot day’
‘she felt hot and her throat was parched’
‘this soup is equally good hot or cold’
‘a very hot dish cooked with green chilli’
‘the idea had been nurtured in his hot imagination’
‘her reply came boiling out of her, hot with rage’
‘steamy bed scenes which may be too hot for young fans’
‘hot salsa and lambada dancing’
‘the environment has become a very hot issue’
‘have I got some hot gossip for you!’
‘they know the hottest dance moves’
‘a hot chick’
‘Tony is very hot on local history’
‘this is not so hot for business’
‘local customs officers are hot on confiscations’
‘he found my story simply too hot to handle’
‘he hotted up the flask’
‘the championship contest hotted up’

--Word--
yellow 
--Type--
adjective, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Of the colour between green and orange in the spectrum, a primary subtractive colour complementary to blue; coloured like ripe lemons or egg yolks.
Having a naturally yellowish or olive skin (as used to describe Chinese or Japanese people).
Denoting a warning of danger which is thought to be near but not actually imminent.
Not brave; cowardly.
Showing jealousy or suspicion.
(of a style of writing, especially in journalism) lurid and sensational.
Yellow colour or pigment.
Yellow clothes or material.
A yellow ball or piece in a game or sport, especially the yellow ball in snooker.
Used in names of moths or butterflies that are mainly yellow in colour.
Any of a number of plant diseases in which the leaves turn yellow, typically caused by viruses and transmitted by insects.
Become yellow, especially with age.
--Examples--
‘curly yellow hair’
‘he put Camp Visoko on yellow alert’
‘he'd better get back there quick and prove he's not yellow’
‘he based his judgement on headlines and yellow journalism’
‘the craft detonated in a blaze of red and yellow’
‘a wide range of colours from rich vibrant reds, yellows, blues, and greens to more unexpected pastel shades’
‘everyone dresses in yellow’
‘he missed an easy yellow in frame four’
‘the cream paint was beginning to yellow’

--Word--
blue 
--Type--
adjective, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Of a colour intermediate between green and violet, as of the sky or sea on a sunny day.
(of a person's skin) having turned blue as a result of cold or breathing difficulties.
(of a bird or other animal) having blue markings.
(of a cat, fox, or rabbit) having fur of a smoky grey colour.
(of a ski run) of the second-lowest level of difficulty, as indicated by blue markers positioned along it.
Denoting one of three colours of quark.
(of a person or mood) melancholy, sad, or depressed.
(of a film, joke, or story) having sexual or pornographic content.
Politically conservative.
Blue colour or pigment.
Blue clothes or material.
The blue ball in snooker, billiards, and similar games.
The sky or sea, or the unknown.
A small butterfly, the male of which is predominantly blue while the female is typically brown.
A person who has represented Cambridge University (a Cambridge blue) or Oxford University (an Oxford blue) at a particular sport in a match between the two universities.
A distinction awarded to a Cambridge blue or an Oxford blue.
An argument or fight.
A mistake.
A nickname for a red-headed person.
A supporter of the Conservative Party.
Make or become blue.
Heat (metal) so as to give it a greyish-blue finish.
Wash (white clothes) with bluing.
--Examples--
‘the clear blue sky’
‘a blue silk shirt’
‘deep blue eyes’
‘Ashley went blue and I panicked’
‘a blue jay’
‘the blue fox’
‘he's feeling blue’
‘a blue movie’
‘the successful blue candidate’
‘she was dressed in blue’
‘the dark blue of his eyes’
‘armchairs in pastel blues and greens’
‘Susan wore blue’
‘far out upon the blue were many sails’
‘a flyweight boxing blue’
‘Adrian's brother won a rugby blue in December’
‘did you have a blue or what?’
‘his tactical blue in saying the opposition wasn't ready to govern’
‘only an Aussie could make a red-headed man ‘Blue.’’
‘the light dims, bluing the retina’
‘blued paper’
‘the day would haze, the air bluing with afternoon’
‘nickel-plated or blued hooks’
‘they blued the shirts and starched the uniforms’

rolled-up 
--Type--
adjective

--Word--
blues 
--Type--
plural noun
--Meanings--
Melancholic music of black American folk origin, typically in a twelve-bar sequence. It developed in the rural southern US towards the end of the 19th century, finding a wider audience in the 1940s, as blacks migrated to the cities. This urban blues gave rise to rhythm and blues and rock and roll.
A piece of blues music.
Feelings of melancholy, sadness, or depression.
--Examples--
‘blues has always had a strong following in Australia’
‘a blues singer’
‘a blues in C’
‘she's got the blues’

--Word--
slate 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A fine-grained grey, green, or bluish-purple metamorphic rock easily split into smooth, flat plates.
A flat plate of slate used as roofing material.
A flat plate of slate formerly used for writing on in schools.
A record of a person's debit or credit (in pubs and shops formerly written on a slate)
A small portable computer that accepts input directly on to its screen rather than via a keyboard or mouse; a tablet computer.
A bluish-grey colour.
A list of candidates for election to a post or office, typically a group sharing a set of political views.
A range of something on offer.
A board showing the identifying details of a take in a film, held in front of the camera at the beginning and end of the take.
Cover (something, especially a roof) with slates.
Criticize severely.
Schedule; plan.
Nominate (someone) as a candidate for an office or post.
Identify (a take in a film) using a slate.
--Examples--
‘slate quarries’
‘a slate floor’
‘a loose slate falls from the roof’
‘a grey slate roof’
‘the teacher was demonstrating, the children copying on to slates’
‘‘Five quid,’ said the barman. ‘Put it on my slate,’ I suggested’
‘after getting our hands on one this afternoon, we found that it’s a solid, well-performing slate that’s easy on the eyes’
‘suits of slate grey’
‘candidates on the left's slate won 74 per cent of constituency votes’
‘the company has revealed details of a $60m slate of film productions’
‘the electronic time-code system allowed us to shoot with or without conventional slates’
‘he was working for his father slating a new roof’
‘a slated roof’
‘his work was slated by the critics’
‘London shows are slated for late June’
‘construction is slated to begin late next year’
‘I understand that I am being slated for promotion’
‘the assistant cameraman is about to slate the scene’

bluetongue 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An insect-borne viral disease of sheep (transmissible with less serious effects to cattle and goats), characterized by fever, lameness, and a blue, swollen mouth and tongue.

blue and white

--Word--
bluff 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An attempt to deceive someone into believing that one can or is going to do something.
Try to deceive someone as to one's abilities or intentions.
Survive a difficult situation by maintaining a pretence.
--Examples--
‘the offer was denounced as a bluff’
‘his game of bluff’
‘he's been bluffing all along’
‘they bluffed their way past the sentries’
‘the object is to bluff your opponent into submission’
‘there's no point in trying to bluff it out’

‘his game of bluff’
‘he's been bluffing all along’
‘they bluffed their way past the sentries’
‘the object is to bluff your opponent into submission’
‘there's no point in trying to bluff it out’
--Word--
bluffer 
--Type--

--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
bluffer 
--Type--

--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
bluff 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An attempt to deceive someone into believing that one can or is going to do something.
Try to deceive someone as to one's abilities or intentions.
Survive a difficult situation by maintaining a pretence.
--Examples--
‘the offer was denounced as a bluff’
‘his game of bluff’
‘he's been bluffing all along’
‘they bluffed their way past the sentries’
‘the object is to bluff your opponent into submission’
‘there's no point in trying to bluff it out’

Blu-Tack 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A pale blue adhesive substance typically used to attach paper to walls or other hard surfaces.
Attach (something) to a wall or other hard surface using Blu-Tack.
--Examples--
‘you needn't invest in permanent notices: slips of paper and Blu-Tack will do’
‘he's Blu-Tacked a large map of the British Isles to his wall’
--Word--
Blum, Léon 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1872–1950), French statesman, prime minister 1936–7, 1938, 1946–7. As France's first socialist and Jewish prime minister, Blum introduced significant labour reforms.
--Examples--
--Word--
Blume, Judy 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(born 1938), US author, mostly of fiction for young adults; full name Judith Sussman Blume. Her works include Are You There, God? It's Me, Margaret (1970), Tales of a Fourth Grade Nothing (1972), Forever … (1975), and, for adults, Wifey (1978) and Summer Sisters (1998).
--Examples--

blunder 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A stupid or careless mistake.
Make a stupid or careless mistake; act or speak clumsily.
Move clumsily or as if unable to see.
--Examples--
‘she stopped, finally aware of the terrible blunder she had made’
‘he knew he'd blundered’
‘we were blundering around in the darkness’
--Word--
blunderbuss 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A short large-bored gun firing balls or slugs.
An action or way of doing something regarded as lacking in subtlety and precision.
--Examples--
‘economists resort too quickly to the blunderbuss of regulation’

--Word--
blunt 
--Type--
adjective, verb, noun
--Meanings--
(of a cutting implement) not having a sharp edge or point.
Having a flat or rounded end.
(of a person or remark) uncompromisingly forthright.
Make or become less sharp.
Weaken or reduce the force of (something)
A hollowed-out cigar filled with cannabis.
--Examples--
‘a blunt knife’
‘the blunt tip of the leaf’
‘a blunt statement of fact’
‘wood can blunt your axe’
‘the edge may blunt very rapidly’
‘their determination had been blunted’

--Word--
blur 
--Type--
verb, noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Make or become unclear or less distinct.
A thing that cannot be seen or heard clearly.
Something remembered or perceived indistinctly, typically because it happened very fast.
(of a person) stupid, clumsy, or confused.
--Examples--
‘tears blurred her vision’
‘his novels blur the boundaries between criticism and fiction’
‘in front of him the page blurred’
‘the pale blur of her face’
‘the words were a blur’
‘the day before was a blur’
‘it was kinda funny seeing how blur someone can be when having to do a task they have no clue about’
--Word--

--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A short description of a book, film, or other product written for promotional purposes.
Write or contribute a blurb for (a book, film, or other product)
--Examples--
‘this is the first time I have blurbed a whole line of books’

blurry 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Not clearly or distinctly visible or audible.
Unable to perceive clear or sharp images.
Perceived or remembered indistinctly.
--Examples--
‘video projectors provided extremely blurry images’
‘vision may be hazy or blurry for a few days after surgery’
‘their eyes were blurry with tears’
‘there's a very blurry line between art and advertising’
‘my memories of him are blurry at best’

--Word--
blush 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Show shyness, embarrassment, or shame by becoming red in the face.
Feel embarrassed or ashamed.
Be or become pink or pale red.
A reddening of the face as a sign of shyness, embarrassment, or shame.
A pink or pale red tinge.
A wine with a slight pink tint made in the manner of white wine but from red grape varieties.
--Examples--
‘she blushed at the unexpected compliment’
‘Kate felt herself blushing scarlet’
‘he blushed to think of how he'd paraded himself’
‘the trees are loaded with blushing blossoms’
‘he had brought a faint blush to her cheeks’
‘the roses were white with a lovely pink blush’
‘blush Zinfandel’

--Word--
compelling 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Evoking interest, attention, or admiration in a powerfully irresistible way.
Not able to be refuted; inspiring conviction.
Not able to be resisted; overwhelming.
--Examples--
‘his eyes were strangely compelling’
‘a compelling film’
‘there is compelling evidence that the recession is ending’
‘a compelling argument’
‘the temptation to give up was compelling’

--Word--
blusher 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A cosmetic of a powder or cream consistency used to give a warm colour to the cheeks.
A toadstool with a buff cap bearing fluffy white spots and with white flesh that turns pink when bruised or cut, found in woodland in Eurasia and North America.
--Examples--
--Word--
blusher 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A cosmetic of a powder or cream consistency used to give a warm colour to the cheeks.
A toadstool with a buff cap bearing fluffy white spots and with white flesh that turns pink when bruised or cut, found in woodland in Eurasia and North America.
--Examples--
--Word--
blush 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Show shyness, embarrassment, or shame by becoming red in the face.
Feel embarrassed or ashamed.
Be or become pink or pale red.
A reddening of the face as a sign of shyness, embarrassment, or shame.
A pink or pale red tinge.
A wine with a slight pink tint made in the manner of white wine but from red grape varieties.
--Examples--
‘she blushed at the unexpected compliment’
‘Kate felt herself blushing scarlet’
‘he blushed to think of how he'd paraded himself’
‘the trees are loaded with blushing blossoms’
‘he had brought a faint blush to her cheeks’
‘the roses were white with a lovely pink blush’
‘blush Zinfandel’

--Word--
bluster 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Talk in a loud, aggressive, or indignant way with little effect.
(of a storm, wind, or rain) blow or beat fiercely and noisily.
Loud, aggressive, or indignant talk with little effect.
--Examples--
‘you threaten and bluster, but won't carry it through’
‘‘I don't care what he says,’ I blustered’
‘a winter gale blustered against the sides of the house’
‘their threats contained a measure of bluster’
--Word--

--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

Talking in a loud, aggressive, or indignant way with little effect.
--Examples--
‘a strong, blustering gale’
‘a blustering bully’

--Word--
boar 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A tusked Eurasian wild pig from which domestic pigs are descended, exterminated in Britain in the 17th century.
The flesh of the wild boar as food.
An uncastrated domestic male pig.
The full-grown male of certain other animals, especially a badger, guinea pig, or hedgehog.
--Examples--
--Word--
board 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A long, thin, flat piece of wood or other hard material, used for floors or other building purposes.
The stage of a theatre.
The part of the floor of a shearing shed where the shearers work.
A thin, flat piece of wood or other stiff material used for various purposes.
A vertical surface on which to write or pin notices.
A horizontal surface on which to cut things, play games, or perform other activities.
A flat insulating sheet used as a mounting for an electronic circuit.
The piece of equipment on which a person stands in surfing, skateboarding, snowboarding, and certain other sports.
Pieces of thick stiff card used for book covers.
The wooden structure surrounding an ice-hockey rink.
A group of people constituted as the decision-making body of an organization.
The provision of regular meals when one stays somewhere, in return for payment or services.
A table set for a meal.
A distance covered by a vessel in a single tack.
Get on or into (a ship, aircraft, or other vehicle)
(of an aircraft) be ready for passengers to get on.
Live and receive regular meals in a house in return for payment or services.
(of a pupil) live in school during term time.
Provide (a person or animal) with regular meals and somewhere to live in return for payment.
Cover or seal a window or building with pieces of wood.
Ride on a snowboard.
--Examples--
‘loose boards creaked as I walked on them’
‘sections of board’
‘he will be on the boards at Stratford tonight’
‘teachers talk and write on the board’
‘Pete set the pieces out on the board’
‘a graphics board’
‘you kick-turn with both feet on the board’
‘he sits on the board of directors’
‘a board meeting’
‘board and lodging’
‘he looked at the banquet which was spread upon his board’
‘we were tacking up to the anchor, shortening cable at each board’
‘we boarded the plane for Oslo’
‘they would not be able to board without a ticket’
‘Flight 172 to Istanbul is now boarding’
‘the cousins boarded for a while with Ruby’
‘parents had to cope with their child boarding at a special school’
‘dogs may have to be boarded at kennels’
‘the shop was still boarded up’
‘when we're not boarding, we're skiing’

--Word--
boast 
--Type--
verb, noun, noun
--Meanings--
Talk with excessive pride and self-satisfaction about one's achievements, possessions, or abilities.
(of a person, place, or thing) possess (a feature that is a source of pride)
An act of talking with excessive pride and self-satisfaction.
(in squash) a stroke in which the ball is made to hit one of the side walls before hitting the front wall.
--Examples--
‘she boasted about her many conquests’
‘he boasted that he had taken part in the crime’
‘Ted used to boast ‘I manage ten people.’’
‘the hotel boasts high standards of comfort’
‘I said I would win and it wasn't an idle boast’

noun, verb
--Meanings--
A small vessel for travelling over water, propelled by oars, sails, or an engine.
A vessel of any size, especially a large one.
A serving dish in the shape of a boat.
Travel in a boat for pleasure.
Transport (someone or something) in a boat.
(of an angler) draw (a hooked fish) into a boat.
--Examples--
‘a fishing boat’
‘a boat trip’
‘those newly arriving here by boat or plane’
‘a gravy boat’
‘they boated through fjords’
‘she likes to go boating’
‘they boated the timber down the lake’
‘he boated a 2 lb 14oz Dover sole’
--Word--
boatel 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A waterside hotel with facilities for mooring boats.
A ship moored at a wharf and used as a hotel.

boatfly 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A predatory water boatman of the genus Notonecta (family Notonectidae), which swims on its back using its long hind legs as oars.

boat 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A small vessel for travelling over water, propelled by oars, sails, or an engine.
A vessel of any size, especially a large one.
A serving dish in the shape of a boat.

‘they boated through fjords’

‘they boated the timber down the lake’
‘he boated a 2 lb 14oz Dover sole’
--Word--
handler 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who handles or deals with certain articles or commodities.
A device which handles certain articles or substances.
A person who trains or has charge of an animal, in particular a police officer in charge of a dog.
A person who trains or manages another person.
A person who trains and acts as second to a boxer.
A publicity agent.
A person who directs the activities of a spy or other freelance agent.
--Examples--
‘a baggage handler’
‘a food handler’
‘the company launched three telescopic handlers’

--Word--
boat race 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A race between rowing crews.
The annual boat race between Oxford and Cambridge. First rowed at Henley in 1829, it has been held over its present course, from Putney to Mortlake (6.8 km, 4.25 miles), since 1845.
A person's face.

adjective
--Meanings--

noun

--Word--
boat-tailed grackle 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of several American grackles of the genus Quiscalus (family Icteridae) having keel-shaped tails; specifically Q. major, found in coastal areas of the south-eastern United States.

--Word--
bob 
--Type--
abbreviation, verb, noun
--Meanings--
Bolivian boliviano(s).
Make a quick, short movement up and down.
Cause (something) to make a bobbing movement.
Make a sudden move so as to appear or disappear.
Make a brief curtsy.
A quick, short movement up and down.
A brief curtsy.
--Examples--
‘I could see his head bobbing about’
‘the boat bobbed up and down’
‘she bobbed her head’
‘a lady bobbed up from beneath the counter’
‘she bobbed and turned away’
‘she could only manage a slight bob of her head’
‘the maid scurried away with a bob’

bobble 
--Type--
noun, verb, noun
--Meanings--
A small ball made of strands of wool used as a decoration on a hat or on furnishings.
Small plastic balls attached to a circular piece of elastic, used for fastening girls' hair.
Move with a feeble or irregular bouncing motion.
Mishandle (a ball)
A feeble or irregular bouncing motion.
A mishandling of a ball.
--Examples--
‘a woollen ski hat with a bobble on top’
‘a bobble hat’
‘some of those goals have bobbled in off the post’
‘Andy bobbled the ball, so his throw home was too late’
‘a once-a-season bobble en route to a breakaway jam’

Bobo-Dioulasso 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A commercial and industrial city in southwestern Burkina Faso; population 483,800 (est. 2009). It is an agricultural market and rail center.

noun, verb

wig out

--Word--
Boccaccio, Giovanni 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1313–75), Italian writer, poet, and humanist. He is most famous for the Decameron (1348–58), a collection of a hundred tales told by ten young people who have moved to the country to escape the Black Death.

--Type--

--Word--
body 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The physical structure, including the bones, flesh, and organs, of a person or an animal.
The trunk apart from the head and the limbs.
A corpse.
The physical and mortal aspect of a person as opposed to the soul or spirit.
A person's body regarded as an object of sexual desire.
A person of a specified type.
The main section of a motor vehicle or aircraft.
The main or central part of something, especially a building or text.
The part of an email containing the message, as opposed to information such as the subject and sender.
A large amount or collection of something.
An organized group of people with a common purpose or function.
A material object.
A full or substantial quality of flavour in wine.
Fullness or thickness of a person's hair.
A woman's close-fitting stretch garment for the upper body, fastening at the crotch.
(in pottery) a clay used for making the main part of ceramic ware, as distinct from a glaze.
Give material form to something abstract.
Build the bodywork of (a motor vehicle)
--Examples--
‘it's important to keep your body in good condition’
‘the blow almost severed his head from his body’
‘they found his body washed up on the beach’
‘we're together in body and spirit’
‘he was just after her body’
‘a motherly body’
‘the factory had produced more car bodies than needed’
‘the body of the aircraft was filled with smoke’
‘the main body of the house was built in 1625’
‘put your name, address, and daytime phone number in the email's body’
‘a rich body of Canadian folklore’
‘large bodies of seawater’
‘a regulatory body’
‘international bodies of experts’
‘the path taken by the falling body’
‘best of all, this wine has body and finish’
‘restructuring formulations help to add body’
‘he bodied forth the traditional Prussian remedy for all ills’
‘an era when automobiles were bodied over wooden frames’

In one mass; as a whole.

--Word--
Boer 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of the Dutch and Huguenot population which settled in southern Africa in the late 17th century. The Boers' present-day descendants are the Afrikaners.
An Afrikaner farmer.
(under apartheid) a member of the police, prison service, or security forces.
Relating to the Boers.

Boethius 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(c.480–524), Roman statesman and philosopher; full name Anicius Manlius Severinus Boethius. He is best known for The Consolation of Philosophy, which he wrote while in prison on a charge of treason.

boff 
--Type--
verb, noun, noun
--Meanings--
Have sexual intercourse with (someone).
Hit (someone).
An act of sexual intercourse.
A blow or punch.
--Examples--
--Word--
boffin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person engaged in scientific or technical research.
A person with knowledge or a skill considered to be complex or arcane.
--Examples--
‘the boffins at the Telecommunications Research Establishment’
‘a computer boffin’
--Word--
boffin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person engaged in scientific or technical research.
A person with knowledge or a skill considered to be complex or arcane.
--Examples--
‘the boffins at the Telecommunications Research Establishment’
‘a computer boffin’
--Word--
boffo 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
(of a theatrical production or film, or a review of one) very successful or wholeheartedly commendatory.
(of a laugh) deep and unrestrained.
Boisterously funny.
A success.
--Examples--
‘a boffo box office certainty’
‘I'm not going for the big boffo laughs’
‘the finale is a genuine boffo’
--Word--
boffola 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A joke or a line in a script intended to get a laugh.
(of a laugh) hearty and unrestrained.
--Examples--
--Word--
boffola 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A joke or a line in a script intended to get a laugh.
(of a laugh) hearty and unrestrained.

bog 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An area of wet muddy ground that is too soft to support a heavy body.
Wetland with acid peaty soil, typically dominated by peat moss.
The toilet.
Be or become stuck in mud or wet ground.
Be prevented from making progress in a task or activity.
Go away.
Start a task enthusiastically.
--Examples--
‘a peat bog’
‘a bog of legal complications’
‘the island is a wilderness of bog and loch’
‘the family Rover became bogged down on the beach road’
‘you must not get bogged down in detail’
‘I told him to bog off’
‘if he saw a trucker in difficulty, he would just bog in and give a hand’
--Word--
bogan 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
An uncouth or unsophisticated person regarded as being of low social status.
A side stream.
--Examples--
‘some bogans yelled at us from their cars’
‘my family are culinary bogans’

--Word--
Bogarde, Sir Dirk 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1921–99), British actor and writer, of Dutch descent; born Derek Niven van den Bogaerde. He became famous in the ‘Doctor’ series of comedy films, and played more serious roles in films such as The Servant (1963) and Death in Venice (1971).
--Examples--
--Word--
bogart 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--

--Examples--
‘don't bogart that joint, my friend’

noun
--Meanings--

bogey 
--Type--
noun, verb, noun, noun
--Meanings--
A score of one stroke over par at a hole.
Play (a hole) in one stroke over par.
An evil or mischievous spirit.
A person or thing that causes fear or alarm.
An unidentified aircraft.
A piece of nasal mucus.
An act of swimming or bathing.
--Examples--
‘he walked off the green with a bogey four’
‘with a handicap of 17, Jones receives an allowance against bogey of 13 strokes’
‘bogeys and other unpleasant denizens of the night’
‘the bogey of recession’

--Word--
boggle 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
(of a person or their mind) be astonished or baffled when trying to imagine something.
Cause (a person or their mind) to be astonished.
(of a person) hesitate to do or accept.
--Examples--
‘the mind boggles at the spectacle’
‘the inflated salary of a star boggles the mind’
‘you never boggle at plain speaking’

--Word--
Bogotá 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The capital of Colombia, situated in the eastern Andes at about 2,610 m (8,560 ft); population 6,778,691 (2005). It was founded by the Spanish in 1538 on the site of a pre-Columbian centre of the Chibcha culture.
--Examples--

--Word--
trot 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
(with reference to a horse or other quadruped) proceed or cause to proceed at a pace faster than a walk, lifting each diagonal pair of legs alternately.
(of a person) run at a moderate pace with short steps.
Go or walk briskly.
A trotting pace.
An act or period of trotting.
Trotting races.
Diarrhoea.
A period of luck of a specified kind.
--Examples--
‘the horses trotted slowly through the night’
‘he trotted his horse forward’
‘the child trotted across to her obediently’
‘I may trot round to Portobello market for vegetables’
‘our horses slowed to a trot’
‘you might like an early morning trot round the crew deck’
‘she was taking me to the trots’
‘Simpson believes his bad trot is about to end’

--Word--
bohemia 
--Type--
noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
Socially unconventional, artistic people and the areas they frequent, viewed collectively.
A region forming the western part of the Czech Republic. Formerly a Slavic kingdom, it became a province of the newly formed Czechoslovakia by the Treaty of Versailles in 1919.
--Examples--
‘Frances couch-surfs around what remains of New York City's bohemia’
‘one of the legendary figures of London's literary bohemia’
--Word--
Moravia 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A region of the Czech Republic, situated between Bohemia in the west and the Carpathians in the east; chief town, Brno. A province of Bohemia from the 11th century, it was made an Austrian province in 1848, becoming a part of Czechoslovakia in 1918.
--Examples--
--Word--
bohemian 
--Type--
noun, adjective, noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A socially unconventional person, especially one who is involved in the arts.
Socially unconventional in an artistic way.
A native or inhabitant of Bohemia (now the western part of the Czech Republic).
Relating to Bohemia or its people.
--Examples--
‘Warhol and the artists and bohemians he worked with in the 1960s’
‘as an opera singer you live a bohemian lifestyle’
‘the urban setting and jazz score give the film a bohemian feel’
‘a bohemian community of artists’
‘the tombs of Bohemian kings’
‘engraved Bohemian glass’
--Word--
bohemianism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--

--Word--
bohemia 
--Type--
noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
Socially unconventional, artistic people and the areas they frequent, viewed collectively.
A region forming the western part of the Czech Republic. Formerly a Slavic kingdom, it became a province of the newly formed Czechoslovakia by the Treaty of Versailles in 1919.
--Examples--
‘Frances couch-surfs around what remains of New York City's bohemia’
‘one of the legendary figures of London's literary bohemia’
--Word--
boho 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Socially unconventional in a way regarded as characteristic of creative artists; bohemian.
Denoting or relating to a woman's fashion aesthetic characterized by flowing print fabrics, layers of clothing, and costume jewellery such as long ropes of beads, dangling earrings, and multiple bangles.
A person who is socially unconventional in a way regarded as characteristic of creative artists; a bohemian.
--Examples--
‘the sisters and their husbands led a boho life in Big Sur’
‘the stereotypical clash of cultures between boho artists and finance folk’
‘she went for the boho look in a floor-length green dress teamed with a fringed jacket and chandelier earrings’
‘paisley is the ultimate in boho chic’
‘East Village bohos’
--Word--
Bohol 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An island lying to the north of Mindanao in the central Philippines; population 1,384,800 (est. 2009); chief town, Tagbilaran.
--Examples--
--Word--
Bohr theory 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A theory of the structure of atoms stating that electrons revolve in discrete orbits around a positively charged nucleus and that radiation is given off or absorbed only when an electron moves from one orbit to another.
--Examples--
--Word--
bohunk 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An immigrant from central or south-eastern Europe, especially a laborer.
--Examples--

bohunk

--Meanings--

--Word--
boy 
--Type--
noun, exclamation
--Meanings--
A male child or youth.
A person's son.
A male child or young man who does a specified job.
A man, especially a young or relatively young one.
Men who mix socially or who belong to a particular group, team, or profession.
A friendly form of address from one man to another, especially from an older man to a young man.
A black male servant or worker (often used as a form of address).
A form of address to a male dog.
Used to express strong feelings, especially of excitement or admiration.
--Examples--
‘a four-year-old boy’
‘the survey showed that both boys and girls smoked regularly’
‘she put her little boy to bed’
‘a delivery boy’
‘I was the new boy at the office’
‘I hope that our boys will continue to play good quality rugby’
‘he is only going to have two days training with the boys’
‘my dear boy, don't say another word!’
‘down boy!’
‘oh boy, that's wonderful!’

boyar 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of the old aristocracy in Russia, next in rank to a prince.
--Examples--
‘the rise of the boyar class’

‘the rise of the boyar class’

Boyce, William 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1711–79), English composer and organist. His compositions include songs, overtures, and eight symphonies; one of his most famous songs is ‘Hearts of Oak’. He is also noted for his Cathedral Music (1760–73).

boycott 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Withdraw from commercial or social relations with (a country, organization, or person) as a punishment or protest.
Refuse to buy or handle (goods) as a punishment or protest.
Refuse to cooperate with or participate in (a policy or event)
A punitive ban on relations with other bodies, cooperation with a policy, or the handling of goods.
--Examples--
‘we will boycott all banks which take part in the loans scheme’
‘an advert urges consumers to boycott the firm's coffee’
‘most parties indicated that they would boycott the election’
‘a boycott of the negotiations’

--Type--
proper noun

--Word--
boil 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
(with reference to a liquid) reach or cause to reach the temperature at which it bubbles and turns to vapour.
(with reference to a kettle, pan, or other container) heat or be heated until the liquid inside starts to boil.
(with reference to food) cook or be cooked by immersing in boiling water or stock.
Wash or sterilize in very hot water.
Execute (someone) by subjecting them to the heat of boiling liquid.
(of the sea or clouds) be turbulent and stormy.
(of a person or strong emotion) be stirred up.
The temperature at which a liquid bubbles and turns to vapour.
The process of heating a liquid to the temperature at which it bubbles and turns to vapour.
A state of great activity or excitement.
A sudden rise of a fish at a fly.
A casual outdoor meal at which shellfish is prepared by boiling.
A dish of shellfish boiled in a large pot with sweetcorn, potatoes, and other ingredients.
--Examples--
‘we asked people to boil their drinking water’
‘he waited for the water to boil’
‘she boiled the kettle and took down a couple of mugs’
‘the kettle boiled and he filled the teapot’
‘boil the potatoes until well done’
‘make the sauce while the lobsters are boiling’
‘boil bedclothes and towels’
‘one valet was ordered to be boiled alive’
‘a huge cliff with the black sea boiling below’
‘he was boiling with rage’
‘bring the sauce to the boil and simmer for 10 minutes’
‘the kettle's on the boil’
‘he has gone off the boil since opening the campaign’
‘a boil from a fish in a pool’
‘the reappearance of warm days signals another revival: weekend crawfish boils’
‘I will definitely come back and try the crab cakes and lobster boil’
--Word--
boiling 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
At or near boiling point.
Extremely hot.
Boiling point.
The action of bringing a liquid to the temperature at which it bubbles and turns to vapour.
--Examples--
‘boiling water’
‘Saturday is forecast to be boiling and sunny’
‘I felt boiling hot’
‘reheat the sauce to just below boiling’
--Word--
Boyle, Robert 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1627–91), Irish-born scientist. Boyle put forward a view of matter based on particles which was a precursor of the modern theory of chemical elements and a cornerstone of his mechanical philosophy, which became very influential. He is best known for his experiments with the air pump, which led to the law named after him.
--Examples--
--Word--
Boileau, Nicholas 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1636–1711), French critic and poet; full name Nicholas Boileau-Despréaux. Boileau is considered particularly important as one of the founders of French literary criticism. His didactic poem Art poétique (1674) defined principles of composition and criticism.
--Examples--

‘only boiled water should be consumed’

--Word--
Boyne, Battle of the 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A battle fought near the River Boyne in Ireland in 1690, in which the Protestant army of William of Orange, the newly crowned William III, defeated the Catholic army (including troops from both France and Ireland) led by the recently deposed James II. The battle is celebrated annually (on 12 July) in Northern Ireland as a victory for the Protestant cause.
--Examples--
--Word--

bold 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
(of a person, action, or idea) showing a willingness to take risks; confident and courageous.
(of a person or their manner) so confident as to be impudent or presumptuous.
(especially of a child) naughty; badly behaved.
(of a colour, design, or shape) having a strong, vivid, or clear appearance.
Of a kind of typeface having dark, heavy strokes, used especially for emphasis.
A bold typeface or letter.
--Examples--
‘a bold attempt to solve the crisis’
‘no journalist was bold enough to take on the Prime Minister’
‘she tossed him a bold look’
‘I slapped him when he was bold’
‘a coat with bold polka dots’
‘cross references are printed in bold type’
‘Shadow cabinet members listed in bold’

adjective, noun
--Meanings--
(of a person, action, or idea) showing a willingness to take risks; confident and courageous.
(of a person or their manner) so confident as to be impudent or presumptuous.
(especially of a child) naughty; badly behaved.
(of a colour, design, or shape) having a strong, vivid, or clear appearance.
Of a kind of typeface having dark, heavy strokes, used especially for emphasis.
A bold typeface or letter.
--Examples--
‘a bold attempt to solve the crisis’
‘no journalist was bold enough to take on the Prime Minister’
‘she tossed him a bold look’
‘I slapped him when he was bold’
‘a coat with bold polka dots’
‘cross references are printed in bold type’
‘Shadow cabinet members listed in bold’
--Word--
boldface 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A kind of typeface with dark, heavy strokes.
Printed in boldface type.
--Examples--
‘the phrase is given in boldface’
‘boldface letters’
--Word--

--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--

Printed in boldface type.

‘the phrase is given in boldface’
‘boldface letters’
--Word--
boldfaced 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Printed in boldface type.
Flagrant or audacious.
--Examples--
‘boldfaced lies’

--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

‘boldfaced lies’

--Word--
following 
--Type--
preposition, noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Coming after or as a result of.
A body of supporters or admirers.
What follows or comes next.
Next in time.
About to be mentioned.
(of a wind) blowing in the same direction as the course of a vessel etc.
--Examples--
‘police are hunting for two men following a spate of robberies in the area’
‘he attracted a worldwide following’
‘the following are both grammatically correct sentences’
‘the following day there was a ceremony in St Peter's Square’
‘you are required to provide us with the following information’
--Word--
boldness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Willingness to take risks and act innovatively; confidence or courage.
Confidence to an impudent or presumptuous degree.
The quality of having a strong, vivid, or clear appearance.
--Examples--
‘the boldness and independence that characterized his leadership’
‘a president who is showing incredible boldness in going after the cartels’
‘they had the boldness to mock a man who had served his country’
‘you will overlook my boldness, I hope’
‘the boldness of the hues are very startling’
‘these works display a great boldness of forms’
--Word--
boldly 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In a confident and courageous way; showing a willingness to take risks.
In a manner that is so confident as to be impudent or presumptuous.
In a way that is characterized by having a strong, vivid, or clear appearance.
--Examples--
‘you will have our support as long as you fight boldly against corruption’
‘we urge the educational community to act boldly’
‘thieves who boldly robbed the wounded and helpless passengers’
‘I grabbed a couple of boldly patterned fabric samples’
--Word--
bold 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
(of a person, action, or idea) showing a willingness to take risks; confident and courageous.

--Word--
boldo 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An evergreen Chilean tree from which are obtained an edible fruit, a dye, and a medicinal leaf infusion.
A medicinal preparation of the leaves of the boldo tree, used as a tonic and digestive aid.
--Examples--

--Word--
Boleyn, Anne 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1507–36), second wife of Henry VIII and mother of Elizabeth I. Henry divorced Catherine of Aragon in order to marry Anne (1533), but she fell from favour when she failed to provide him with a male heir and was eventually executed on the grounds of alleged infidelities.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Meanings--

A woman's short open jacket.

Bolivia 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A landlocked country in South America; population 11,700,000 (estimated 2015); languages, Spanish (official), Aymara, and Quechua; capital, La Paz; legal capital and seat of the judiciary, Sucre.
--Examples--
--Word--
Bolivian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to Bolivia, its people, or their culture.
A native or inhabitant of Bolivia, or a person of Bolivian descent.
--Examples--
‘a major Bolivian city’
‘a Bolivian who revolutionized salsa’
‘many Bolivians marry in church’
--Word--
boliviano 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The basic monetary unit of Bolivia (1863–1962 and since 1987), equal to 100 centavos or cents.

bologna 
--Type--
noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
A large smoked sausage made of bacon, veal, pork suet, and other meats.
A city in northern Italy, capital of Emilia-Romagna region; population 374,944 (2008). Its university, which dates from the 11th century, is the oldest in Europe.
--Examples--
--Word--
bologna 
--Type--
noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
A large smoked sausage made of bacon, veal, pork suet, and other meats.

--Word--
Bolognese 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to Bologna or its people.
Denoting a sauce of minced beef, tomato, onion, and herbs, typically served with pasta.
A native or inhabitant of Bologna.
A pasta dish made with bolognese sauce, in particular spaghetti bolognese, or the sauce itself.
--Examples--
‘the Bolognese painters of the 17th century’
‘ravioli with bolognese sauce’
‘tagliatelle bolognaise’
‘the Bolognese invented tagliatelle, tortellini, and lasagne’
‘I offered to cook a bolognese for lunch’
‘the bolognaise was delicious’

Bolshevik 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of the majority faction of the Russian Social Democratic Party, which seized power in the October Revolution of 1917.
(in general use) a person with politically subversive or radical views; a revolutionary.
Relating to or characteristic of Bolsheviks or Bolshevism.
--Examples--
‘the Bolshevik revolution’

--Word--
Bolshevik 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of the majority faction of the Russian Social Democratic Party, which seized power in the October Revolution of 1917.

--Examples--

--Word--
Bolshevism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The communist form of government adopted in Russia following the Bolshevik revolution of 1917.
--Examples--
‘enthusiastic supporters of Bolshevism’
--Word--
Bolshevist 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A supporter or member of the majority faction of the Russian Social Democratic Party, which seized power in the October Revolution of 1917.
(in general use) a person with politically subversive or radical views; a revolutionary.
--Examples--
‘the seizure of power by the Bolshevists’
‘the Bolshevist movement’
‘he is not a bolshevist, but he is by nature a bit of a grumbler’
‘students with bolshevist tendencies’

--Word--
Bolshoi Ballet 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A Moscow ballet company. Since 1825 it has been based at the Bolshoi Theatre, where it staged the first production of Tchaikovsky's Swan Lake (1877).
--Examples--
--Word--
bolster 
--Type--
noun, verb, noun
--Meanings--
A long, thick pillow that is placed under other pillows for support.
A part on a vehicle or tool providing structural support or reducing friction.
A short timber cap over a post designed to increase the bearing of the beams it supports.
Support or strengthen.
Provide (a seat) with padded support.
A heavy chisel used for cutting bricks.
--Examples--
‘the fall in interest rates is starting to bolster confidence’
‘they bolstered the seats for a more comfortable ride’

--Meanings--

--Word--
bolt 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A bar that slides into a socket to fasten a door or window.
A long pin with a head that screws into a nut, used to fasten things together.
The sliding piece of the breech mechanism of a rifle.
A long pin that is driven into a rock face so that a rope can be attached to it.
A short, heavy arrow shot from a crossbow.
A jagged white flash of lightning.
Fasten (a door or window) with a bar that slides into a socket.
Fasten (something) to something else with a long pin that screws into a nut.
--Examples--
‘all the doors were locked and bolted’
‘the lid was bolted down’
‘new benefits have been bolted on to the social security system’
--Word--
bolt-action 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a gun) having a breech which is opened by turning a bolt and sliding it back.
--Examples--
--Word--
cutting 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
The action of cutting something.
A piece cut off from something, especially what remains when something is being trimmed or prepared.
An article or other piece cut from a newspaper or periodical.
A piece cut from a plant for propagation.
An open passage excavated through higher ground for a railway, road, or canal.
Capable of cutting something.
(of a comment) causing emotional pain; hurtful.
(of the wind) bitterly cold.
--Examples--
‘the cutting of the cake’
‘tax-cutting’
‘grass cuttings’
‘an archive of newspaper cuttings’
‘take cuttings of Christmas cactus and pot them on’
‘they found the cutting and scrambled down the slope’
‘the cutting blades of the hedge trimmer’
‘a cutting remark’
‘cutting winter winds’
--Word--
bolt 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A bar that slides into a socket to fasten a door or window.
A long pin with a head that screws into a nut, used to fasten things together.
The sliding piece of the breech mechanism of a rifle.
A long pin that is driven into a rock face so that a rope can be attached to it.
A short, heavy arrow shot from a crossbow.
A jagged white flash of lightning.
Fasten (a door or window) with a bar that slides into a socket.
Fasten (something) to something else with a long pin that screws into a nut.
--Examples--
‘all the doors were locked and bolted’
‘the lid was bolted down’
‘new benefits have been bolted on to the social security system’
--Word--
bolter 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person or animal that bolts or runs away.
An outsider in a sporting event or other competition.
An escaped convict or absconder.
--Examples--

--Word--
down 
--Type--
adverb, preposition, adjective, verb, noun
--Meanings--
Towards or in a lower place or position, especially to or on the ground or another surface.
At or to a specified distance below.
Downstairs.
Expressing movement or position away from the north.
To or at a place perceived as lower (often expressing casualness or lack of hurry)
Away from the capital or major city.
Away from a university, especially Oxford or Cambridge.
(with reference to food or drink swallowed) in or into the stomach.
So as to lie or be fixed flush or flat.
Used as a command to a person or animal to sit or lie down.
Referring to a crossword answer which reads vertically.
To or at a lower level of intensity, volume, or activity.
To or at a lower price, value, or rank.
To a finer consistency, a smaller amount or size, or a simpler or more basic state.
From an earlier to a later point in time or order.
In or into a weaker or worse position, mood, or condition.
Losing or at a disadvantage by a specified amount.
Used to express progress through a series of tasks or items.
(of a computer system) out of action or unavailable for use.
Shouted to express strong dislike of a specified person or thing.
In or into writing.
On or on to a list, schedule, or record.
(with reference to partial payment of a sum of money) made initially or on the spot.
(of sailing) with the current or the wind.
(of a ship's helm) moved round to leeward so that the rudder is to windward and the vessel swings toward the wind.
(of the ball or a player in possession) not in play, typically through progress being stopped.
From a higher to a lower point of (something)
At or to the part of (a river or stream) that is nearer the sea.
Moving or at a point further along the course of (something)
At or to (a place)
Throughout (a period of time)
Directed or moving towards a lower place or position.
Relating to or denoting trains travelling away from the main terminus.
Denoting a flavour of quark having a charge of −1/3. Protons and neutrons are thought to be composed of combinations of up and down quarks.
Unhappy; depressed.
(of a computer system) temporarily out of action or unavailable.
Supporting or going along with someone or something.
Aware of and following the latest fashion.
Knock or bring to the ground.
Put (the ball) out of play deliberately by touching one's knee to the ground while holding the ball or touching the ball itself to the ground.
Consume (something, typically a drink)
Sink (a putt)
A chance for a team to advance the ball, ending when the ball carrier is tackled or the ball becomes out of play. A team must advance at least ten yards in a series of four downs in order to keep possession.
Unwelcome experiences or events.
A feeling or period of unhappiness or depression.
--Examples--
‘she looked down’
‘the sun started to go down’
‘he put his glass down’
‘he swung the axe to chop down the tree’
‘you can plainly see the bottom 35 feet down’
‘I went down to put the kettle on’
‘they're living down south’
‘I'd rather be down at the villa’
‘I'm going down to the pub’
‘there are eight trains a day, four up and four down’
‘he was down from Oxford’
‘she couldn't keep anything down’
‘she stuck down a Christmas label’
‘down, boy!’
‘how many letters in fifteen down?’
‘keep the noise down’
‘the panic was dying down’
‘at night it would cool down’
‘output was down by 20 per cent’
‘soup is down from 59p to 49p’
‘I must slim down a bit’
‘a formal statement that can't be edited down’
‘thin down an oil-based paint with spirits’
‘buildings in England down to 1540’
‘everyone, from the President down to the bloke selling hot dogs, wants her dead’
‘the scandal brought down the government’
‘he was down with the flu’
‘United were 3–0 down’
‘one down and only six more to go’
‘the system went down yesterday’
‘crowds chanted ‘Down with America!’’
‘Graham noted the numbers down carefully’
‘taking down notes’
‘I'll put you down for the evening shift’
‘pay £5 down and the rest at the end of the month’
‘up and down the stairs’
‘tears streaming down her face’
‘a dozen miles or so down the Thames’
‘he lived down the street’
‘I wandered down the road’
‘she was tired of going down the pub every night’
‘astrologers down the ages’
‘the down escalator’
‘click on the down arrow’
‘we travelled on the first down train’
‘he's been so down lately’
‘sorry, but the computer's down’
‘you got to be down with me’
‘she was totally down for a selfie’
‘‘You going to the movies?’ ‘Yo, I'm down.’’
‘a seriously down, hip-hop homie’
‘175 enemy aircraft had been downed’
‘he struck Slater on the face, downing him’
‘Jones downed the ball in the end zone’
‘he downed five pints of cider’
‘he downed a 20-foot putt for victory’
‘there had been more downs than ups during his years at Ferrari’
‘everyone gets their downs, their depressive periods’

--Word--
bolt 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A bar that slides into a socket to fasten a door or window.
A long pin with a head that screws into a nut, used to fasten things together.
The sliding piece of the breech mechanism of a rifle.
A long pin that is driven into a rock face so that a rope can be attached to it.
A short, heavy arrow shot from a crossbow.
A jagged white flash of lightning.
Fasten (a door or window) with a bar that slides into a socket.
Fasten (something) to something else with a long pin that screws into a nut.
--Examples--
‘all the doors were locked and bolted’
‘the lid was bolted down’
‘new benefits have been bolted on to the social security system’

bomb 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
