An explosive device fitted into a specified object.
Nuclear weapons considered collectively as agents of mass destruction.
A lump of lava thrown out by an erupting volcano.
A pear-shaped weight used to anchor a fishing line to the bottom.
A large sum of money.
A film, play, or other event that fails badly.
An outstandingly good person or thing.
A long forward pass or hit in a ball game.
A cannabis cigarette.
Attack (a place or object) with a bomb or bombs.
Make someone homeless by destroying their home with bombs.
Move very quickly.
(of a film, play, or other event) fail badly.
--Examples--
‘a bomb attack’
‘a 100 lb van bomb’
‘she joined the fight against the bomb’

‘they bombed the city at dawn’

‘we were bombing down the motorway at breakneck speed’

--Word--
bone 
--Type--
noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
Any of the pieces of hard whitish tissue making up the skeleton in humans and other vertebrates.
One's body.
A corpse or skeleton.
A bone of an animal with meat on it fed to a dog.
The calcified material of which bones consist.
A substance similar to bone, such as ivory or whalebone.
A thing made or formerly made of bone, such as a strip of stiffening for a foundation garment.
(in southern Africa) one of a set of carved dice or bones used by traditional healers in divination.
The basic or essential framework of something.
--Examples--
‘his injuries included many broken bones’
‘a shoulder bone’
‘he hauled his tired bones upright’
‘the discovery of the bones of Richard III’
‘dogs yelping over a bone’
‘an earring of bone’
‘you need to put some flesh on the bones of your idea’

noun
--Meanings--
A situation which creates a sudden increase in wealth, good fortune, or profits.
A large amount of something desirable.
--Examples--
‘a natural gas bonanza for Britain’
‘a bonanza year for the computer industry’
‘the festive feature-film bonanza’
--Word--
Bonaparte 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A Corsican family including the three French rulers named Napoleon.
--Examples--
--Word--
Bonapartism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The political movement in France that aimed to restore the French empire under the house of Bonaparte.
--Examples--
‘a continuity of Bonapartism throughout the 19th century’
--Word--
Bonapartist 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Consistent with or supportive of the political movement in France that aimed to restore the French empire under the house of Bonaparte.
A supporter of the political movement in France that aimed to restore the French empire under the house of Bonaparte.
--Examples--
‘a Bonapartist regime’
‘an ardent Bonapartist’
--Word--
Law, Bonar 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1858–1923), Canadian-born British Conservative statesman, prime minister 1922–3; full name Andrew Bonar Law. He was leader of the Conservative Party 1911–21. He retired in 1921, but returned in 1922, following Lloyd George's resignation, to become prime minister for six months.
--Examples--
--Word--
nulla bona 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The return made (by a sheriff or other officer) upon an execution for debt when the party has no goods to be seized.
--Examples--
--Word--
Bonaventura, St. 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1221–74), Franciscan theologian; born Giovanni di Fidanza ; known as the Seraphic Doctor. He wrote the official biography of St. Francis. Feast day, July 15 (formerly 14).
--Examples--

--Word--
bond 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A thing used to tie something or to fasten things together.
Ropes, chains, or other restraints used to hold someone prisoner.
A force or feeling that unites people; a shared emotion or interest.
An agreement with legal force.
A deed by which a person is committed to make payment to another.
A mortgage.
A certificate issued by a government or a public company promising to repay borrowed money at a fixed rate of interest at a specified time.
An insurance policy held by a company, which protects against losses resulting from circumstances such as bankruptcy.
A sum of money paid as bail.
A strong force of attraction holding atoms together in a molecule or crystal, resulting from the sharing or transfer of electrons.
A pattern in which bricks are laid in order to ensure the strength of the resulting structure.
Join or be joined securely to something else, especially by means of an adhesive substance, heat, or pressure.
Establish a relationship or link with someone based on shared feelings, interests, or experiences.
Join or be joined by a chemical bond.
Lay (bricks) in an overlapping pattern so as to form a strong structure.
Place (dutiable goods) in bond.
--Examples--
‘she brushed back a curl which had strayed from its bonds’
‘he stooped over the trussed man and tested his bonds’
‘there was a bond of understanding between them’
‘each carbon atom uses three electrons to form bonds with the adjacent atoms’
‘stretcher bond’
‘press the material to bond the layers together’
‘this material will bond well to stainless steel rods’
‘the failure to properly bond with their children’
‘neutral molecules bond to the central atom’
‘a bonding course’
‘they want the introduction of bonding to guarantee that consignments will be properly handled’
--Word--
bonding 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
The establishment of a relationship or link with someone based on shared feelings, interests, or experiences.
Having the function of joining things securely, especially by means of an adhesive substance, heat, or pressure.
Establishing a relationship or link with someone based on shared feelings, interests, or experiences.
--Examples--
‘we were friendly to each other, but there was no bonding’
‘a bonding agent’
‘it's bonding to sing together’
--Word--
bondage 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The state of being a slave.
Sexual practice that involves the tying up or restraining of one partner.
--Examples--
‘the deliverance of the Israelites from Egypt's bondage’
‘the bondage of drug addiction’
--Word--
bondager 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who performed services as a condition of feudal tenure.
(in southern Scotland and north-eastern England) a female outworker supplied to a proprietor by a tenant.

--Word--
bonded 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a thing or things) joined securely to another or each other, especially by an adhesive, heat process, or pressure.
Emotionally or psychologically linked.
Held by a chemical bond.
(of a person or company) bound by a legal agreement.
(of a travel agent or tour operator) holding an insurance policy which protects travellers' holidays and money should the company go bankrupt.
(of a worker or workforce) obliged to work for a particular employer, typically in a condition close to slavery.
(of dutiable goods) placed in bond.
--Examples--
‘a bonded carpet’
‘a strongly bonded group of females’
‘bonded atoms’
‘a fully bonded member of the Association of Independent Tour Operators’
‘it is estimated that there are now some 50 million bonded labourers’

A pattern in which bricks are laid in order to ensure the strength of the resulting structure.
Join or be joined securely to something else, especially by means of an adhesive substance, heat, or pressure.
Establish a relationship or link with someone based on shared feelings, interests, or experiences.

--Word--
bone 
--Type--
noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
Any of the pieces of hard whitish tissue making up the skeleton in humans and other vertebrates.
One's body.
A corpse or skeleton.
A bone of an animal with meat on it fed to a dog.
The calcified material of which bones consist.
A substance similar to bone, such as ivory or whalebone.
A thing made or formerly made of bone, such as a strip of stiffening for a foundation garment.
(in southern Africa) one of a set of carved dice or bones used by traditional healers in divination.
The basic or essential framework of something.
--Examples--
‘his injuries included many broken bones’
‘a shoulder bone’
‘he hauled his tired bones upright’
‘the discovery of the bones of Richard III’
‘dogs yelping over a bone’
‘an earring of bone’
‘you need to put some flesh on the bones of your idea’
--Word--
ace 
--Type--
noun, adjective, verb
--Meanings--
A playing card with a single spot on it, ranked as the highest card in its suit in most card games.
A person who excels at a particular sport or other activity.
A pilot who has shot down many enemy aircraft.
(in tennis and similar games) a service that an opponent is unable to return and thus wins a point.
A hole in one.
Very good.
(in tennis and similar games) serve an ace against (an opponent)
Score an ace on (a hole) or with (a shot)
Achieve high marks in (a test or exam)
Outdo someone in a competitive situation.
--Examples--
‘the ace of diamonds’
‘life had started dealing him aces again’
‘a motorcycle ace’
‘a Battle of Britain ace’
‘Nadal banged down eight aces in the set’
‘his hole in one at the 15th was Senior's second ace as a professional’
‘an ace swimmer’
‘Ace! You've done it!’
‘he can ace opponents with serves of no more than 62 mph’
‘there was a prize for the first player to ace the hole’
‘I aced my grammar test’
‘the magazine won an award, acing out its rivals’

dryness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Absence or lack of moisture or liquid.
Lack or absence of rainfall or humidity.
Lack of interest, excitement, or embellishment; dullness.
The quality of being unemotional, undemonstrative, or impassive.
The quality in an alcoholic drink of not being sweet.
--Examples--
‘dryness of the mouth may occur while you are taking this medicine’
‘hand sanitizers contain ingredients that help prevent skin dryness’

‘the sea retreated in periods of prolonged dryness’
‘readers are repelled by the dryness of much of the matter’
‘it does little to rescue the ordinary moment from dryness and tedium’
‘the dryness of his delivery’
‘a certain dryness of style’
‘there's a lovely dryness to this straw-coloured wine’

lace 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A fine open fabric of cotton or silk, made by looping, twisting, or knitting thread in patterns and used especially for trimming garments.
Braid used for trimming, especially on military dress uniforms.
A cord or leather strip passed through eyelets or hooks on opposite sides of a shoe or garment and then pulled tight and fastened.
Fasten or tighten (a shoe or garment) by tying the laces.
Tighten a laced corset around the waist of.
Fasten someone into (a garment) by tightening the laces.
(of a garment or shoe) be fastened by means of laces.
Entwine (things, especially fingers) together.
Pass a lace or cord through (a hole)
Add an ingredient, especially alcohol, to (a drink or dish) to enhance its flavour or strength.
Give (something) a large amount or degree of a feature or quality.
lace into
Attack verbally or physically.
--Examples--
‘a dress trimmed in white lace’
‘a lace collar’
‘fine needlepoint laces’
‘his generals were covered with gold lace’
‘brown shoes with laces’
‘he put the shoes on and laced them up’
‘Rosina laced her up tight to show off her neat waist’
‘she couldn't breathe, laced into this frock’
‘the shoes laced at the front’
‘she laced her fingers together’
‘he laced the twine through the eyelets and pulled it tight’
‘coffee laced with brandy’
‘the script is laced with expletives’
‘his voice was laced with derision’
‘Brady laced into his teammates for playing with a lack of passion’

piercing 
--Type--
adjective, noun

‘the piercing cold of winter’
‘I recall one moment of piercing sadness’

‘two months ago, I decided to take out all my piercings’

boneset 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A North American plant of the daisy family, which bears clusters of small white flowers and is used in herbal medicine.
The common comfrey, the ground-up root of which was formerly used as a ‘plaster’ to set broken bones.
--Examples--

bone-tired 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Extremely tired.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Type--

--Meanings--

--Examples--
--Word--
bone 
--Type--
noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
Any of the pieces of hard whitish tissue making up the skeleton in humans and other vertebrates.
One's body.
A corpse or skeleton.
A bone of an animal with meat on it fed to a dog.
The calcified material of which bones consist.
A substance similar to bone, such as ivory or whalebone.
A thing made or formerly made of bone, such as a strip of stiffening for a foundation garment.
(in southern Africa) one of a set of carved dice or bones used by traditional healers in divination.
The basic or essential framework of something.
--Examples--
‘his injuries included many broken bones’
‘a shoulder bone’
‘he hauled his tired bones upright’
‘the discovery of the bones of Richard III’
‘dogs yelping over a bone’
‘an earring of bone’
‘you need to put some flesh on the bones of your idea’
--Word--
wort 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Used in names of plants and herbs, especially those used formerly as food or medicinally, e.g. butterwort, lungwort, woundwort.
A plant or herb used as food or medicinally.
The sweet infusion of ground malt or other grain before fermentation, used to produce beer and distilled malt liquors.
--Examples--
‘yeast is added to the wort’
--Word--
bonfire 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A large open-air fire used for burning rubbish or as part of a celebration.
--Examples--
‘the smell of burning leaves from a garden bonfire’
‘yet again, events had made a bonfire of her plans’

--Word--
bong 
--Type--
noun, verb, noun, noun
--Meanings--
A low-pitched, resonant sound of the kind made by a large bell.
(especially of a bell) emit a low-pitched, resonant sound.
A water pipe used for smoking cannabis or other drugs.
A large piton.
--Examples--
‘the clock had struck the hour and it was only three bongs’

--Word--
bongo 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
Each of a joined pair of small deep-bodied drums, typically held between the knees and played with the fingers.
A forest antelope that has a chestnut coat with narrow white vertical stripes, native to central Africa.
--Examples--

--Word--
Bonhoeffer, Dietrich 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1906–45), German Lutheran theologian and pastor. He was an active opponent of Nazism and was involved in the German resistance movement. Arrested in 1943, he was sent to Buchenwald concentration camp and later executed.
--Examples--

--Word--
bony 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or like bone.
(of a fish eaten as food) having many bones.
(of a person or part of the body) so thin that the bones can be seen.
--Examples--
‘the bony plates that protect turtles and tortoises’
‘he held up his bony fingers’

--Word--
Boniface, St. 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(680–754), Anglo-Saxon missionary; born Wynfrith ; known as the Apostle of Germany. He was sent to Frisia and Germany to spread the Christian faith and was appointed primate of Germany in 732. He was martyred in Frisia. Feast day, June 5.
--Examples--
--Word--
Boniface, St. 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(680–754), Anglo-Saxon missionary; born Wynfrith ; known as the Apostle of Germany. He was sent to Frisia and Germany to spread the Christian faith and was appointed primate of Germany in 732. He was martyred in Frisia. Feast day, June 5.

--Word--
bone 
--Type--
noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
Any of the pieces of hard whitish tissue making up the skeleton in humans and other vertebrates.
One's body.
A corpse or skeleton.
A bone of an animal with meat on it fed to a dog.
The calcified material of which bones consist.
A substance similar to bone, such as ivory or whalebone.
A thing made or formerly made of bone, such as a strip of stiffening for a foundation garment.
(in southern Africa) one of a set of carved dice or bones used by traditional healers in divination.
The basic or essential framework of something.
--Examples--
‘his injuries included many broken bones’
‘a shoulder bone’
‘he hauled his tired bones upright’
‘the discovery of the bones of Richard III’
‘dogs yelping over a bone’
‘an earring of bone’
‘you need to put some flesh on the bones of your idea’
--Word--
Bonington, Chris 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(born 1934), English mountaineer; full name Christian John Storey Bonington. He made the first British ascent of the north face of the Eiger in 1962 and led expeditions to Mount Everest in 1975 and 1985 (when he reached the summit).
--Examples--

bonk 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Hit (someone or something)
Have sexual intercourse.
(of a cyclist or runner) reach a point of exhaustion that makes it impossible to go further.
An act or the sound of hitting someone or something.
An act of sexual intercourse.
A level of exhaustion that makes a cyclist or runner unable to go further.
--Examples--
‘he bonked his head on the plane's low bulkhead’
‘the young couple bonking upstairs’
‘I don't think that bonking the boss is a wise career strategy’
‘I bonked and couldn't pedal another stroke’
‘give it a bonk with a hammer’
‘we had the bonk when we were saddle sore’

--Word--
Bonn 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city in the state of North Rhine-Westphalia in Germany; population 314,300 (est. 2006). From 1949 until the reunification of Germany in 1990 Bonn was the capital of the Federal Republic of Germany.
--Examples--
--Word--
Bonnard, Pierre 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1867–1947), French painter and graphic artist, a member of the Nabi Group. Notable for their rich, glowing colours, his works continue and develop the impressionist tradition; they mostly depict domestic interior scenes, nudes, and landscapes.
--Examples--
--Word--
bonne 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A nursemaid or housemaid, typically a French one.
--Examples--
--Word--
Bonney, William H. 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1859–81), American outlaw; born Henry McCarty; known as Billy the Kid. A notorious robber and murderer, he was captured by Sheriff Pat Garrett in 1880, and was shot by Garrett after he escaped.
--Examples--

--Type--

--Meanings--

bonnet 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A woman's or child's hat tied under the chin and with a brim framing the face.
A soft, round brimless hat like a beret, as worn by men and boys in Scotland.
The velvet cap within a coronet.
The ceremonial feathered headdress of a North American Indian.
The hinged metal canopy covering the engine of a motor vehicle.
A cowl on a chimney.
An additional canvas laced to the foot of a sail to catch more wind.
--Examples--

boo 
--Type--
exclamation, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Said suddenly to surprise someone who is unaware of one's presence.
Said to show disapproval or contempt.
An utterance of ‘boo’ to show disapproval of a speaker or performer.
Say ‘boo’ to show disapproval of a speaker or performer.
--Examples--
‘‘Boo!’ she cried, jumping up to frighten him’
‘‘There's only one bar.’ ‘Boo!’’
‘the audience greeted this comment with boos and hisses’
‘they booed and hissed when he stepped on stage’
‘the team were booed off the pitch’

‘we found that we had boobed and the booking was for the previous week’

--Word--
booby trap 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An apparently harmless object containing a concealed explosive device designed to detonate when someone touches it.
A trap intended as a practical joke, especially one involving an object placed on top of a door ajar ready to fall on a person passing through.
Place a booby trap in or on (an object or area)
--Examples--
‘using the two remaining grenades he booby-trapped the radio’
--Word--
booby-trapped 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of an object or area) planted with a booby trap.
--Examples--
‘a booby-trapped house’
--Word--
booby trap 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--

--Examples--

‘we found that we had boobed and the booking was for the previous week’

--Word--
boo 
--Type--
exclamation, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Said suddenly to surprise someone who is unaware of one's presence.
Said to show disapproval or contempt.
An utterance of ‘boo’ to show disapproval of a speaker or performer.
Say ‘boo’ to show disapproval of a speaker or performer.
--Examples--
‘‘Boo!’ she cried, jumping up to frighten him’
‘‘There's only one bar.’ ‘Boo!’’
‘the audience greeted this comment with boos and hisses’
‘they booed and hissed when he stepped on stage’
‘the team were booed off the pitch’

book 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A written or printed work consisting of pages glued or sewn together along one side and bound in covers.
A literary composition that is published or intended for publication as a book.
A main division of a literary work or of the Bible.
The libretto of a musical or opera, or the script of a play.
Used to refer to studying.
The telephone directory for the area in which someone lives.
A magazine.
An imaginary record or list (often used to emphasize the comprehensiveness of someone's actions or experience)
A bound set of blank sheets for writing in.
A set of records or accounts.
A bookmaker's record of bets accepted and money paid out.
The notebook in which a referee writes the names of players who are cautioned for foul play.
The first six tricks taken by the declarer in a hand of bridge, after which further tricks count towards fulfilling the contract.
A set of tickets, stamps, matches, samples of cloth, etc., bound together.
Reserve (accommodation, a place, etc.); buy (a ticket) in advance.
Reserve accommodation for (someone)
Register one's arrival at a hotel.
Engage (a performer or guest) for an event.
Have all places reserved; be full.
Make an official note of the personal details of (a person who has broken a law or rule)
(of a referee) note down the name of (a player) who is cautioned for foul play.
Leave suddenly.
Move quickly; hurry.
--Examples--
‘a book of selected poems’
‘he's writing a book about his experiences’
‘the Book of Genesis’
‘he was so deep in his books he would forget to eat’
‘is your name in the book?’
‘women's books like Cosmopolitan and Ladies' Home Journal’
‘Charlotte's mother always called magazines ‘books’’
‘she felt every emotion in the book of love’
‘an accounts book’
‘a bid to balance the books’
‘his name went into the book for a foul on Smyth’
‘a pattern book’
‘I have booked a table at the Swan’
‘book early to avoid disappointment’
‘his secretary had booked him into the Howard Hotel’
‘book me a single room at my usual hotel’
‘he booked in at a hotel’
‘the promoter booked him for another appearance’
‘at weekends we're usually booked up’
‘the cop booked me and took me down to the station’
‘McMahon was booked for a foul’
‘they just ate your pizza and drank your soda and booked’
‘my sister and I booked to the playground’
‘I didn't hear the verdict because I had to book it to work’

--Word--
flat 
--Type--
adjective, adverb, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Having a level surface; without raised areas or indentations.
(of land) without hills.
(of an expanse of water) calm and without waves.
Not sloping.
Having a broad level surface but little height or depth; shallow.
(of shoes) without heels or with very low heels.
Lacking emotion; dull and lifeless.
(of a person) without energy or enthusiasm.
(of trade, prices, etc.) not showing much activity; sluggish.
(of a colour) uniform.
(of a photograph or negative) lacking contrast.
(of a sparkling drink) having lost its effervescence.
(of something kept inflated, especially a tyre) having lost some or all of its air, typically because of a puncture.
(of a battery) having exhausted its charge.
(of a fee, wage, or price) the same in all cases, not varying with changed conditions or in particular cases.
(of a denial, contradiction, or refusal) completely definite and firm; absolute.
(of musical sound) below true or normal pitch.
(of a key) having a flat or flats in the signature.
(of a note) a semitone lower than a specified note.
Relating to flat racing.
In or to a horizontal position.
Lying in close juxtaposition, especially against another surface.
So as to become smooth and even.
Completely; absolutely.
Used with an expression of time to emphasize how quickly something can be done or has been done.
Below the true or normal pitch of musical sound.
The flat part of something.
An area of low level ground, especially near water.
A shallow container in which seedlings are grown and sold.
A shoe with a very low heel or no heel.
A railway wagon with a flat floor and no sides or roof; a flatcar.
An upright section of stage scenery mounted on a movable frame.
A flat tyre.
Flat racing.
A musical note lowered a semitone below natural pitch.
The sign ♭, indicating a flat.
Lower (a note) by a semitone.
Make flat; flatten.
--Examples--
‘he sat down on a flat rock’
‘trim the surface of the cake to make it completely flat’
‘thirty-five acres of flat countryside’
‘the flat roof of a garage’
‘a flat rectangular box’
‘a flat cap’
‘‘I'm sorry,’ he said, in a flat voice’
‘his sense of intoxication wore off until he felt flat and weary’
‘the UK housing market was flat’
‘a flat shade of grey’
‘she sipped some of the flat champagne’
‘a flat fare of £2.50’
‘the request was met with a flat refusal’
‘E flat’
‘the Flat season’
‘he was lying flat on his back’
‘she had been knocked flat by the blast’
‘his black curly hair was blown flat across his skull’
‘I hammered the metal flat’
‘I thought you'd turn me down flat’
‘Myers was flat broke’
‘you can prepare a healthy meal in ten minutes flat’
‘it wasn't a question of singing flat, but of simply singing the wrong notes’
‘she placed the flat of her hand over her glass’
‘the shingle flats of the lake’
‘she wore a white strapless dress and a pair of electric blue flats’
‘I've got a flat—there were nails under the wheel’
‘‘blue’ harmony emphasizing the flatted third and seventh’
‘flat the loaves down’

--Word--
bookless 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Lacking books, having no books. Now often: specifically designating a (notional) library, classroom, etc., in which information is stored electronically rather than in printed books, and is accessed by computer.
Chiefly literary or poetic. Ignorant of books, unscholarly. Also as noun (with the and plural concord): unscholarly people as a class.

A strip of leather, card, or other material, used to mark one's place in a book.
A record of the address of a website, file, or other data made to enable quick access in future.
Record the address of (a website, file, etc.) to enable quick access in future.
--Examples--
‘fans will want to bookmark this site’

--Word--
book 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A written or printed work consisting of pages glued or sewn together along one side and bound in covers.
A literary composition that is published or intended for publication as a book.
A main division of a literary work or of the Bible.
The libretto of a musical or opera, or the script of a play.
Used to refer to studying.
The telephone directory for the area in which someone lives.
A magazine.
An imaginary record or list (often used to emphasize the comprehensiveness of someone's actions or experience)
A bound set of blank sheets for writing in.
A set of records or accounts.
A bookmaker's record of bets accepted and money paid out.
The notebook in which a referee writes the names of players who are cautioned for foul play.
The first six tricks taken by the declarer in a hand of bridge, after which further tricks count towards fulfilling the contract.
A set of tickets, stamps, matches, samples of cloth, etc., bound together.
Reserve (accommodation, a place, etc.); buy (a ticket) in advance.
Reserve accommodation for (someone)
Register one's arrival at a hotel.
Engage (a performer or guest) for an event.
Have all places reserved; be full.
Make an official note of the personal details of (a person who has broken a law or rule)
(of a referee) note down the name of (a player) who is cautioned for foul play.
Leave suddenly.
Move quickly; hurry.
--Examples--
‘a book of selected poems’
‘he's writing a book about his experiences’
‘the Book of Genesis’
‘he was so deep in his books he would forget to eat’
‘is your name in the book?’
‘women's books like Cosmopolitan and Ladies' Home Journal’
‘Charlotte's mother always called magazines ‘books’’
‘she felt every emotion in the book of love’
‘an accounts book’
‘a bid to balance the books’
‘his name went into the book for a foul on Smyth’
‘a pattern book’
‘I have booked a table at the Swan’
‘book early to avoid disappointment’
‘his secretary had booked him into the Howard Hotel’
‘book me a single room at my usual hotel’
‘he booked in at a hotel’
‘the promoter booked him for another appearance’
‘at weekends we're usually booked up’
‘the cop booked me and took me down to the station’
‘McMahon was booked for a foul’
‘they just ate your pizza and drank your soda and booked’
‘my sister and I booked to the playground’
‘I didn't hear the verdict because I had to book it to work’

--Word--
wing 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
(in a bird) a modified forelimb that bears large feathers and is used for flying.
(in a bat or pterosaur) a modified forelimb with skin stretched between or behind the fingers.
(in most insects) each of two or four flat extensions of the thoracic cuticle, either transparent or covered in scales.
The wing of a bird as food.
Used with reference to ease and swiftness of movement.
A rigid horizontal structure that projects from both sides of an aircraft and supports it in the air.
A pilot's certificate of ability to fly a plane, indicated by a badge representing a pair of wings.
A raised part of the body of a car or other vehicle above the wheel.
A part of a large building, especially one that projects from the main part.
A group within a political party or other organization having particular views or a particular function.
The sides of a theatre stage out of view of the audience.
(in soccer, rugby, and hockey) the part of the field close to the sidelines.
An attacking player positioned near to one of the sidelines.
A lateral part or projection of an organ or structure.
A thin membranous appendage of a fruit or seed that is dispersed by the wind.
An air force unit of several squadrons or groups.
The right or left flank of the main body of a battle formation.
A flock of plovers (birds)
Travel on wings or by aircraft; fly.
Move, travel, or be sent quickly, as if flying.
Send or convey (something) quickly, as if by air.
Enable (someone or something) to fly or move rapidly.
Shoot (a bird) in the wing, so as to prevent flight without causing death.
Wound (someone) superficially, especially in the arm or shoulder.
Speak or act without preparation; improvise.
--Examples--
‘the thought gave wings to her feet’
‘Michael earned his wings as a commercial pilot’
‘a maternity wing’
‘a candidate from the liberal wing of the party’
‘some sportsmen make no scruple about firing into the thick of a wing of plover’
‘George satisfied his keen urge to fly by winging homewards with the Royal Air Force’
‘the prize will be winging its way to you soon’
‘just jot down the title on a postcard and wing it to us’
‘the convent was at some distance, but fear would wing her steps’
‘one bird was winged for every bird killed’
‘a little preparation puts you ahead of the job-seekers who try to wing it’

Boole, George 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1815–64), English mathematician responsible for Boolean algebra. The study of mathematical or symbolic logic developed mainly from his ideas.
--Examples--
--Word--
Boolean 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Denoting a system of algebraic notation used to represent logical propositions by means of the binary digits 0 (false) and 1 (true), especially in computing and electronics.
A binary variable that can have one of two possible values, 0 (false) or 1 (true).
--Examples--

boo 
--Type--
exclamation, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Said suddenly to surprise someone who is unaware of one's presence.
Said to show disapproval or contempt.
An utterance of ‘boo’ to show disapproval of a speaker or performer.
Say ‘boo’ to show disapproval of a speaker or performer.
--Examples--
‘‘Boo!’ she cried, jumping up to frighten him’
‘‘There's only one bar.’ ‘Boo!’’
‘the audience greeted this comment with boos and hisses’
‘they booed and hissed when he stepped on stage’
‘the team were booed off the pitch’

--Word--
boom 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A loud, deep, resonant sound.
The characteristic resonant cry of the bittern.
Make a loud, deep, resonant sound.
Say in a loud, deep, resonant voice.
(of a bittern) utter its characteristic resonant cry.
--Examples--
‘the deep boom of the bass drum’
‘the boom of the bittern may be enjoyed in the country’
‘thunder boomed in the sky’
‘‘Stop right there,’ boomed the Headmaster’
‘a dozen bitterns boom mysteriously from the reeds’
--Word--
booming 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having a period of great prosperity or rapid economic growth.
(of a sound or voice) loud, deep, and resonant.
Struck with great force.
--Examples--
‘the booming economy of the 1920s’
‘his booming voice’
‘a booming laugh’
‘a booming kick from the touchline’
--Word--
boom and bust 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A situation in which a period of great prosperity or rapid economic growth is abruptly followed by one of economic decline.
--Examples--
‘he has warned it is a return to boom and bust’
‘the boom and bust business cycle’

noun, verb

--Word--
Boone, Daniel 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(c.1734–1820), American pioneer. He made trips west from North Carolina into the area that is now Kentucky, organizing settlements and successfully defending them from attacks carried out by North American Indians. He later moved further west to what is now Missouri, having been granted land there in 1799.
--Examples--

--Word--
boost 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Help or encourage (something) to increase or improve.
Amplify (an electrical signal)
Push from below.
Steal (something)
A source of help or encouragement leading to increase or improvement.
An increase or improvement.
A push from below.
--Examples--
‘a range of measures to boost tourism’
‘the specially designed circuit boosts signal strength’
‘Andy boosted him up high enough to reach the keys’
‘he'd had his wallet boosted in a bar’
‘the cut in interest rates will give a further boost to the economy’
‘a boost in exports’

booster 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A device for increasing electrical voltage or signal strength.
The first stage of a rocket or spacecraft, used to give initial acceleration and then jettisoned.
A dose of a vaccine that increases or renews the effect of an earlier one.
A source of help or encouragement.
A keen promoter of a person, organization, or cause.
A shoplifter.
--Examples--
‘boosters at five-year intervals are recommended’
‘a booster injection’
‘job fairs are a great morale booster’
--Word--
boosterism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The keen promotion of a person, organization, or cause.
--Examples--
‘it would be easy to dismiss such hyperbole as blatant boosterism’
--Word--
booster 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A device for increasing electrical voltage or signal strength.

A keen promoter of a person, organization, or cause.
A shoplifter.

‘a booster injection’
‘job fairs are a great morale booster’
--Word--
boost 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Help or encourage (something) to increase or improve.
Amplify (an electrical signal)
Push from below.
Steal (something)
A source of help or encouragement leading to increase or improvement.
An increase or improvement.
A push from below.
--Examples--
‘a range of measures to boost tourism’
‘the specially designed circuit boosts signal strength’
‘Andy boosted him up high enough to reach the keys’
‘he'd had his wallet boosted in a bar’
‘the cut in interest rates will give a further boost to the economy’
‘a boost in exports’

--Word--
boot 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A sturdy item of footwear covering the foot and ankle, and sometimes also the lower leg.
A covering to protect the lower part of a horse's leg.
An instrument of torture encasing and crushing the foot.
A hard kick.
An enclosed space at the back of a car for carrying luggage or other goods.
The process of starting a computer and putting it into a state of readiness for operation.
Kick (something) hard in a specified direction.
Force someone to leave a vehicle unceremoniously.
Force someone to leave a place or job unceremoniously.
Start (a computer) and put it into a state of readiness for operation.
Place a wheel clamp on (an illegally parked car)
--Examples--
‘a pair of walking boots’
‘he got a boot in the stomach’
‘a boot disk’
‘he ended up booting the ball into the stand’
‘a guard booted two children off a train’
‘she had been booted out of school’
‘the menu will be ready as soon as you boot up your computer’
‘the system won't boot from the original drive’
‘once a car is booted, the owner must pay all fines plus a fee to have the boot removed’
--Word--
bootable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a disk) containing the software required to boot a computer.
--Examples--

Boötes 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A northern constellation (the Herdsman), said to represent a man holding the leash of two dogs (Canes Venatici) while driving a bear (Ursa Major). It contains the bright star Arcturus.
Used with preceding letter or numeral to designate a star in the constellation Boötes.
--Examples--
‘the star Gamma Boötis’

--Word--
Luce, Clare Boothe 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1903–87), US playwright and public official; wife of Henry Robinson Luce. After a stint writing and editing at the magazine Vanity Fair 1929–34, she wrote the plays The Women (1936), Kiss the Boys Goodbye (1938), and Margin for Error (1939). She was a war correspondent during World War II, served in the US House of Representatives 1943–47 as a Republican from Connecticut, and was US ambassador to Italy 1953–57. Presidential Medal of Freedom (1983).
--Examples--
--Word--

A shoulder bone in a joint of meat, or the joint itself.
The flat part of the tongue behind the tip.
A long, narrow leaf of grass or another similar plant.
The broad, thin part of a leaf apart from the stalk.
A dashing or energetic young man.
Skate using Rollerblades.

bootleg 
--Type--
adjective, verb, noun
--Meanings--
(of alcoholic drink or a recording) made, distributed, or sold illegally.

‘he amassed a fortune bootlegging whisky’
‘he scored on a 29-yard bootleg on fourth down’

bootstrap 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A loop at the back of a boot, used to pull it on.
A technique of loading a program into a computer by means of a few initial instructions which enable the introduction of the rest of the program from an input device.
The technique of starting with existing resources to create something more complex and effective.
Start up (an Internet-based business or other enterprise) with minimal financial resources.
Get (oneself or something) into or out of a situation using existing resources.
--Examples--
‘we see the creative act as a bootstrap process’
‘the company is bootstrapping itself out of a marred financial past’

noun
--Meanings--
Any of a series of unstable binary compounds of boron and hydrogen, analogous to the alkanes. The simplest example is diborane, B₂H₆.
--Examples--
--Word--
borane 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of a series of unstable binary compounds of boron and hydrogen, analogous to the alkanes. The simplest example is diborane, B₂H₆.
--Examples--
--Word--
Borås 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An industrial city in south-western Sweden; population 101,487 (2008).

noun

A salt in which the anion contains both boron and oxygen, as in borax.

--Word--
borax 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
A white compound which occurs as a mineral in some alkaline salt deposits and is used in making glass and ceramics, as a metallurgical flux, and as an antiseptic.
Good-natured teasing or ridicule; banter.
--Examples--
‘they take a bit of borax, but that is part of the job’
--Word--
borax 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
A white compound which occurs as a mineral in some alkaline salt deposits and is used in making glass and ceramics, as a metallurgical flux, and as an antiseptic.
Good-natured teasing or ridicule; banter.
--Examples--
‘they take a bit of borax, but that is part of the job’

pillar and stall 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A method of mining in which the working is advanced in a series of stalls; frequently attributive; cf "room and pillar".
--Examples--
--Word--
Bordeaux 
--Type--
proper noun, noun
--Meanings--
A port of south-western France on the River Garonne, capital of Aquitaine; population 235,878 (2006). It is a centre of the wine trade.
A red, white, or rosé wine from the district of Bordeaux.

--Word--
Borden, Lizzie 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1860–1927), US accused murderess; full name Lizzie Andrew Borden. Accused of the murder of her father and stepmother in Fall River, Massachusetts, in 1892, she was acquitted in a trial that became a national sensation.
--Examples--
--Word--
border 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A line separating two countries, administrative divisions, or other areas.
A district near the border between two areas.
The boundary and adjoining districts between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland.
The boundary and adjoining districts between Scotland and England.
The edge or boundary of something, or the part near it.
A decorative strip around the edge of something.
A strip of ground along the edge of a lawn or path for planting flowers or shrubs.
Form an edge along or beside (something)
Provide (something) with a decorative edge.
(of a country or area) be adjacent to (another country or area)
Come close to or be developing into (an extreme condition)
--Examples--
‘Panama's western border with Costa Rica’
‘border controls’
‘a refugee camp on the border’
‘the northern border of their distribution area’
‘the unknown regions at the borders of physics and electronics’
‘she stitched a border on to one of the plain white saris’
‘geraniums are among the best of border perennials’
‘a pool bordered by palm trees’
‘the walls were bordered with carved scrolls and cornices’
‘regions bordering Azerbaijan’
‘the states bordering on the Black Sea’
‘Sam arrived in a state of excitement bordering on hysteria’

--Word--
borderless 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Without boundaries between countries, administrative divisions, or other areas.
Without restrictions caused by movement between or actions across boundaries of countries, administrative divisions, or other areas.
Lacking edges, limits, or boundaries.
Lacking a plain or decorated strip around the edge.
--Examples--
‘we want to share our space and live in a borderless region’
‘naval forces will continue operating from an essentially borderless domain’
‘the borderless EU’
‘the era of unlimited competition and borderless economy’
‘an open, borderless digital society’
‘the uniform spread of blue light creates a borderless space’
‘the printer can produce a 4x6 inch borderless photo in 36 seconds’
--Word--
borderline 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A boundary separating two countries or areas.
A division between two distinct or opposite things.
Only just acceptable in quality or as belonging to a category.
--Examples--
‘the borderline between ritual and custom’
‘references may be requested in borderline cases’

--Word--
Bordet, Jules 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1870–1961), Belgian bacteriologist and immunologist. He discovered the complement system of blood serum, and developed a vaccine for whooping cough. Nobel Prize for Physiology or Medicine (1919).

--Word--
bore 
--Type--
verb, noun, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Make (a hole) in something with a tool or by digging.
Hollow out (a gun barrel or other tube)
(of an athlete or racehorse) push another competitor out of the way.
The hollow part inside a gun barrel or other tube.
The diameter of a bore; the calibre.
A gun of a specified bore.
A person whose talk or behaviour is dull and uninteresting.
A tedious or annoying situation or activity.
Cause (someone) to feel weary and uninterested by dull talk or behaviour.
--Examples--
‘bore a hole in the wall to pass the cable through’
‘the drill can bore through rock’
‘his eyes bored into hers’
‘an 1100 cc road bike bored out to 1168 cc’
‘a small-bore rifle’
‘he shot a guard in the leg with a twelve-bore’
‘he can be a crashing bore’
‘it's such a bore cooking when one's alone’
‘she is too polite to bore us with anecdotes’
‘timid women quickly bore her silly’
--Word--
boring 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Not interesting; tedious.
--Examples--
‘I've got a boring job in an office’
--Word--
boreal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of the north or northern regions.
Relating to or characteristic of the climatic zone south of the Arctic, especially the cold temperate region dominated by taiga and forests of birch, poplar, and conifers.
Relating to or denoting a phytogeographical kingdom comprising the arctic and temperate regions of Eurasia and North America.
Relating to or denoting the second climatic stage of the postglacial period in northern Europe, between the Preboreal and Atlantic stages (about 9,000 to 7,500 years ago), marked by a warm, dry climate.
--Examples--
‘northern boreal forest’
--Word--
Corona Borealis 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A northern constellation (the Northern Crown), in which the main stars form a small but prominent arc.
Used with preceding letter or numeral to designate a star in the constellation Corona Borealis.
--Examples--
‘the star R Coronae Borealis’
--Word--
bored 
--Type--
adjective, adjective
--Meanings--
Feeling weary and impatient because one is unoccupied or lacks interest in one's current activity.
(of a gun) having a specified bore.
--Examples--
‘she got bored with staring out of the window’
‘they hung around all day, bored stiff’
‘bored teenagers’
‘John was soon bored to tears with the work’
‘she's bored out of her mind’
‘large-bored guns’

--Word--
Borg, Björn 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(born 1956), Swedish tennis player; full name Björn Rune Borg. He won five consecutive men's singles titles at Wimbledon (1976–80), beating the record of three consecutive wins held by Fred Perry.
--Examples--
--Word--
Borges, Jorge Luis 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1899–1986), Argentinian poet, short-story writer, and essayist. The volume of short stories A Universal History of Infamy (1935, revised 1954) is regarded as a founding work of magic realism.
--Examples--
--Word--
Borgia, Lucrezia 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1480–1519), Italian noblewoman, sister of Cesare Borgia. She married three times, according to the political alliances useful to her family; after her third marriage in 1501 she established herself as a patron of the arts.
--Examples--
--Word--
Borglum, Gutzon 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1867–1941), US sculptor; full name John Gutzon de la Mothe Borglum. His most famous work is the Mount Rushmore National Memorial in South Dakota, which features the monumental heads of US presidents Washington, Jefferson, Lincoln, and T. Roosevelt. The work, begun in 1927, was completed in 1941 with the help of his son Lincoln Borglum (1912–86).
--Examples--

--Word--
Yeltsin, Boris 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1931–2007), Russian statesman, president of the Russian Federation 1991–9; full name Boris Nikolaevich Yeltsin. Impatient with the slow pace of Gorbachev's reforms, Yeltsin resigned from the Communist Party after becoming president of the Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic in 1990. As president of the independent Russian Federation he faced opposition to his reforms and in 1993 survived an attempted coup, but was re-elected in 1996.

Borodin, Aleksandr 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1833–87), Russian composer; full name Aleksandr Porfirevich Borodin. He is best known for the epic opera Prince Igor (completed after his death by Rimsky-Korsakov and Glazunov).
--Examples--
--Word--
Borodino, Battle of 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A battle in 1812 at Borodino, a village about 110 km (70 miles) west of Moscow, at which Napoleon's forces defeated the Russian army.

A town or district which is an administrative unit.
A town (as distinct from a city) with a corporation and privileges granted by a royal charter.
A town sending representatives to Parliament.
An administrative division of London.
A municipal corporation in certain US states.
Each of five divisions of New York City.
(in Alaska) a district corresponding to a county elsewhere in the US.
--Examples--

--Word--
borrow 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Take and use (something belonging to someone else) with the intention of returning it.
Take and use (money) from a person or bank under an agreement to pay it back later.
Take and use (a book) from a library for a fixed period of time.
Take (a word or idea) from another language, person, or source and use it in one's own language or work.
Allow (a certain distance) when playing a shot to compensate for sideways motion of the ball due to a slope or other irregularity.
A slope or other irregularity on a golf course which must be compensated for when playing a shot.
--Examples--
‘he had borrowed a car from one of his colleagues’
‘to meet this deficit the government has to borrow money’
‘lower interest rates will make it cheaper for individuals to borrow’
‘you could easily have borrowed a book from your local library’
‘the term is borrowed from Greek’
--Word--
borrower 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person or organization that takes and uses something belonging to someone else with the intention of returning it.
A person or organization that takes out a loan from a bank under an agreement to pay it back later, typically with interest.
A person who is registered to take books from a library for a fixed period of time.
--Examples--
‘my last pair of secateurs were ruined by a careless borrower’
‘hundreds of thousands of borrowers of aircraft fly without any insurance’
‘most mortgage borrowers pay far too much interest’
‘companies that provided credit cards to high-risk borrowers’
‘her books continue to be popular among library borrowers into the twenty-first century’

--Word--
bosom 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A woman's chest or breasts.
A part of a dress covering the chest.
The space between a person's clothing and their chest used for carrying things.
A person's loving care and protection.
Used to refer to the chest as the seat of emotions.
(of a friend) very close or intimate.
--Examples--
‘her ample bosom’
‘the dress offered a fair display of bosom’
‘she had plucked the brooch from her bosom’
‘he carried a letter in his bosom’
‘Bruno went home each night to the bosom of his family’
‘quivering dread was settling in her bosom’
‘the two girls had become bosom friends’

--Word--
felt 
--Type--
noun, verb
UnKnownKind
--Meanings--
A kind of cloth made by rolling and pressing wool or another suitable textile accompanied by the application of moisture or heat, which causes the constituent fibres to mat together to create a smooth surface.
Make into felt; mat together.
Become matted.
Cover with felt.
--Examples--
‘a felt hat’
‘the fibres are shredded and felted together’
‘care must be taken in washing, or the wool will shrink and felt’
‘it wasn't long before we had felted the roof making it totally watertight’

boson 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A subatomic particle, such as a photon, which has zero or integral spin and follows the statistical description given by S. N. Bose and Einstein.

Bosporus 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A strait connecting the Black Sea with the Sea of Marmara, and separating Europe from the Anatolian peninsula of western Asia. Istanbul is located at its south end.

boss 
--Type--
noun, verb, adjective
--Meanings--
A person who is in charge of a worker or organization.
A person in control of a group or situation.
(in computer gaming) a particularly tough enemy, usually appearing at the end of a section or level.
Give (someone) orders in a domineering manner.
Excellent; outstanding.
--Examples--
‘her boss offered her a promotion’
‘union bosses’
‘does he see you as a partner, or is he already the boss?’
‘the boss characters provide more than enough challenge’
‘you may be required to kill a boss monster’
‘you're always bossing us about’
‘she's a real boss chick’

A card game resembling solo whist.

‘a Bostonian arrived last week to give out presents and to entertain local youngsters’

Boswell, James 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1740–95), Scottish author, companion and biographer of Samuel Johnson. He is known for Journal of a Tour to the Hebrides (1785) and The Life of Samuel Johnson (1791).
--Examples--
--Word--
Boswellian 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or characteristic of the Scottish author and biographer James Boswell or his works, especially in being a close companion and observer of a biographical subject.
--Examples--
‘a biographer with Boswellian devotion’
--Word--
Boswell, James 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1740–95), Scottish author, companion and biographer of Samuel Johnson. He is known for Journal of a Tour to the Hebrides (1785) and The Life of Samuel Johnson (1791).
--Examples--
--Word--
Bosworth Field 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A battle of the Wars of the Roses fought in 1485 near Market Bosworth in Leicestershire. Henry Tudor defeated and killed the Yorkist king Richard III, enabling him to take the throne as Henry VII.
--Examples--
--Word--
bot 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
(chiefly in science fiction) a robot.
An autonomous program on a network (especially the Internet) which can interact with systems or users, especially one designed to behave like a player in some video games.
The larva of the botfly, which is an internal parasite of horses.
The sheep nostril fly.
A person who persistently borrows or cadges from others.
--Examples--
‘we have maintenance bots in there’
‘a mailbot’
--Word--
bot. 
--Type--
abbreviation
--Meanings--
(with reference to journal titles) botanic; botanical; botany.
Bottle.
Bought.
--Examples--
--Word--
bota 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
Originally: a measure of capacity for liquid, used especially in Spain and Portugal and varying according to locality and the nature of the contents. In later use: a large cask for wine or other liquids, the capacity of which varies according to the contents and locality.
A small wine flask made of leather or goatskin which may be slung over the shoulder or chest, having a narrow nozzle from which wine is squirted directly into the mouth.
A boot, especially for riding. Also (in plural): leather leggings or similar protective coverings for the legs.
--Examples--
--Word--
botanism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The use of specific plants or plant-based medicines for healing purposes; herbal medicine, botanical medicine. Now historical.
--Examples--
--Word--
botany 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
The scientific study of the physiology, structure, genetics, ecology, distribution, classification, and economic importance of plants.
The plant life of a particular region, habitat, or geological period.
Merino wool, especially from Australia.
--Examples--
‘the botany of North America’
--Word--
botanic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
botanica 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(in the US) a small shop that sells herbal and other traditional remedies, together with charms, incense, candles, and other items used for religious or spiritual purposes.
--Examples--
‘he performed cleansing rituals at a botanica he owned in Montebello’
--Word--
botanical 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to botany.
A substance obtained from a plant and used typically in medicinal or cosmetic products.
--Examples--
‘botanical specimens’

--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--

--Word--
bota 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
Originally: a measure of capacity for liquid, used especially in Spain and Portugal and varying according to locality and the nature of the contents. In later use: a large cask for wine or other liquids, the capacity of which varies according to the contents and locality.
A small wine flask made of leather or goatskin which may be slung over the shoulder or chest, having a narrow nozzle from which wine is squirted directly into the mouth.
A boot, especially for riding. Also (in plural): leather leggings or similar protective coverings for the legs.
--Examples--
--Word--
botch 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Carry out (a task) badly or carelessly.
A bungled task.
--Examples--
‘he was accused of botching the job’
‘I've probably made a botch of things’

adjective
--Meanings--

--Examples--
‘a botched attempt to steal a car’

--Word--
both 
--Type--
UnKnownKind, adverb
--Meanings--
Used for emphasis to refer to two people or things, regarded and identified together.
Used before the first of two alternatives to emphasize that the statement being made applies to each (the other alternative being introduced by ‘and’)
--Examples--
‘both his parents indulged him’
‘she held on with both hands’
‘cars parked on both sides of the road’
‘a picture of both of us together’
‘he looked at them both’
‘the film has won favour with both young and old’
‘studies of zebra finches, both in the wild and in captivity’
--Word--
Botha, Louis 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1862–1919), South African soldier and statesman, first prime minister of the Union of South Africa 1910–19.
--Examples--
--Word--
bother 
--Type--
verb, noun, exclamation
--Meanings--
Take the trouble to do something.
(of a circumstance or event) worry, disturb, or upset (someone)
Feel concern about or interest in.
Cause trouble or annoyance to (someone) by interrupting or otherwise inconveniencing them.
Effort, trouble, or difficulty.
A person or thing that causes annoyance or difficulty.
Used to express mild irritation or impatience.
--Examples--
‘scientists rarely bother with such niceties’
‘the driver didn't bother to ask why’
‘secrecy is an issue which bothers journalists’
‘it bothered me that I hadn't done anything’
‘don't bother about me—I'll find my own way home’
‘he wasn't to bother himself with day-to-day things’
‘I'm sorry to bother you at this time of night’
‘he saved me the bother of having to come up with a speech’
‘it may seem like too much bother to cook just for yourself’
‘I hope she hasn't been a bother’
‘‘Bother!’ she muttered’
--Word--
botheration 
--Type--
noun, exclamation
--Meanings--
Effort, worry, or difficulty; bother.
Used to express mild irritation or annoyance.
--Examples--
‘he has caused us a deal of unnecessary botheration’
--Word--
bothered 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Concerned about something.
--Examples--
‘he was trying to play it cool and not look bothered’
‘I'm not particularly bothered about how I look’
--Word--
botherer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who or thing which bothers, annoys, or harasses someone.
With modifying word: one who persistently pursues, annoys, or (in ironic use) is overly attentive to or enthusiastic about the person or thing specified.
--Examples--
--Word--
bother-headed 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Stupid, foolish; muddle-headed.

adjective, adverb

Bothnia, Gulf of 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A northern arm of the Baltic Sea, between Sweden and Finland.
--Examples--
--Word--
Bothnian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Designating (part of) the northern arm of the Baltic Sea lying between Sweden and Finland, now usually called the Gulf of Bothnia; of or belonging to the Gulf of Bothnia or the lands surrounding it.
A native or inhabitant of the region around the Gulf of Bothnia. Also with distinguishing word, as West Bothnian, North Bothnian, etc. Now somewhat rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
Bothnic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of, belonging to, or designating (part of) the Gulf of Bothnia or the lands surrounding it; = Bothnian.
--Examples--
--Word--
Bothrodendron 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An extinct genus of tree-sized lycopod plants (family Lycopodiaceae), known from their fossil remains found chiefly in coal measures; (also in form bothrodendron) a plant of this genus.
--Examples--

--Word--
Bothwell, James Hepburn 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
4th Earl of Bothwell (c.1536–78), Scottish nobleman and third husband of Mary, Queen of Scots. He was implicated in the murder of Mary's previous husband, Lord Darnley (1567), a crime for which he was tried but acquitted; he married Mary later the same year.
--Examples--
--Word--
botony 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of a cross: having arms which terminate in an ornament of three rounded knobs or buds resembling a three-lobed leaf. Chiefly as postpositive.
--Examples--

bo tree 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A fig tree native to India and SE Asia, regarded as sacred by Buddhists.

--Word--
botryogen 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A magnesium-containing mineral that is an alteration product of pyrite typically occurring as reddish crystalline masses, often botryoidal or reniform.

--Word--
botryose 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Shaped like a bunch of grapes; (in early use) bearing flowers in clusters or racemes, which develop successively from the base upward. Now chiefly Mycology.
--Examples--
--Word--
botrytis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A greyish powdery mould which causes a number of plant diseases and is deliberately cultivated (as noble rot) on the grapes used for certain wines.
--Examples--
--Word--
bot 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
(chiefly in science fiction) a robot.
An autonomous program on a network (especially the Internet) which can interact with systems or users, especially one designed to behave like a player in some video games.
The larva of the botfly, which is an internal parasite of horses.
The sheep nostril fly.
A person who persistently borrows or cadges from others.
--Examples--
‘we have maintenance bots in there’
‘a mailbot’

--Word--
Botticelli, Sandro 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1445–1510), Italian painter; born Alessandro di Mariano Filipepi. He worked in Renaissance Florence under the patronage of the Medicis. Botticelli is best known for his mythological works such as Primavera (c.1478) and The Birth of Venus (c.1480).
--Examples--
--Word--
Botticellian 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having the characteristics of Botticelli's work.
--Examples--

noun
--Meanings--

A kind of light boot worn by women and children, a half-boot.
--Examples--
--Word--
bottle 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A glass or plastic container with a narrow neck, used for storing drinks or other liquids.
The contents of a bottle.
Used in reference to the heavy drinking of alcohol.
A bottle fitted with a teat for giving milk or other drinks to babies and very young children.
A large metal cylinder holding liquefied gas.
The courage or confidence needed to do something difficult or dangerous.
Place (drinks or other liquid) in bottles for storage.
Place (fruit or vegetables) in glass jars with other ingredients in order to preserve them.
Store (gas) in a container in liquefied form.
Throw a glass bottle at (someone)
Lose one's nerve and decide not to do (something)
--Examples--
‘he opened the bottle of beer’
‘she managed to get through a bottle of wine’
‘more women are taking to the bottle’
‘I lost my bottle completely and ran’
‘the wine was bottled in 1997’
‘Angela bottled fruit and jam and chutneys’
‘she set about connecting the bottled gas to the stove’
‘he was bottled offstage at a club’
‘the leader had completely bottled his confrontation with them’
‘one terrified contestant bottles it and scarpers’

noun
--Meanings--
A stomach shaped like a bottle, especially one which is rounded or protuberant.
--Examples--

safe-blowing 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action or occupation of using explosives to blow open safes.

bottlebrush

noun
--Meanings--

Any of a number of plants bearing flowers similar to those of the bottlebrush.

--Meanings--
A person who holds a bottle; specifically a second responsible for a contestant's water bottle during a boxing match (now historical).
Figurative. A supporter or backer, especially in a conflict; an ally; a defender; an apologist. Now rare.
A device or receptacle for holding a bottle or bottles, especially one which holds an (open) bottle in an upright position.
--Examples--
--Word--
bottle-like 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Resembling or shaped like a bottle.
--Examples--
--Word--
bottle-maker 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who or (in later use) business which makes bottles.
--Examples--
--Word--
bottleman 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who supervises, or is employed in, a wine or beer cellar (now historical).
--Examples--
--Word--
bottleneck 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The neck or mouth of a bottle.
A narrow section of road or a junction that impedes traffic flow.
A situation that causes delay in a process or system.
A device shaped like the neck of a bottle that is worn on a guitarist's finger and used to produce sliding effects on the strings.
The style of playing that uses a bottleneck.
--Examples--
‘the bottleneck on Talbot Road’
‘animated films are still stymied by a technological bottleneck’
‘I started using bottleneck on the guitar’
‘it is the perfect instrument for playing bottleneck’

bottle-nosed 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having a bulbous or swollen nose, which resembles a round-bottomed bottle.

--Word--
bottle 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A glass or plastic container with a narrow neck, used for storing drinks or other liquids.
The contents of a bottle.
Used in reference to the heavy drinking of alcohol.
A bottle fitted with a teat for giving milk or other drinks to babies and very young children.
A large metal cylinder holding liquefied gas.
The courage or confidence needed to do something difficult or dangerous.
Place (drinks or other liquid) in bottles for storage.
Place (fruit or vegetables) in glass jars with other ingredients in order to preserve them.
Store (gas) in a container in liquefied form.
Throw a glass bottle at (someone)
Lose one's nerve and decide not to do (something)
--Examples--
‘he opened the bottle of beer’
‘she managed to get through a bottle of wine’
‘more women are taking to the bottle’
‘I lost my bottle completely and ran’
‘the wine was bottled in 1997’
‘Angela bottled fruit and jam and chutneys’
‘she set about connecting the bottled gas to the stove’
‘he was bottled offstage at a club’
‘the leader had completely bottled his confrontation with them’
‘one terrified contestant bottles it and scarpers’

--Word--
tight 
--Type--
adjective, adverb
--Meanings--
Fixed, fastened, or closed firmly; hard to move, undo, or open.
(of clothes or shoes) close-fitting, especially uncomfortably so.
(of a grip) very firm.
(of a ship, building, or object) well sealed against something such as water or air.
(of a rope, fabric, or surface) stretched so as to leave no slack; not loose.
(of muscles or skin) firm or taut.
(of part of the body) feeling painful and constricted as a result of anxiety or illness.
(of appearance or manner) tense, irritated, or angry.
(of a rule or form of control) strictly imposed.
(of a written work or form) concise, condensed, or well structured.
(of an organization or group of people) disciplined or well coordinated.
(of an area or space) having or allowing little room for manoeuvre.
(of a bend, turn, or angle) changing direction sharply; having a short radius.
(of money or time) limited or restricted.
(of a formation or group) closely or densely packed together.
(of a community or other group of people) having close relations; tight-knit.
(of a game or contest) with evenly matched competitors; very close.
Not willing to spend or give much money; mean.
Drunk.
Very firmly, closely, or tensely.
--Examples--
‘she twisted her handkerchief into a tight knot’
‘I prised the tight lid off with my knife’
‘the dress was too tight for her’
‘a tight-fitting top’
‘she released her tight hold on the dog’
‘presidential advisers keep a tight grip on domestic policy’
‘a light-tight container’
‘the drawcord pulls tight’
‘he showed off his tight abs’
‘the tight skin on your face may start to sag’
‘there was a tight feeling in his gut’
‘she gave him a tight smile’
‘security was tight at yesterday's ceremony’
‘a tight argument’
‘the vocalists are strong and the band is tight’
‘a tight parking spot’
‘it was a tight squeeze in the tiny vestibule’
‘the coach failed to negotiate the tight bend’
‘David was out of work and money was tight’
‘an ability to work to tight deadlines’
‘he levered the bishop out from a tight knot of clerical wives’
‘New York's tight Orthodox Jewish community’
‘the folk were far too tight to let anyone know’
‘he won in a tight finish’
‘he is tight with his money’
‘he got tight on brandy’
‘he went downstairs, holding tight to the bannisters’

--Word--
bottom 
--Type--
noun, adjective, verb
--Meanings--
The lowest point or part of something.
The ground under a sea, river, or lake.
The lowest surface on the inside of a container.
The seat of a chair.
The furthest part or point of something.
The lowest position in a competition or ranking.
The lower half of a specified two-piece garment.
The keel or hull of a ship.
A ship, especially a cargo carrier.
A person's buttocks.
One of six flavours of quark.
Stamina or strength of character.
A man who takes the passive role in anal intercourse with another man.
In the lowest position.
(of a place) in the furthest position away in a downhill direction.
In the lowest or last position in a competition or ranking.
(of a ship) reach or touch the ground under the sea.
Excavate (a hole or mine) to the level of a mineral-bearing stratum.
Find gold or other minerals while mining.
Find the extent or real nature of.
(of a situation) reach the lowest point before stabilizing or improving.
--Examples--
‘the bottom of the page’
‘she paused at the bottom of the stairs’
‘the liner plunged to the bottom of the sea’
‘place the fruit on the bottom of the dish’
‘the shed at the bottom of the garden’
‘he started at the bottom and now has his own business’
‘a pair of pyjama bottoms’
‘river bottoms’
‘the double bottoms of the ship’
‘he climbs the side of the gorge, scratching his bottom unselfconsciously’
‘whatever his faults, he possesses that old-fashioned quality—bottom’
‘the books on the bottom shelf’
‘the bottom field’
‘I was put in the bottom class’
‘they came bottom with 17 points’
‘nuclear submarines cannot bottom’
‘scores of abandoned claims have never been properly bottomed, according to the old prospectors’
‘he's bottomed on opal there’
‘he had bottomed the whole inquiry’
‘encouraging signs suggested the recession was bottoming out’
--Word--
bottomed 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having a base or lowest point of the specified kind.
Having buttocks of the specified kind.
--Examples--
‘a heavy-bottomed copper pan’
‘a clear, sandy-bottomed lake’
‘a rather unique glass-bottomed boat’
‘big-bottomed tourists’
‘babies sat, bare-bottomed, in the sand’

--Word--
bottom-set 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Designating a more or less horizontal layer of sediment formed by deposition of fine material from a river into a larger body of water at some distance from the point of inflow and beyond the fore-set deposits.

boubou 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An African bush shrike (songbird) with the upper parts mainly blackish in colour. It is noted for the duet of bell-like calls produced by the male and female together.

--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1703–70), French painter and decorative artist, one of the foremost artists of the rococo style in France. Notable paintings: The Rising of the Sun (1753) and Summer Pastoral (1749).

--Word--
Boudicca 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(d. AD 62), a queen of the Britons, ruler of the Iceni tribe in eastern England; also known as Boadicea. Boudicca led her forces in revolt against the Romans and sacked Colchester, St Albans, and London before being defeated by the Roman governor Suetonius Paulinus.

--Examples--

--Word--
boule 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
A metal ball used in the French game of boules.
A French game using boules (metal balls), a form of bowls played on rough ground.
A legislative body of ancient or modern Greece.
--Examples--
‘in the central square a game of boules was in progress’

Boulez, Pierre 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1925–2016), French composer and conductor. His works explored and developed serialism and aleatory music, making use of both traditional and electronic instruments.

Boulogne 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
bolt 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A bar that slides into a socket to fasten a door or window.
A long pin with a head that screws into a nut, used to fasten things together.
The sliding piece of the breech mechanism of a rifle.
A long pin that is driven into a rock face so that a rope can be attached to it.
A short, heavy arrow shot from a crossbow.
A jagged white flash of lightning.
Fasten (a door or window) with a bar that slides into a socket.
Fasten (something) to something else with a long pin that screws into a nut.
--Examples--
‘all the doors were locked and bolted’
‘the lid was bolted down’
‘new benefits have been bolted on to the social security system’
--Word--
bounce 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
(with reference to an object, especially a ball) move quickly up, back, or away from a surface after hitting it.
(of light, sound, or an electronic signal) come into contact with an object or surface and be reflected back.
(of an email) be returned to its sender after failing to reach its destination.
Recover well after a setback or problem.
Come into sudden forceful contact with; collide with.
Jump repeatedly up and down, typically on something springy.
Move up and down repeatedly.
Cause (a child) to move lightly up and down on one's knee as a game.
(of a vehicle) move jerkily along a bumpy surface.
Move in a particular direction in an energetic, happy, or enthusiastic manner.
(of a cheque) be returned by a bank to the payee when there are not enough funds in the drawer's account to meet it.
(of a bank) return a cheque to the payee when there are not enough funds in the drawer's account to meet it.
Eject (a troublemaker) forcibly from a nightclub or similar establishment.
Dismiss (someone) from a job.
Pressurize (someone) into doing something, typically by presenting them with a fait accompli.
A rebound of a ball or other object.
The ability of a surface to make a ball rebound in a specified way.
A collision.
An act of jumping or of moving up and down jerkily.
A sudden rise in the level of something.
Exuberant self-confidence.
Health and body in a person's hair.
--Examples--
‘the ball bounced away and he chased it’
‘he was bouncing the ball against the wall’
‘short sound waves bounce off even small objects’
‘I tried to email him, but the message bounced’
‘the savings rate has already started to bounce back and is sure to rise further’
‘people cross the road as slowly as possible, as if daring the cars to bounce them’
‘Emma was happily bouncing up and down on the mattress’
‘the gangplank bounced under his confident step’
‘I remember how you used to bounce me on your knee’
‘the car bounced down the narrow track’
‘Linda bounced in through the open front door’
‘a further two cheques of £160 also bounced’
‘the bank bounced the cheque’
‘those who put in a dismal performance will be bounced from the tour’
‘the government should beware being bounced into any ill-considered foreign gamble’
‘the wicket was causing the occasional erratic bounce’
‘a pitch of low bounce’
‘every bounce of the truck brought them into fresh contact’
‘economists agree that there could be a bounce in prices next year’
‘the bounce was now back in Jenny's step’
‘use conditioner to help hair regain its bounce’

--Word--
bounceback 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A rapid recovery, especially after a period of decline; a rebound.
As a mass noun: resilience.
Marketing. A strategy encouraging repeat patronage, typically by means of coupons redeemable on a return visit. Usually attributive.
--Examples--

bouncy

adjective
--Meanings--

--Examples--

‘a bouncy ball’
‘she was still the girl he remembered, bouncy and full of life’
‘bouncy 1960s tunes’

--Word--
bound 
--Type--
verb, noun, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Walk or run with leaping strides.
(of an object) rebound from a surface.
A leaping movement towards or over something.
A territorial limit; a boundary.
A limitation or restriction on feeling or action.
A limiting value.
Form the boundary of; enclose.
Place within certain limits; restrict.
--Examples--
‘Louis came bounding down the stairs’
‘shares bounded ahead in early dealing’
‘bullets bounded off the veranda’
‘I went up the steps in two effortless bounds’
‘the ancient bounds of the forest’
‘it is not beyond the bounds of possibility that the issue could arise again’
‘enthusiasm to join the union knew no bounds’
‘an upper bound on each modulus’
‘the ground was bounded by a main road on one side and a meadow on the other’
‘freedom of action is bounded by law’

--Word--
boundary 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A line which marks the limits of an area; a dividing line.
A limit of something abstract, especially a subject or sphere of activity.
A hit crossing the limits of the field, scoring four or six runs.
--Examples--

‘the river marks the boundary between the two regions’
‘a boundary wall’
‘a community without class or political boundaries’

‘Louis came bounding down the stairs’
‘shares bounded ahead in early dealing’
‘bullets bounded off the veranda’
‘I went up the steps in two effortless bounds’
‘the ancient bounds of the forest’
‘it is not beyond the bounds of possibility that the issue could arise again’
‘enthusiasm to join the union knew no bounds’
‘an upper bound on each modulus’
‘the ground was bounded by a main road on one side and a meadow on the other’
‘freedom of action is bounded by law’
--Word--
bound 
--Type--
verb, noun, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Walk or run with leaping strides.
(of an object) rebound from a surface.
A leaping movement towards or over something.
A territorial limit; a boundary.
A limitation or restriction on feeling or action.
A limiting value.
Form the boundary of; enclose.
Place within certain limits; restrict.
--Examples--
‘Louis came bounding down the stairs’
‘shares bounded ahead in early dealing’
‘bullets bounded off the veranda’
‘I went up the steps in two effortless bounds’
‘the ancient bounds of the forest’
‘it is not beyond the bounds of possibility that the issue could arise again’
‘enthusiasm to join the union knew no bounds’
‘an upper bound on each modulus’
‘the ground was bounded by a main road on one side and a meadow on the other’
‘freedom of action is bounded by law’

--Word--
bounty 
--Type--
noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
A sum paid for killing or capturing a person or animal.
A sum paid by the state to encourage trade.
A sum paid by the state to army or navy recruits on enlistment.
Something given or occurring in generous amounts.
Generosity.
A ship of the British navy on which in 1789 part of the crew, led by Fletcher Christian, mutinied against their commander, William Bligh, and set him adrift in an open boat with eighteen crewmen.
--Examples--
‘there was an increased bounty on his head’
‘bounties were paid to colonial producers of indigo dye’
‘they do not qualify for their bounty because they have spent insufficient time at summer camp’
‘the bounties of nature’
‘for millennia the people along the Nile have depended entirely on its bounty’
