--Word--
Bourbaki, Nicolas 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A pseudonym of a group of mathematicians, mainly French, attempting to give a complete account of the foundations of pure mathematics. Their first publication was in 1939.
--Examples--
--Word--
bourbon 
--Type--
noun, proper noun, noun
--Meanings--
A kind of American whisky distilled from maize and rye.
The surname of a branch of the royal family of France. The Bourbons ruled France from 1589, when Henry IV succeeded to the throne, until the monarchy was overthrown in 1848, and reached the peak of their power under Louis XIV in the late 17th century. Members of this family have also been kings of Spain (1700–1931 and since 1975).
A chocolate-flavoured biscuit with a chocolate-cream filling.
A reactionary.
A rose of a variety which flowers over a long period and has a rich scent. It arose as a natural hybrid on the island of Réunion (formerly Île de Bourbon) and was introduced into Europe in the early 19th century.
--Examples--
‘he moved to the sideboard to pour himself a bourbon’

Bourbonnais 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A former duchy and province of central France; chief town, Moulins. It forms part of the Auvergne and Centre regions.

--Word--
bourgeois 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Belonging to or characteristic of the middle class, typically with reference to its perceived materialistic values or conventional attitudes.
(in Marxist contexts) upholding the interests of capitalism; not communist.
A bourgeois person.
--Examples--
‘a rich, bored, bourgeois family’
‘these views will shock the bourgeois critics’
‘bourgeois society took for granted the sanctity of property’
‘a self-confessed and proud bourgeois’
--Word--
bourgeoise 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Belonging to or characteristic of female members of the bourgeoisie.
A female member of the bourgeoisie.
--Examples--
‘a cosy, bourgeoise, widowed ex-mayoress in a provincial town’
--Word--
bourgeoise 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Belonging to or characteristic of female members of the bourgeoisie.
A female member of the bourgeoisie.
--Examples--
‘a cosy, bourgeoise, widowed ex-mayoress in a provincial town’
--Word--
bourgeoisie 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The middle class, typically with reference to its perceived materialistic values or conventional attitudes.
(in Marxist contexts) the capitalist class who own most of society's wealth and means of production.
--Examples--
‘the rise of the bourgeoisie at the end of the eighteenth century’
‘the landed gentry were replaced by a local bourgeoisie’
‘the conflict of interest between the bourgeoisie and the proletariat’
--Word--
bourgeoisie 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The middle class, typically with reference to its perceived materialistic values or conventional attitudes.
(in Marxist contexts) the capitalist class who own most of society's wealth and means of production.
--Examples--
‘the rise of the bourgeoisie at the end of the eighteenth century’
‘the landed gentry were replaced by a local bourgeoisie’
‘the conflict of interest between the bourgeoisie and the proletariat’
--Word--
bourgeoisify 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To make bourgeois; to convert to a bourgeois outlook or mode of life. Also without object: to become bourgeois.

bourrée 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A lively French dance like a gavotte.
A series of very fast little steps, with the feet close together, usually performed on the tips of the toes and giving the impression that the dancer is gliding over the floor.
Perform a bourrée.

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

A wrestling or boxing match.
A curve in the side of a violin, guitar, or other musical instrument.

‘a drinking bout’
‘a severe bout of flu’
‘he fought 350 bouts, losing only nine times’

--Word--
bow 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A knot tied with two loops and two loose ends, used especially for tying shoelaces and decorative ribbons.
A decorative ribbon tied in a bow.
A weapon for shooting arrows, typically made of a curved piece of wood joined at both ends by a taut string.
A long, partially curved rod with horsehair stretched along its length, used for playing the violin and other stringed instruments.
A single passage of a bow over the strings of an instrument.
A curved stroke forming part of a letter (e.g. b, p).
A metal ring forming the handle of a key or pair of scissors.
A side piece or lens frame of a pair of glasses.
Play (a stringed instrument or music) using a bow.
--Examples--
‘a girl with long hair tied back in a bow’
‘the techniques by which the pieces were bowed’

bearer

noun
--Meanings--

A compass with jointed legs.
--Examples--
--Word--
dye 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A natural or synthetic substance used to add a colour to or change the colour of something.
Add a colour to or change the colour of (something) by soaking it in a solution impregnated with a dye.
Take colour well or badly during the dyeing process.
--Examples--
‘blonde hair dye’
‘a black dye’
‘I dyed my hair blonde’
‘it's good material—it should dye well’
--Word--
dyer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person whose trade is the dyeing of cloth or other material.
--Examples--

bowdlerization 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
bowdlerize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Remove material that is considered improper or offensive from (a text or account), especially with the result that the text becomes weaker or less effective.
--Examples--
‘every edition of his letters and diaries has been bowdlerized’
--Word--
bowdlerized 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a text or account) having had material considered improper or offensive removed.
--Examples--
‘a bowdlerized version of the story’

--Word--
draught 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A current of cool air in a room or other confined space.
A single act of drinking or inhaling.
The amount swallowed or inhaled in a draught.
A quantity of a liquid with medicinal properties.
The depth of water needed to float a ship.
The drawing in of a fishing net.
The fish taken at one drawing; a catch.
Denoting beer or cider served from a barrel or tank rather than from a bottle or can.
Denoting an animal used for pulling heavy loads.
--Examples--
‘heavy curtains at the windows cut out draughts’
‘she downed the remaining beer in one draught’
‘he took deep draughts of oxygen into his lungs’
‘a sleeping draught’
‘the shallow draught enabled her to get close inshore’
‘draught ale’
‘a draught horse’
--Word--
bow 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A knot tied with two loops and two loose ends, used especially for tying shoelaces and decorative ribbons.
A decorative ribbon tied in a bow.
A weapon for shooting arrows, typically made of a curved piece of wood joined at both ends by a taut string.
A long, partially curved rod with horsehair stretched along its length, used for playing the violin and other stringed instruments.
A single passage of a bow over the strings of an instrument.
A curved stroke forming part of a letter (e.g. b, p).
A metal ring forming the handle of a key or pair of scissors.
A side piece or lens frame of a pair of glasses.
Play (a stringed instrument or music) using a bow.
--Examples--
‘a girl with long hair tied back in a bow’
‘the techniques by which the pieces were bowed’
--Word--
down 
--Type--
adverb, preposition, adjective, verb, noun
--Meanings--
Towards or in a lower place or position, especially to or on the ground or another surface.
At or to a specified distance below.
Downstairs.
Expressing movement or position away from the north.
To or at a place perceived as lower (often expressing casualness or lack of hurry)
Away from the capital or major city.
Away from a university, especially Oxford or Cambridge.
(with reference to food or drink swallowed) in or into the stomach.
So as to lie or be fixed flush or flat.
Used as a command to a person or animal to sit or lie down.
Referring to a crossword answer which reads vertically.
To or at a lower level of intensity, volume, or activity.
To or at a lower price, value, or rank.
To a finer consistency, a smaller amount or size, or a simpler or more basic state.
From an earlier to a later point in time or order.
In or into a weaker or worse position, mood, or condition.
Losing or at a disadvantage by a specified amount.
Used to express progress through a series of tasks or items.
(of a computer system) out of action or unavailable for use.
Shouted to express strong dislike of a specified person or thing.
In or into writing.
On or on to a list, schedule, or record.
(with reference to partial payment of a sum of money) made initially or on the spot.
(of sailing) with the current or the wind.
(of a ship's helm) moved round to leeward so that the rudder is to windward and the vessel swings toward the wind.
(of the ball or a player in possession) not in play, typically through progress being stopped.
From a higher to a lower point of (something)
At or to the part of (a river or stream) that is nearer the sea.
Moving or at a point further along the course of (something)
At or to (a place)
Throughout (a period of time)
Directed or moving towards a lower place or position.
Relating to or denoting trains travelling away from the main terminus.
Denoting a flavour of quark having a charge of −1/3. Protons and neutrons are thought to be composed of combinations of up and down quarks.
Unhappy; depressed.
(of a computer system) temporarily out of action or unavailable.
Supporting or going along with someone or something.
Aware of and following the latest fashion.
Knock or bring to the ground.
Put (the ball) out of play deliberately by touching one's knee to the ground while holding the ball or touching the ball itself to the ground.
Consume (something, typically a drink)
Sink (a putt)
A chance for a team to advance the ball, ending when the ball carrier is tackled or the ball becomes out of play. A team must advance at least ten yards in a series of four downs in order to keep possession.
Unwelcome experiences or events.
A feeling or period of unhappiness or depression.
--Examples--
‘she looked down’
‘the sun started to go down’
‘he put his glass down’
‘he swung the axe to chop down the tree’
‘you can plainly see the bottom 35 feet down’
‘I went down to put the kettle on’
‘they're living down south’
‘I'd rather be down at the villa’
‘I'm going down to the pub’
‘there are eight trains a day, four up and four down’
‘he was down from Oxford’
‘she couldn't keep anything down’
‘she stuck down a Christmas label’
‘down, boy!’
‘how many letters in fifteen down?’
‘keep the noise down’
‘the panic was dying down’
‘at night it would cool down’
‘output was down by 20 per cent’
‘soup is down from 59p to 49p’
‘I must slim down a bit’
‘a formal statement that can't be edited down’
‘thin down an oil-based paint with spirits’
‘buildings in England down to 1540’
‘everyone, from the President down to the bloke selling hot dogs, wants her dead’
‘the scandal brought down the government’
‘he was down with the flu’
‘United were 3–0 down’
‘one down and only six more to go’
‘the system went down yesterday’
‘crowds chanted ‘Down with America!’’
‘Graham noted the numbers down carefully’
‘taking down notes’
‘I'll put you down for the evening shift’
‘pay £5 down and the rest at the end of the month’
‘up and down the stairs’
‘tears streaming down her face’
‘a dozen miles or so down the Thames’
‘he lived down the street’
‘I wandered down the road’
‘she was tired of going down the pub every night’
‘astrologers down the ages’
‘the down escalator’
‘click on the down arrow’
‘we travelled on the first down train’
‘he's been so down lately’
‘sorry, but the computer's down’
‘you got to be down with me’
‘she was totally down for a selfie’
‘‘You going to the movies?’ ‘Yo, I'm down.’’
‘a seriously down, hip-hop homie’
‘175 enemy aircraft had been downed’
‘he struck Slater on the face, downing him’
‘Jones downed the ball in the end zone’
‘he downed five pints of cider’
‘he downed a 20-foot putt for victory’
‘there had been more downs than ups during his years at Ferrari’
‘everyone gets their downs, their depressive periods’

bowel 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The part of the alimentary canal below the stomach; the intestine.
The deepest inner parts or areas of (something)
--Examples--
‘he felt his bowels loosen’
‘the lining of the bowel’
‘bowel cancer’
‘the mineshaft descended deep into the bowels of the earth’

Bowen, Elizabeth 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1899–1973), British novelist and short-story writer, born in Ireland; full name Elizabeth Dorothea Cole Bowen. Notable novels: The Death of the Heart (1938) and The Heat of the Day (1949).

--Word--
bower 
--Type--
noun, verb, noun
--Meanings--
A pleasant shady place under trees or climbing plants in a garden or wood.
A summer house or country cottage.
A woman's private room or bedroom.
Shade or enclose (a place or person)
Each of two anchors carried at a ship's bow, formerly distinguished as the best bower (starboard) or small bower (port).
--Examples--
‘trees here and there bowered the cottages’
--Word--
bowerbird 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A strong-billed Australasian bird, noted for the male's habit of constructing an elaborate run or bower adorned with feathers, shells, and other objects to attract the female for courtship.
--Examples--

bow 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A knot tied with two loops and two loose ends, used especially for tying shoelaces and decorative ribbons.
A decorative ribbon tied in a bow.
A weapon for shooting arrows, typically made of a curved piece of wood joined at both ends by a taut string.

A curved stroke forming part of a letter (e.g. b, p).
A metal ring forming the handle of a key or pair of scissors.
A side piece or lens frame of a pair of glasses.
Play (a stringed instrument or music) using a bow.
--Examples--
‘a girl with long hair tied back in a bow’
‘the techniques by which the pieces were bowed’
--Word--
bowfin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A predatory American freshwater fish with a large blunt head and a long dorsal fin. It is able to survive for long periods out of water.

--Word--
bowl 
--Type--
noun, noun, verb
--Meanings--
A round, deep dish or basin used for food or liquid.
The contents of a bowl.
A decorative round dish awarded as a prize in a competition.
A rounded, concave part of an object.
A pipe used to smoke marijuana, or the contents of such a pipe.
A natural basin.
A stadium for sporting or musical events.
An American football game played after the regular season between leading teams.
A wooden or hard rubber ball, slightly asymmetrical so that it runs on a curved course, used in the game of bowls.
A large ball with indentations for gripping, used in tenpin bowling.
A wooden ball or disc used in playing skittles.
A spell or turn of bowling in cricket.
Roll (a ball or other round object) along the ground.
(of a bowler) propel (the ball) with a straight arm towards the batsman, typically in such a way that the ball bounces once.
Dismiss (a batsman) by knocking down the wicket with the ball which one has bowled.
Get an entire team out.
Move rapidly and smoothly in a specified direction.
bowl someone over
Knock someone down.
Greatly impress someone by one's good qualities, looks, or achievements.
--Examples--
‘a mixing bowl’
‘a sugar bowl’
‘they ate huge bowls of steaming spaghetti’
‘the McGeorge Rose Bowl’
‘a toilet bowl’
‘the bowl of a spoon’
‘hey, you wanna smoke a bowl with us?’
‘the Hollywood Bowl’
‘Pro Bowl’
‘their last four bowl games’
‘she snatched her hat off and bowled it ahead of her’
‘Lillee bowled another bouncer’
‘Sobers bowled to Willis’
‘Stewart was bowled for 33’
‘they bowled Lancashire out for 143’
‘they bowled along the country roads’
‘he was almost bowling people over in his haste’
‘when he met Angela he was just bowled over by her’

Bowles, Paul 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1910–99), American writer and composer; full name Paul Frederick Bowles. His novels, which include The Sheltering Sky (1949) and The Spider's House (1966), typically concern westerners in the Arab world.
--Examples--
--Word--
-less 
--Type--
suffix
--Meanings--
(forming adjectives and adverbs from nouns) not having; free from.
(forming adjectives and adverbs from verbs) not affected by or not carrying out the action of the verb.
--Examples--
‘flavourless’
‘skinless’
‘fathomless’
‘tireless’

--Meanings--

A simple knot for forming a non-slipping loop at the end of a rope.
--Examples--
--Word--
bowling 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The game of bowls as a sport or recreation.
The game of tenpin bowling.
The game of skittles.
The action of a bowler in sending down balls towards the batsman's wicket.
The bowlers in a team.
--Examples--
‘fast bowling’
‘on paper their bowling looks weak’
--Word--
bowling 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The game of bowls as a sport or recreation.
The game of tenpin bowling.
The game of skittles.
The action of a bowler in sending down balls towards the batsman's wicket.
The bowlers in a team.
--Examples--
‘fast bowling’
‘on paper their bowling looks weak’
--Word--
bowls 
--Type--
plural noun
--Meanings--
A game played with heavy bowls, the object of which is to propel one's bowl so that it comes to rest as close as possible to a previously bowled small ball (the jack). Bowls is played chiefly out of doors (though indoor bowls is also popular) on a closely trimmed lawn called a green.
Tenpin bowling or skittles.
--Examples--
--Word--
bowl 
--Type--
noun, noun, verb
--Meanings--
A round, deep dish or basin used for food or liquid.
The contents of a bowl.
A decorative round dish awarded as a prize in a competition.
A rounded, concave part of an object.
A pipe used to smoke marijuana, or the contents of such a pipe.
A natural basin.
A stadium for sporting or musical events.
An American football game played after the regular season between leading teams.
A wooden or hard rubber ball, slightly asymmetrical so that it runs on a curved course, used in the game of bowls.
A large ball with indentations for gripping, used in tenpin bowling.
A wooden ball or disc used in playing skittles.
A spell or turn of bowling in cricket.
Roll (a ball or other round object) along the ground.
(of a bowler) propel (the ball) with a straight arm towards the batsman, typically in such a way that the ball bounces once.
Dismiss (a batsman) by knocking down the wicket with the ball which one has bowled.
Get an entire team out.
Move rapidly and smoothly in a specified direction.
bowl someone over
Knock someone down.
Greatly impress someone by one's good qualities, looks, or achievements.
--Examples--
‘a mixing bowl’
‘a sugar bowl’
‘they ate huge bowls of steaming spaghetti’
‘the McGeorge Rose Bowl’
‘a toilet bowl’
‘the bowl of a spoon’
‘hey, you wanna smoke a bowl with us?’
‘the Hollywood Bowl’
‘Pro Bowl’
‘their last four bowl games’
‘she snatched her hat off and bowled it ahead of her’
‘Lillee bowled another bouncer’
‘Sobers bowled to Willis’
‘Stewart was bowled for 33’
‘they bowled Lancashire out for 143’
‘they bowled along the country roads’
‘he was almost bowling people over in his haste’
‘when he met Angela he was just bowled over by her’

--Word--
bow 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A knot tied with two loops and two loose ends, used especially for tying shoelaces and decorative ribbons.
A decorative ribbon tied in a bow.
A weapon for shooting arrows, typically made of a curved piece of wood joined at both ends by a taut string.
A long, partially curved rod with horsehair stretched along its length, used for playing the violin and other stringed instruments.
A single passage of a bow over the strings of an instrument.
A curved stroke forming part of a letter (e.g. b, p).
A metal ring forming the handle of a key or pair of scissors.
A side piece or lens frame of a pair of glasses.
Play (a stringed instrument or music) using a bow.
--Examples--
‘a girl with long hair tied back in a bow’
‘the techniques by which the pieces were bowed’

--Word--
box 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A container with a flat base and sides, typically square or rectangular and having a lid.
The contents of a box.
Television or a television set.
A casing containing a computer.
A coffin.
A coachman's seat.
An area on a page that is to be filled in or that contains separate printed matter.
An area on a computer screen for user input or displaying information.
A box junction.
The penalty area.
The area occupied by the batter.
A separate section or enclosed area reserved for a group of people in a theatre or sports ground, or for witnesses or the jury in a law court.
A small country house for use when shooting or fishing.
A protective casing for a piece of a mechanism.
A light shield for protecting a man's genitals in sport, especially in cricket.
A facility at a newspaper office for receiving replies to an advertisement.
A facility at a post office whereby letters are kept until called for by the addressee.
A woman's vagina.
Put in or provide with a box.
Enclose (a piece of text) within printed lines.
Restrict the ability of (a person or vehicle) to move freely.
Mix up different flocks.
--Examples--
‘a cigarette box’
‘a hat box’
‘she ate a whole box of chocolates that night’
‘we sat around watching the box’
‘the new model is half the cost of an equivalent IBM box’
‘I always thought I'd be in a box when I finally left here’
‘tick the box on the coupon’
‘a new box appears containing the names of all the programs which are opened’
‘do not enter the box until your exit is clear’
‘he curled in a brilliant second from the edge of the box’
‘ten thousand people booed him when he stepped into the box’
‘the royal box’
‘in the second variation, a switch loop, only one cable enters the box’
‘write to me care of Box 112’
‘the books are sold as a boxed set’
‘Muriel boxed up all Christopher's clothes’
‘boxed sections in magazines’
‘a van had double-parked alongside her car and totally boxed her in’

--Word--
haul 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
(of a person) pull or drag with effort or force.
Propel or pull oneself with difficulty.
Force (someone) to appear for reprimand or trial.
(of a vehicle) pull (an attached trailer or carriage) behind it.
Transport in a lorry or cart.
(especially of a sailing ship) make an abrupt change of course.
A quantity of something that has been stolen or is possessed illegally.
A number of fish caught.
The number of points, medals, or titles won by a person or team in a sporting event or over a period.
All the products purchased by someone during a particular episode of shopping.
A distance to be covered in a journey.
haul off
Leave; depart.
Withdraw a little before doing something.
haul out
(of a seal or similar marine mammal) come out of the water to spend time on land.
--Examples--
‘he hauled his bike out of the shed’
‘she hauled on the reins’
‘he hauled himself along the cliff face’
‘he is to be hauled before the Press Council’
‘the engine hauls the overnight sleeper from London Euston’
‘he made a living hauling coal’
‘my plan was to haul offshore, well clear of the land’
‘they escaped with a haul of antiques’
‘he landed a record pike haul’
‘his seven-goal haul against Liverpool’
‘I'm really pleased with my haul as I think I got some great bargains’
‘included in her beauty haul were a lot of facial masks’
‘the thirty-mile haul to Boston’
‘he hauled off and smacked the kid’
‘seals haul out to bask in areas where they can see and smell approaching predators’

A woman's vagina.
Put in or provide with a box.
Enclose (a piece of text) within printed lines.
Restrict the ability of (a person or vehicle) to move freely.
Mix up different flocks.

‘a cigarette box’
‘a hat box’

‘in the second variation, a switch loop, only one cable enters the box’

‘Muriel boxed up all Christopher's clothes’
‘boxed sections in magazines’

Brabant 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A former duchy in western Europe, lying between the Meuse and Scheldt Rivers. Its capital was Brussels. It is now divided into two provinces in two countries: North Brabant in the Netherlands, of which the capital is 's-Hertogenbosch; and Brabant in Belgium, of which the capital remains Brussels.

--Word--
brace 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A device fitted to something, in particular a weak or injured part of the body, to give support.
A strengthening piece of iron or timber used in building or carpentry.
A wire device fitted in the mouth to straighten the teeth.
A drilling tool with a crank handle and a socket to hold a bit.
A rope attached to the yard of a ship for trimming the sail.
A pair of straps that pass over the shoulders and fasten to the top of trousers at the front and back to hold them up.
A pair of something, typically of birds or mammals killed in hunting.
Either of the two marks { and }, used either to indicate that two or more items on one side have the same relationship as each other to the single item to which the other side points, or in pairs to show that words between them are connected.
A similar mark connecting staves to be performed at the same time.
Make (a structure) stronger or firmer with wood, iron, or other forms of support.
Press (one's body or part of one's body) firmly against something in order to stay balanced.
Prepare (someone) for something difficult or unpleasant.
brace up
Be strong or courageous.
--Examples--
‘a neck brace’
‘thirty brace of grouse’
‘the posts were braced by lengths of timber’
‘she braced her feet against a projecting shelf’
‘he stood with legs braced’
‘both stations are bracing themselves for job losses’
‘she was about to tell him to brace up’

--Word--
bracket 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
Each of a pair of marks ( ) [ ] { } 〈 〉 used to enclose words or figures so as to separate them from the context.
A category of people or things that are similar or fall between specified limits.
A right-angled support attached to a wall for holding a shelf, lamp, or other object.
The distance between two artillery shots fired either side of the target to establish range.
A diagram representing the sequence of matches in a sports tournament, especially as used for making predictions about its outcome.
A person's nose or jaw.
Enclose (words or figures) in brackets.
Enclose (a complex expression) in brackets to denote that the whole of the expression rather than just a part of it has a particular relation, such as multiplication or division, to another expression.
Put (a belief or matter) aside temporarily.
Place (one or more people or things) in the same category or group.
Hold or attach (something) by means of a right-angled support.
Establish the range of (a target) by firing two preliminary shots, one short of the target and the other beyond it.
Establish (the correct exposure) by taking several pictures with slightly more or less exposure.
--Examples--
‘symbols are given in brackets’
‘those in a high income bracket’
‘with the March Madness tournament half the fun is filling out your bracket’
‘a quick punch up the bracket’
‘I have bracketed the phrase ‘of contrary qualities’ in the translation, since it is not explicit in the Greek’
‘he bracketed off the question of God himself’
‘he is sometimes bracketed with the ‘new wave’ of film directors’
‘pipes should be bracketed’
‘it's always best to bracket your exposures’
--Word--
bracketed 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of words or figures) enclosed in brackets.
--Examples--
‘the relevant data is included as bracketed points’

braconid 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small parasitic wasp of a family (Braconidae ) which is related to the ichneumons. Unlike the latter, braconids lay numerous eggs in a single host.

braconid 
--Type--

--Meanings--
A small parasitic wasp of a family (Braconidae ) which is related to the ichneumons. Unlike the latter, braconids lay numerous eggs in a single host.

bract 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

A city in southwestern Florida, noted as a resort and for citrus processing; population 53,513 (est. 2008).

bradykinin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A compound released in the blood in some circumstances which causes contraction of smooth muscle and dilation of blood vessels. It is a peptide with nine amino-acid residues.

Bradman, Don 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1908–2001), Australian cricketer; full name Sir Donald George Bradman. His Test match batting average of 99.94 is well above that of any other cricketer of any era.
--Examples--

Bradstreet, Anne 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1612–72), American poet; full name Anne Dudley Bradstreet. She came from England with her husband Simon Bradstreet to the Massachusetts Bay Colony in 1630. Her poetry was first collected in The Tenth Muse Lately Sprung Up in America (1650).

brag 
--Type--
verb, noun, adjective
--Meanings--
Say something in a boastful manner.
A gambling card game which is a simplified form of poker.
A boastful statement.
Excellent; first-rate.
--Examples--
‘he bragged that he was sure of victory’
‘they were bragging about how easy it had been’
‘games of pontoon, brag, and poker’
‘he was not the kind of man to make a brag’
‘that was my brag heifer’

‘a competitive, bragging culture’
‘we became involved in a lively bragging session’
--Word--
Bragg, Sir William Henry 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1862–1942), English physicist, a founder of solid-state physics; full name William Henry Bragg. He collaborated with his son, Sir (William) Lawrence Bragg (1890–1971), in developing the technique of X-ray diffraction for determining the atomic structure of crystals; for this they shared the 1915 Nobel Prize for Physics.

--Word--
Brahe, Tycho 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1546–1601), Danish astronomer. He built an observatory equipped with precision instruments, but despite demonstrating that comets follow sun-centred paths he adhered to a geocentric view of the planets.
--Examples--
--Word--
brahma 
--Type--
noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
The creator god in Hinduism, who forms a triad with Vishnu and Shiva. Brahma was an important god of late Vedic religion, but has been little worshipped since the 5th century AD.
--Examples--
--Word--
Brahman 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of the highest Hindu caste, originally that of the priesthood.
The ultimate reality underlying all phenomena in the Hindu scriptures.
--Examples--
‘a Brahman family’
‘Brahman is formless but is the birthplace of all forms in visible reality’
--Word--
Brahmana 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(in Hinduism) any of the lengthy commentaries on the Vedas, composed in Sanskrit c.900–700 BC and containing expository material relating to Vedic sacrificial ritual.
--Examples--

Brahmanism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The complex sacrificial religion that emerged in post-Vedic India (c.900 BC) under the influence of the dominant priesthood (Brahmans), an early stage in the development of Hinduism.
--Examples--

brahmaputra 
--Type--
noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
A chicken of a large Asian breed.
A river of southern Asia, rising in the Himalayas and flowing 2,900 km (1,800 miles) through Tibet, north-eastern India, and Bangladesh, to join the River Ganges at its delta on the Bay of Bengal.

Brahmin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A socially or culturally superior person, especially one from New England.
An ox of a humped breed originally domesticated in India, which is tolerant of heat and drought and is now kept widely in tropical and warm-temperate countries.
--Examples--
‘he did not talk like the son of a New England Brahmin’
‘a verbal style filched from one of her Brahmin bosses’

--Word--
Brahms, Johannes 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1833–97), German composer and pianist. He eschewed programme music and opera and concentrated on traditional forms. He composed four symphonies, four concertos, chamber and piano music, choral works including the German Requiem (1857–68), and nearly 200 songs.
--Examples--
--Word--
Brahmsian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or characteristic of the German composer and pianist Johannes Brahms or his work.
An admirer of the German composer and pianist Johannes Brahms or his work.
A performer of the music of the German composer and pianist Johannes Brahms.
--Examples--
‘a Brahmsian melody pours forth’
‘many Brahmsians have told me that one day I will begin to appreciate the beauties of his music’
‘he proved a Brahmsian of uncommon majesty’
--Word--
Brahui 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a pastoral people of western Pakistan.
The language of the Brahui, a Dravidian language isolated for several thousand years from other members of the family. It has nearly 2 million speakers.
Relating to the Brahui or their language.
--Examples--
--Word--
bray 
--Type--
noun, verb, verb
--Meanings--
The loud, harsh cry of a donkey or mule.
A sound, voice, or laugh resembling a bray.
(of a donkey or mule) utter a bray.
(of a person) speak or laugh loudly and harshly.
Pound or crush (something) to small pieces, typically with a pestle and mortar.
--Examples--
‘the mule uttered its insane bray’
‘he recognized the loud bray of the doctor’
‘the donkey brayed and kicked’
‘he brayed with laughter’
‘‘Leave!’ brayed a voice behind her’
‘the kernels of this fruit the Arabs bray in a mortar’
--Word--
braid 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
Threads of silk, cotton, or other material woven into a decorative band for edging or trimming garments.
A length of hair made up of three or more interlaced strands.
A length made up of three or more interlaced strands of any flexible material.
Interlace three or more strands of (hair or other flexible material) to form a length.
Edge or trim (a garment) with braid.
(of a river or stream) flow into shallow interconnected channels divided by deposited earth or alluvium.
--Examples--
‘a coat trimmed with gold braid’
‘fancy braids’
‘her hair curled neatly in blonde braids’
‘a flexible copper braid’
‘their long hair was tightly braided’
‘braided red trousers’
‘a braided river carries an enormous burden of sand and gravel’

brail 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--

Furl a sail by hauling on brails.

Braille 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A form of written language for blind people, in which characters are represented by patterns of raised dots that are felt with the fingertips.
Print or transcribe in Braille.
--Examples--
‘she taught herself Braille’
‘all the plants are labelled in Braille’
‘Braille medicine labels’
‘a select list of new books have been Brailled and added to stock’

brain 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An organ of soft nervous tissue contained in the skull of vertebrates, functioning as the coordinating centre of sensation and intellectual and nervous activity.
The substance of an animal's brain used as food.
An electronic device with functions comparable to those of the human brain.
Intellectual capacity.
A clever person who supplies the ideas and plans for a group of people.
A person's mind.
Hit (someone) hard on the head with an object.
--Examples--
‘a brain tumour’
‘an electronic brain’
‘I didn't have enough brains for the sciences’
‘success requires brain as well as brawn’
‘Tom was the brains of the outfit’
‘a tiny alarm bell began to ring in her brain’
‘she brained me with a rolling pin’

adjective
--Meanings--

--Examples--

‘I was born with a sense of curiosity’

cracked 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Damaged and showing lines on the surface from having split without coming apart.
(of a person's voice) having an unusual harshness or pitch, especially through strain.
Crazy; insane.
--Examples--
‘the old pipes were cracked and leaking’
‘her voice emerged, cracked, from a throat tight with dread’
‘the captain was screaming orders in a cracked baritone’
‘you must think my family are cracked’

--Word--
brain-damaged 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Suffering from an injury to the brain that impairs its functions, especially on a permanent basis.
Extremely foolish or stupid.
--Examples--
‘she was irreversibly brain-damaged’
‘a neurologist who studies brain-damaged patients’
‘he's a treacherous brain-damaged old vulture’

fret 
--Type--
verb, noun, noun, verb, noun, verb, noun
--Meanings--
Be constantly or visibly anxious.
Cause anxiety to.
Gradually wear away (something) by rubbing or gnawing.
Form (a channel or passage) by rubbing or wearing away.
Flow or move in small waves.
A state of anxiety.
A repeating ornamental design of vertical and horizontal lines, such as the Greek key pattern.
A device of narrow diagonal bands interlaced through a diamond.
Decorate with fretwork.
Each of a sequence of ridges on the fingerboard of some stringed musical instruments (such as the guitar), used for fixing the positions of the fingers to produce the desired notes.
Provide (a stringed instrument) with frets.
Play (a note) while pressing the string down against a fret.
A mist coming in off the sea; a sea fog.
--Examples--
‘she fretted about the cost of groceries’
‘his absence during her times awake began to fret her’
‘the bay's black waves fret the seafront’
‘what shape the sea has fretted into the land’
‘squelchy clay that fretted between his toes’
‘why would anyone get themselves in a fret over something so simple?’
‘intricately carved and fretted balustrades’
‘a fretted neck’
‘fretted notes’

noun, verb
--Meanings--
An organ of soft nervous tissue contained in the skull of vertebrates, functioning as the coordinating centre of sensation and intellectual and nervous activity.
The substance of an animal's brain used as food.

Intellectual capacity.
A clever person who supplies the ideas and plans for a group of people.
A person's mind.
Hit (someone) hard on the head with an object.

--Word--
brainstormer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
US informal. A person who experiences brainstorms; an insane, mercurial, or unstable person; an inspired or eccentric thinker, an intellectual. Frequently depreciative. Now rare.
Originally US. A participant in a brainstorming session.

--Word--
strong 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having the power to move heavy weights or perform other physically demanding tasks.
Able to perform a specified action well and powerfully.
Exerting great force.
Powerful and difficult to resist or defeat.
(of an argument or case) likely to succeed because of sound reasoning or convincing evidence.
Powerfully affecting the mind, senses, or emotions.
(of language or actions) forceful and extreme, especially excessively or unacceptably so.
Able to withstand force, pressure, or wear.
Not easily affected by disease or hardship.
Not easily disturbed, upset, or affected.
Firmly held or established.
(of a market) having steadily high or rising prices.
Very intense.
(of something seen or heard) not soft or muted; clear or prominent.
(of food or its flavour) distinctive and pungent.
(of a solution or drink) containing a large proportion of a particular substance; concentrated.
(of an acid or base) fully ionized into cations and anions in solution; having (respectively) a very low or a very high pH.
Used after a number to indicate the size of a group.
Denoting a class of verbs in Germanic languages that form the past tense and past participle by a change of vowel within the stem rather than by addition of a suffix (e.g. swim, swam, swum).
Relating to or denoting the strongest of the known kinds of force between particles, which acts between nucleons and other hadrons when closer than about 10^-13 cm (so binding protons in a nucleus despite the repulsion due to their charge), and which conserves strangeness, parity, and isospin.
--Examples--
‘she cut through the water with her strong arms’
‘he was not a strong swimmer’
‘a strong current’
‘a strong leader’
‘the competition was too strong’
‘the company was in a strong position to negotiate a deal’
‘there is a strong argument for decentralization’
‘his imagery made a strong impression on the critics’
‘the government were urged to take strong measures against the perpetrators of violence’
‘a play full of strong language’
‘cotton is strong, hard-wearing, and easy to handle’
‘despite his strong constitution, constant worry and exposure to the elements had worn him down’
‘driving on these motorways requires strong nerves’
‘only a strong will enabled him to survive’
‘he was a man of strong, though unconventional, religious beliefs’
‘they had established a strong and trusting relationship’
‘a strong smell’
‘she should wear strong colours’
‘strong cheese’
‘a cup of strong coffee’
‘strong lager’
‘a hostile crowd several thousands strong’

brake 
--Type--
noun, verb, noun, noun, noun, noun
UnKnownKind
--Meanings--
A device for slowing or stopping a moving vehicle, typically by applying pressure to the wheels.
A thing that slows or hinders a process.
Make a moving vehicle slow down or stop by using a brake.
An open horse-drawn carriage with four wheels.
A toothed instrument used for crushing flax and hemp.
A heavy machine formerly used in agriculture for breaking up large lumps of earth.
A thicket.
A coarse fern of warm and tropical countries, frequently having the fronds divided into long linear segments.

‘he slammed on his brakes’
‘a brake pedal’
‘constrained resources will act as a brake on research’
‘she had to brake hard to avoid a milk float’

--Word--
Stoker, Bram 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1847–1912), Irish novelist and theatre manager; full name Abraham Stoker. He was secretary and touring manager to the actor Henry Irving but is chiefly remembered as the author of the vampire story Dracula (1897).
--Examples--
--Word--
Bramah, Joseph 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1748–1814), English inventor. One of the most influential engineers of the Industrial Revolution, Bramah is best known for his hydraulic press, used for heavy forging.
--Examples--
--Word--
Bramante, Donato 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1444–1514), Italian architect; full name Donato di Angelo Bramante. As architect to Pope Julius II he drew up the first plan for the new St Peter's (begun in 1506), instigating the concept of a huge central dome.

--Word--
branch 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A part of a tree which grows out from the trunk or from a bough.
A lateral extension or subdivision extending from the main part of a river, road, railway, etc.
A division or office of a large business or organization, operating locally or having a particular function.
A conceptual subdivision of a family, subject, group of languages, etc.
(of a road or path) divide into one or more subdivisions.
Diverge from the main route or part.
Extend or expand one's activities or interests in a new direction.
(of a tree or plant) bear or send out branches.
--Examples--
‘Sophie was in the branches of a tree eating an apple’
‘a branch of the Clinton River’
‘he went to work at our Birmingham branch’
‘a branch of mathematics called graph theory’
‘follow this track south until it branches into two’
‘the road branched off at the market town’
‘the company is branching out into Europe’
‘this rose has a tendency to branch and spread at the top’
‘the branching heads of large yellow daisies’

A lateral extension or subdivision extending from the main part of a river, road, railway, etc.
A division or office of a large business or organization, operating locally or having a particular function.
A conceptual subdivision of a family, subject, group of languages, etc.
(of a road or path) divide into one or more subdivisions.
Diverge from the main route or part.
Extend or expand one's activities or interests in a new direction.
(of a tree or plant) bear or send out branches.
--Examples--
‘Sophie was in the branches of a tree eating an apple’
‘a branch of the Clinton River’
‘he went to work at our Birmingham branch’
‘a branch of mathematics called graph theory’
‘follow this track south until it branches into two’
‘the road branched off at the market town’
‘the company is branching out into Europe’
‘this rose has a tendency to branch and spread at the top’
‘the branching heads of large yellow daisies’
--Word--
root and brancher 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who advocates or carries out root and branch reform; a proponent of radical change to a process, institution, etc.
--Examples--

--Word--
Branchiopoda 
--Type--
plural noun
--Meanings--
A class of small aquatic crustaceans that includes water fleas and fairy shrimps, which are distinguished by having gills upon the feet.

--Word--
Brancusi, Constantin 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1876–1957), Romanian sculptor, who spent much of his working life in France. His sculpture represents an attempt to move away from a representational art and to capture the essence of forms by reducing them to their ultimate, almost abstract, simplicity.
--Examples--
--Word--
brand 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A type of product manufactured by a particular company under a particular name.
A brand name.
A particular identity or image regarded as an asset.
A particular type or kind of something.
An identifying mark burned on livestock or (especially in former times) criminals or slaves with a branding iron.
A branding iron.
A habit or quality that causes someone public shame or disgrace.
A piece of burning or smouldering wood.
A sword.
Mark with a branding iron.
Mark indelibly.
Mark out as having a particular bad or shameful quality.
Assign a brand name to.
The promotion of a particular product or company by means of advertising and distinctive design.
--Examples--
‘a new brand of soap powder’
‘the firm will market computer software under its own brand’
‘it takes a long time to build a brand’
‘you can still invent your own career, be your own brand’
‘they entertained millions with their inimitable brand of comedy’
‘the brand on a sheep identifies it as mine’
‘the brand of Paula's dipsomania’
‘he took two burning brands from the fire’
‘the seller had branded the animal with his grandfather's name’
‘regulations concerning the branding, movement, and sale of cattle’
‘an ointment that branded her with unsightly violet-coloured splotches’
‘he had a look of unabashed power that only years of experience could brand on to a man's face’
‘anyone who says anything bad about the country is branded as a traitor’
‘she was branded a liar’
‘what is missing in travel and tourism marketing is the heavy and effective branding used in other consumer industries’
--Word--
brandade 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A Provençal dish consisting of salt cod mixed into a puree with olive oil and milk.
--Examples--

--Word--
Brandeis, Louis 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1856–1941), US Supreme Court associate justice 1916–39; full name Louis Dembitz Brandeis. He gained an early reputation as the “people's attorney” by defending without a fee Boston residents seeking regulation of local public utilities. His “Brandeis brief” made use of social facts, rather than relying solely on precedent and general arguments.
--Examples--
--Word--
Brandenburg 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A state of north-eastern Germany; capital, Potsdam. The modern state corresponds to the western part of the former Prussian electorate, of which the eastern part was ceded to Poland after the Second World War.
--Examples--
--Word--
Brandenburg 
--Type--

--Meanings--
A state of north-eastern Germany; capital, Potsdam. The modern state corresponds to the western part of the former Prussian electorate, of which the eastern part was ceded to Poland after the Second World War.

--Word--
Pawnee 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a group of North American peoples formerly living in Nebraska, and now mainly in Oklahoma.
The language of the Pawnee, belonging to the Caddoan family and now almost extinct.
Relating to the Pawnee or their language.

brandling

noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
Brando, Marlon 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1924–2004), American actor. An exponent of method acting, he first attracted critical acclaim in the stage production of A Streetcar Named Desire (1947); he starred in the film version four years later. Other notable films: On the Waterfront (1954, for which he won an Oscar) and The Godfather (1972).
--Examples--

--Word--
Brandt, Willy 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1913–92), German statesman, Chancellor of West Germany 1969–74; born Karl Herbert Frahm. He achieved international recognition for his policy of detente and the opening of relations with the countries of the Eastern bloc (Ostpolitik). Nobel Peace Prize (1971).

Braque, Georges 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1882–1963), French painter. His collages, which introduced commercial lettering and fragmented objects into pictures to contrast the real with the ‘illusory’ painted image, were the first stage in the development of synthetic cubism.
--Examples--

brash 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Self-assertive in a rude, noisy, or overbearing way.
Having an ostentatious or tasteless appearance.
Loose broken rock or ice.
Clippings from hedges, shrubs, or other plants.
--Examples--
‘he was brash, cocky, and arrogant’
‘the cafe was a brash new building’
‘brash ice’
‘cutting up the timber and burning the brash’

--Word--
Brasilia 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The capital, since 1960, of Brazil; population 2,455,903 (2007). Designed by Lúcio Costa in 1956, the city was located in the centre of the country with the intention of drawing people away from the crowded coastal areas.
--Examples--
--Word--
Brasil 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
Braşov 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city in Romania; population 281,375 (2006). It belonged to Hungary until after the First World War, and was ceded to Romania in 1920.
--Examples--
--Word--
brass 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A yellow alloy of copper and zinc.
A decorative object made of brass.
A round flat brass ornament for the harness of a draught horse.
A memorial, typically a medieval one, consisting of a flat piece of inscribed brass, laid in the floor or set into the wall of a church.
A brass block or die used for stamping a design on a book binding.
Brass wind instruments (including trumpet, horn, and trombone) forming a band or a section of an orchestra.
People in authority or of high military rank.
Money.
--Examples--
‘a brass plate on the door’
‘shining brasses stood on the mantelpiece’
‘children do not appear on memorial brasses until the 1420s’
‘the brass were consistently too loud’
‘the top brass of the Jockey Club’
‘they wanted to spend their newly acquired brass’

A piece of armour for the upper arm.

--Examples--
‘heavily armed troops’
‘armed robbery’
‘a lion rampant argent, armed and langued azure’
--Word--
(as) bold as brass 
--Type--
phrase
--Meanings--
Confident to the point of impudence.
--Examples--
‘she marched into the library as bold as brass’
--Word--
brass-bound 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Trimmed or banded with brass fittings.
(of a person) adhering inflexibly to tradition or belief.
(of a person) brazen or impudent.
--Examples--

-browed

cheeked 
--Type--

--Meanings--
--Examples--

--Word--
brass 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A yellow alloy of copper and zinc.
A decorative object made of brass.
A round flat brass ornament for the harness of a draught horse.
A memorial, typically a medieval one, consisting of a flat piece of inscribed brass, laid in the floor or set into the wall of a church.
A brass block or die used for stamping a design on a book binding.
Brass wind instruments (including trumpet, horn, and trombone) forming a band or a section of an orchestra.
People in authority or of high military rank.
Money.
--Examples--
‘a brass plate on the door’
‘shining brasses stood on the mantelpiece’
‘children do not appear on memorial brasses until the 1420s’
‘the brass were consistently too loud’
‘the top brass of the Jockey Club’
‘they wanted to spend their newly acquired brass’
--Word--
electro-brassed 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(Of an article, metal, etc.) coated with brass by electroplating.
--Examples--
--Word--
Brassey, Thomas 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1805–70), English engineer and railway contractor. He built more than 10,000 km (6,500 miles) of railways in Europe, India, South America, and Australia.
--Examples--

--Word--
fitted 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Made or shaped to fill a space or to cover something closely or exactly.
(of a carpet) cut and laid to cover a floor completely.
(of furniture) built to be fixed into a particular space.
(of a room) equipped with matching units of fitted furniture.
Attached to or provided with a particular component or article.
Having the appropriate qualities or skills to do something.
--Examples--
‘the blouse has a fitted bodice’
‘navy-blue fitted sheets’
‘a fitted wardrobe’
‘a fitted kitchen’
‘a piping bag fitted with a star nozzle’
‘I don't think he was fitted for the job’

--Word--
brassy 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Resembling brass in colour.
Sounding like a brass musical instrument; harsh and loud.
(typically of a woman) tastelessly showy or loud in appearance or manner.
--Examples--
‘the last rays of the sun were brassy and chill’
‘audience members are tapping their feet to the brassy music of the band’
‘her brassy, audacious exterior’

--Word--
Bratislava 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The capital of Slovakia, a port on the River Danube; population 426,927 (2007). From 1526 to 1784 it was the capital of Hungary.

--Word--
Brattain, Walter Houser 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1902–87), US physicist and inventor. He invented the point-contact transistor 1947 with John Bardeen and William Shockley. The three shared the Nobel Prize for Physics (1956).
--Examples--

Braun, Eva 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1910–45), German mistress of Adolf Hitler. Braun and Hitler are thought to have married during the fall of Berlin, shortly before committing suicide together in the air-raid shelter of his Berlin headquarters.

--Word--
brave 
--Type--
adjective, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Ready to face and endure danger or pain; showing courage.
Fine or splendid in appearance.
A North American Indian warrior.
Endure or face (unpleasant conditions or behaviour) without showing fear.
--Examples--
‘a brave soldier’
‘he put up a brave fight before losing’
‘she was very brave about the whole thing’
‘it was a time to remember the brave’
‘his medals made a brave show’
‘these six men braved the rough seas’

--Word--
bravely 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--

--Examples--
‘he has been hailed a hero after he bravely tackled a thief at a hotel’
‘she bravely had a go at paragliding’

‘a brave soldier’
‘he put up a brave fight before losing’
‘she was very brave about the whole thing’
‘it was a time to remember the brave’
‘his medals made a brave show’
‘these six men braved the rough seas’
--Word--
brave 
--Type--
adjective, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Ready to face and endure danger or pain; showing courage.
Fine or splendid in appearance.
A North American Indian warrior.
Endure or face (unpleasant conditions or behaviour) without showing fear.
--Examples--
‘a brave soldier’
‘he put up a brave fight before losing’
‘she was very brave about the whole thing’
‘it was a time to remember the brave’
‘his medals made a brave show’
‘these six men braved the rough seas’

--Word--
showing 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of showing something, or the fact of being shown.
A presentation of a cinema film or television programme.
A performance of a specified quality.
The way in which something is argued or represented.
--Examples--
‘Alsatian dog, championship quality, excellent results in showing’
‘another showing of the three-part series’
‘despite poor opinion poll showings, the party selected him as its candidate’
‘even on their own showing and by their own admission, the evidence for this is very weak’

bravo 
--Type--
exclamation, noun, noun
--Meanings--
Used to express approval when a performer or other person has done something well.
A cry of bravo.
A code word representing the letter B, used in radio communication.
A thug or hired assassin.
--Examples--
‘bravo, you're improving!’
‘bravos rang out’

noun, verb
--Meanings--
A rough or noisy fight or quarrel.

(of a stream) flow noisily.

‘a street brawl’
‘he ended up brawling with a lout outside his house’

--Word--
brazen 
--Type--
adjective, verb
--Meanings--
Bold and without shame.
Made of brass.
Harsh in sound.
Endure an embarrassing or difficult situation by behaving with apparent confidence and lack of shame.
--Examples--
‘he went about his illegal business with a brazen assurance’
‘a brazen hussy’
‘brazen fire irons’
‘the music's brazen chords’
‘there was nothing to do but brazen it out’

--Word--
Brazil 
--Type--
proper noun, noun
--Meanings--
The largest country in South America; population 207,900,000 (estimated 2015); official language, Portuguese; capital, Brasilia.
A large three-sided nut with an edible kernel, several of which develop inside a large woody capsule borne by a South American forest tree.
Hard red timber from which dye may be obtained.
--Examples--
--Word--
Brazilian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A native or inhabitant of Brazil.
A style of waxing a woman's pubic hair in which almost all the hair is removed, with only a very small central strip remaining.
Relating to Brazil.
--Examples--

--Word--
Brazos River 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A river that flows southeast for 840 miles (1,350 km) across Texas, from the Panhandle to the Gulf of Mexico. The cities at its mouth are called collectively Brazosport.
--Examples--
--Word--
Brazzaville 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The capital of Congo, a major port; population 1,357,392 (est. 2009). It was founded in 1880 by the French explorer Savorgnan de Brazza (1852–1905) and was capital of French Equatorial Africa from 1910 to 1958.
--Examples--
--Word--
BrE 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
British English.
--Examples--
--Word--
breach 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An act of breaking or failing to observe a law, agreement, or code of conduct.
A break in relations.
A gap in a wall, barrier, or defence, especially one made by an attacking army.
Make a gap in and break through (a wall, barrier, or defence)
Break or fail to observe (a law, agreement, or code of conduct)
(of a whale) rise and break through the surface of the water.
--Examples--
‘a breach of confidence’
‘they alleged breach of copyright’
‘a widening breach between government and Church’
‘a breach in the mountain wall’
‘the river breached its bank’
‘these outside bodies are bootlegging albums and breaching copyright’
‘we saw whales breaching in the distance’
--Word--
breach 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--

noun
--Meanings--

stitch 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A loop of thread or yarn resulting from a single pass or movement of the needle in sewing, knitting, or crocheting.
A loop of thread used to join the edges of a wound or surgical incision.
A method of sewing, knitting, or crocheting producing a particular pattern or design.
The smallest item of clothing.
A sudden sharp pain in the side of the body, caused by strenuous exercise.
Make, mend, or join (something) with stitches.
Manipulate a situation so that someone is placed at a disadvantage or wrongly blamed for something.
Arrange or secure a deal or agreement to one's advantage.
--Examples--
‘he had to have sixteen stitches to his head’
‘basic embroidery stitches’
‘nymphs with come-hither looks and not a stitch on’
‘he was panting and had a stitch’

‘they stitched the cut on her face’
‘hand-stitched dresses’
‘he was stitched up by outsiders and ousted as chairman’
‘the company has stitched up major deals all over the world to boost sales’

--Word--
break 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Separate into pieces as a result of a blow, shock, or strain.
Sustain an injury involving the fracture of a bone or bones in a part of the body.
Cause a cut or graze in (the skin)
Make or become inoperative.
(of the amniotic fluid surrounding a fetus) be discharged when the sac is ruptured in the first stages of labour.
Open (a safe) forcibly.
Use (a banknote) to pay for something and receive change out of the transaction.
(of two boxers or wrestlers) come out of a clinch, especially at the referee's command.
Make the first stroke at the beginning of a game of billiards, pool, or snooker.
Unfurl (a flag or sail).
Succeed in deciphering (a code)
Disprove (an alibi).
Interrupt (a continuity, sequence, or course)
Put an end to (a silence) by speaking or making contact.
Make a pause in (a journey)
Stop proceedings in order to have a pause or vacation.
Lessen the impact of (a fall)
Disconnect or interrupt (an electric circuit)
Stop oneself from engaging in (a habitual practice)
Surpass (a record)
Fail to observe (a law, regulation, or agreement)
Fail to continue with (a self-imposed discipline)
Crush the emotional strength, spirit, or resistance of.
(of a person's emotional strength or control) give way.
Destroy the power of (a movement or organization)
Destroy the effectiveness of (a strike), typically by moving in other people to replace the striking workers.
(of the weather) change suddenly, especially after a fine spell.
(of a storm) begin violently.
(of dawn or a day) begin as the sun rises.
(of clouds) move apart and begin to disperse.
(of waves) curl over and dissolve into foam.
(of a person's voice) falter and change tone, due to emotion.
(of a boy's voice) change in tone and register at puberty.
(of a vowel) develop into a diphthong, under the influence of an adjacent sound.
(of prices on the stock exchange) fall sharply.
(of news or a scandal) suddenly become public.
Make bad news known to (someone)
(chiefly of an attacking player or team, or of a military force) make a rush or dash in a particular direction.
(of a bowled cricket ball) change direction on bouncing, due to spin.
(of a ball) rebound unpredictably.
An interruption of continuity or uniformity.
An act of separating oneself from a pre-existing state of affairs.
A change in the weather.
A change of line, paragraph, or page.
A change of tone in a person's voice due to emotion.
An interruption in an electric circuit.
The winning of a game against an opponent's serve.
A pause in work or during an activity or event.
An interval during the school day.
A short holiday.
A short solo or instrumental passage in jazz or popular music.
Dance music featuring breakbeats.
A gap or opening.
An instance of breaking something, or the point where something is broken.
A rush or dash in a particular direction, especially by an attacking player or team.
An escape, typically from prison.
A change in the direction of a bowled ball on bouncing.
An opportunity or chance, especially one leading to professional success.
A consecutive series of successful shots, scoring a specified number of points.
A player's turn to make the opening shot of a game.
A bud or shoot sprouting from a stem.
--Examples--
‘the rope broke with a loud snap’
‘windows in the street were broken by the blast’
‘she had broken her leg in two places’
‘what if his leg had broken?’
‘the bite had scarcely broken the skin’
‘the machine has broken and they can't fix it until next week’
‘he's broken the video’
‘she realized her waters had broken’
‘she had to break a tenner’
‘I was acting as referee and telling them to break’
‘ciphers are easily broken by the new wonder machines’
‘the new government broke the pattern of growth’
‘his concentration was broken by a sound’
‘it was some time before he broke the silence’
‘we will break our journey in Venice’
‘at mid-morning they broke for coffee’
‘she put out an arm to break her fall’
‘a multimeter able to measure current without having to break the circuit under test’
‘try to break the habit of adding salt at the table’
‘the film broke box office records in the US’
‘the council says it will prosecute traders who break the law’
‘a legally binding contract which can only be broken by mutual consent’
‘diets started without preparation are broken all the time’
‘the idea was to better the prisoners, not to break them’
‘her self-control finally broke’
‘strategies used to break the union’
‘a government threat to use the army to break the strike’
‘the weather broke and thunder rumbled through a leaden sky’
‘when all were aboard, the storm broke’
‘dawn was just breaking’
‘on the seventh of September the clouds broke for the first time’
‘the Caribbean sea was breaking gently on the shore’
‘her voice broke as she relived the experience’
‘after his voice broke, he left the choir’
‘since the news broke I've received thousands of wonderful letters’
‘he was trying to break the terrible news gently to his father’
‘Mitchell won possession and broke quickly, allowing Hughes to score’
‘the ball broke to Craig but his shot rebounded from the post’
‘the magazine has been published without a break since 1950’
‘a break with the past’
‘a week or so may pass without a break in the weather’
‘dotted lines on the screen show page breaks’
‘there was a break in her voice now’
‘I need a break from mental activity’
‘those returning to work after a career break’
‘a coffee break’
‘the bell went for break’
‘a weekend break in the Cotswolds’
‘the track bends left through a break in the hedge’
‘he stopped to wait for a break in the traffic’
‘he was stretchered off with a break to the leg’
‘Norwich scored on a rare break with 11 minutes left’
‘he got his break as an entertainer on a TV music hall show’
‘a break of 83 put him in front for the first time’
‘whose break is it?’
--Word--
break 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Separate into pieces as a result of a blow, shock, or strain.

--Word--
breakable 
--Type--
adjective, plural noun
--Meanings--
Capable of breaking or being broken easily.
Things which are fragile and easily broken.
--Examples--
‘breakable ornaments’
‘an encrypted password isn't easily breakable’
‘breakables, like china, should be padded thoroughly and placed in smaller boxes’
--Word--
breakable 
--Type--
adjective, plural noun
--Meanings--
Capable of breaking or being broken easily.
Things which are fragile and easily broken.
--Examples--
‘breakable ornaments’
‘an encrypted password isn't easily breakable’
‘breakables, like china, should be padded thoroughly and placed in smaller boxes’
--Word--
breakable 
--Type--
adjective, plural noun
--Meanings--

Things which are fragile and easily broken.
--Examples--
‘breakable ornaments’
‘an encrypted password isn't easily breakable’
‘breakables, like china, should be padded thoroughly and placed in smaller boxes’

--Word--
breakable 
--Type--
adjective, plural noun
--Meanings--
Capable of breaking or being broken easily.
Things which are fragile and easily broken.
--Examples--
‘breakable ornaments’
‘an encrypted password isn't easily breakable’
‘breakables, like china, should be padded thoroughly and placed in smaller boxes’
--Word--
breakage 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of breaking something, or the fact of being broken.
--Examples--
‘some breakage of bone has occurred’
‘there had been three breakages in the overhead wires’
--Word--
breakage 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of breaking something, or the fact of being broken.
--Examples--
‘some breakage of bone has occurred’
‘there had been three breakages in the overhead wires’
--Word--
breakaway 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A divergence or radical change from something established or long-standing.
A secession of a number of people from an organization, resulting in the establishment of a new organization.
A sudden attack or forward movement, especially in a race or a soccer game.
Each of the two flank forwards on the outsides of the second row of a scrum formation.
A stampede of animals, typically at the sight or smell of water.
--Examples--
‘rock was a breakaway from pop’
‘a breakaway group’
‘a winning breakaway’
--Word--
break the back of 
--Type--
phrase
--Meanings--
Accomplish the main or hardest part of (a task)
Overwhelm or defeat.
--Examples--
‘we've broken the back of the problem’
‘I thought we really had broken the back of inflation’

--Examples--

--Examples--
--Word--
circuit 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A roughly circular line, route, or movement that starts and finishes at the same place.
A track used for motor racing, horse racing, or athletics.
An established itinerary of events or venues used for a particular activity, typically involving sport or public performance.
A series of athletic exercises performed consecutively in one training session.
A regular journey made by a judge around a particular district to hear cases in court.
A district administered or formerly administered by travelling judges.
A group of local Methodist Churches forming an administrative unit.
A chain of theatres or cinemas under a single management.
A complete and closed path around which a circulating electric current can flow.
A system of electrical conductors and components forming an electrical circuit.
Move all the way around (a place or thing)
--Examples--
‘I ran a circuit of the village’
‘Hockenheim was a fast circuit but was regarded as one of the safest’
‘the alternative cabaret circuit’
‘circuit training’
‘a circuit judge’
‘the six circuits of England and Wales replaced the old system of assizes’
‘the success of any chapel or Methodist circuit depended on the minister’
‘the company also bought cinema circuits in Canada, New Zealand, and Australia’
‘the maximum number of light fittings on a circuit is twelve’
‘control circuits’
‘the trains will follow the Northern line, circuiting the capital’
--Word--
breakdown 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A mechanical failure.
A failure of a relationship or system.
A sudden collapse in someone's mental health.
The chemical or physical decomposition of something.
An explanatory analysis, especially of statistics.
--Examples--
‘breakdowns could totally disrupt production’
‘a breakdown in military discipline’
‘a communications breakdown’
‘some of these women will have experienced marital breakdown’
‘Heather had a breakdown following the death of her sister’
‘the breakdown of ammonia to nitrites’
‘a detailed cost breakdown’

--Word--
breaker 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A heavy sea wave that breaks into white foam on the shore.
A person or thing that breaks something.
A person who breaks up disused machinery.
A person who interrupts a conversation on a Citizens' Band radio channel, indicating that they wish to transmit a message.
Any CB radio user.
A break dancer.
--Examples--
‘a rule-breaker’
‘those steam engines were now gone to the breaker's yard’

--Word--
break 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Separate into pieces as a result of a blow, shock, or strain.
Sustain an injury involving the fracture of a bone or bones in a part of the body.
Cause a cut or graze in (the skin)
Make or become inoperative.
(of the amniotic fluid surrounding a fetus) be discharged when the sac is ruptured in the first stages of labour.
Open (a safe) forcibly.
Use (a banknote) to pay for something and receive change out of the transaction.
(of two boxers or wrestlers) come out of a clinch, especially at the referee's command.
Make the first stroke at the beginning of a game of billiards, pool, or snooker.
Unfurl (a flag or sail).
Succeed in deciphering (a code)
Disprove (an alibi).
Interrupt (a continuity, sequence, or course)
Put an end to (a silence) by speaking or making contact.
Make a pause in (a journey)
Stop proceedings in order to have a pause or vacation.
Lessen the impact of (a fall)
Disconnect or interrupt (an electric circuit)
Stop oneself from engaging in (a habitual practice)
Surpass (a record)
Fail to observe (a law, regulation, or agreement)
Fail to continue with (a self-imposed discipline)
Crush the emotional strength, spirit, or resistance of.
(of a person's emotional strength or control) give way.
Destroy the power of (a movement or organization)
Destroy the effectiveness of (a strike), typically by moving in other people to replace the striking workers.
(of the weather) change suddenly, especially after a fine spell.
(of a storm) begin violently.
(of dawn or a day) begin as the sun rises.
(of clouds) move apart and begin to disperse.
(of waves) curl over and dissolve into foam.
(of a person's voice) falter and change tone, due to emotion.
(of a boy's voice) change in tone and register at puberty.
(of a vowel) develop into a diphthong, under the influence of an adjacent sound.
(of prices on the stock exchange) fall sharply.
(of news or a scandal) suddenly become public.
Make bad news known to (someone)
(chiefly of an attacking player or team, or of a military force) make a rush or dash in a particular direction.
(of a bowled cricket ball) change direction on bouncing, due to spin.
(of a ball) rebound unpredictably.
An interruption of continuity or uniformity.
An act of separating oneself from a pre-existing state of affairs.
A change in the weather.
A change of line, paragraph, or page.
A change of tone in a person's voice due to emotion.
An interruption in an electric circuit.
The winning of a game against an opponent's serve.
A pause in work or during an activity or event.
An interval during the school day.
A short holiday.
A short solo or instrumental passage in jazz or popular music.
Dance music featuring breakbeats.
A gap or opening.
An instance of breaking something, or the point where something is broken.
A rush or dash in a particular direction, especially by an attacking player or team.
An escape, typically from prison.
A change in the direction of a bowled ball on bouncing.
An opportunity or chance, especially one leading to professional success.
A consecutive series of successful shots, scoring a specified number of points.
A player's turn to make the opening shot of a game.
A bud or shoot sprouting from a stem.
--Examples--
‘the rope broke with a loud snap’
‘windows in the street were broken by the blast’
‘she had broken her leg in two places’
‘what if his leg had broken?’
‘the bite had scarcely broken the skin’
‘the machine has broken and they can't fix it until next week’
‘he's broken the video’
‘she realized her waters had broken’
‘she had to break a tenner’
‘I was acting as referee and telling them to break’
‘ciphers are easily broken by the new wonder machines’
‘the new government broke the pattern of growth’
‘his concentration was broken by a sound’
‘it was some time before he broke the silence’
‘we will break our journey in Venice’
‘at mid-morning they broke for coffee’
‘she put out an arm to break her fall’
‘a multimeter able to measure current without having to break the circuit under test’
‘try to break the habit of adding salt at the table’
‘the film broke box office records in the US’
‘the council says it will prosecute traders who break the law’
‘a legally binding contract which can only be broken by mutual consent’
‘diets started without preparation are broken all the time’
‘the idea was to better the prisoners, not to break them’
‘her self-control finally broke’
‘strategies used to break the union’
‘a government threat to use the army to break the strike’
‘the weather broke and thunder rumbled through a leaden sky’
‘when all were aboard, the storm broke’
‘dawn was just breaking’
‘on the seventh of September the clouds broke for the first time’
‘the Caribbean sea was breaking gently on the shore’
‘her voice broke as she relived the experience’
‘after his voice broke, he left the choir’
‘since the news broke I've received thousands of wonderful letters’
‘he was trying to break the terrible news gently to his father’
‘Mitchell won possession and broke quickly, allowing Hughes to score’
‘the ball broke to Craig but his shot rebounded from the post’
‘the magazine has been published without a break since 1950’
‘a break with the past’
‘a week or so may pass without a break in the weather’
‘dotted lines on the screen show page breaks’
‘there was a break in her voice now’
‘I need a break from mental activity’
‘those returning to work after a career break’
‘a coffee break’
‘the bell went for break’
‘a weekend break in the Cotswolds’
‘the track bends left through a break in the hedge’
‘he stopped to wait for a break in the traffic’
‘he was stretchered off with a break to the leg’
‘Norwich scored on a rare break with 11 minutes left’
‘he got his break as an entertainer on a TV music hall show’
‘a break of 83 put him in front for the first time’
‘whose break is it?’

--Word--
breakout 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A forcible escape, especially from prison.
(in soccer and other sports) a sudden attack by a team that has been defending.
An outbreak.
The deformation or splintering of wood, stone, or other material being drilled or planed.
Suddenly and extremely popular or successful.
Denoting a group which breaks away from a larger gathering for discussion.
--Examples--
‘a prison breakout’
‘the Dutch tend to be defensive and go for the breakout’
‘a breakout of hostilities’
‘avoid breakout and fluffy edges’
‘a breakout movie’
‘breakout discussion groups’
--Word--

--Word--
break point 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A place or time at which an interruption or change is made.
A place in a computer program where the sequence of instructions is interrupted, especially by another program or operator intervention.
The state of a game when the player or side receiving service needs only one more point to win the game.
--Examples--
‘he hit a winner to reach break point’
--Word--
promise 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A declaration or assurance that one will do something or that a particular thing will happen.
An indication that something is likely to occur.
The quality of potential excellence.
Assure someone that one will definitely do something or that something will happen.
Pledge (someone, especially a woman) to marry someone else; betroth.
Give good grounds for expecting (a particular occurrence)
Announce (something) as being expected to happen.
Contemplate the pleasant expectation of.
--Examples--
‘what happened to all those firm promises of support?’
‘I did not keep my promise to go home early’
‘dawn came with the promise of fine weather’
‘he showed great promise even as a junior officer’
‘he promised to forward my mail’
‘she made him promise that he wouldn't do it again’
‘‘I'll bring it straight back,’ she promised’
‘he promised her the job’
‘I've been promised to him for years’
‘forthcoming concerts promise a feast of music’
‘it promised to be a night that all would remember’
‘forecasters were promising a record snowfall in Boston’
‘we're promised more winter weather tonight’
‘he tidied up the sitting room, promising himself an early night’

--Word--
breakthrough 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A sudden, dramatic, and important discovery or development.
An instance of achieving success in a particular sphere or activity.
--Examples--
‘a major breakthrough in DNA research’
‘his big breakthrough came in 1988 when he had two paintings accepted by the RSA’
‘the band's breakthrough album’

breakup

noun
--Meanings--
The separation or breaking up of something into several pieces or sections.
The end of a relationship.
--Examples--
‘the breakup of the Ottoman Empire’
‘large quantities of oil are released after the breakup of a tanker’
‘a marriage breakup’
--Word--
breakwater 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A barrier built out into the sea to protect a coast or harbour from the force of waves.
--Examples--

--Word--
bream 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A greenish-bronze deep-bodied freshwater fish native to Europe.
Used in names of other fishes resembling or related to the bream, e.g. sea bream, Ray's bream.
Clear (a ship or its bottom) of weeds, shells, or other accumulated matter by burning and scraping it.
--Examples--
‘bonfires of brushwood, lighted to bream the sharp-bowed craft’
--Word--

bream

noun, verb
