--Word--
breast 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
Either of the two soft, protruding organs on the upper front of a woman's body which secrete milk after childbirth.
A person's chest, especially when regarded as the seat of the emotions.
The part of a bird or mammal that corresponds to a person's chest.
A joint of meat or portion of poultry cut from the breast of a bird or mammal.
The part of a garment that covers the chest.
Face and move forwards against or through (something)
Reach the top of (a hill)
--Examples--
‘Caroline crossed her arms over her breasts’
‘breast cancer’
‘wild feelings of frustration were rising up in his breast’
‘her heart was hammering in her breast’
‘the breast feathers of the doves’
‘Lisa popped a breast of chicken into the microwave’
‘a breast pocket’
‘I watched him breast the wave’
‘a pair of riders breasted the rise ahead’

--Word--
beater 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who hits someone or something, typically on a habitual basis.
A person who beats metal in manufacturing.
A person employed to raise game birds for shooting by striking at the ground cover.
An implement or machine used for beating.
A person or thing that overcomes or prevents something.
An old or dilapidated vehicle.
--Examples--
‘he is not a drug addict, an alcoholic, or a woman beater’
‘he started out as a metal beater in the sheet metal shop’
‘he had regularly worked as a beater on grouse shoots on Soyland Moor’
‘beat two eggs in large bowl with a hand beater until fluffy’
‘a recession beater’
‘I bought a beater and drove that for a few years’

--Word--
breaststroke 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A swimming stroke in which the arms are pushed forwards and then swept back in a circular movement, while the legs are tucked in towards the body and then kicked out in a corresponding movement.
--Examples--
‘the breaststroke is one of the most difficult strokes’
‘I am good at breaststroke’
‘backstroke and breaststroke events’

--Word--
breath 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The air taken into or expelled from the lungs.
An inhalation or exhalation of air from the lungs.
The power of breathing; life.
A slight movement of air.
A sign, hint, or suggestion.
--Examples--
‘I was gasping for breath’
‘his breath smelled of garlic’
‘she drew in a quick breath’
‘the weather was balmy, not a breath of wind’
‘he avoided the slightest breath of scandal’

breathability 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
breathable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of the air) fit or pleasant to breathe.
(of clothes or material) admitting air to the skin and allowing sweat to evaporate.
--Examples--
‘further in the air seemed less breathable’
‘a breathable atmosphere’
‘the jacket is waterproof, windproof, and breathable’
‘a breathable fabric’

verb
--Meanings--

breathalyser 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A device used by police for measuring the amount of alcohol in a driver's breath.
--Examples--
‘a breathalyser test proved negative’

--Word--
breathe 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Take air into the lungs and then expel it, especially as a regular physiological process.
(of a fish) draw in water with dissolved oxygen through the mouth and force it out through the gills.
(of a cell, tissue, or living organism) exchange gases, especially by means of a diffusion process.
Be alive; remain living.
(of wind) blow softly.
Say something with quiet intensity.
Give an impression of (something)
(of wine) be exposed to fresh air.
(of material or soil) admit or emit air or moisture.
Allow (a horse) to rest after exertion.
Tarnish or taint.
--Examples--
‘she was breathing deeply’
‘breathe in through your nose’
‘he breathed out heavily’
‘we are polluting the air we breathe’
‘you will see the gill cover opening and the gills fluttering, as water is drawn over the gills and the fish breathes’
‘adult amphibians also breathe through their skin’
‘plants breathe through all their organs, including roots’
‘at least I'm still breathing’
‘‘We're together at last,’ she breathed’
‘the whole room breathed an air of hygienic efficiency’
‘letting a wine breathe allows oxygen to enter’
‘let your lawn breathe by putting air into the soil’
‘before the queen's fair name was breathed upon’

--Word--
breather 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person or animal that breathes in a particular way.
A brief pause for rest.
A vent or valve to release pressure or to allow air to move freely around something.
--Examples--
‘a heavy breather’
‘let's take a breather’
‘a cask breather’
‘a crankcase breather’
‘a breather pipe’

breathing 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The process of taking air into and expelling it from the lungs.
A sign in Greek (῾ or ᾿) indicating the presence of an aspirate (rough breathing) or the absence of an aspirate (smooth breathing) at the beginning of a word.
--Examples--
‘his breathing was shallow’
--Word--
breathing 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

A sign in Greek (῾ or ᾿) indicating the presence of an aspirate (rough breathing) or the absence of an aspirate (smooth breathing) at the beginning of a word.
--Examples--
‘his breathing was shallow’
--Word--
breathless 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Gasping for breath, typically due to exertion.
Feeling or causing great excitement or other strong feelings.
(of the air) not stirred by any wind or breeze; stiflingly still.
--Examples--
‘the climb left me breathless’
‘she was breathless with shock’
‘the warm breathless air’
--Word--
breathlessly 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In a way that involves gasping for breath, typically due to exertion.
In a way that is characterized by great excitement or suspense.
--Examples--
‘breathlessly, we run faster and faster’
‘she laughed breathlessly’
‘we breathlessly await their new release’
‘fan websites that are breathlessly updated’

--Meanings--

--Type--
adverb

To an extreme or shocking degree; incredibly.
--Examples--
‘the beach is endless and breathtakingly beautiful’
‘the sharks will pass breathtakingly close if you stay completely still’
‘a breathtakingly rude letter’
‘a breathtakingly aggressive takeover’
--Word--
breccia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Rock consisting of angular fragments of stones cemented by finer calcareous material.
--Examples--
‘copious quantities of breccia’

--Word--
Brecht, Bertolt 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1898–1956), German playwright, producer, and poet; full name Eugen Bertolt Friedrich Brecht. His interest in combining music and drama led to collaboration with Kurt Weill, for example in The Threepenny Opera (1928), an adaptation of John Gay's The Beggar's Opera. Brecht's later drama, written in exile after Hitler's rise to power, uses techniques of theatrical alienation and includes Mother Courage (1941) and The Caucasian Chalk Circle (1948).
--Examples--
--Word--
Brechtian 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or characteristic of the German playwright, producer, and poet Bertolt Brecht or his work.
--Examples--
‘a masterpiece of Brechtian alienation’
--Word--
Breckinridge, John C. 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1821–75), US politician and vice president of the US 1857–61; full name John Cabell Breckinridge. He also served as a major general in the Confederate army 1861.
--Examples--

--Word--
Breda 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A manufacturing town in the south-western Netherlands; population 170,960 (2008). It is noted for the Compromise of Breda of 1566, a protest against Spanish rule over the Netherlands; the 1660 manifesto of Charles II (who lived there in exile), stating his terms for accepting the throne of Britain; and the Treaty of Breda, which ended the Anglo-Dutch war of 1665–7.
--Examples--
--Word--
bred-in-the-bone

adjective
--Meanings--
Firmly established; deep-rooted.
Long established and unlikely to change; inveterate.
--Examples--

--Meanings--

--Word--
breech 
--Type--
noun, adjective, verb
--Meanings--
The part of a cannon behind the bore.
The back part of a rifle or gun barrel.
A person's buttocks.
Relating to or denoting presentation of a fetus in which the buttocks, rump, or legs are nearest the cervix and emerge first at birth.
Dress (a boy) in breeches after he had been in petticoats since birth.
--Examples--
‘the 47-round ammunition drum fits over the breech’
‘breech presentation occurs in up to 3 per cent of pregnancies at term’
‘my second son was breech and my doctor recommended a planned C-section’
‘in those days it wasn't customary to breech a boy until he was about four’

noun

A strong leather strap passing round the hindquarters of a horse harnessed to a vehicle and enabling the horse to push backwards.

--Word--
breed 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
(of animals) mate and then produce offspring.
Cause (an animal) to produce offspring, especially in a controlled and organized way.
Develop (a variety of animal or plant) for a particular purpose or quality.
Rear and train (someone) to behave in a particular way.
Produce or lead to (something) over a period of time.
Create (fissile material) by nuclear reaction.
A stock of animals or plants within a species having a distinctive appearance and typically having been developed by deliberate selection.
A sort or kind of person or thing.
--Examples--
‘toads are said to return to the pond of their birth to breed’
‘bitches may not be bred from more than once a year’
‘these horses are bred for this sport’
‘Theodora had been beautifully bred’
‘success had bred a certain arrogance’
‘the big continental breeds are eagerly being imported by British farmers’
‘a new breed of entrepreneurs was brought into being’

--Word--
breeze 
--Type--
noun, verb, noun
--Meanings--
A gentle wind.
A wind of force 2 to 6 on the Beaufort scale (4–27 knots or 7–50 km/h).
A thing that is easy to do or accomplish.
Come or go in a casual or light-hearted manner.
Deal with something with apparently casual ease.
Small cinders mixed with sand and cement to make breeze blocks.
--Examples--
‘tantalizing cooking smells wafted on the evening breeze’
‘travelling through London was a breeze’
‘Roger breezed into her office’
‘Milan had breezed through their first defence of the European Cup’
--Word--

--Examples--
‘waterborne bacteria’

Bremen 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A state of north-westernGermany. Divided into two parts, which centre on the city of Bremen and the port of Bremerhaven, it is surrounded by the state of Lower Saxony.
The capital of the state of Bremen, an industrial city linked by the River Weser to the port of Bremerhaven and the North Sea; population 547,900 (est. 2006).
--Examples--
--Word--
Bremerhaven 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A seaport in northwestern Germany, on the North Sea coast, north of Bremen; population 115,300 (est. 2007). Bremerhaven is one of the largest seaports and fishing centers in Europe. The first regular shipping service between the US and Europe began here. Former name Wesermünde.
--Examples--

--Meanings--
A city in west central Washington, on Puget Sound, home to large naval shipyards; population 36,006 (est. 2008).

noun
--Meanings--

Brennan, Walter 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1894–1974), US actor. A character actor, he appeared in many movies and was the first actor to win three Academy Awards, all for best supporting actor. His award-winning movies were Come and Get It (1936), Kentucky (1938), and The Westerner (1940).

Brest 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A port and naval base in north-western France, on the Atlantic coast of Brittany; population 148,316 (2006).
A river port and industrial city in Belarus, situated close to the border with Poland; population 318,000 (est. 2009). The peace treaty between Germany and Russia was signed there in March 1918. Former name (until 1921) Brest-Litovsk.

Brett, George 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1953–), US baseball player. Playing for the Kansas City Royals 1973–93, he was the American League batting champion in three different decades (1976, 1980, 1990). Baseball Hall of Fame (1999).

--Word--
Breuer, Marcel Lajos 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1902–81), US architect; born in Hungary. He designed the UNESCO headquarters in Paris 1953–58 and the Whitney Museum of American Art in New York City 1963–66. He is also known for his chair designs.
--Examples--
--Word--
Bruegel 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The name of a family of Flemish artists.
Pieter (c.1525–69); known as Pieter Bruegel the Elder. He produced landscapes, religious allegories, and satires of peasant life. Notable works: The Procession to Calvary (1564).
Pieter Bruegel the Younger (1564–1638), son of Pieter Bruegel the Elder; known as Hell Bruegel. A very able copyist of his father's work, he is also noted for his paintings of devils.
Jan (1568–1623), son of Pieter Bruegel the Elder; known as Velvet Bruegel. He was a celebrated painter of flowers, landscapes, and mythological scenes.
--Examples--
--Word--
Brevard County 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A county in east central Florida, on the Atlantic Ocean, the site of Cape Canaveral and of large citrus and resort industries; population 536,521 (est. 2008).
--Examples--
--Word--
breve 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A note, rarely used in modern music, having the time value of two semibreves, and represented as a semibreve with two short bars either side, or as a square.
A written or printed mark (˘) indicating a short or unstressed vowel.
An authoritative letter from a pope or monarch.

‘a brevet lieutenant’
--Word--
brevet 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A former type of military commission conferred especially for outstanding service, by which an officer was promoted to a higher rank without the corresponding pay.
Confer a brevet rank on.
--Examples--
‘a brevet lieutenant’

--Type--

brevity 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Concise and exact use of words in writing or speech.
Shortness of time.
--Examples--

‘for brevity, it is worth using these little symbols’
‘the brevity of human life’

--Word--
brew 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Make (beer) by soaking, boiling, and fermentation.
Make (tea or coffee) by mixing it with hot water.
Make tea.
(of an unwelcome event or situation) begin to develop.
A kind of beer.
A glass or can of beer.
A cup or mug of tea or coffee.
A mixture of events, people, or things which interact to form a more potent whole.
--Examples--
‘within five years the company will brew as much beer in China as in Australia’
‘the brewing industry’
‘I've just brewed some coffee’
‘he insisted on sitting us down and then went to brew up’
‘there was more trouble brewing as the miners went on strike’
‘a storm was brewing’
‘small breweries which are able to offer rare brews’
‘he dug a brew out from the cooler and flipped the ringtop’
‘she took a sip of the hot reviving brew’
‘a dangerous brew of political turmoil and violent conflict’

--Word--
Brewster, Sir David 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1781–1868), Scottish physicist. He is best known for his work on the laws governing the polarization of light, and for his invention of the kaleidoscope.
--Examples--
--Word--
Brezhnev, Leonid 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1906–82), Soviet statesman, General Secretary of the Communist Party of the USSR 1966–82 and president 1977–82; full name Leonid Ilich Brezhnev. His period in power was marked by intensified persecution of dissidents at home and by attempted detente followed by renewed Cold War in 1968; he was largely responsible for the invasion of Czechoslovakia (1968).
--Examples--
--Word--
bris 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The ceremony in which a Jewish baby boy is circumcised.
--Examples--
--Word--
Lara, Brian 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(born 1969), West Indian cricketer; full name Brian Charles Lara. He scored 501 not out, a world record in first-class cricket, for Warwickshire against Durham in 1994, and 400 against England in Antigua in 2004, the highest individual score in a test innings.
--Examples--

--Word--
Bryant, William Cullen 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1794–1878), US poet and editor. He was co-owner and editor of the New York Evening Post 1829–78; his poems “Thanatopsis” (1811) and “To a Waterfowl” (1821) established him as the leading poet of his time.
--Examples--
--Word--
briar 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
Any of a number of prickly scrambling shrubs, especially a wild rose.
A tobacco pipe made from woody nodules borne at ground level by a large woody plant of the heather family.
The tree heath, which bears the nodules from which briar pipes are made.

bribe 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Dishonestly persuade (someone) to act in one's favour by a gift of money or other inducement.
A sum of money or other inducement offered or given to bribe someone.
--Examples--
‘they attempted to bribe opponents into losing’
‘they had bribed an official to sell them a certificate’
‘lawmakers were caught accepting bribes to bring in legalized gambling’

--Word--
brick 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A small rectangular block typically made of fired or sun-dried clay, used in building.
Bricks collectively as a building material.
A small rectangular object.
A child's toy building block.
A large and relatively heavy mobile phone, typically an early model with limited functionality.
A smartphone or other electronic device that has completely ceased to function.
A generous, helpful, and reliable person.
Block or enclose with a wall of bricks.
Throw bricks at.
Cause (a smartphone or other electronic device) to become completely unable to function, typically on a permanent basis.
Be extremely worried or nervous.
--Examples--
‘this mill was built of brick’
‘a large brick building’
‘a brick of ice cream’
‘the bricks and other plastic toys then need to be fitted back into their appropriate containers’
‘I had one of those Motorola bricks as my first cell phone’
‘while updating the firmware the USB cable got disconnected and the phone is now a brick’
‘‘You are really a brick, Vi,’ Gloria said’
‘the doors have been bricked up’
‘the pub was attacked and windows in the area were bricked’
‘installing an unofficial OS voids the warranty and may brick the phone’

‘installing an unofficial OS voids the warranty and may brick the phone’

--Word--
brick 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A small rectangular block typically made of fired or sun-dried clay, used in building.
Bricks collectively as a building material.
A small rectangular object.
A child's toy building block.
A large and relatively heavy mobile phone, typically an early model with limited functionality.
A smartphone or other electronic device that has completely ceased to function.
A generous, helpful, and reliable person.
Block or enclose with a wall of bricks.
Throw bricks at.
Cause (a smartphone or other electronic device) to become completely unable to function, typically on a permanent basis.
Be extremely worried or nervous.
--Examples--
‘this mill was built of brick’
‘a large brick building’
‘a brick of ice cream’
‘the bricks and other plastic toys then need to be fitted back into their appropriate containers’
‘I had one of those Motorola bricks as my first cell phone’
‘while updating the firmware the USB cable got disconnected and the phone is now a brick’
‘‘You are really a brick, Vi,’ Gloria said’
‘the doors have been bricked up’
‘the pub was attacked and windows in the area were bricked’
‘installing an unofficial OS voids the warranty and may brick the phone’

--Word--
bridge 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A structure carrying a road, path, railway, etc. across a river, road, or other obstacle.
Something intended to reconcile or connect two seemingly incompatible things.
The elevated, enclosed platform on a ship from which the captain and officers direct operations.
The upper bony part of a person's nose.
The central part of a pair of glasses, fitting over the bridge of the nose.
A partial denture supported by natural teeth on either side.
The part of a stringed instrument over which the strings are stretched.
A bridge passage or middle eight.
The support for the tip of a billiard cue formed by the hand.
A long stick with a frame at the end which is used to support a cue for a difficult shot.
An electric circuit with two branches across which a detector or load is connected, used to measure resistance or other property by equalizing the potential across the two ends of a detector, or to rectify an alternating voltage or current.
Be or make a bridge over (something)
Make (a difference between two groups) smaller or less significant.
--Examples--
‘a bridge across the River Thames’
‘a railway bridge’
‘a committee which was formed to create a bridge between rival party groups’
‘Talbot stepped across the two gunwales and made his way up to the bridge’
‘he pushed his spectacles further up the bridge of his nose’
‘these sunglasses have a special nose bridge for comfort’
‘ebony bridges and fingerboards’
‘a covered walkway bridged the gardens’
‘earlier attempts to bridge St George's Channel had failed’
‘new initiatives were needed to bridge the great abyss of class’

Riley, Bridget 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(born 1931), English painter; full name Bridget Louise Riley. A leading exponent of op art, she worked with flat patterns to create optical illusions of light and movement. Notable paintings: Fall (1963).

Bridgman, Percy Williams 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1882–1961), American physicist. He worked with liquids and solids under very high pressures and his techniques were later used in making artificial minerals (including diamonds). Nobel Prize for Physics (1946).

bridle 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The headgear used to control a horse, consisting of buckled straps to which a bit and reins are attached.
A line, rope, or device that is used to restrain or control the action or movement of something.
A mooring cable.
Put a bridle on (a horse)
Bring (something) under control; curb.
Show one's resentment or anger, especially by throwing up one's head and drawing in one's chin.
--Examples--
‘grooms came at once to take the bridles’
‘five horses, saddled and bridled, were tied by the reins to branches of trees’
‘the fact that he was their servant bridled his tongue’
‘she bridled at his tone’

--Word--
brief 
--Type--
adjective, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Of short duration; not lasting for long.
Concise in expression; using few words.
(of a piece of clothing) not covering much of the body; scanty.
A set of instructions given to a person about a job or task.
A summary of the facts and legal points in a case given to a barrister to argue in court.
A piece of work for a barrister.
A solicitor or barrister.
A written statement of the facts and legal points supporting one side of a case, for presentation to a court.
A letter from the Pope to a person or community on a matter of discipline.
Instruct or inform (someone) thoroughly, especially in preparation for a task.
Instruct (a barrister) by brief.
--Examples--
‘the president made a brief working visit to Moscow’
‘introductions were brief and polite’
‘be brief and don't talk for longer than is necessary’
‘a pair of extremely brief black shorts’
‘his brief is to turn round the county's fortunes’
‘he cannot be too highly recommended, if he is free and will take the brief’
‘it was only his brief's eloquence that had saved him from prison’
‘she briefed him on last week's decisions’
--Word--
briefcase 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A leather or plastic rectangular container with a handle for carrying books and documents.

--Word--
brief 
--Type--
adjective, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Of short duration; not lasting for long.
Concise in expression; using few words.
(of a piece of clothing) not covering much of the body; scanty.
A set of instructions given to a person about a job or task.
A summary of the facts and legal points in a case given to a barrister to argue in court.
A piece of work for a barrister.
A solicitor or barrister.
A written statement of the facts and legal points supporting one side of a case, for presentation to a court.
A letter from the Pope to a person or community on a matter of discipline.
Instruct or inform (someone) thoroughly, especially in preparation for a task.
Instruct (a barrister) by brief.
--Examples--
‘the president made a brief working visit to Moscow’
‘introductions were brief and polite’
‘be brief and don't talk for longer than is necessary’
‘a pair of extremely brief black shorts’
‘his brief is to turn round the county's fortunes’
‘he cannot be too highly recommended, if he is free and will take the brief’
‘it was only his brief's eloquence that had saved him from prison’
‘she briefed him on last week's decisions’
--Word--
briefer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who presents detailed information and offers instruction to someone, especially in preparation for a task.
--Examples--
‘military briefers prepare for war’
‘we have a briefer who will be able to go into this in greater detail’

--Word--
briar 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
Any of a number of prickly scrambling shrubs, especially a wild rose.
A tobacco pipe made from woody nodules borne at ground level by a large woody plant of the heather family.
The tree heath, which bears the nodules from which briar pipes are made.

brig 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
brigade 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A subdivision of an army, typically consisting of a small number of infantry battalions and/or other units and forming part of a division.
An organization with a military or quasi-military structure.
A group of people with a characteristic in common.
Form into a brigade.
Associate with (someone or something)
--Examples--
‘he commanded a brigade of 3,000 men’
‘a volunteer ambulance brigade’
‘the anti-smoking brigade’
‘the militia, which was brigaded with regular formations to improve its training’
‘they thought the speech too closely brigaded with illegal action’

--Word--
Young, Brigham 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1801–77), American Mormon leader. He succeeded Joseph Smith as the leader of the Mormons in 1844, and established their headquarters at Salt Lake City, Utah.

--Word--
bright 
--Type--
adjective, adverb, noun
--Meanings--
Giving out or reflecting much light; shining.
Full of light.
(of a period of time) having sunny, cloudless weather.
(of colour) vivid and bold.
Having a vivid colour.
Intelligent and quick-witted.
Cheerful and lively.
(of someone's future) likely to be successful and happy.
(of sound) clear, vibrant, and typically high-pitched.
Brightly.
Bold and vivid colours.
Headlights switched to full beam.
--Examples--
‘the sun was dazzlingly bright’
‘her bright, dark eyes’
‘the rooms are bright and spacious’
‘the long, bright days of June’
‘the bright green leaves’
‘a bright tie’
‘a bright idea’
‘a bright young journalist’
‘at breakfast she would be persistently bright and chirpy’
‘she gave a bright smile’
‘these young people have a bright future ahead of them’
‘her voice is fresh and bright’
‘a full moon shining bright’
‘a choice of colours from pastels through to brights’
‘he turned the brights on and we drove along the dirt road’

--Word--
brighten 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Make or become more light.
Make (something) more attractively colourful.
Make or become happier and more cheerful.
--Examples--
‘most of the country should brighten up later’
‘the fire began to blaze fiercely, brightening the room’
‘daffodils brighten up many gardens and parks’
‘Sarah brightened up considerably as she thought of Emily's words’
‘she seems to brighten his life’

flaming 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Burning fiercely and emitting flames.
Very hot.
Of a bright orange or red colour.
Passionate or violent.
Used for emphasis to express annoyance.
(of a gay man) having a manner or appearance regarded as stereotypically homosexual.
--Examples--
‘they dragged her away from the flaming car’
‘flaming June’
‘her flaming hair’
‘a flaming row’
‘where's that flaming taxi?’

--Word--
brightly 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In a way that gives out or reflects much light.
In a way that is characterized by having vivid colours.
In an intelligent and quick-witted way.
In a cheerful and lively way.
--Examples--
‘diamond stud earrings shone brightly in his ears’
‘lanterns glow brightly in the dark hall’
‘a very brightly patterned floral jumper’
‘brightly painted fingernails’
‘a wry, brightly written essay’
‘chattering brightly’
‘those on stage smiled brightly at the crowd’

--Word--
brightness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The quality or state of giving out or reflecting light.
The quality or state of being well lit.
Sunny, cloudless weather.
The quality of being vividly and boldly coloured.
The quality of being intelligent and quick-witted.
The quality of being cheerful or lively.
Success and happiness.
The quality in sound of being clear, vibrant, and typically high-pitched.
--Examples--
‘we can change the brightness of the bulb’
‘the comet's brightness had dimmed’
‘his mother called to him from the brightness of the kitchen’
‘the brightness will linger through Wednesday’
‘the brightness of a winter's day’
‘he adds brightness to the dishes by tossing in fresh herbs’
‘he reminded me of my first son with his brightness and inquisitiveness’
‘there's so much light and brightness in their faces’
‘there had been some brightness in her life’
‘tone alters the brightness of the sound’
--Word--
brightness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The quality or state of giving out or reflecting light.
The quality or state of being well lit.
Sunny, cloudless weather.
The quality of being vividly and boldly coloured.
The quality of being intelligent and quick-witted.
The quality of being cheerful or lively.
Success and happiness.
The quality in sound of being clear, vibrant, and typically high-pitched.
--Examples--
‘we can change the brightness of the bulb’
‘the comet's brightness had dimmed’
‘his mother called to him from the brightness of the kitchen’
‘the brightness will linger through Wednesday’
‘the brightness of a winter's day’
‘he adds brightness to the dishes by tossing in fresh herbs’
‘he reminded me of my first son with his brightness and inquisitiveness’
‘there's so much light and brightness in their faces’
‘there had been some brightness in her life’
‘tone alters the brightness of the sound’
--Word--
Brighton 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A resort on the south coast of England, in East Sussex; population 127,700 (est. 2009). It was patronized by the Prince of Wales (later George IV) from c.1780 to 1827, and is noted for its Regency architecture. It became a city (with Hove) in 2000.
--Examples--
--Word--
bright 
--Type--
adjective, adverb, noun
--Meanings--
Giving out or reflecting much light; shining.
Full of light.
(of a period of time) having sunny, cloudless weather.
(of colour) vivid and bold.
Having a vivid colour.
Intelligent and quick-witted.
Cheerful and lively.
(of someone's future) likely to be successful and happy.
(of sound) clear, vibrant, and typically high-pitched.
Brightly.
Bold and vivid colours.
Headlights switched to full beam.
--Examples--
‘the sun was dazzlingly bright’
‘her bright, dark eyes’
‘the rooms are bright and spacious’
‘the long, bright days of June’
‘the bright green leaves’
‘a bright tie’
‘a bright idea’
‘a bright young journalist’
‘at breakfast she would be persistently bright and chirpy’
‘she gave a bright smile’
‘these young people have a bright future ahead of them’
‘her voice is fresh and bright’
‘a full moon shining bright’
‘a choice of colours from pastels through to brights’
‘he turned the brights on and we drove along the dirt road’

--Word--
Bridget, St. 
--Type--
proper noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
(6th century), Irish abbess; also known as St. Bridget of Ireland. She was venerated in Ireland as a virgin saint and noted in miracle stories for her compassion. Feast day, July 23.
(c.1303–73), Swedish nun and visionary; also known as St. Bridget of Sweden. She experienced her first vision of the Virgin Mary at the age of seven. Feast day, February 1.
--Examples--
--Word--
Bardot, Brigitte 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(born 1934), French actress. The film And God Created Woman (1956) established her reputation as an international sex symbol.
--Examples--

--Word--
brig 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
A two-masted square-rigged ship, typically having an additional lower fore-and-aft sail on the gaff and a boom to the mainmast.
A prison, especially on a warship.
A bridge.

--Word--
brilliant 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
(of light or colour) very bright.
Exceptionally clever or talented.
Outstanding; impressive.
Excellent; marvellous.
A diamond of brilliant cut.
--Examples--
‘brilliant sunshine illuminated the scene’
‘he was quite brilliant and was promoted almost at once’
‘the germ of a brilliant idea hit her’
‘his brilliant career at Harvard’
‘we had a brilliant time’
‘‘Brilliant!’ he declared excitedly’
‘an elegant necklace with four rows of brilliants’
--Word--
brilliant cut 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A circular cut for diamonds and other gemstones in the form of two many-faceted pyramids joined at their bases, the upper one truncated near its apex.
--Examples--
‘brilliant-cut diamond ear studs’

noun, verb
--Meanings--

Be full to the point of overflowing.
Fill something so completely that it almost overflows.
Be full of a particular quality, feeling, etc.

‘a soft hat with a turned-up brim’
‘he filled her glass to the brim’
‘a brimming cup’
‘large tears brimmed in her eyes’
‘he is brimming with ideas’

--Word--
brine 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
Water strongly impregnated with salt.
Seawater.
A solution of salt and water in which food is preserved.
A strong solution of a salt or salts.
Soak or preserve in salty water.
--Examples--
‘the olives have been stored in brine’
‘dolphins and whales can't help taking in the odd gulp of brine as they swallow a fish’
‘the classic dirty martini includes a few drops of olive brine’
‘these brines percolated downwards’
‘brined anchovies’

--Meanings--

--Word--
bring 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Take or go with (someone or something) to a place.
Cause (someone or something) to come to a place.
Involve (someone) in a particular activity.
Cause someone to receive (an amount of money) as income or profit.
Cause (someone or something) to move in a particular direction.
Cause (something)
Cause (someone or something) to be in a particular state or condition.
Initiate (legal action) against someone.
Force oneself to do something unpleasant.
--Examples--
‘she brought Luke home from hospital’
‘Liz brought her a glass of water’
‘what brings you here?’
‘a felony case brought before a jury’
‘his inner confidence has brought him through his ordeal’
‘he has brought in a consultancy company’
‘two important Chippendale lots brought £10,000 each’
‘five more novels brought him £150,000’
‘he brought his hands out of his pockets’
‘heavy rain brought down the ceiling’
‘the bad weather brought famine’
‘an economic policy that would have brought the country to bankruptcy’
‘I'll give you an aspirin to bring down your temperature’
‘riot and conspiracy charges should be brought against them’
‘she could not bring herself to mention it’

--Word--
brink 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The extreme edge of land before a steep slope or a body or water.
A point at which something, typically something unwelcome, is about to happen; the verge.
--Examples--
‘the brink of the cliffs’
‘at the brink of the pond I hesitated’
‘the country was on the brink of a constitutional crisis’
‘the club has come close to the brink, surviving winding-up orders’
--Word--
Brinkley, David 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1920–2003), US news commentator. He reported news for NBC 1951–81, co-anchoring The Huntley-Brinkley Report 1956–70 with Chet Huntley. He anchored ABC's This Week 1981–97.
--Examples--
--Word--
brinkmanship 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The art or practice of pursuing a dangerous policy to the limits of safety before stopping, especially in politics.
--Examples--
‘in any game of brinkmanship, it is possible that one side will collapse suddenly’

--Word--
Bryophyta 
--Type--
plural noun
--Meanings--
A division of small flowerless green plants which comprises the mosses and liverworts. They lack true roots and reproduce by spores released from a stalked capsule.
--Examples--
--Word--
bryophyte 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small flowerless green plant of the division Bryophyta, which comprises the mosses and liverworts.

Bryozoa 
--Type--
plural noun
--Meanings--
A phylum of sedentary aquatic invertebrates that comprises the moss animals.

--Word--
bryozoan 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A sedentary aquatic invertebrate of the phylum Bryozoa, which comprises the moss animals.
Relating to or denoting bryozoans.

Brisbane 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The capital of Queensland, Australia; population 1,945,639 (est. 2008). It was founded in 1824 as a penal colony.
--Examples--
--Word--
brisé 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A jump in which the dancer sweeps one leg into the air to the side while jumping off the other, brings both legs together in the air and beats them before landing.
(of a fan) consisting entirely of pierced sticks of ivory, horn, or tortoiseshell.
--Examples--

--Word--
brise-soleil 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A device, such as a perforated screen or louvres, for shutting out direct or excessive sunlight.
--Examples--
‘this north-facing brise-soleil provided minimal shade’
--Word--
brisk 
--Type--
adjective, verb
--Meanings--
Active and energetic.
Showing a wish to deal with things quickly; slightly brusque.
(of wind or the weather) cold but pleasantly invigorating.
Quicken something.
--Examples--
‘a good brisk walk’
‘business appeared to be brisk’
‘she adopted a brisk, businesslike tone’
‘the sea was shimmering and heaving beneath the brisk breeze’
‘Mary brisked up her pace’

brisken 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--

‘suppose we brisken up’
‘they briskened their steps back to the house’

--Word--
briskly 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In an active, quick, or energetic way.
In an impatient or brusque way.
In a cold but pleasantly invigorating way.
--Examples--
‘she walked briskly into the building’
‘tickets have been selling briskly’
‘he replied briskly that no one at his school had ever gone truant’
‘the wind blew fairly briskly’
‘we spent our day swimming in the briskly cold water’

noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--

--Word--
bristle 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A short, stiff hair on an animal's skin or a man's face.
A stiff animal hair, or a man-made substitute, used to make a brush.
(of hair or fur) stand upright away from the skin, typically as a sign of anger or fear.
(of an animal) react in such a way that its hair or fur stands on end.
(of a person) react angrily or defensively.
Be covered with or abundant in.
--Examples--
‘a toothbrush with nylon bristles’
‘the heads are made with natural bristle’
‘the hair on the back of his neck bristled’
‘the cat bristled in annoyance’
‘she bristled at his rudeness’
‘the roof bristled with antennae’
--Word--
bristlebird 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An Australian songbird with mainly brown plumage, a long cocked tail, a fringe of bristles around the bill, and secretive habits.
--Examples--
--Word--
bristlecone pine 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A very long-lived shrubby pine of western North America. It has been used in dendrochronology to check radiocarbon dating.
--Examples--

--Word--
rough bristle-grass 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A bristle-grass, Setaria verticillata, native to warm temperate Europe and Asia but introduced or naturalized elsewhere, and having reflexed teeth on its bristles.
--Examples--

--Word--
bristling 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(especially of hair) short, stiff, and spiky.
Aggressively brisk or tense.
--Examples--
‘a bristling beard’
‘he fills the screen with a restless, bristling energy’

--Word--
bristly 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of hair or foliage) having a stiff and prickly texture.
Covered with short, stiff hairs.
--Examples--
‘he washed his bristly black hair’
‘the dunes were dotted with bristly little bushes’
‘he rubbed his bristly chin’

--Word--
Bristol 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city in south-western England; population 374,000 (est. 2009). Situated on the River Avon about 10 km (6 miles) from the Bristol Channel, it has been a leading port since the 12th century.

--Examples--
--Word--
Britain 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The island containing England, Wales, and Scotland. The name is broadly synonymous with Great Britain, but the longer form is more usual for the political unit.
--Examples--
--Word--
Britannia 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The personification of Britain, usually depicted as a helmeted woman with shield and trident. The figure appeared on Roman coins and was revived with the name Britannia on the coinage of Charles II.
--Examples--
--Word--
Britannic 
--Type--

--Meanings--
(chiefly in names or titles) of Britain or the British Empire.
--Examples--
‘he answered His Britannic Majesty's call to arms’

Britannically

--Meanings--
In a manner or style characteristic of the British.
In reference to Great Britain.

Brython 
--Type--

--Meanings--
Briton.
--Examples--
--Word--
Brythonic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Denoting or relating to the southern group of Celtic languages, consisting of Welsh, Cornish, and Breton. They were spoken in Britain before and during the Roman occupation, surviving as Welsh and Cornish after the Anglo-Saxon invasions, and being taken to Brittany by emigrants.
The Brythonic languages collectively.
--Examples--
--Word--
Briticism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An idiom used in Britain but not in other English-speaking countries.
--Examples--
‘‘toy boy’ is a Briticism for a ‘gigolo’’
--Word--

--Word--
Icelandic 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to Iceland or its language.
The language of Iceland. A Scandinavian language, it has remained closely similar to Old Norse, due partly to the geographical isolation of Iceland and partly to a policy of avoiding loanwords.
--Examples--

Edgar Britt 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An act of defecating.
Diarrhoea.
--Examples--
‘he raced out to the john for an Edgar Britt’
‘it gives you a violent headache and a good dose of the Edgar Britts’
--Word--
Brittany 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A region and former duchy of north-western France, forming a peninsula between the Bay of Biscay and the English Channel. It was occupied in the 5th and 6th centuries by Britons fleeing the Saxons, and was incorporated into France in 1532.
--Examples--
--Word--
Britten, Benjamin 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
Lord Britten of Aldeburgh (1913–76), English composer, pianist, and conductor; full name Edward Benjamin Britten. He founded the Aldeburgh festival with Peter Pears in 1948, and in 1976 became the first composer to be made a life peer. Notable operas: Peter Grimes (1945), A Midsummer Night's Dream (1960), and Death in Venice (1973).
--Examples--
--Word--
brittle 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Hard but liable to break easily.
(of a person's voice) unpleasantly hard and sharp and showing signs of instability or nervousness.
Appearing decisive or cheerful but unstable or nervous within.
A brittle sweet made from nuts and set melted sugar.
--Examples--
‘her bones became fragile and brittle’
‘a brittle laugh’
‘her manner was artificially bright and brittle’
‘peanut brittle’
--Word--
brittlebush 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of several plants of the genus Encelia (family Asteraceae (Compositae)), comprising low-growing, drought tolerant shrubs of arid areas of southern America and Mexico; now especially E. farinosa, which has silvery foliage and bright yellow flowers.
--Examples--

--Examples--
‘he raced out to the john for an Edgar Britt’
‘it gives you a violent headache and a good dose of the Edgar Britts’

--Word--
bro 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Brother (used before a first name when referring in writing to a member of a religious order of men)
A male friend (often used as a form of address)
A young man, especially one who socializes primarily with his male peers and enjoys lively, unintellectual pursuits.
--Examples--
‘his baby bro’
‘Bro. Felix’
‘they'd never choose a girl over their bros’
‘not cool, bro’
‘shirtless bros with plaid shorts throwing frisbees’
--Word--
broach 
--Type--
verb, verb, noun
--Meanings--
Raise (a difficult subject) for discussion.
Pierce (a cask) to draw out liquid.
Open and start using the contents of (a bottle or other container)
(of a fish or sea mammal) rise through the water and break the surface.
(of a ship) veer and pitch forward, presenting a side to the wind and waves and losing steerage control.
A sudden and unwelcome veering of a ship that causes it to broach.
--Examples--
‘he broached the subject he had been avoiding all evening’
‘he watched a pot boy broach a new cask’
‘boxed wines will remain in good condition for up to four months once broached’
‘the salmon broach, then fall to slap the water’
‘we had broached badly, side on to the wind and sea’
‘the helmsman was forced to use the engines in conjunction with the wheel to prevent a broach’

--Word--
broad 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Having a distance larger than usual from side to side; wide.
(after a measurement) giving the distance from side to side.
Large in area.
Covering a large number and wide scope of subjects.
Having a wide range of meanings or applications; loosely defined.
Including many people of many kinds.
General; without detail.
(of a hint) clear and unambiguous; not subtle.
(of a phonetic transcription) showing only meaningful distinctions in sound and ignoring minor details.
Somewhat coarse and indecent.
(of a regional accent) very noticeable and strong.
A woman.
--Examples--
‘a broad staircase’
‘the valley is three miles long and half a mile broad’
‘a broad expanse of paddy fields’
‘the company has a broad range of experience’
‘our range of programmes comprises three broad categories’
‘the polls registered broad support for Labour’
‘a broad outline of the legal framework for pension schemes’
‘a broad hint’
‘the broad humour has been toned down’
‘the words had a distinct tang of broad Lancashire’
‘I get drunk, follow the pretty broads, and make a fool of myself’

--Meanings--

--Examples--

broadbill 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
broadcast 
--Type--
verb, noun, adjective, adverb
--Meanings--
Transmit (a programme or some information) by radio or television.
Take part in a radio or television transmission.
Tell (something) to many people.
Scatter (seeds) by hand or machine rather than placing in drills or rows.
A radio or television programme or transmission.
Relating to radio or television programmes.
By scattering.
--Examples--
‘the announcement was broadcast live’
‘they regularly broadcast on Radio 2’
‘we don't want to broadcast our unhappiness to the world’
‘the second method is to broadcast the seeds together with not more than 1 kg to the acre of rapeseed’
‘the Queen's annual Christmas TV broadcast’
‘a broadcast journalist’
‘green manures can be sown broadcast or in rows’

noun

‘the veteran broadcaster put everyone at their ease’
‘he became a successful broadcaster, both on television and the wireless’

‘he has to broaden Labour's appeal to the whole community’

‘the polls registered broad support for Labour’
‘a broad outline of the legal framework for pension schemes’
‘a broad hint’
‘the broad humour has been toned down’
‘the words had a distinct tang of broad Lancashire’
‘I get drunk, follow the pretty broads, and make a fool of myself’
--Word--
broad 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Having a distance larger than usual from side to side; wide.
(after a measurement) giving the distance from side to side.
Large in area.
Covering a large number and wide scope of subjects.
Having a wide range of meanings or applications; loosely defined.
Including many people of many kinds.
General; without detail.
(of a hint) clear and unambiguous; not subtle.
(of a phonetic transcription) showing only meaningful distinctions in sound and ignoring minor details.
Somewhat coarse and indecent.
(of a regional accent) very noticeable and strong.
A woman.
--Examples--
‘a broad staircase’
‘the valley is three miles long and half a mile broad’
‘a broad expanse of paddy fields’
‘the company has a broad range of experience’
‘our range of programmes comprises three broad categories’
‘the polls registered broad support for Labour’
‘a broad outline of the legal framework for pension schemes’
‘a broad hint’
‘the broad humour has been toned down’
‘the words had a distinct tang of broad Lancashire’
‘I get drunk, follow the pretty broads, and make a fool of myself’

--Word--
gage 
--Type--
noun, verb
UnKnownKind, noun
--Meanings--
A valued object deposited as a guarantee of good faith.
A pledge, especially a glove, thrown down as a symbol of a challenge to fight.
Offer (an object or one's life) as a guarantee of good faith.
--Examples--
‘a guide sent to them by the headman of this place gaged his life as a forfeit if he failed’

--Word--
Broadmoor 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A special hospital near Reading in southern England for the secure holding of patients regarded as both mentally ill and potentially dangerous. It was established in 1863.

--Word--
Broads 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A network of shallow freshwater lakes, traversed by slow-moving rivers, in Norfolk and Suffolk. They were formed by the gradual natural flooding of medieval peat diggings.
--Examples--

noun

--Word--
broadside 
--Type--
noun, adverb, verb
--Meanings--
A fierce verbal attack.
A firing of all the guns from one side of a warship.
The set of guns which can fire on each side of a warship.
The side of a ship above the water between the bow and quarter.
A sheet of paper printed on one side only, forming one large page.
With the side turned in a particular direction.
On the side.
Collide with the side of (a vehicle)
--Examples--
‘he launched a broadside against the economic reforms’
‘a broadside of Lee's farewell address’
‘the yacht was drifting broadside to the wind’
‘her car was hit broadside by another vehicle’
‘I had to skid my bike sideways to avoid broadsiding her’

tired 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

‘a few boxes of tired vegetables’
‘I have to look after these animals when you get tired of them’
‘tired clichés like the ‘information revolution’’

--Word--
Watson, John Broadus 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1878–1958), American psychologist, founder of the school of behaviourism. He held that the role of the psychologist was to discern, through observation and experimentation, the innate behaviour and acquired behaviour in an individual.
--Examples--
--Word--
broadway 
--Type--
noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
A large open or main road.
A street traversing the length of Manhattan, New York. It is famous for its theatres, and its name has become synonymous with show business.
--Examples--
‘Fulham Broadway’
--Word--
wayed 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of a place (especially a city): that has ways or streets. Chiefly as the second element of a compound, as "many-wayed", "wide-wayed", etc.
--Examples--

--Meanings--
(of a vehicle or other object) having wheels to enable it to move over the ground.
--Examples--
‘orders are stacked on to wheeled carts’
‘an 18-wheeled truck’
--Word--
broad 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Having a distance larger than usual from side to side; wide.
(after a measurement) giving the distance from side to side.
Large in area.
Covering a large number and wide scope of subjects.
Having a wide range of meanings or applications; loosely defined.
Including many people of many kinds.
General; without detail.
(of a hint) clear and unambiguous; not subtle.
(of a phonetic transcription) showing only meaningful distinctions in sound and ignoring minor details.
Somewhat coarse and indecent.
(of a regional accent) very noticeable and strong.
A woman.
--Examples--
‘a broad staircase’
‘the valley is three miles long and half a mile broad’
‘a broad expanse of paddy fields’
‘the company has a broad range of experience’
‘our range of programmes comprises three broad categories’
‘the polls registered broad support for Labour’
‘a broad outline of the legal framework for pension schemes’
‘a broad hint’
‘the broad humour has been toned down’
‘the words had a distinct tang of broad Lancashire’
‘I get drunk, follow the pretty broads, and make a fool of myself’
--Word--
Brobdingnagian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Huge; gigantic.
A giant.
--Examples--
‘a beam engine of Brobdingnagian proportions’
--Word--
Broca's area 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A region of the brain concerned with the production of speech, located in the cortex of the dominant frontal lobe. Damage in this area causes Broca's aphasia, characterized by hesitant and fragmented speech with little grammatical structure.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Meanings--

--Examples--
‘the quilt was of white silk brocade’
‘a heavy brocade curtain’

--Word--
Brocken 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The highest of the Harz Mountains in north central Germany, rising to 1,143 m (3,747 ft). It is noted for the phenomenon of the Brocken spectre and for witches' revels which reputedly took place there on Walpurgis night.
--Examples--

--Word--
Brodsky, Joseph 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1940–96), Russian-born American poet; born Iosif Aleksandrovich Brodsky. He wrote both in Russian and in English, and was most famous for his collection The End of a Beautiful Era (1977). Nobel Prize for Literature (1987).
--Examples--
--Word--
Broederbond 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A largely secret society in South Africa (founded in 1918) promoting the interests of and restricted in membership to male, Protestant Afrikaners.

--Word--
de Broglie, Louis-Victor 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
Prince (1892–1987), French physicist. He was the first to suggest that subatomic particles can also have the properties of waves, and his name is now applied to such a wave. He further developed the study of wave mechanics, which was fundamental to the subsequent development of quantum mechanics. Nobel Prize for Physics (1929).
--Examples--
--Word--
brogue 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
A strong outdoor shoe with ornamental perforated patterns in the leather.
A rough shoe of untanned leather, formerly worn in parts of Ireland and the Scottish Highlands.
A marked accent, especially Irish or Scottish, when speaking English.
--Examples--
‘a fine Irish brogue’
‘a sweet lilt of brogue in her voice’

--Word--
broken 
--Type--
verb, adjective
--Meanings--
Having been broken.
(of a marriage or other long-term relationship) having ended.
(of a person) having given up all hope; despairing.
Having breaks or gaps in continuity.
(of a language) spoken falteringly and with many mistakes, as by a foreigner.
Having an uneven and rough surface.
--Examples--
‘he had a broken arm’
‘he went to his grave a broken man’
‘a broken white line across the road’
‘a young man talking in broken Italian’
‘he pressed onwards over the broken ground’

--Word--
broken record 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Used, especially in similes, to refer to a person's constant and annoying repetition of a particular statement or opinion.
--Examples--
‘at the risk of sounding like a broken record, let me repeat: it will be difficult to do well in the exam without attending classes regularly’
‘I know I'm a broken record on this, but once again, they are lying about the deficit’

--Word--
bromeliad 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A plant of tropical and subtropical America, typically having short stems with rosettes of stiff, spiny leaves. Some kinds are epiphytic and many are cultivated as pot plants.
--Examples--
--Word--
brome 
--Type--
noun

--Examples--
--Word--
bromic acid 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A strongly oxidizing acid known only in aqueous solutions.
--Examples--
--Word--
bromide 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A compound of bromine with another element or group, especially a salt containing the anion Br- or an organic compound with bromine bonded to an alkyl radical.
A trite statement that is intended to soothe or placate.
A sedative preparation containing potassium bromide.
A reproduction or piece of typesetting on bromide paper.
--Examples--
‘feel-good bromides create the illusion of problem-solving’
--Word--
bromide 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A compound of bromine with another element or group, especially a salt containing the anion Br- or an organic compound with bromine bonded to an alkyl radical.
A trite statement that is intended to soothe or placate.
A sedative preparation containing potassium bromide.
A reproduction or piece of typesetting on bromide paper.
--Examples--
‘feel-good bromides create the illusion of problem-solving’
--Word--
bromidic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Attempting to soothe or placate in a trite or clichéd way.
--Examples--
‘he was happy to regurgitate the same worn, bromidic phrases’

brominate

verb
--Meanings--

Introduce one or more bromine atoms into a compound or molecule, usually in place of hydrogen.
--Examples--

--Word--
bromine 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The chemical element of atomic number 35, a dark red fuming toxic liquid with a choking, irritating smell. It is a member of the halogen group and occurs chiefly in the form of salts in seawater and brines.
--Examples--
--Word--

bronchitis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
Alcott, Bronson 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1799–1888), US educator; father of Louisa May Alcott; full name Amos Bronson Alcott. He advocated radical reforms in education, including racial integration in the classroom. Appointed superintendent of schools in Concord, Massachusetts, in 1859, he created the first parent–teacher association.
--Examples--
--Word--
Brontë 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The name of three English novelists.
Charlotte (1816–55), author of Jane Eyre (1847), Shirley (1849), and Villette (1853).
Emily (1818–48), author of Wuthering Heights (1847); also a poet.
Anne (1820–49), author of Agnes Grey (1845) and The Tenant of Wildfell Hall (1847).
--Examples--
--Word--
Brontë 
--Type--

--Meanings--
The name of three English novelists.

Anne (1820–49), author of Agnes Grey (1845) and The Tenant of Wildfell Hall (1847).

--Word--
bronze 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A yellowish-brown alloy of copper with up to one-third tin.
A sculpture or other object made of bronze.
A yellowish-brown colour.
Make (a person or part of the body) suntanned.
Give (something) a surface of bronze or something resembling bronze.
--Examples--
‘the Minoans made large numbers of statuettes in ivory and bronze’
‘a bronze statue’
‘on the black bookcase were three exquisite bronzes’
‘rich, gleaming shades of bronze’
‘Alison was bronzed by outdoor life’
‘the doors were bronzed with sculpted reliefs’

Bronzino, Agnolo 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1503–72), Italian mannerist painter; born Agnolo di Cosimo. He spent most of his career in Florence as court painter to Cosimo de' Medici. Notable works: Venus, Cupid, Folly, and Time (c.1546).

--Word--
brood 
--Type--
noun, verb, adjective
--Meanings--
A family of birds or other young animals produced at one hatching or birth.
A large family of children.
Bee or wasp larvae.
Think deeply about something that makes one unhappy, angry, or worried.
(of a bird) sit on (eggs) to hatch them.
(of a fish, frog, or invertebrate) hold (developing eggs) within the body.
(of an animal) kept to be used for breeding.
--Examples--
‘a brood of chicks’
‘she was brought up as part of a brood of eight’
‘she had brooded over the subject a thousand times’
‘the male pheasant-tailed jacana takes over once the eggs are laid and broods them’
‘a brood mare’

--Type--
adjective

--Word--
Brooke, Rupert 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1887–1915), English poet; full name Rupert Chawner Brooke. He is most famous for his wartime poetry 1914 and Other Poems (1915). He died while on naval service in the Mediterranean.
--Examples--

brook 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A small stream.
Tolerate or allow (something, typically dissent or opposition)
--Examples--
‘the Lake District boasts lovely lakes and babbling brooks’
‘Jenny would brook no criticism of Matthew’
--Word--
Brookfield 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city in southeastern Wisconsin, west of Milwaukee; population 39,020 (est. 2008).
--Examples--
--Word--
Brookhaven 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A town in eastern Long Island in New York that includes the villages of Brookhaven and Stony Brook, home to a noted nuclear laboratory; population 488,800 (est. 2008).
--Examples--

Brooklands 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A motor-racing circuit near Weybridge in Surrey, England, opened in 1907. During the Second World War the course was converted for aircraft manufacture.

--Word--
brooklime 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A Eurasian speedwell with smooth fleshy leaves and deep blue flowers on long stalks. It grows in wet areas, where the stems take root or float in the water.
--Examples--
--Word--
Brooklyn 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A borough of New York City, at the south-western corner of Long Island. The Brooklyn Bridge (built 1869–83) links Long Island with lower Manhattan.
--Examples--
--Word--
Brookline 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A town in eastern Massachusetts, on the west side of Boston and almost surrounded by the city; population 54,896 (est. 2008).
--Examples--

noun
--Meanings--

noun

Brookner, Anita 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1928–2016), English novelist and art historian. She won the Booker Prize for Hotel du Lac (1984).

broom 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A long-handled brush of bristles or twigs, used for sweeping.
An implement for sweeping the ice in the game of curling.
A flowering shrub with long, thin green stems and small or few leaves, cultivated for its profusion of flowers.
--Examples--

broomball 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A game similar to ice hockey in which players run rather than skate and use rubber brooms or broom handles to push a ball into the goal.

--Meanings--

broomrape 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A parasitic plant which bears tubular flowers on a leafless brown stem. It is attached by its tubers to the roots of the host plant.

--Word--
broth 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Soup consisting of meat or vegetables cooked in stock, sometimes thickened with barley or other cereals.
Meat or fish stock.
A liquid medium containing proteins and other nutrients for the culture of bacteria.
A liquid mixture for the preservation of tissue.
--Examples--
‘mutton broth’
‘the pig made five pots of broth’
‘she made a broth from the bones’
‘in vitro cultures were established in MG3 broth’
‘broth cultures of intestinal tissue’

--Word--
brother 
--Type--
noun, exclamation
--Meanings--
A man or boy in relation to other sons and daughters of his parents.
A male associate or fellow member of an organization.
A black man (often used as a term of address by other black people)
A thing which resembles or is connected to another thing.
A (male) fellow Christian.
A member of a religious order of men.
A member of a fundamentalist Protestant denomination.
Used to express annoyance or surprise.
--Examples--
‘he recognized her from her strong resemblance to her brother’
‘the time is coming, brothers, for us to act’
‘there I was with one white boy and this other brother’
‘the machine is almost identical to its larger brother’
‘a Benedictine brother’
‘the Plymouth Brethren’
‘oh brother!’
--Word--
brothered 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of two or more people or things: united by brotherhood; having a relationship likened to that of brothers. Now rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
brother-german 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A brother sharing both parents, as opposed to a half-brother or stepbrother.
--Examples--
--Word--
brotherhood 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The relationship between brothers.
The feeling of kinship with and closeness to a group of people or all people.
An association or community of people linked by a common interest, religion, or trade.
A trade union.
--Examples--
‘the bonds of brotherhood’
‘a gesture of solidarity and brotherhood’
‘a religious brotherhood’
‘the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners of America’

--Word--
brown 
--Type--
adjective, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Of a colour produced by mixing red, yellow, and blue, as of dark wood or rich soil.
(of bread) light brown in colour and typically made with unbleached or unrefined wholemeal flour.
Dark-skinned or suntanned.
Relating or belonging to a human group characterized as having relatively dark-coloured skin (chiefly used of peoples of ancestry other than European or African)
Brown colour or pigment.
Brown clothes or material.
A brown thing, in particular the brown ball in snooker.
A satyrid butterfly, which typically has brown wings with small eyespots.
Make or become brown, typically by cooking.
--Examples--
‘an old brown coat’
‘she had warm brown eyes’
‘a slice of brown toast with low fat spread’
‘his face was brown from the sun’
‘I interviewed 60 mostly black and brown leaders around our nation’
‘the brown of his eyes’
‘a pair of boots in brown’
‘the print is rich with velvety browns’
‘a woman all in brown’
‘a skillet in which food has been browned’
‘grill the pizza until the cheese has browned’
--Word--
armed 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Equipped with or carrying a firearm or firearms.
Involving the use of firearms.
Having claws, a beak, etc. of a specified tincture.
--Examples--
‘heavily armed troops’
‘armed robbery’
‘a lion rampant argent, armed and langued azure’

Make or become brown, typically by cooking.

--Word--
faced 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having a face or expression of a specified kind.
Having a surface or front of a specified kind.
(of a solid) having a specified number of surfaces.
(of a piece of stone or other material) having a smoothed or polished surface.
(of a playing card) turned face up.
--Examples--
‘a pimply-faced teenager’
‘a burly, square-faced doorman’
‘sad-faced children’
‘a heavy, square-faced hammer’
‘a stone-faced building’
‘a twelve-faced solid’
‘walls and pillars had faced stone on the outer surfaces’
‘he gets the faced card as his first card’
--Word--
brownfield 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Denoting or relating to urban sites for potential building development that have had previous development on them.
--Examples--
‘a contaminated brownfield site in the inner city’
--Word--
brown 
--Type--

--Meanings--
Of a colour produced by mixing red, yellow, and blue, as of dark wood or rich soil.
(of bread) light brown in colour and typically made with unbleached or unrefined wholemeal flour.
Dark-skinned or suntanned.
Relating or belonging to a human group characterized as having relatively dark-coloured skin (chiefly used of peoples of ancestry other than European or African)
Brown colour or pigment.
Brown clothes or material.
A brown thing, in particular the brown ball in snooker.
A satyrid butterfly, which typically has brown wings with small eyespots.
Make or become brown, typically by cooking.
--Examples--
‘an old brown coat’
‘she had warm brown eyes’
‘a slice of brown toast with low fat spread’
‘his face was brown from the sun’
‘I interviewed 60 mostly black and brown leaders around our nation’
‘the brown of his eyes’
‘a pair of boots in brown’
‘the print is rich with velvety browns’
‘a woman all in brown’
‘a skillet in which food has been browned’
‘grill the pizza until the cheese has browned’
--Word--
brown-haired 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having brown-coloured hair.
--Examples--
‘a rangy, brown-haired man’
--Word--
brown 
--Type--
adjective, noun, verb
--Meanings--
Of a colour produced by mixing red, yellow, and blue, as of dark wood or rich soil.
(of bread) light brown in colour and typically made with unbleached or unrefined wholemeal flour.
Dark-skinned or suntanned.
Relating or belonging to a human group characterized as having relatively dark-coloured skin (chiefly used of peoples of ancestry other than European or African)
Brown colour or pigment.
Brown clothes or material.
A brown thing, in particular the brown ball in snooker.
A satyrid butterfly, which typically has brown wings with small eyespots.
Make or become brown, typically by cooking.
--Examples--
‘an old brown coat’
‘she had warm brown eyes’

Brownian motion 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The erratic random movement of microscopic particles in a fluid, as a result of continuous bombardment from molecules of the surrounding medium.
--Examples--

brownie 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small square of rich chocolate cake, typically containing nuts.
A piece of sweet currant bread.
A member of the junior branch of the Guide Association, for girls aged between about 7 and 10, wearing a brown uniform.
A benevolent elf that supposedly haunts houses and does housework secretly.
--Examples--
‘for my birthday I want to join the Brownies’

purple 
--Type--
noun, adjective, verb
--Meanings--
A colour intermediate between red and blue.
Purple clothing or material.
A crimson dye obtained from some molluscs, formerly used for fabric worn by an emperor or senior magistrate in ancient Rome or Byzantium.
(in ancient Rome or Byzantium) clothing made from fabric dyed with Tyrian purple.
(in ancient Rome) a position of rank, authority, or privilege.
The scarlet official dress of a cardinal.
Of a colour intermediate between red and blue.
Make or become purple in colour.
--Examples--
‘the painting was mostly in shades of blue and purple’
‘he was too young to assume the purple’
‘a faded purple T-shirt’
‘Edmund's cheeks purpled’
‘the neon was purpling the horizon above the highway’

--Word--
Brownshirt 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of a Nazi militia founded by Hitler in Munich in 1921, with brown uniforms resembling those of Mussolini's Blackshirts. They aided Hitler's rise to power, but were eclipsed by the SS after the ‘night of the long knives’ in June 1934.
--Examples--

--Word--
Brownsville 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city in southern Texas, on the Rio Grande and the Mexican border; population 175,494 (est. 2008).
A section of eastern Brooklyn in New York City, noted in the early 20th century for its Jewish community, today a struggling inner-city neighborhood.
--Examples--
--Word--
brown-tail 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A white European tussock moth with a tuft of brown hairs on the tip of the abdomen. The caterpillars have severely irritant hairs that can produce an allergic reaction, overwinter in a communal web, and can be a pest of tree foliage.
--Examples--

browse 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Survey goods for sale in a leisurely and casual way.
Scan through a text, website, or collection of data to gain an impression of the contents.
(of an animal) feed on leaves, twigs, or other high-growing vegetation.
An act of casual looking or reading.
A book, magazine, or website to be casually looked through.
Vegetation, such as twigs and young shoots, eaten by animals.
--Examples--
‘he stopped to browse around a second-hand bookshop’
‘she browsed through the newspaper’
‘I decided to spend the night browsing the Internet’
‘they reach upward to browse on bushes’
‘a browse through the sports pages’
‘I was just having a quick browse around the antique stalls’
‘the brochure is well worth a browse’
‘this book is a useful browse for a new worker in the field’
‘a moose needs to eat forty to fifty pounds of browse a day’

--Word--
Brubeck, Dave 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1920–2012), American jazz pianist, composer, and bandleader; full name David Warren Brubeck. He formed the Dave Brubeck Quartet in 1951 and won international recognition with the album Time Out, which included ‘Take Five’ (1959).
--Examples--

brubru 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small tropical African shrike (bird) with striking black-and-white plumage and chestnut flanks.

Springsteen, Bruce 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(born 1949), US rock singer, songwriter, and guitarist; noted for his songs about working-class life in the US; full name Bruce Frederick Joseph Springsteen. Notable albums: Born to Run (1975) and Born in the U.S.A. (1984).
--Examples--
--Word--
Brucella 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of small, Gram-negative, non-motile coccoid or rod-shaped bacteria which are parasites and pathogens of various species of mammal, especially cattle and pigs, and can be transmitted from livestock to humans in infected milk or meat or by contact with infected animals; (also brucella) a bacterium of this genus.
--Examples--
--Word--
Brucella 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of small, Gram-negative, non-motile coccoid or rod-shaped bacteria which are parasites and pathogens of various species of mammal, especially cattle and pigs, and can be transmitted from livestock to humans in infected milk or meat or by contact with infected animals; (also brucella) a bacterium of this genus.
--Examples--
--Word--
brucellosis 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A bacterial disease typically affecting cattle and causing undulant fever in humans.
--Examples--
--Word--
bruchid 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of the numerous small beetles constituting the subfamily Bruchinae (family Chrysomelidae), having larvae which develop within a single bean or seed. Also "bruchid beetle".
--Examples--
--Word--
Bruchus 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of beetles (family Chrysomelidae), the larvae of which develop and feed on leguminous plants and so are destructive to pulse crops; any beetle of this genus or of the subfamily Bruchinae to which it belongs; a seed beetle.
--Examples--
--Word--
brucine 
--Type--

--Meanings--
A highly toxic alkaloid present in nux vomica.

brucite 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A white, grey, or greenish mineral typically occurring in the form of tabular crystals. It consists of hydrated magnesium hydroxide.

Bruckner, Anton 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1824–96), Austrian composer and organist. He wrote ten symphonies, four masses, and a Te Deum (1884).
--Examples--
--Word--
Bruegel 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The name of a family of Flemish artists.
Pieter (c.1525–69); known as Pieter Bruegel the Elder. He produced landscapes, religious allegories, and satires of peasant life. Notable works: The Procession to Calvary (1564).
Pieter Bruegel the Younger (1564–1638), son of Pieter Bruegel the Elder; known as Hell Bruegel. A very able copyist of his father's work, he is also noted for his paintings of devils.
Jan (1568–1623), son of Pieter Bruegel the Elder; known as Velvet Bruegel. He was a celebrated painter of flowers, landscapes, and mythological scenes.
--Examples--
--Word--
Bruegel 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The name of a family of Flemish artists.
Pieter (c.1525–69); known as Pieter Bruegel the Elder. He produced landscapes, religious allegories, and satires of peasant life. Notable works: The Procession to Calvary (1564).
Pieter Bruegel the Younger (1564–1638), son of Pieter Bruegel the Elder; known as Hell Bruegel. A very able copyist of his father's work, he is also noted for his paintings of devils.
Jan (1568–1623), son of Pieter Bruegel the Elder; known as Velvet Bruegel. He was a celebrated painter of flowers, landscapes, and mythological scenes.
--Examples--
--Word--
Bruges 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city in north-western Belgium, capital of the province of West Flanders; population 117,071 (2008). A centre of the Flemish textile trade until the 15th century, it is a well-preserved medieval city surrounded by canals.
--Examples--
--Word--
Brugge 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
La Bruyère, Jean de 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1645–96), French writer and moralist. He is known for his Caractères (1688), based on a translation of the Characters of Theophrastus and exposing the vanity and corruption of human behaviour by satirizing Parisian society.
--Examples--
--Word--
La Bruyère, Jean de 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1645–96), French writer and moralist. He is known for his Caractères (1688), based on a translation of the Characters of Theophrastus and exposing the vanity and corruption of human behaviour by satirizing Parisian society.

--Word--
bruise 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An injury appearing as an area of discoloured skin on the body, caused by a blow or impact rupturing underlying blood vessels.
A mark indicating damage on a fruit, vegetable, or plant.
Inflict a bruise on (someone or something)
Be susceptible to bruising.
Hurt (someone's feelings)
Crush or pound (food)
--Examples--
‘his body was a mass of bruises after he had been attacked’
‘a bruised knee’
‘potatoes bruise easily, so treat them with care’
‘she tried to bolster her bruised pride’
‘the mix contains bruised oats’

bruiser 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person who is tough and aggressive and enjoys a fight or argument.
A professional boxer.
--Examples--
‘thick-necked bruisers in shell suits’
‘his reputation as a political bruiser’
‘a decent, gentle bruiser who almost knocked out one the greatest heavyweights of all time’

bruisewort 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: either of two plants, comfrey, Symphytum officinale, and the common daisy, Bellis perennis. In later use also: soapwort, Saponaria officinalis (now rare).
--Examples--

bruit 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Spread (a report or rumour) widely.
A report or rumour.
A sound, especially an abnormal one, heard through a stethoscope; a murmur.
--Examples--
‘I didn't want to have our relationship bruited about the office’
‘the wildest bruits were greedily credited’
‘is virtue to be established by common bruit only?’

brulé 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In Canada, especially the north-west: an area of forest which has been destroyed or cleared by fire, typically characterized by charred tree stumps.
Louisiana. An area of swampland in which the trees have been destroyed or cleared by fire, typically in order to be utilized as land for farming.

Brummellism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The style or manners exemplified by or characteristic of Beau Brummell, English dandy and arbiter of British fashion for the first decade and a half of the 19th cent.
--Examples--
--Word--
brummer fly 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A flesh fly of semi-desert regions in southern Africa, Wohlfahrtia pachytyli (family Sarcophagidae), which sometimes deposits its larvae as parasites on the brown locust (Locustana pardalina). More usually called locust fly.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Word--
Brunei 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A small oil-rich constitutional sultanate on the north-western coast of Borneo, divided by parts of Malaysia's state of Sarawak; population 423,000 (estimated 2015); capital, Bandar Seri Begawan; languages, Malay (official), English, Chinese. Official name Brunei Darussalam.
--Examples--
--Word--
Brunel, Sir Marc Isambard 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1769–1849), French-born English engineer, father of Isambard Kingdom Brunel. He introduced mass-production machinery to Portsmouth dockyard and designed other machines for woodworking, boot-making, knitting, and printing. He also worked to construct the first tunnel under the Thames (1825–43).
--Examples--
--Word--
Brunelleschi, Filippo 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1377–1446), Italian architect; born Filippo di Ser Brunellesco. He is especially noted for the dome of Florence cathedral (1420–61), which he raised without the use of temporary supports. He is often credited with the Renaissance ‘discovery’ of perspective.
--Examples--
--Word--
