--Word--
Brunfelsia 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A genus of tropical American shrubs and small trees (family Solanaceae), the members of which have evergreen leathery leaves and large, fragrant, tubular or bell-shaped flowers (typically purple or yellow fading to white); (also brunfelsia) any plant of this genus, especially one cultivated as an ornamental.
--Examples--
--Word--
Brunhild 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(in the Nibelungenlied) the wife of Gunther, who instigated the murder of Siegfried. In the Norse versions she is a Valkyrie whom Sigurd (the counterpart of Siegfried) wins by penetrating the wall of fire behind which she lies in an enchanted sleep.
--Examples--
--Word--
brunneous 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of a dark brown colour.
--Examples--
--Word--
Brunner 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In the genitive, attributive, and with of, especially in "Brunner's glands". Designating the numerous small mucus-secreting glands located in the submucosa of the upper part of the small intestine.
--Examples--
--Word--
San Bruno 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city in north central California, on San Francisco Bay, south of San Francisco; population 40,315 (est. 2008).
--Examples--
--Word--
Brunonian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Medicine. Designating a theory of medicine according to which diseases are believed to arise from deficiency or excess of nervous excitement, and hence to be curable with stimulant or sedative drugs and therapies. Now historical.
US. Of or relating to Brown University or its members.
Medicine. An advocate of the Brunonian theory of medicine. Now historical.
US. A student or graduate of Brown University.
--Examples--
--Word--
Brunswick 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A former duchy and state of Germany, mostly incorporated into Lower Saxony.
An industrial city in Lower Saxony, Germany; population 245,500 (est. 2006).

--Word--
brush 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An implement with a handle and a block of bristles, hair, or wire, used especially for cleaning, applying a liquid or powder to a surface, or arranging the hair.
An act of sweeping, applying, or arranging with a brush or with one's hand.
A light and fleeting touch.
A brief encounter with someone or something unpleasant or notable.
The bushy tail of a fox.
A drumstick with long wire bristles, used to make a soft hissing sound on drums or cymbals.
A piece of carbon or metal serving as an electrical contact with a moving part in a motor or alternator.
Girls or women regarded sexually.
Remove (dust or dirt) by sweeping or scrubbing.
Use a brush or one's hand to remove dust or dirt from (something)
Clean (one's teeth) with a brush.
Arrange (one's hair) by running a brush through it.
Apply a liquid to (a surface) with a brush.
Touch lightly and gently.
Push (something) away with a quick movement of the hand.
--Examples--
‘a shaving brush’
‘he gave the seat a brush’
‘the lightest brush of his lips against her cheek’
‘a brush with death’
‘my first brush with fame’
‘‘Beer first, brush later.’’
‘we'll be able to brush the mud off easily’
‘she brushed down her best coat’
‘she carefully made up her face and brushed her long auburn hair’
‘brush the potatoes with oil’
‘stems of grass brush against her legs’
‘their fingers brushed as she took the glass from him’
‘she brushed a wisp of hair away from her face’
--Word--
brushed 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of fabric) having a soft raised nap.
(of metal) finished with a non-reflective surface.
--Examples--
‘brushed cotton’
‘brushed aluminium’

brushback

--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
brush-off 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A rejection or dismissal of someone by treating them as unimportant.
--Examples--
‘he's given her the brush-off’
--Word--

--Type--

--Meanings--

--Examples--
‘he's given her the brush-off’
--Word--

--Word--
brush 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An implement with a handle and a block of bristles, hair, or wire, used especially for cleaning, applying a liquid or powder to a surface, or arranging the hair.
An act of sweeping, applying, or arranging with a brush or with one's hand.
A light and fleeting touch.
A brief encounter with someone or something unpleasant or notable.
The bushy tail of a fox.
A drumstick with long wire bristles, used to make a soft hissing sound on drums or cymbals.
A piece of carbon or metal serving as an electrical contact with a moving part in a motor or alternator.
Girls or women regarded sexually.
Remove (dust or dirt) by sweeping or scrubbing.
Use a brush or one's hand to remove dust or dirt from (something)
Clean (one's teeth) with a brush.
Arrange (one's hair) by running a brush through it.
Apply a liquid to (a surface) with a brush.
Touch lightly and gently.
Push (something) away with a quick movement of the hand.
--Examples--
‘a shaving brush’
‘he gave the seat a brush’
‘the lightest brush of his lips against her cheek’
‘a brush with death’
‘my first brush with fame’
‘‘Beer first, brush later.’’
‘we'll be able to brush the mud off easily’
‘she brushed down her best coat’
‘she carefully made up her face and brushed her long auburn hair’
‘brush the potatoes with oil’
‘stems of grass brush against her legs’
‘their fingers brushed as she took the glass from him’
‘she brushed a wisp of hair away from her face’
--Word--
brushtail 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A nocturnal and mainly tree-dwelling Australasian marsupial, which has a pointed muzzle and a furred tail with a naked tip.
--Examples--
--Word--
brush 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An implement with a handle and a block of bristles, hair, or wire, used especially for cleaning, applying a liquid or powder to a surface, or arranging the hair.
An act of sweeping, applying, or arranging with a brush or with one's hand.
A light and fleeting touch.
A brief encounter with someone or something unpleasant or notable.
The bushy tail of a fox.
A drumstick with long wire bristles, used to make a soft hissing sound on drums or cymbals.
A piece of carbon or metal serving as an electrical contact with a moving part in a motor or alternator.
Girls or women regarded sexually.
Remove (dust or dirt) by sweeping or scrubbing.
Use a brush or one's hand to remove dust or dirt from (something)
Clean (one's teeth) with a brush.
Arrange (one's hair) by running a brush through it.
Apply a liquid to (a surface) with a brush.
Touch lightly and gently.
Push (something) away with a quick movement of the hand.
--Examples--
‘a shaving brush’
‘he gave the seat a brush’
‘the lightest brush of his lips against her cheek’
‘a brush with death’
‘my first brush with fame’
‘‘Beer first, brush later.’’
‘we'll be able to brush the mud off easily’
‘she brushed down her best coat’
‘she carefully made up her face and brushed her long auburn hair’
‘brush the potatoes with oil’
‘stems of grass brush against her legs’
‘their fingers brushed as she took the glass from him’
‘she brushed a wisp of hair away from her face’
--Word--
tongued 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having a specified kind of tongue.
(in carpentry) constructed using a tongue.
(of a note) played by tonguing.
--Examples--
‘the blue-tongued lizard’
‘the tongued boards of the ceiling’
‘a series of rapidly tongued notes’
--Word--
treat 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Behave towards or deal with in a certain way.
Regard something as being of a specified nature with implications for one's actions concerning it.
Present or discuss (a subject)
Give medical care or attention to; try to heal or cure.
Apply a process or a substance to (something) to protect or preserve it or to give it particular properties.
Provide someone with (food, drink, or entertainment) at one's own expense.
Give someone (something) as a favour.
Do or have something that gives one great pleasure.
Negotiate terms with someone, especially an opponent.
An event or item that is out of the ordinary and gives great pleasure.
An act of treating someone to something.
A sweet, biscuit, or other item of sweet food.
--Examples--
‘she had been brutally treated’
‘he treated her with grave courtesy’
‘the names are being treated as classified information’
‘the issue is more fully treated in chapter five’
‘the two were treated for cuts and bruises’
‘the lawns were treated with weedkiller every year’
‘he treated her to a slap-up lunch’
‘he treated her to one of his smiles’
‘treat yourself—you can diet tomorrow’
‘propagandists claimed that he was treating with the enemy’
‘he wanted to take her to the pictures as a treat’
‘‘My treat,’ he insisted, reaching for the bill’

noun
--Meanings--
An act of cleaning or smartening oneself or something up.

--Examples--
‘he must want a wash and brush-up after the long journey’
‘a two-day brush-up course’

Brussels 
--Type--
proper noun, plural noun
--Meanings--
The capital of Belgium and of the Belgian province of Brabant; population 1,048,491 (2008). The headquarters of the European Commission is located there. Flemish name Brussel /ˈbrys(ə)l/. French name Bruxelles /bʀysɛl/.
Brussels sprouts.

--Word--
brutal 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Savagely violent.
Unpleasant or harsh.
Direct and without attempting to disguise unpleasantness.
--Examples--
‘a brutal murder’
‘the brutal morning light’
‘the brutal honesty of his observations’
--Word--
brutalization 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
brutalize 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Make (someone) cruel, violent, or insensitive to the pain of others by repeated exposure to violence.
Treat (someone) in a savage and violent way.
--Examples--
‘he had been brutalized in prison and become cynical’
‘they brutalize and torture persons in their custody’
--Word--

--Type--
verb
--Meanings--

--Word--
brutalizing 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Inducing cruelty, violence, or insensitivity to the pain of others by repeated exposure to violence.
--Examples--
‘the brutalizing effects of warfare’
--Word--
brutalism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Cruelty and savageness.
A stark style of functionalist architecture, especially of the 1950s and 1960s, characterized by the use of steel and concrete in massive blocks.
--Examples--
‘exchanging one kind of social and economic brutalism for another is not what they had in mind’
‘the long, low, concrete-faced buildings were remarkable solely for their brutalism’

--Word--
brutally 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In a savagely violent way.
In a direct way that does not attempt to disguise unpleasantness.
To an extremely unpleasant or harsh degree.
--Examples--
‘he was imprisoned and brutally tortured’
‘he brutally murdered an innocent man’
‘she was unapologetic and brutally honest’
‘a brutally candid interview’
‘weeks of brutally cold weather’
‘a brutally competitive market’
--Word--
brutally 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--

--Word--
brute 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A savagely violent person or animal.
A cruel or insensitive person.
Something awkward, difficult, or unpleasant.
An animal as opposed to a human being.
Characterized by an absence of reasoning or intelligence.
Merely physical.
Fundamental, inescapable, and unpleasant.
--Examples--
‘he was a cold-blooded brute’
‘what an unfeeling little brute you are’
‘a great brute of a machine’
‘we, unlike dumb brutes, can reflect upon our impulses’
‘a brute struggle for social superiority’
‘we achieve little by brute force’
‘the brute necessities of basic subsistence’

--Word--
Brutus 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A legendary Trojan hero, great-grandson of Aeneas and supposed ancestor of the British people. In medieval legend he was said to have brought a group of Trojans to England and founded Troynovant or New Troy (London).
--Examples--

--Word--
b 
--Type--
abbreviation, noun, abbreviation
UnKnownKind
--Meanings--
Barn(s).
Born (used to indicate a date of birth)
(on scorecards) bowled by.
(on scorecards) bye(s)
The second letter of the alphabet.
Denoting the second in a set of items, categories, sizes, etc.
The second highest class of academic mark.
(in the UK) denoting a secondary road.
Denoting the second-highest-earning socio-economic category for marketing purposes, including intermediate management and professional personnel.
Denoting the second file from the left, as viewed from White's side of the board.
The second fixed constant to appear in an algebraic equation.
Denoting a soil horizon of intermediate depth, typically the subsoil.
The human blood type (in the ABO system) containing the B antigen and lacking the A.
(with numeral) denoting a series of international standard paper sizes each twice the area of the next, as B0, B1, B2, B3, B4, etc., B4 being 250 × 353 mm.
The seventh note of the diatonic scale of C major.
A key based on a scale with B as its keynote.
Belgium (international vehicle registration).
Bishop (used in recording moves in chess)
Black (used in describing grades of pencil lead)
Bomber (in designations of US aircraft types)
The chemical element boron.
Magnetic flux density.
--Examples--
‘George Lloyd (b.1913)’
‘AC Hudson b Prasad 146’
‘extras (b 6, lb 24, nb 9) 39’
‘my grade on that first paper was a B’
‘the B4248’
‘B-roads’
‘Be5’
‘2B pencils’
‘a B-52’

--Word--
BSE 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Bovine spongiform encephalopathy, a disease of cattle which affects the central nervous system, causing agitation and staggering, and is usually fatal. It is believed to be caused by an agent such as a prion or a virino, and to be related to Creutzfeldt–Jakob disease in humans.
--Examples--
--Word--
BSE 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Bovine spongiform encephalopathy, a disease of cattle which affects the central nervous system, causing agitation and staggering, and is usually fatal. It is believed to be caused by an agent such as a prion or a virino, and to be related to Creutzfeldt–Jakob disease in humans.
--Examples--

--Word--
bubble 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A thin sphere of liquid enclosing air or another gas.
An air- or gas-filled spherical cavity in a liquid or a solidified liquid such as glass.
Used to refer to a good or fortunate situation that is isolated from reality or unlikely to last.
Used to refer to a significant, usually rapid, increase in asset prices that is soon followed by a collapse in prices and typically arises from speculation or enthusiasm rather than intrinsic increases in value.
A transparent domed cover or enclosure.
A place or position that is protected from danger or unpleasant reality.
A marine mollusc that typically has a thin scroll-like shell.
(of a liquid) form rising bubbles of gas or air.
Make a bubbling sound.
Be filled with an irrepressible positive feeling.
(of a feeling) become more intense and approach the point of being expressed.
--Examples--
‘we'd shake up a piece of soap in a tin of warm water and blow bubbles’
‘the white foamy part of a broken wave is largely made up of air bubbles’
‘we both lived in a bubble, the kind provided by occupying a privileged pied-à-terre in Greenwich Village’
‘the US economy squandered trillions as a result of the 1990s stock market bubble’
‘many companies enjoyed rapid expansion before the bubble burst’
‘piglets born into a sterile bubble’
‘they are not on tour packages seeing foreign ports from a bubble’
‘a pot of coffee bubbled away on the stove’
‘close by, a stream bubbled along through reeds and rushes’
‘Ellen was bubbling with enthusiasm’
‘the fury bubbling up inside her’
--Word--
bubble and squeak 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Cooked cabbage fried with cooked potatoes and often meat.
--Examples--

A transparent domed cover or enclosure.
A place or position that is protected from danger or unpleasant reality.
A marine mollusc that typically has a thin scroll-like shell.
(of a liquid) form rising bubbles of gas or air.
Make a bubbling sound.
Be filled with an irrepressible positive feeling.
(of a feeling) become more intense and approach the point of being expressed.
--Examples--
‘we'd shake up a piece of soap in a tin of warm water and blow bubbles’
‘the white foamy part of a broken wave is largely made up of air bubbles’
‘we both lived in a bubble, the kind provided by occupying a privileged pied-à-terre in Greenwich Village’
‘the US economy squandered trillions as a result of the 1990s stock market bubble’
‘many companies enjoyed rapid expansion before the bubble burst’
‘piglets born into a sterile bubble’
‘they are not on tour packages seeing foreign ports from a bubble’
‘a pot of coffee bubbled away on the stove’
‘close by, a stream bubbled along through reeds and rushes’
‘Ellen was bubbling with enthusiasm’
‘the fury bubbling up inside her’
--Word--
bubbling 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Containing bubbles or making a bubbling sound.
Characterized by cheerful high spirits.
--Examples--
‘flutes full of bubbling champagne’
‘a bubbling fountain’
‘a bubbling cocktail party’
--Word--
bubbler 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A drinking fountain.
--Examples--
--Word--
bubbler 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A drinking fountain.
--Examples--
--Word--
bubble 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A thin sphere of liquid enclosing air or another gas.
An air- or gas-filled spherical cavity in a liquid or a solidified liquid such as glass.
Used to refer to a good or fortunate situation that is isolated from reality or unlikely to last.
Used to refer to a significant, usually rapid, increase in asset prices that is soon followed by a collapse in prices and typically arises from speculation or enthusiasm rather than intrinsic increases in value.
A transparent domed cover or enclosure.
A place or position that is protected from danger or unpleasant reality.
A marine mollusc that typically has a thin scroll-like shell.
(of a liquid) form rising bubbles of gas or air.
Make a bubbling sound.
Be filled with an irrepressible positive feeling.
(of a feeling) become more intense and approach the point of being expressed.
--Examples--
‘we'd shake up a piece of soap in a tin of warm water and blow bubbles’
‘the white foamy part of a broken wave is largely made up of air bubbles’
‘we both lived in a bubble, the kind provided by occupying a privileged pied-à-terre in Greenwich Village’
‘the US economy squandered trillions as a result of the 1990s stock market bubble’
‘many companies enjoyed rapid expansion before the bubble burst’
‘piglets born into a sterile bubble’
‘they are not on tour packages seeing foreign ports from a bubble’
‘a pot of coffee bubbled away on the stove’
‘close by, a stream bubbled along through reeds and rushes’
‘Ellen was bubbling with enthusiasm’
‘the fury bubbling up inside her’
--Word--
bubbly 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Containing bubbles.
(of a person) full of cheerful high spirits.
Champagne.
--Examples--
‘bake until the top is crisp and bubbly’
‘a bright and bubbly personality’
‘I'll get us a little bottle of bubbly’

--Word--
Buber, Martin 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1878–1965), Israeli religious philosopher, born in Austria. In his existentialist work I and Thou (1923) he argues that religious experience involves reciprocal relationships with a personal subject, rather than knowledge of some ‘thing’.
--Examples--

--Word--
buccaneer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A pirate, originally one operating in the Caribbean.
A person who acts in a recklessly adventurous and often unscrupulous way, especially in business.
--Examples--
‘the marauding buccaneers who used to terrorize the Mediterranean coasts’
‘the company might be a target for an individual buccaneer seeking power and prestige’
--Word--
buccaneering 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(especially in a business context) high-risk and adventurous.
--Examples--
‘the buccaneering nature of the oil-transport industry’

buccinator 
--Type--

--Word--
Bucephalus 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The favourite horse of Alexander the Great, who tamed the horse as a boy and took it with him on his campaigns until its death, after a battle, in 326 BC.
--Examples--
--Word--
Buchan, John 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
1st Baron Tweedsmuir (1875–1940), Scottish novelist. His adventure stories feature recurring heroes such as Richard Hannay. Notable works: The Thirty-Nine Steps (1915).
--Examples--
--Word--
Buchanan, James 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1791–1868), American Democratic statesman, 15th president of the US 1857–61. His leanings towards the pro-slavery side in the developing dispute over slavery made the issue more fraught and he retired from politics in 1861.
--Examples--
--Word--
Bucharest 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The capital of Romania; population 1,931,236 (2006). It was founded in the 14th century on the trade route between Europe and Constantinople.
--Examples--
--Word--
Buchenwald 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A Nazi concentration camp in the Second World War, near Weimar in eastern Germany.
--Examples--
--Word--
Buchner, Eduard 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1860–1917), German organic chemist. He studied the chemistry of alcoholic fermentation and identified several enzymes, notably zymase. Nobel Prize for Chemistry (1907).
--Examples--
--Word--
buchu 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A South African shrub which is cultivated for its essential oil and as an ornamental.
A diuretic drug made from the powdered leaves of the buchu.
--Examples--
--Word--
buck 
--Type--
noun, verb, adjective
--Meanings--
The male of some horned animals, especially the fallow deer, roe deer, reindeer, and antelopes.
A male hare, rabbit, ferret, rat, or kangaroo.
An antelope of either sex.
A vertical jump performed by a horse, with the head lowered, back arched, and back legs thrown out behind.
A fashionable and spirited young man.
(of a horse) to perform a buck.
(of a vehicle) make sudden jerky movements.
Oppose or resist (something oppressive or inevitable)
Make or become more cheerful.
Lowest of a particular rank.
--Examples--
‘the horse seemed to leap, making a mighty buck that shipped the rider off’
‘the dashing young buck, driving his own equipage’
‘he's got to get his head down to buck’
‘she bucked them off if they tried to get on her back’
‘the boat began to buck in the water’
‘the shares bucked the market trend’
‘Bella and Jim need me to buck them up’
‘buck up, kid, it's not the end of the game’
‘a buck private’
--Word--
buck-and-wing

noun
--Meanings--
A lively solo tap dance, performed typically in wooden-soled shoes.
--Examples--
‘buck-and-wing dance’

buckeye 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An American tree or shrub related to the horse chestnut, with showy red or white flowers.

A kind of automatic coupling for railway rolling stock.

buck up one's ideas 
--Type--
phrase
--Meanings--

--Word--
bucket 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A roughly cylindrical open container with a handle, made of metal or plastic and used to hold and carry liquids.
The contents of a bucket or the amount it can contain.
Large quantities of something, especially liquid.
A compartment on the outer edge of a waterwheel.
The scoop of a dredger or grain elevator.
A scoop attached to the front of a loader, digger, or tractor.
A unit of data that can be transferred from a backing store in a single operation.
Rain heavily.
(of a vehicle) move quickly and jerkily.
--Examples--
‘a bucket and spade’
‘an ice bucket’
‘she emptied a bucket of water over them’
‘I wept buckets’
‘the Laxey wheel had 168 buckets, each holding 24 gallons’
‘as the chain turns the buckets bite into the canal bed and scoop out the mud’
‘it was still bucketing down’
‘the car came bucketing out of a side road’

roaring buckie 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The shell of the common whelk, Buccinum undatum, which appears to make a loud roaring noise (imagined to be the sound of the sea) when the opening is held to the ear.
--Examples--

--Type--
noun, verb, adjective
--Meanings--
The male of some horned animals, especially the fallow deer, roe deer, reindeer, and antelopes.

--Word--
Buckingham Palace 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The London residence of the British sovereign since 1837, adjoining St James's Park, Westminster. It was built for the Duke of Buckingham in the early 18th century and bought by George III in 1761.
--Examples--
--Word--
Buckinghamshire 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A county of central England; county town, Aylesbury.
--Examples--
--Word--
Bucks. 
--Type--
abbreviation
--Meanings--
Buckinghamshire.
--Examples--
--Word--
buckjump 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
(of a horse) jump vertically with its head lowered, back arched, and legs drawn together in an attempt to unseat its rider.
An act of buckjumping.
--Examples--
‘a buckjump rider’
--Word--
buckjump 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
(of a horse) jump vertically with its head lowered, back arched, and legs drawn together in an attempt to unseat its rider.
An act of buckjumping.
--Examples--
‘a buckjump rider’
--Word--
buckjumper 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
--Examples--
--Word--
Buckland, William 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1784–1856), English geologist. He helped to redefine geology, correlating deposits and associated fossils with former conditions, and developed the idea of an ice age. He was the first to describe and name a dinosaur (Megalosaurus), in 1824.
--Examples--
--Word--
buckle 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A flat, typically rectangular frame with a hinged pin, used for joining the ends of a belt or strap.
A similarly shaped ornament on a shoe.
A cake made with fruit (typically blueberries) and having a streusel topping.
Fasten or decorate with a buckle.
Fasten one's seat belt in a car or aircraft.
Bend and give way under pressure or strain.
Bend (something) out of shape.
(of a person) suffer a psychological collapse as a result of stress.
buckle down
Tackle a task with determination.
buckle to
Make a determined effort.
--Examples--
‘most rucksacks have quick release buckles’
‘a belt buckle’
‘black shoes with ornate buckles’
‘finish off the meal with a blueberry buckle for dessert’
‘he buckled his belt’
‘it is advisable to buckle up as some of the mountain roads require skilful manoeuvring’
‘the earth buckled under the titanic stress’
‘a lorry backed into the wall and buckled the gate’
‘a weaker person might have buckled under the strain’
‘they will buckle down to negotiations over the next few months’

buckle 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A flat, typically rectangular frame with a hinged pin, used for joining the ends of a belt or strap.
A similarly shaped ornament on a shoe.
A cake made with fruit (typically blueberries) and having a streusel topping.
Fasten or decorate with a buckle.
Fasten one's seat belt in a car or aircraft.
Bend and give way under pressure or strain.
Bend (something) out of shape.
(of a person) suffer a psychological collapse as a result of stress.
buckle down
Tackle a task with determination.
buckle to
Make a determined effort.
--Examples--
‘most rucksacks have quick release buckles’
‘a belt buckle’
‘black shoes with ornate buckles’

--Word--
buck 
--Type--
noun, verb, adjective
--Meanings--
The male of some horned animals, especially the fallow deer, roe deer, reindeer, and antelopes.
A male hare, rabbit, ferret, rat, or kangaroo.
An antelope of either sex.
A vertical jump performed by a horse, with the head lowered, back arched, and back legs thrown out behind.
A fashionable and spirited young man.
(of a horse) to perform a buck.
(of a vehicle) make sudden jerky movements.
Oppose or resist (something oppressive or inevitable)
Make or become more cheerful.
Lowest of a particular rank.
--Examples--
‘the horse seemed to leap, making a mighty buck that shipped the rider off’
‘the dashing young buck, driving his own equipage’
‘he's got to get his head down to buck’
‘she bucked them off if they tried to get on her back’
‘the boat began to buck in the water’
‘the shares bucked the market trend’
‘Bella and Jim need me to buck them up’
‘buck up, kid, it's not the end of the game’
‘a buck private’
--Word--
bucko 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A young man (often as a form of address)
--Examples--
‘I know you, my bucko, you're a troublemaker’
--Word--
buck 
--Type--
noun, verb, adjective
--Meanings--
The male of some horned animals, especially the fallow deer, roe deer, reindeer, and antelopes.
A male hare, rabbit, ferret, rat, or kangaroo.
An antelope of either sex.
A vertical jump performed by a horse, with the head lowered, back arched, and back legs thrown out behind.
A fashionable and spirited young man.
(of a horse) to perform a buck.
(of a vehicle) make sudden jerky movements.
Oppose or resist (something oppressive or inevitable)
Make or become more cheerful.
Lowest of a particular rank.
--Examples--
‘the horse seemed to leap, making a mighty buck that shipped the rider off’
‘the dashing young buck, driving his own equipage’
‘he's got to get his head down to buck’
‘she bucked them off if they tried to get on her back’
‘the boat began to buck in the water’
‘the shares bucked the market trend’
‘Bella and Jim need me to buck them up’
‘buck up, kid, it's not the end of the game’
‘a buck private’
--Word--
buck-passing 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The practice of shifting the responsibility for something to someone else.
--Examples--
‘I have seen a lot of buck-passing in the government in my day’
‘buck-passing comments’

buckram 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--
‘our sewn bindings incorporate buckram and leather’
‘a curtain with buckram headings’

--Word--
buckskin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The skin of a male deer.
Greyish leather with a suede finish, traditionally made from buckskin but now often made from sheepskin.
Clothes or shoes made from buckskin leather.
Thick, smooth cotton or woollen fabric.
A horse of a greyish-yellow colour.
--Examples--
‘she knelt on a buckskin’
‘a pair of buckskin moccasins’
‘the Great Plainsman wore fringed buckskins’
‘buckskin cloth’
‘the buckskin mare stumbled’

--Type--

--Meanings--

--Word--
buckskin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The skin of a male deer.

--Word--
stall 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A stand, booth, or compartment for the sale of goods in a market or large covered area.
An individual compartment for an animal in a stable or cowshed, enclosed on three sides.
A stable or cowshed.
A marked-out parking space for a vehicle.
A cage-like compartment in which a horse is held immediately prior to the start of a race.
A compartment for one person in a set of toilets, shower cubicles, etc.
A fixed seat in the choir or chancel of a church, enclosed at the back and sides and often canopied, typically reserved for a particular member of the clergy.
The seats on the ground floor in a theatre.
An instance of an engine, vehicle, aircraft, or boat stalling.
(of a motor vehicle or its engine) stop running, typically because of an overload on the engine.
(of an aircraft) stop flying and begin to fall because the speed is too low or the angle of attack too large to maintain adequate lift.
Have insufficient wind power in the sails to give controlled motion.
Cause to stall.
Stop or cause to stop making progress.
Speak or act in a deliberately vague way in order to gain more time to deal with something; prevaricate.
Delay or divert (someone) by prevarication.
Put or keep (an animal) in a stall, especially in order to fatten it.
--Examples--
‘fruit and vegetable stalls’
‘a parking stall’
‘a stalls seat’
‘speed must be maintained to avoid a stall and loss of control’
‘her car stalled at the crossroads’
‘his career had stalled, hers taken off’
‘the government has stalled the much-needed project’
‘she was stalling for time’
‘stall him until I've had time to take a look’
‘the horses were stalled at Upper Bolney Farm’

--Meanings--

buckthorn

noun
--Meanings--
A shrub or small tree that typically bears thorns and black berries. Some kinds yield dyes and others have been used medicinally.

--Word--
buckwheat 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An Asian plant of the dock family, producing starchy seeds that are used for fodder and also milled into flour which is widely used in the US.

--Word--
bud 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A compact growth on a plant that develops into a leaf, flower, or shoot.
An outgrowth from an organism, e.g. a yeast cell, that separates to form a new individual without sexual reproduction taking place.
A rudimentary leg or other appendage of an animal which has not yet grown, or never will grow, to full size.
Cannabis.
(of a plant or animal) form a bud.
Graft a bud of (a plant) on to another plant.
--Examples--
‘in certain limbless lizards and snakes a limb bud develops’
‘I found him outside, smoking some bud’
‘new blood vessels bud out from the vascular bed’
--Word--
Budapest 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The capital of Hungary; population 1,712,210 (2009). The city was formed in 1873 by the union of the hilly city of Buda on the right bank of the River Danube with the low-lying city of Pest on the left.
--Examples--
--Word--

--Word--
Buddha 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A title given to the founder of Buddhism, Siddartha Gautama (c.563–c.483 BC). Born a prince in what is now Nepal, he renounced wealth and family to become an ascetic, and after achieving enlightenment while meditating, taught all who came to learn from him.
A person who has attained full enlightenment.
A statue or picture of the Buddha.
--Examples--
--Word--
Buddha 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A title given to the founder of Buddhism, Siddartha Gautama (c.563–c.483 BC). Born a prince in what is now Nepal, he renounced wealth and family to become an ascetic, and after achieving enlightenment while meditating, taught all who came to learn from him.
A person who has attained full enlightenment.
A statue or picture of the Buddha.
--Examples--
--Word--
Buddhahood 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The state or condition of being or becoming a Buddha; spiritual awakening, enlightenment.
--Examples--
--Word--
Buddhaship 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The position or state of being a Buddha.
--Examples--
--Word--
Buddhic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to Buddhism; = "Buddhist".
--Examples--
--Word--
Buddhism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A widespread Asian religion or philosophy, founded by Siddartha Gautama in north-eastern India in the 5th century BC.
--Examples--
--Word--
Buddhist 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
An adherent of the religion based on the teachings of Buddha.
Relating to the religion based on the teachings of Buddha.
--Examples--
‘she was a practicing Buddhist’
‘devout Buddhists participate in the ceremonies’
‘the retiring Buddhist abbot’
‘a huge Buddhist altar’

--Type--

‘a huge Buddhist altar’
--Word--
Buddhology 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Originally: a theory or doctrine of the nature or role of the Buddha or a Buddha; the study of Buddhahood. Now usually: the study of Buddhism and Buddhist culture; Buddhist studies.
--Examples--
--Word--
Buddhological 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Of or relating to Buddhology.
--Examples--
--Word--
buddy 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A close friend.
A working companion with whom close cooperation is required.
A person who befriends and helps another with an incapacitating disease, typically AIDS.
Used as a form of address to a man whose name is not known.
Become friendly and spend time with someone.
--Examples--
‘they had become the best of buddies’
‘gay male counsellors, buddies, and helpline volunteers are available upon request’
‘I'm working on it, buddy’
‘I decided to buddy up to them’
--Word--
buddy boy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
(Chiefly as a form of address) a close male friend, a pal.
--Examples--
--Word--
buddy-buddy 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Very friendly.
--Examples--
‘he's buddy-buddy with the Ambassador’

--Word--
budding 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a plant) having or developing buds.
(of a body part) becoming larger as part of normal growth.
(of a person) beginning and showing signs of promise in a particular sphere.
Beginning and showing promising signs of continuing.
--Examples--

‘her budding breasts’
‘budding young actors’
‘their budding relationship’

A close friend.
A working companion with whom close cooperation is required.
A person who befriends and helps another with an incapacitating disease, typically AIDS.
Used as a form of address to a man whose name is not known.
Become friendly and spend time with someone.
--Examples--
‘they had become the best of buddies’
‘gay male counsellors, buddies, and helpline volunteers are available upon request’
‘I'm working on it, buddy’
‘I decided to buddy up to them’

--Word--
bude 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
With a person or thing as subject and bare or to-infinitive. Was necessitated or obliged; should, must (with both deontic and epistemic force).
With bare or (now usually) to-infinitive. With present or future reference. Is necessitated to; is destined to; shall.
--Examples--
--Word--
budge 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Make or cause to make the slightest movement.
Make room for another person by moving.
Change an opinion.
--Examples--
‘the queue in the bank hasn't budged’
‘I couldn't budge the door’
‘budge up, boys, make room for your uncle’
‘he wouldn't budge on his decision’

--Word--
budget 
--Type--
noun, verb, adjective
--Meanings--
An estimate of income and expenditure for a set period of time.
An annual or other regular estimate of national revenue and expenditure put forward by a finance minister.
The amount of money needed or available for a purpose.
A quantity of written or printed material.
Allow or provide a particular amount of money in a budget.
Provide (a sum of money) for a particular purpose from a budget.
Inexpensive.
--Examples--
‘keep within the household budget’
‘the government had put forward the biggest tax increases for any Budget in history’
‘they have a limited budget’
‘the university is budgeting for a deficit’
‘the council proposes to budget £100,000 to provide grants’
‘a budget guitar’
--Word--
budgetary 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to or in accordance with an estimate of income and expenditure.
--Examples--
‘tight budgetary constraints’
‘a coalition to prevent budgetary cuts to schools’

--Meanings--
(of a sum of money) provided for a particular purpose from a budget.
--Examples--
‘a budgeted figure of £31,000’

--Word--
bud 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A compact growth on a plant that develops into a leaf, flower, or shoot.
An outgrowth from an organism, e.g. a yeast cell, that separates to form a new individual without sexual reproduction taking place.
A rudimentary leg or other appendage of an animal which has not yet grown, or never will grow, to full size.
Cannabis.
(of a plant or animal) form a bud.
Graft a bud of (a plant) on to another plant.
--Examples--
‘in certain limbless lizards and snakes a limb bud develops’
‘I found him outside, smoking some bud’
‘new blood vessels bud out from the vascular bed’

Buerger's disease 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Inflammation and thrombosis in small and medium-sized blood vessels, typically in the legs and leading to gangrene. It has been associated with smoking.

--Word--
buff 
--Type--
noun, verb, adjective
--Meanings--
A yellowish-beige colour.
A stout dull yellow leather with a velvety surface.
A stick, wheel, or pad used for polishing.
Polish (something)
Give (leather) a velvety finish by removing the surface of the grain.
Make (an element in a role-playing or video game) more powerful.
(of a person or their body) in good physical shape with well-developed muscles.
--Examples--
‘a buff envelope’
‘he buffed the glass until it gleamed’
‘there are cards that'll buff your troops’
‘the driver was a buff blond named March’

--Word--
buffalo 
--Type--
noun, verb, proper noun
--Meanings--
A heavily built wild ox with backswept horns, found mainly in the Old World tropics.
The North American bison.
A large greyish-olive freshwater fish with thick lips, common in North America.
Overawe or intimidate (someone)
Baffle (someone)
An industrial city in New York State; population 270,919 (est. 2008). Situated at the eastern end of Lake Erie, it is a major port of the St Lawrence Seaway.
--Examples--
‘she didn't like being buffaloed’
‘the problem has buffaloed the advertising staff’

--Word--
buffer 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A person or thing that reduces a shock or that forms a barrier between incompatible or antagonistic people or things.
A pair of shock-absorbing pistons projecting from a cross-beam at the end of a railway track or on the front and rear of a railway vehicle.
A solution which resists changes in pH when acid or alkali is added to it.
A temporary memory area in which data is stored while it is being processed or transferred, especially one used while streaming video or downloading audio.
Lessen or moderate the impact of (something)
Treat with a chemical buffer.
Store (data) in a buffer while it is being processed or transferred.
--Examples--
‘family and friends can provide a buffer against stress’
‘print speed is boosted by pages being formatted in a buffer while another is printing’
‘the massage helped to buffer the strain’
‘add organic matter to buffer the resulting alkalinity’
‘try buffering as much of the video stream as you can before you hit the 'play' button’

--Word--
buffet 
--Type--
noun, verb, noun, noun
--Meanings--
A meal consisting of several dishes from which guests serve themselves.
A room or counter in a station, hotel, or other public building selling light meals or snacks.
A railway carriage selling light meals or snacks.
A cabinet with shelves and drawers for keeping dinnerware and table linens; a sideboard.
(especially of wind or waves) strike repeatedly and violently; batter.
Knock (someone) off course.
(of difficulties) afflict (someone) over a long period.
A blow or punch.
A shock or misfortune.
A low stool or hassock.
--Examples--
‘a cold buffet lunch’
‘rough seas buffeted the coast’
‘the wind was buffeting at their bodies’
‘he was buffeted from side to side’
‘they were buffeted by a major recession’
‘the daily buffets of urban civilization’
‘fifteen degrees of flap induce marked buffet’
--Word--
buffet 
--Type--
noun, verb, noun, noun
--Meanings--
A meal consisting of several dishes from which guests serve themselves.
A room or counter in a station, hotel, or other public building selling light meals or snacks.
A railway carriage selling light meals or snacks.
A cabinet with shelves and drawers for keeping dinnerware and table linens; a sideboard.
(especially of wind or waves) strike repeatedly and violently; batter.
Knock (someone) off course.
(of difficulties) afflict (someone) over a long period.
A blow or punch.
A shock or misfortune.
A low stool or hassock.
--Examples--
‘a cold buffet lunch’
‘rough seas buffeted the coast’
‘the wind was buffeting at their bodies’
‘he was buffeted from side to side’
‘they were buffeted by a major recession’
‘the daily buffets of urban civilization’
‘fifteen degrees of flap induce marked buffet’
--Word--
buffeting 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action of striking someone or something repeatedly and violently.
Irregular oscillation of part of an aircraft, caused by turbulence.
--Examples--
‘the roofs have survived the buffeting of worse winds than this’

noun, verb, noun, noun
--Meanings--
A meal consisting of several dishes from which guests serve themselves.
A room or counter in a station, hotel, or other public building selling light meals or snacks.
A railway carriage selling light meals or snacks.
A cabinet with shelves and drawers for keeping dinnerware and table linens; a sideboard.
(especially of wind or waves) strike repeatedly and violently; batter.
Knock (someone) off course.
(of difficulties) afflict (someone) over a long period.
A blow or punch.
A shock or misfortune.
A low stool or hassock.
--Examples--
‘a cold buffet lunch’
‘rough seas buffeted the coast’
‘the wind was buffeting at their bodies’
‘he was buffeted from side to side’
‘they were buffeted by a major recession’
‘the daily buffets of urban civilization’
‘fifteen degrees of flap induce marked buffet’
--Word--
buff 
--Type--
noun, verb, adjective
--Meanings--
A yellowish-beige colour.
A stout dull yellow leather with a velvety surface.
A stick, wheel, or pad used for polishing.
Polish (something)
Give (leather) a velvety finish by removing the surface of the grain.
Make (an element in a role-playing or video game) more powerful.
(of a person or their body) in good physical shape with well-developed muscles.
--Examples--
‘a buff envelope’
‘he buffed the glass until it gleamed’
‘there are cards that'll buff your troops’
‘the driver was a buff blond named March’

--Word--
bufflehead 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small North American diving duck related to the goldeneye, with a large puffy head. The male has white plumage with a black back.
--Examples--
--Word--
headed 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having a head of a specified kind.
Having an intellect or personality of a specified kind.
Having a tip, end, or top part of a specified kind.
(of certain green vegetables) having the edible leafy part at the top of the stem.
Having a particular person in charge; having a director or leader.
(of paper) having a printed heading, typically the name and address of a person or organization.
--Examples--
‘bald-headed men’
‘a seven-headed dragon’
‘woolly-headed thinking’
‘she was always cool-headed’
‘single-headed arrows’
‘short flat-headed nails’
‘headed cabbages’
‘female-headed households’
‘headed notepaper’
--Word--
buffo 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A comic actor in Italian opera.
Of or typical of Italian comic opera.
--Examples--
‘a buffo character’
--Word--
Buffon, Comte de 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1707–88), French naturalist; born Georges-Louis Leclerc. A founder of palaeontology, he emphasized the unity of all living species, minimizing the apparent differences between animals and plants. He produced a compilation of the animal kingdom, the Histoire Naturelle, which had reached thirty-six volumes by the time of his death.
--Examples--
--Word--
buffoon 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A ridiculous but amusing person; a clown.
--Examples--
--Word--
buffoonery 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Behaviour that is ridiculous but amusing.
--Examples--
‘the film is full of wordplay and buffoonery’
‘predictable jeers, buffooneries, and cheap shots’

buff-tip 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A European moth that has buff-coloured wing tips and thoracic hair, giving it the appearance of a twig when at rest.

--Word--
bug 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A harmful microorganism, typically a bacterium.
An illness caused by a microorganism.
An enthusiastic interest in something.
A small insect.
An insect of a large order distinguished by having mouthparts that are modified for piercing and sucking.
A concealed miniature microphone, used for secret eavesdropping or recording.
An error in a computer program or system.
Conceal a miniature microphone in (a room or telephone) in order to eavesdrop on or record someone's conversations secretly.
Record or eavesdrop on (a conversation) using a concealed microphone.
Annoy or bother (someone)
bug off
Go away.
bug out
Leave quickly.
Bulge outwards.
--Examples--
‘their ham was found to be contaminated with food bugs’
‘he'd just recovered from a flu bug’
‘they caught the sailing bug’
‘a thick green scum which crawls with bugs, centipedes, and worse’
‘they cleaned out the bugs and wiretaps’
‘a custom program we used developed a bug’
‘the telephones in the presidential palace were bugged’
‘she fears that her conversations were bugged’
‘a persistent reporter was bugging me’
‘I assumed you'd come to tell me to bug off’
‘if you see enemy troops, bug out’
‘he did a double take and his eyes bugged out’

bugbear 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--

bugeye 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A type of sailing boat used mainly for oyster fishing in the Chesapeake Bay area, typically having a centreboard and two masts.

bug-eyes 
--Type--
noun

--Word--
bugger 
--Type--
noun, verb, exclamation
--Meanings--
Used as a term of abuse, especially for a man.
Used as a term of affection or respect, typically grudgingly.
An annoyingly awkward thing.
A person who penetrates the anus of someone during sexual intercourse.
Penetrate the anus of (someone) during sexual intercourse.
Cause serious harm or trouble to.
Act in a stupid or feckless way.
Used to express an angrily dismissive attitude to (someone or something).
Used to express annoyance or anger.
--Examples--
‘I just hope you didn't hurt the poor bugger’
‘all right, let the little buggers come in’
‘muskets are a bugger to load’
--Word--
buggered 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a person) extremely tired.
--Examples--
‘when I got there I was absolutely buggered’

buggery 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Anal intercourse. In law the term also covers bestiality.
Used in various expressions as an intensifier.

buggy 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A small motor vehicle, typically with an open top.
A light horse-drawn vehicle for one or two people, with two or (in North America) four wheels.
A light folding chair on wheels, in which a baby or young child can be pushed along.
Infested with bugs.
(of a computer program or system) faulty in operation.
Mad; insane.
--Examples--
‘a golf buggy’
‘her two younger children were in a buggy’

--Word--
bugginess 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The fact or condition of being infested with insects or other bugs; characterized by the presence of a large number of these.
Computing. Of software: the fact or condition of being prone to malfunction due to programming errors or flaws; the fact or condition of containing many bugs.

Bugis 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a people of South Sulawesi, a province on the southern peninsula of the Indonesian island of Sulawesi (formerly called Celebes).
The Malayo-Polynesian language of the Bugis.
Of or relating to the Bugis or their language.
--Examples--
--Word--
Buginese 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a people living in South Sulawesi, a province of the Indonesian island of Sulawesi; = Bugis.
The Malayo-Polynesian language of the Buginese; = Bugis.
Of or relating to the Buginese or their language; = Bugis.
--Examples--

--Word--
bugle 
--Type--
noun, verb, noun, noun
--Meanings--
A brass instrument like a small trumpet, typically without valves or keys and used for military signals.
Sound a bugle.
Sound (a note or call) on a bugle.
A creeping Eurasian plant of the mint family, with blue flowers held on upright stems.
An ornamental tube-shaped glass or plastic bead sewn on to clothing.
--Examples--
‘the bugle sounded the charge’
‘a bugle call’
‘he bugled a warning’

--Word--
buglet 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small bugle, having its tubing closely coiled so as to make it more compact and portable than the standard bugle. Also more fully "†buglet horn".

--Word--
bug word 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A word causing or intended to cause fear or dread. In early use also (in plural): †pompous, conceited, or boastful language (obsolete).
--Examples--
--Word--
bugwort 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Either of two toxic American plants of the family Ranunculaceae, black bugbane (Actaea racemosa) and Indian poke (Veratrum viride).
--Examples--

buhrstone

--Word--
buy 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Obtain in exchange for payment.
Pay someone to give up an ownership, interest, or share.
Obtain one's release from the armed services by payment.
Withdraw something at auction because it fails to meet the reserve price.
Procure the loyalty and support of (someone) by bribery.
Be a means of obtaining (something) through exchange or payment.
Get by sacrifice or great effort.
Be a buyer for a store or firm.
Accept the truth of.
A purchase.
An act of purchasing something.
--Examples--
‘she bought six first-class stamps’
‘he had been able to buy up hundreds of acres’
‘he bought me a new frock’
‘homeowners who buy into housing developments’
‘when their affair ended, she bought him out’

‘a drug buy’

adjective

--Word--
buy 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Obtain in exchange for payment.
Pay someone to give up an ownership, interest, or share.
Obtain one's release from the armed services by payment.
Withdraw something at auction because it fails to meet the reserve price.
Procure the loyalty and support of (someone) by bribery.
Be a means of obtaining (something) through exchange or payment.
Get by sacrifice or great effort.
Be a buyer for a store or firm.
Accept the truth of.
A purchase.
An act of purchasing something.

--Word--
build 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Construct (something) by putting parts or material together.
Commission, finance, and oversee the building of (something)
Incorporate something and make it a permanent part of a structure, system, or situation.
Compile (a program, database, index, etc.)
Make or become stronger or more intense.
Establish and develop (a business or situation) over a period of time.
Use as a basis for further development.
The proportions of a person's or animal's body.
The style or form of construction of something, especially a vehicle.
A compiled version of a program.
The process of compiling a program.
--Examples--
‘the ironworks were built in 1736’
‘the county council plans to build a bypass’
‘engineers want to build in extra traction’
‘you can build database applications without writing any code’
‘we built up confidence in our abilities’
‘the air of excited anticipation builds’
‘he'd built up the store from nothing’
‘Britain should build on the talents of its workforce’
‘she was of medium height and slim build’
‘he had an ideal build for a sprinter’
‘the car's high specification and impressive build quality’
‘a beta build of the program’

--Word--
Bujumbura 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
The capital of Burundi, at the north-eastern end of Lake Tanganyika; population 429,000 (est. 2007). It was known as Usumbura until 1962.
--Examples--
--Word--
Bukhara 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city in the central Asian republic of Uzbekistan; population 249,000 (est. 2009). It is one of the oldest trade centres in central Asia, and is noted for the production of karakul fleeces.
--Examples--
--Word--
Bukharin, Nikolai 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1888–1938), Russian revolutionary activist and theorist; full name Nikolai Ivanovich Bukharin. Editor of Pravda (1918–29) and Izvestia (1934–7), a member of the Politburo (1924–9), and chairman of Comintern from 1926, he was executed in one of Stalin's purges.
--Examples--
--Word--
Bukovina 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A region of south-eastern Europe in the Carpathians, divided between Romania and Ukraine. Formerly a province of Moldavia, it was ceded to Austria by the Turks in 1775. After the First World War it was made part of Romania, the northern part being incorporated into the Ukrainian SSR in the Second World War.
--Examples--
--Word--
Bulawayo 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
An industrial city in western Zimbabwe; population 740,100 (est. 2009).

bulb 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A rounded underground storage organ present in some plants, notably those of the lily family, consisting of a short stem surrounded by fleshy scale leaves or leaf bases, lying dormant over winter.
A light bulb.
An expanded part of a glass tube such as that forming the reservoir of a thermometer.
A hollow flexible container with an opening through which the air can be expelled by squeezing, such as that used to fill a syringe.
A spheroidal dilated part at the end of an anatomical structure.

tee 
--Type--
noun, noun, verb, noun
--Meanings--
A cleared space on a golf course, from which the ball is struck at the beginning of play for each hole.
A small peg with a concave head which can be placed in the ground to support a golf ball before it is struck from a tee.
A mark aimed at in bowls, quoits, curling, and other similar games.
Place the ball on a tee ready to make the first stroke of the round or hole.
(especially in soccer) place or move the ball into position to be struck by another player.
tee off
Begin a round or hole of golf by playing the ball from a tee.
Make a start on something.
tee someone off
Make someone angry or annoyed.
A T-shirt.

Bulganin, Nikolai 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1895–1975), Soviet statesman, Chairman of the Council of Ministers (premier) 1955–8; full name Nikolai Aleksandrovich Bulganin. He was vice premier in the government of Georgi Malenkov in 1953, and in 1955 shared the premiership with Khrushchev.

bulk 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The mass or size of something large.
Large size or shape.
A large mass or shape.
Large in quantity.
Roughage in food.
Cargo in an unpackaged mass such as grain or oil.
The thickness of paper or a book.
The greater part of something.
Treat (a product) so that its quantity appears greater than it is.
Build up flesh and muscle, typically in training for sporting events.
Combine (shares or commodities for sale)
--Examples--
‘residents jump up and down on their rubbish to reduce its bulk’
‘he moved quickly in spite of his bulk’
‘bulk orders of over 100 copies’
‘potatoes supply energy, essential protein, and bulk’
‘the port is specially designed for the largest dry bulk vessels’
‘the bulk of the traffic had passed’
‘traders were bulking up their flour with chalk’
‘he took dietary supplements to bulk up as he lifted weights’
‘your shares will be bulked with others and sold at the best prices available’

--Examples--
‘a bulky carrier bag’
‘a bulky, overcoat-clad figure’

--Word--
bulk 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
The mass or size of something large.
Large size or shape.
A large mass or shape.
Large in quantity.
Roughage in food.
Cargo in an unpackaged mass such as grain or oil.
The thickness of paper or a book.
The greater part of something.
Treat (a product) so that its quantity appears greater than it is.
Build up flesh and muscle, typically in training for sporting events.
Combine (shares or commodities for sale)
--Examples--
‘residents jump up and down on their rubbish to reduce its bulk’
‘he moved quickly in spite of his bulk’
‘bulk orders of over 100 copies’
‘potatoes supply energy, essential protein, and bulk’
‘the port is specially designed for the largest dry bulk vessels’
‘the bulk of the traffic had passed’
‘traders were bulking up their flour with chalk’
‘he took dietary supplements to bulk up as he lifted weights’
‘your shares will be bulked with others and sold at the best prices available’

bull

noun, verb

An uncastrated male bovine animal.

--Word--
bearing 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person's way of standing or moving.
The way a person behaves or conducts themselves.
Relation; relevance.
The ability to tolerate something bad or to be tolerated.
A part of a machine that allows one part to rotate or move in contact with another part with as little friction as possible.
The direction or position of something, or the direction of movement, relative to a fixed point. It is usually measured in degrees, typically with magnetic north as zero.
Awareness of one's position relative to one's surroundings.
A device or charge.
--Examples--
‘a man of precise military bearing’
‘she has the bearing of a First Lady’
‘the case has no direct bearing on the issues being considered’
‘school was bad enough, but now it's past bearing’
‘the Point is on a bearing of 015°’
‘there were no steeples or bridges from which to take a bearing’
‘he flashed the torch around, trying to get his bearings’
‘armorial bearings’

‘why should I beggar myself for you?’

bitch 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A female dog, wolf, fox, or otter.
A spiteful or unpleasant woman.
A woman.
A person who is completely subservient to another.
Used as a form of address.
A difficult or unpleasant situation or thing.
A complaint.
Make spitefully critical comments.
--Examples--
‘I'm free, bitches!’
‘working the night shift is a bitch’
‘my big bitch is that there's nothing new here’
‘everybody was bitching about their colleagues’

--Word--
bulldog 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A dog of a sturdy smooth-haired breed with a large head and powerful protruding lower jaw, a flat wrinkled face, and a broad chest.
A person noted for courageous or stubborn tenacity.
(at Oxford and Cambridge Universities) an official who assists the proctors, especially in disciplinary matters.
Wrestle (a steer) to the ground by holding its horns and twisting its neck.
--Examples--
‘the bulldog spirit’
‘Cal was bulldogging a mean steer’
‘I bulldogged and rode broncos’
‘cowboys compete in bulldogging and bareback riding’

--Word--
bullet 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A metal projectile for firing from a rifle, revolver, or other small firearm, typically cylindrical and pointed, and sometimes containing an explosive.
Used in similes to refer to someone or something that moves very fast.
(in sporting contexts) a very fast ball.
Dismissal from employment.
A small symbol used to introduce each item in a list, for emphasis.
A stick of lipstick (considered separately from the tube in which it is encased)
--Examples--
‘the ball sped across the grass like a bullet’
‘all afternoon, he threw bullets at the other team's batters’
‘your record's bad, but it's doubtful they'll give you the bullet’
‘you can apply your lipstick straight from the bullet but I like to use a brush’
--Word--
bulleted

adjective
--Meanings--
(of items in a list) preceded by a printed bullet or bullet point.
--Examples--

--Word--
grip 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Take and keep a firm hold of; grasp tightly.
Maintain a firm contact, especially by friction.
(of an emotion or situation) have a strong or adverse effect on.
Firmly hold the attention or interest of.
A firm hold; a tight grasp.
A manner of holding something.
The ability of something, especially a wheel or shoe, to maintain a firm contact with a surface.
Effective control over something.
An understanding of something.
A part or attachment by which something is held in the hand.
A hairgrip.
A travelling bag.
A stagehand in a theatre.
A member of a camera crew responsible for moving and setting up equipment.
--Examples--
‘his knuckles were white as he gripped the steering wheel’
‘a sole that really grips well on wet rock’
‘she was gripped by a feeling of excitement’
‘the country was gripped by recession’
‘we were gripped by the drama’
‘his arm was held in a vice-like grip’
‘the icy grip of winter’
‘I've changed my grip and my backswing’
‘these shoes have got no grip’
‘he had to take a grip on his nerves’
‘you've got a good grip on what's going on’
‘handlebar grips’
‘a grip crammed with new clothes’

An electronic device for amplifying the sound of the voice so it can be heard at a distance; a megaphone.
--Examples--
--Word--
bully 
--Type--
noun, verb, adjective
--Meanings--
A person who habitually seeks to harm or intimidate those whom they perceive as vulnerable.
Seek to harm, intimidate, or coerce (someone perceived as vulnerable)
Very good; excellent.
--Examples--
‘he is a ranting, domineering bully’
‘her 11- year-old son has been constantly bullied at school’
‘a local man was bullied into helping them’
‘the statue really looked bully’

--Word--
bull 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An uncastrated male bovine animal.
A large male animal, especially a whale or elephant.
The zodiacal sign or constellation Taurus.
A bullseye.
A person who buys shares hoping to sell them at a higher price later.
Push or move powerfully or violently.
(of a cow) behave in a manner characteristic of being on heat.
--Examples--
‘bull calves’
‘aim for the bull!’
‘he bulled the motor cycle clear of the tunnel’

--Word--
bullish 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Aggressively confident and self-assertive.
Characterized by rising share prices.
(of a dealer) inclined to buy because of an anticipated rise in prices.
Confident or optimistic about something.
--Examples--
‘he has campaigned courageously despite difficulties that would have stopped many more bullish men’
‘the market was bullish’
‘high points in the stock market cycle, when investors are at their most bullish’
‘we are very bullish about our prospects’

--Word--
roaring 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Making or uttering a roar.
(of a fire) burning fiercely and noisily.
Behaving or living in a noisy riotous manner.
(of a period of time) characterized by prosperity, optimism, and excitement.
Very obviously or unequivocally the thing mentioned (used for emphasis)
--Examples--
‘he was greeted everywhere with roaring crowds’
‘a swollen, roaring river’
‘he sat by the roaring fire’
‘a roaring boy’
‘the Roaring Twenties’
‘last week's 70s night was a roaring success’
‘two roaring drunk firemen’

proper noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
bullseye 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The centre of the target in sports such as archery, shooting, and darts.
A shot that hits the bullseye in sports such as archery, shooting, and darts.
Used to refer to something that achieves exactly the intended effect.
A large, hard round peppermint sweet.
A thick disc of glass forming a small window in a ship or the glass of a lamp.
A thick knob of glass at the centre of a blown glass sheet.
--Examples--
‘the silence told him he'd scored a bullseye’
‘a bullseye lantern’
--Word--

--Word--
whack 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Strike forcefully with a sharp blow.
Defeat in a contest.
Put or push (something) roughly or carelessly in a specified place or direction.
Murder.
A sharp or resounding blow.
A try or attempt.
A specified share of or contribution to something.
A large quantity or amount.
--Examples--
‘his attacker whacked him on the head’
‘she found a stick to whack at the branches’
‘the team were whacked six-nil’
‘he whacks a tape into the cassette recorder’
‘he was whacked while sitting in his car’
‘with a few whacks and some loud whistles, they drove the animals away’
‘we decided to take a whack at spotting the decade's trends’
‘motorists pay a fair whack for the use of the roads through taxes’

Bultmann, Rudolf 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1884–1976), German Lutheran theologian; full name Rudolf Karl Bultmann. He emphasized the ‘existential’ rather than the historical significance of the Gospel story.
--Examples--

bulwark 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A defensive wall.
A person or thing that acts as a defence.
An extension of a ship's sides above the level of the deck.
--Examples--
‘the security forces are a bulwark against the breakdown of society’
‘the ships met, their crews lining the bulwarks’

--Word--
Strachey, Lytton 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1880–1932), English biographer; full name Giles Lytton Strachey. A prominent member of the Bloomsbury Group, he achieved recognition with Eminent Victorians (1918), which attacked the literary Establishment through its satirical biographies of Florence Nightingale, General Gordon, and others.
--Examples--
--Word--
bum 
--Type--
noun, verb, adjective
--Meanings--
A vagrant.
A lazy or worthless person.
A person who devotes a great deal of time to a specified activity.
Travel with no particular purpose.
Pass one's time idly.
Get by asking or begging.
Of poor quality; bad or wrong.
--Examples--
‘bums had been known to wander up to their door and ask for a sandwich’
‘you ungrateful bum!’
‘a ski bum’
‘he bummed around Florida for a few months’
‘students bumming around at university’
‘they tried to bum quarters off us’
‘not one bum note was played’
--Word--

verb

‘she watched a bee bumble among the flowers’

--Meanings--
Move or act in an awkward or confused manner.
Speak in a confused or indistinct way.
(of an insect) buzz or hum.
--Examples--
‘they bumbled around the house’
‘the succeeding speakers bumbled’
‘she watched a bee bumble among the flowers’
--Word--
bumbling 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Acting in a confused or ineffectual way; incompetent.
--Examples--
‘he's a bumbling fool’

bumf 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Useless or tedious printed material.

--Examples--
‘most of his mail was just bumf, bills, and Christmas cards’
‘I've got a bit of bumf in case of air raids’

--Word--
bummed 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Annoyed, upset, or disappointed.
--Examples--
‘she was really bummed out that she never got to meet you’
‘given the foot-tapping music, a lot of people were bummed about not being able to dance’
--Word--
bummer 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A disappointing or unpleasant situation or experience.
A loafer or vagrant.
--Examples--
‘the party was a real bummer’
--Word--

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Examples--
‘the party was a real bummer’
--Word--
bum 
--Type--
noun, verb, adjective
--Meanings--
A vagrant.
A lazy or worthless person.
A person who devotes a great deal of time to a specified activity.
Travel with no particular purpose.
Pass one's time idly.
Get by asking or begging.
Of poor quality; bad or wrong.
--Examples--
‘bums had been known to wander up to their door and ask for a sandwich’
‘you ungrateful bum!’
‘a ski bum’
‘he bummed around Florida for a few months’
‘students bumming around at university’
‘they tried to bum quarters off us’
‘not one bum note was played’
--Word--
bump 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A light blow or a jolting collision.
(on a person's birthday) a custom by which the person is lifted by the arms and legs and let down on to the ground, once for each year of their age.
(in races where boats make a spaced start one behind another) the point at which a boat begins to overtake or touch the boat ahead, thereby defeating it.
A rising air current causing an irregularity in an aircraft's motion.
A protuberance on a level surface.
A swelling on the skin, especially one caused by illness or injury.
A lump on a person's skull, formerly thought to indicate a particular mental faculty.
An increase.
(in an online forum) an act of posting on an inactive thread in order to move it to the top of the list of active threads.
A loosely woven fleeced cotton fabric used in upholstery and as lining material.
Knock or run into someone or something with a jolt.
Meet by chance.
Hurt or damage (something) by striking it on something else.
(in a race) gain a bump against.
Move or travel with much jolting.
Push (something) jerkily in a specified direction.
Refuse (a passenger) a reserved place on a flight because of deliberate overbooking by the airline.
Displace from a job or role, especially in favour of someone else.
(in an online forum) post on (an inactive thread) in order to move it to the top of the list of active threads.
--Examples--
‘a nasty bump on the head’
‘the children were given the bumps’
‘bumps in the road’
‘her mosquito bites had come up in huge red bumps’
‘there was a bump in the number of outbound flights’
‘I'm giving this thread a well-deserved bump’
‘I almost bumped into him’
‘she bumped the girl with her hip’
‘we might just bump into each other’
‘she bumped her head on the sink’
‘the car bumped along the rutted track’
‘she had to bump the pushchair down the steps’
‘if you check in on time and are bumped, you will be entitled to a full refund’
‘she was bumped for a youthful model’
‘if no one responds after 24 hours, you can bump your thread’

bump 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--

--Word--
bumper 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A horizontal bar fixed across the front or back of a motor vehicle to reduce damage in a collision.
A shock-absorbing piston projecting from a cross-beam at the end of a railway track or at the end of a railway vehicle.
A flat race for inexperienced horses which are intended for future racing in hurdles or steeplechases.
A generous glassful of an alcoholic drink, typically one drunk as a toast.
Exceptionally large, fine, or successful.
--Examples--
‘she started the car with a jerk and hit the bumper of the car in front’
‘a bumper crop’
‘everyone in the business predicts a bumper year’

--Word--
bumpy 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a surface) uneven, with many patches raised above the rest.
(of a journey or other movement) involving sudden jolts and jerks.
--Examples--
‘the car jolted on the bumpy road’
‘the bumpy flight brought on a bout of airsickness’
‘investors could be in for a bumpy ride’

bun 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small cake, typically containing dried fruit.
A bread roll.
(in Scotland and Jamaica) a rich fruit cake or currant bread.
A hairstyle in which the hair is drawn back into a tight coil at the back of the head.
A person's buttocks.
--Examples--
‘a currant bun’
--Word--
bunce 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Money or profit gained by someone.
--Examples--
‘they can turn their hand to many jobs as long as there's a bit of bunce in it’
--Word--
bunch 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A number of things, typically of the same kind, growing or fastened together.
A group of people.
A large number or quantity; a lot.
A girl's hairstyle in which the hair is tied back into two clumps at the back or on either side of the head.
Collect or fasten into a compact group.
Form or cause to form tight folds.
Form into a tight group or crowd.
(of muscles) flex or bulge.
--Examples--
‘a bunch of grapes’
‘the people who wrote in complaining are a bunch of idiots’
‘I was awoken by a bunch of rowdy drunkards’
‘the bluesy style that earned him a bunch of '70s hits’
‘she bunched the needles together’
‘the bedclothes had bunched up around his waist’
‘he halted, forcing the rest of the field to bunch up behind him’

--Word--
bunchberry 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A low-growing plant of the dogwood family, which produces white flowers followed by red berries and bright red autumn foliage. It is native to North America, eastern Asia, and Greenland.
--Examples--
--Word--
bunchberry 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A low-growing plant of the dogwood family, which produces white flowers followed by red berries and bright red autumn foliage. It is native to North America, eastern Asia, and Greenland.
--Examples--
--Word--
Bunche, Ralph 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1904–71), US diplomat and statesman; full name Ralph Johnson Bunche. Instrumental in the settlement of the Israeli-Arab conflict in 1948, he was the first African American to receive a Nobel Prize. Nobel Peace Prize (1950).
--Examples--

‘a bunco artist’
‘he didn't propose to be buncoed without a fight’

--Word--
bundle 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A collection of things or quantity of material tied or wrapped up together.
A set of nerve, muscle, or other fibres running in parallel close together.
A set of software or hardware sold together.
A large amount of money.
Tie or roll up (a number of things) together as though into a parcel.
Dress (someone) in many warm clothes.
Sell (items of hardware and software) as a package.
Push, carry, or send forcibly, hastily, or unceremoniously.
(of a group of people) move in a disorganized way.
Sleep fully clothed with another person, as a former local custom during courtship.
--Examples--
‘a thick bundle of envelopes’
‘a bundle of 15 desktop utilities’
‘the new printer cost a bundle’
‘she quickly bundled up her clothes’
‘they were bundled up in thick sweaters’
‘he was bundled into a van’
‘they bundled out into the corridor’

Bunyan, John 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1628–88), English writer. A Nonconformist, he was imprisoned twice for unlicensed preaching, during which time he wrote his spiritual autobiography Grace Abounding (1666) and began his major work The Pilgrim's Progress (1678–84).
--Examples--

--Word--
Bunin, Ivan 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1870–1953), Russian poet and prose writer; full name Ivan Alekseevich Bunin. An opponent of modernism, he concentrated on the themes of peasant life and love. Nobel Prize for Literature (1933, the first Russian prizewinner).
--Examples--

--Word--
bunker 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A large container or compartment for storing fuel.
A reinforced underground shelter, typically for use in wartime.
A hollow filled with sand, used as an obstacle on a golf course.
Fill the fuel containers of (a ship); refuel.
(of a player) have one's ball lodged in a bunker.
Hit (the ball) into a bunker.
Cause difficulties to; hinder the progress of.
Take refuge in a bunker or other shelter.
--Examples--
‘a coal bunker’
‘he was bunkered at the fifth hole’
‘he bunkered his second shot’
‘he may find his new sporting pursuits bunkered by activities he hadn't planned on’
‘his family had bunkered down inside their home’
‘the former Governor has spent four days bunkered down at Government House’

--Word--
Bunsen, Robert 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1811–99), German chemist; full name Robert Wilhelm Eberhard Bunsen. With Gustav Kirchhoff he pioneered spectroscopy, detecting new elements (caesium and rubidium) and determining the composition of many substances and of the sun and stars. He designed numerous items of chemical apparatus, notably the Bunsen burner (1855).
--Examples--
--Word--
bunt 
--Type--
verb, noun, noun, noun
--Meanings--
(of a batter) gently tap (a pitched ball) without swinging in an attempt to make it more difficult to field.
(of a batter) help (a base runner) to progress to a further base by bunting a ball.
Push or butt.
An act or result of bunting a pitched ball.
An act of flying an aircraft in part of an outside loop.
The baggy centre of a fishing net or a sail.
A disease of wheat caused by a smut fungus, the spores of which give off a smell of rotten fish.
--Examples--
‘he tried to bunt the ball down the first baseline’
‘Phil bunted and got to first’
‘he bunted Davis to third’
‘Gary bunted her with his head’
--Word--
buntal 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The straw from a talipot palm used for making hats.
--Examples--
‘a buntal hat’

bunt 
--Type--
verb, noun, noun, noun

An act of flying an aircraft in part of an outside loop.

‘Gary bunted her with his head’

bunting 
--Type--
noun, noun, noun
--Meanings--
An Old World seed-eating songbird related to the finches, typically having brown streaked plumage and a boldly marked head.
A small New World songbird of the cardinal subfamily, the male of which is mainly or partly bright blue in colour.
Flags and other colourful festive decorations.
A loosely woven fabric used to make bunting.
A hooded sleeping bag for babies.
--Examples--
--Word--

A loosely woven fabric used to make bunting.
A hooded sleeping bag for babies.

verb, noun, noun, noun
--Meanings--
(of a batter) gently tap (a pitched ball) without swinging in an attempt to make it more difficult to field.
(of a batter) help (a base runner) to progress to a further base by bunting a ball.
Push or butt.
An act or result of bunting a pitched ball.
An act of flying an aircraft in part of an outside loop.
The baggy centre of a fishing net or a sail.
A disease of wheat caused by a smut fungus, the spores of which give off a smell of rotten fish.
--Examples--
‘he tried to bunt the ball down the first baseline’
‘Phil bunted and got to first’
‘he bunted Davis to third’
‘Gary bunted her with his head’
--Word--
Buñuel, Luis 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1900–83), Spanish film director. Influenced by surrealism, he wrote and directed his first film, Un Chien andalou (1929), jointly with Salvador Dalí. Other notable films: Belle de jour (1967) and The Discreet Charm of the Bourgeoisie (1972).
--Examples--
--Word--
buoy 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An anchored float serving as a navigation mark, to show reefs or other hazards, or for mooring.
Keep (someone or something) afloat.
Make (someone) cheerful and confident.
Cause (a price) to rise to or remain at a high level.
Mark with an anchored float.
--Examples--
‘the creatures could swim, both buoyed up and cooled by the water’
‘she was buoyed up by his praise’
‘shares were up 4p, buoyed by his cut-and-thrust management style’
‘a buoyed channel’
