--Word--
buoyancy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The ability or tendency of something to float in water or other fluid.
The power of a liquid to keep something afloat.
A cheerful and optimistic attitude or disposition.
A high level of activity in an economy or stock market.
--Examples--
‘she plunged into the sea, grateful for the buoyancy of the salt water’
‘there is renewed buoyancy in the demand for steel’
--Word--
buoyancy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The ability or tendency of something to float in water or other fluid.
The power of a liquid to keep something afloat.
A cheerful and optimistic attitude or disposition.
A high level of activity in an economy or stock market.
--Examples--
‘she plunged into the sea, grateful for the buoyancy of the salt water’
‘there is renewed buoyancy in the demand for steel’
--Word--
buoyant 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Able or tending to keep afloat or rise to the top of a liquid or gas.
(of a liquid or gas) able to keep something afloat.
Cheerful and optimistic.
(of an economy, business, or market) involving or engaged in much successful trade or activity.
--Examples--
‘buoyant water’
‘the conference ended with the party in a buoyant mood’
‘car sales were buoyant’

adverb
--Meanings--
--Examples--

--Word--
Burbage, Richard 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(c.1567–1619), English actor. He was the creator of most of Shakespeare's great tragic roles — Hamlet, Othello, Lear, and Richard III — and was also associated with the building of the Globe Theatre.
--Examples--
--Word--
Burbank 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A city in southern California, on the north side of the Los Angeles conurbation; population 102,968 (est. 2008). It is a centre of the film and television industries.
--Examples--

--Word--
burble 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Make a continuous murmuring noise.
Speak continuously and at length in an unintelligible or confused way.
(of an airflow) break up into turbulence.
Continuous murmuring noise.
Rambling speech.
--Examples--
‘a stream burbled through the woods’
‘he burbled on about annuities’
‘he was burbling inanities’
‘the steady burble of running water’
‘an hour of boring burble’

burbot 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An elongated bottom-dwelling fish that is the only freshwater member of the cod family, occurring in Eurasia and North America but almost extinct in Britain.

--Word--
alone 
--Type--
UnKnownKind
--Meanings--
Having no one else present; on one's own.
Without others' help or participation; single-handed.
Isolated and lonely.
Indicating that something is confined to the specified subject or recipient.
Used to emphasize that only one factor out of several is being considered and that the whole is greater or more extreme.
--Examples--
‘she was alone that evening’
‘he lives alone’
‘team members are more effective than individuals working alone’
‘they were not alone in dissenting from the advice’
‘she was terribly alone and exposed’
‘he is answerable to Parliament alone’
‘it was a smile for him alone’
‘there were fifteen churches in the town centre alone’
--Word--
burden 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A load, typically a heavy one.
A duty or misfortune that causes worry, hardship, or distress.
The main responsibility for achieving a specified aim or task.
A ship's carrying capacity; tonnage.
The main theme or gist of a speech, book, or argument.
The refrain or chorus of a song.
Load heavily.
Cause (someone) worry, hardship, or distress.
--Examples--
‘the tax burden on low-wage earners’
‘the burden of establishing that the authority had misused its powers rests upon the prosecution’
‘the schooner Wyoming, of about 6,000 tons burden’
‘she walked forwards burdened with a wooden box’
‘they were not yet burdened with adult responsibility’

--Word--
burdock 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A large herbaceous Old World plant of the daisy family. The hook-bearing flowers become woody burrs after fertilization and cling to animals' coats to aid seed dispersal.
--Examples--

bureau 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A writing desk with drawers and typically an angled top opening downwards to form a writing surface.
A chest of drawers.
An office or department for transacting particular business.
A government department.
--Examples--
‘a news bureau’
‘the London bureau of the Washington Post’
‘the intelligence bureau’
--Word--
bureaucracy 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A system of government in which most of the important decisions are taken by state officials rather than by elected representatives.
A state or organization governed or managed as a bureaucracy.
The officials in a bureaucracy, considered as a group or hierarchy.
Excessively complicated administrative procedure.
--Examples--
‘the unnecessary bureaucracy in local government’

--Word--
bureaucrat 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An official in a government department, in particular one perceived as being concerned with procedural correctness at the expense of people's needs.
--Examples--
‘the unemployed will be dealt with not by faceless bureaucrats but by individuals’
--Word--
bureaucratese 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A style of speech or writing characterized by jargon, euphemism, and abstractions, held to be typical of bureaucrats.
--Examples--
--Word--
bureaucratic 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Relating to a system of government in which most of the important decisions are taken by state officials rather than by elected representatives.
Over-concerned with procedure at the expense of efficiency or common sense.
--Examples--
‘well-established bureaucratic procedures’
‘the scheme is overly bureaucratic and complex’

noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
burgess 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An inhabitant of a town or borough with full rights of citizenship.
A Member of Parliament for a borough, corporate town, or university.
(in the US and also historically in the UK) a magistrate or member of the governing body of a town.
A member of the assembly of colonial Maryland or Virginia.
--Examples--
--Word--
burgessdom 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The state or fact of being a burgess; the body of burgesses in a particular borough; burgess-ship.
--Examples--
--Word--
burgess 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An inhabitant of a town or borough with full rights of citizenship.
A Member of Parliament for a borough, corporate town, or university.
(in the US and also historically in the UK) a magistrate or member of the governing body of a town.
A member of the assembly of colonial Maryland or Virginia.
--Examples--
--Word--
burgess 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An inhabitant of a town or borough with full rights of citizenship.
A Member of Parliament for a borough, corporate town, or university.

A member of the assembly of colonial Maryland or Virginia.
--Examples--
--Word--
burgess-ship 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The state or fact of being a burgess (of a town, borough, etc.); the status and privileges of a burgess; the freedom of a borough, citizenship.
British. The position of member of parliament for a borough. Now rare.
--Examples--
--Word--
burgh 
--Type--

--Meanings--
A borough or chartered town.

--Examples--
--Word--
burgher 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A citizen of a town or city, typically a member of the wealthy bourgeoisie.
(in southern Africa) an Afrikaans citizen of a Boer Republic.
(in southern Africa) a civilian member of a local militia unit.
A descendant of a Dutch or Portuguese colonist in Sri Lanka.
--Examples--
‘the poem is not the sort of thing the sturdy burghers of Manchester would wish to read’

--Word--
Burghley, 1st Baron 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1520–98), English statesman; born William Cecil. Secretary of State to Queen Elizabeth I 1558–72 and Lord High Treasurer 1572–98, he was the queen's most trusted councillor and minister.

--Word--
Burgoyne, John 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1722–92), English general and playwright; known as Gentleman Johnny. He surrendered to the Americans at Saratoga (1777) in the War of American Independence.

Burgos 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A town in northern Spain; population 177,879 (est. 2008). It was the capital of Castile during the 11th century, and the official seat of Franco's Nationalist government (1936–9).

--Word--
burgundy 
--Type--
noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
A wine from Burgundy (usually taken to be red unless otherwise specified)
A deep red colour like that of burgundy wine.
A region and former duchy of east central France, centred on Dijon. The region is noted for its wine.
--Examples--
‘a glass of Burgundy’
‘elegant red burgundies’
‘warm shades of brown and burgundy’
‘burgundy leather’
--Word--
Burgundian 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A native or inhabitant of Burgundy.
A member of a Germanic people that invaded Gaul from the east and established the kingdom of Burgundy in the 5th century AD.
Relating to Burgundy or the Burgundians.
--Examples--
--Word--
burgundy 
--Type--
noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
A wine from Burgundy (usually taken to be red unless otherwise specified)
A deep red colour like that of burgundy wine.

‘elegant red burgundies’
‘warm shades of brown and burgundy’
‘burgundy leather’
--Word--
bury 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Put or hide underground.
Place (a dead body) in the earth or in a tomb, usually with funeral rites.
Lose (someone, especially a relative) through death.
Cover (someone or something) completely.
Hide (something) from sight.
Hide or try to forget (a feeling or memory)
Involve oneself deeply in something to the exclusion of other concerns.
(of a football player) shoot (the ball) into the goal.
--Examples--
‘he buried the box in the back garden’
‘he was buried in St John's churchyard’
‘a rich old lady who had buried two husbands’
‘the countryside has been buried under layers of concrete’
‘the sheep were buried beneath six-foot drifts of snow’
‘she buried her face in her hands’
‘they had buried their feelings of embarrassment and fear’
‘he buried himself in work’
‘he ran through to bury a right-foot shot inside the near post’
--Word--
burial 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The action or practice of burying a dead body.
A ceremony at which someone's body is buried; a funeral.
A grave or the remains found in it.
--Examples--
‘his remains were shipped home for burial’
‘they will give him a proper burial’
‘burial rites’
‘burial mounds’
--Word--
burial ground 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An area of ground set aside for the burying of human bodies.
--Examples--
--Word--

Buryat 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of a people living in southern Siberia, Mongolia, and northern China.
The language of the Buryat, related to Mongolian and having over 400,000 speakers.
Relating to the Buryat or their language.

Burke, William 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1792–1829), Irish murderer. He was a bodysnatcher operating in Edinburgh with his accomplice William Hare.

Burkitt's lymphoma 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Cancer of the lymphatic system, caused by the Epstein–Barr virus, chiefly affecting children in central Africa.
--Examples--
--Word--
burl 
--Type--
noun, noun
--Meanings--
A slub or lump in wool or cloth.
A rounded knotty growth on a tree, used especially in handcrafted objects and veneers.
An attempt.
--Examples--
‘she used warty burls to construct her pieces’
‘wooden coin banks made of elm burl’
‘a burl bowl’
‘we'll give it a burl’
--Word--
burlap 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Coarse canvas woven from jute, hemp, or a similar fibre, used especially for sacking.
Lighter material of a kind similar to burlap, used in dressmaking and furnishing.
--Examples--
‘a burlap sack’
‘a burlap shirt’
‘fabrics ranging from hessians to burlaps’

--Word--
burlesque 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An absurd or comically exaggerated imitation of something, especially in a literary or dramatic work; a parody.
A variety show, typically including striptease.
Parody or imitate in an absurd or comically exaggerated way.
--Examples--
‘a novel which is a burlesque of the literary life’
‘the argument descends into music-hall burlesque’
‘burlesque clubs’
‘a mock-heroic farce that burlesques the affectations of Restoration heroic drama’

Burma

proper noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
Burmese 
--Type--
noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A member of the largest ethnic group of Burma (Myanmar) in SE Asia.
A native or inhabitant of Burma.
The official language of Burma, which is the first language of about 22 million people (75 per cent of the population). It is a tonal Sino-Tibetan language written in an alphabet derived from that of ancient Pali.
A cat of a short-coated breed originating in Asia.
Relating to Burma, its people, or their language.
--Examples--
--Word--
Chinese 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to China or its language, culture, or people.
Belonging to the people forming the dominant ethnic group of China and also widely dispersed elsewhere.
The Sino-Tibetan language of China.
A native or inhabitant of China, or a person of Chinese descent.
A Chinese meal.
A Chinese restaurant.
--Examples--
‘a takeaway Chinese washed down with Chardonnay’
‘we found a Chinese in Soho’
--Word--
burn 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
(of a fire) flame or glow while consuming a material such as coal or wood.
(of a candle or other source of light) be alight.
Be in flames.
Use (a type of fuel) as a source of heat or energy.
(of the body of a person or animal) convert (calories) to energy.
Be or cause to be destroyed by fire.
Be or cause to be damaged, injured, or spoiled by heat or fire.
(of the skin) become red and painful through exposure to the sun.
Feel hot or sore, typically as a result of illness or injury.
Insult (someone) in a particularly cutting way.
Be entirely possessed by (a desire or an emotion)
Drive very fast.
Produce (a CD or DVD) by copying from an original or master copy.
An injury caused by exposure to heat or flame.
A mark left on something as a result of being burned.
An injury caused by friction.
A hot, painful sensation in the muscles experienced as a result of sustained vigorous exercise.
A particularly cutting insult.
Consumption of a type of fuel as an energy source.
A firing of a rocket engine in flight.
An act of clearing of vegetation by burning.
An area of land cleared by burning vegetation.
A cigarette.
--Examples--
‘a fire burned and crackled cheerfully in the grate’
‘a light was burning in the hall’
‘by nightfall, the whole city was burning’
‘a diesel engine converted to burn natural gas’
‘exercise does help to burn up calories’
‘he watched his restaurant burn to the ground’
‘he burned all the letters’
‘I burned myself on the stove’
‘the toast's burning’
‘my skin tans easily but sometimes burns’
‘her forehead was burning and her throat ached’
‘Mark burns him by saying he hasn't even heard of the guy's agency’
‘Martha was burning with curiosity’
‘a despatch rider burning up the highways’
‘he was treated in hospital for burns to his hands’
‘the carpet was covered in cigarette burns’
‘they found rope burns around her waist’
‘he's been on the receiving end of his fair share of sick burns’
‘‘No, it's not ready, probably because I work twice as many accounts as you do.’ (Burn!)’
‘natural gas produces the cleanest burn of the lot’
--Word--
burn 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
(of a fire) flame or glow while consuming a material such as coal or wood.
(of a candle or other source of light) be alight.
Be in flames.
Use (a type of fuel) as a source of heat or energy.
(of the body of a person or animal) convert (calories) to energy.
Be or cause to be destroyed by fire.
Be or cause to be damaged, injured, or spoiled by heat or fire.
(of the skin) become red and painful through exposure to the sun.
Feel hot or sore, typically as a result of illness or injury.
Insult (someone) in a particularly cutting way.
Be entirely possessed by (a desire or an emotion)
Drive very fast.
Produce (a CD or DVD) by copying from an original or master copy.
An injury caused by exposure to heat or flame.
A mark left on something as a result of being burned.
An injury caused by friction.
A hot, painful sensation in the muscles experienced as a result of sustained vigorous exercise.
A particularly cutting insult.
Consumption of a type of fuel as an energy source.
A firing of a rocket engine in flight.
An act of clearing of vegetation by burning.
An area of land cleared by burning vegetation.
A cigarette.
--Examples--
‘a fire burned and crackled cheerfully in the grate’
‘a light was burning in the hall’
‘by nightfall, the whole city was burning’
‘a diesel engine converted to burn natural gas’
‘exercise does help to burn up calories’
‘he watched his restaurant burn to the ground’
‘he burned all the letters’
‘I burned myself on the stove’
‘the toast's burning’
‘my skin tans easily but sometimes burns’
‘her forehead was burning and her throat ached’
‘Mark burns him by saying he hasn't even heard of the guy's agency’
‘Martha was burning with curiosity’
‘a despatch rider burning up the highways’
‘he was treated in hospital for burns to his hands’
‘the carpet was covered in cigarette burns’
‘they found rope burns around her waist’
‘he's been on the receiving end of his fair share of sick burns’
‘‘No, it's not ready, probably because I work twice as many accounts as you do.’ (Burn!)’
‘natural gas produces the cleanest burn of the lot’
--Word--
burnable 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Consisting or made of material that is able to be burned or is suitable for burning.
--Examples--
‘in 2000 Switzerland closed all of its landfills to burnable waste’

--Word--
Burne-Jones, Sir Edward 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1833–98), English painter and designer; full name Sir Edward Coley Burne-Jones. His work, which included tapestry and stained-glass window designs, reflected his interest in medieval and literary themes and is typical of the later Pre-Raphaelite style.
--Examples--
--Word--
burned 
--Type--
UnKnownKind, adjective
--Meanings--
Having been burned.
(of a taste) like that of food that has been charred in cooking.
(of sugar) cooked or heated until caramelized.
(of a warm color) dark or deep.
--Examples--
‘burned wood’
‘burned shoulders and peeling noses’
‘burnt orange’
--Word--
burned-out 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a vehicle or building) destroyed or badly damaged by fire; gutted.
(of an electrical device or component) having failed through overheating.
(of a person) in a state of physical or mental collapse caused by overwork or stress.
(of a teenager or other person) having dropped out; drug-using.
--Examples--
‘she felt burned out, an empty shell’
‘a burned-out undercover cop’
--Word--
over-burn 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
To burn (something) to excess or so as to consume too much of; to burn (something) for too long; to fire (a brick) for longer than usual.
--Examples--
--Word--
Burney, Fanny 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1752–1840), English novelist; born Frances Burney. Notable works: Evelina (1778), Cecilia (1782), and Letters and Diaries (1846).
--Examples--
--Word--
Burne-Jones, Sir Edward 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1833–98), English painter and designer; full name Sir Edward Coley Burne-Jones. His work, which included tapestry and stained-glass window designs, reflected his interest in medieval and literary themes and is typical of the later Pre-Raphaelite style.
--Examples--
--Word--
burner 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person or thing that burns.
A part of a cooker, lamp, etc. that emits a flame.
An apparatus in which a substance is heated.
The heating element of an electric cooker.
A device for producing a CD or DVD by copying from an original or master copy.
A cheap mobile phone paid for in advance.
--Examples--
‘uphill walking is a great calorie-burner’
‘the hob has four gas burners’
‘the figures carried small incense burners’
‘he bought a burner to get in touch with Shapiro’
‘one national security reporter suggested using burner phones’

Burnett, Carol 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(born 1933), US comedienne and actress. She is best known for the television program The Carol Burnett Show (1967–78).
--Examples--
--Word--
Woods, William Burnham 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1824–87), US Supreme Court associate justice 1880–87. A judge on the circuit court, he was appointed to the Supreme Court by President Hayes.
--Examples--
--Word--
burning 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
On fire.
Very hot or bright.
Very keenly or deeply felt; intense.
Of urgent interest and importance; exciting or calling for debate.
--Examples--
‘a burning building’
‘the burning midday sun’
‘he had a burning ambition to climb to the upper reaches of management’
‘pension reform is still a burning issue’
‘the burning question of independence’
--Word--
burning bush 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Any of a number of shrubs noted for their bright red autumn foliage, in particular the kochia or the smoke tree.
Any of a number of shrubs or trees with bright red leaves or fruits.

burnout 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The reduction of a fuel or substance to nothing through use or combustion.
The failure of an electrical device or component through overheating.
Physical or mental collapse caused by overwork or stress.
A dropout or drug abuser.
Denoting fabric whose pattern is produced by using chemicals to burn away areas of the pile or the fabric itself.
--Examples--
‘an anti-stall mechanism prevents motor burnout’
‘high levels of professionalism which may result in burnout’
‘burnout velvet’
‘a long-sleeved jersey burnout top’

--Word--
burr 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A whirring sound, such as a telephone ringing tone or the sound of cogs turning.
A rough pronunciation of the letter r, especially with a uvular trill as in a Northumberland accent.
(loosely) a regional accent.
A rough edge or ridge left on an object (especially of metal) by the action of a tool or machine.
A small rotary cutting tool with a shaped end, used chiefly in woodworking and dentistry.
A small surgical drill for making holes in bone, especially in the skull.
A siliceous rock used for millstones.
A whetstone.
A prickly seed case or flower head that clings to clothing and animal fur.
A plant that produces burrs, for example bur reed.
Denoting wood containing knots or other growths which show a pattern of dense swirls in the grain when sawn, used for veneers and other decorative woodwork.
The coronet of a deer's antler.
Make a whirring sound.
Speak with a regional accent, especially one in which the letter r is prominent.
Form a rough edge on (metal).
--Examples--
‘a soft Scottish burr’
‘burr walnut’
--Word--
bada

adjective
--Meanings--
Big or important.
--Examples--
‘if you want to become a bada star, rush to the auditions between 10 a.m and 6 p.m’
--Word--
pipe 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A tube used to convey water, gas, oil, or other fluid substances.
A cylindrical vein of ore or rock, especially one in which diamonds are found.
A cavity in cast metal.
A duct, vessel, or tubular structure in the body, or in an animal or plant.
A connection to the Internet or to a website.
A device for smoking tobacco, consisting of a narrow tube made from wood, clay, etc. with a bowl at one end in which the tobacco is burned, the smoke from which is drawn into the mouth.
A quantity of tobacco held by a pipe.
A device for smoking illegal drugs.
A wind instrument consisting of a single tube with holes along its length that are covered by the fingers to produce different notes.
Bagpipes.
A set of musical pipes joined together, as in pan pipes.
Any of the cylindrical tubes by which notes are produced in an organ.
A boatswain's whistle.
A high-pitched cry or song, especially of a bird.
A command which causes the output from one routine to be the input for another.
The symbol |.
A cask for wine, especially as a measure equal to two hogsheads, usually equivalent to 105 gallons (about 477 litres)
Convey (water, gas, oil, or other fluid substances) through a pipe or pipes.
Transmit (music, a radio or television programme, signal, etc.) by wire or cable.
Play (a tune) on a pipe or pipes.
Play a pipe or pipes as a ceremonial accompaniment to the arrival or departure of (someone)
Use a boatswain's whistle to summon (the crew) to work or a meal.
(of a bird) sing in a high or shrill voice.
Say something in a high, shrill voice.
Decorate (clothing or soft furnishings) with thin cord covered in fabric and inserted into a seam.
Arrange (food, particularly icing or cream) in decorative lines or patterns.
Propagate (a pink or similar plant) by taking a cutting at the joint of a stem.
--Examples--
‘a smell of pipe tobacco’
‘they were sharing a pipe of tobacco’
‘a crack pipe’
‘the tone of a reed pipe’
‘the sad little pipe of the ringed plover’
‘a fresh pipe of port’
‘water from the lakes is piped to Manchester’
‘he was watching a movie piped to his room on one of the hotel's video channels’
‘he believed he'd heard music—a tune being piped’
‘the Duke was piped on board’
‘the hands were piped to breakfast’
‘outside at the back a curlew piped’
‘‘No, miss,’ piped Lucy’
‘she had been piping cream round a flan’
--Word--
burrawang 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An Australian cycad with palmlike leaves and a sunken underground trunk.
The poisonous nut of the burrawang, which becomes edible after prolonged soaking.
--Examples--
--Word--
burr 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A whirring sound, such as a telephone ringing tone or the sound of cogs turning.
A rough pronunciation of the letter r, especially with a uvular trill as in a Northumberland accent.
(loosely) a regional accent.
A rough edge or ridge left on an object (especially of metal) by the action of a tool or machine.
A small rotary cutting tool with a shaped end, used chiefly in woodworking and dentistry.
A small surgical drill for making holes in bone, especially in the skull.
A siliceous rock used for millstones.
A whetstone.
A prickly seed case or flower head that clings to clothing and animal fur.
A plant that produces burrs, for example bur reed.
Denoting wood containing knots or other growths which show a pattern of dense swirls in the grain when sawn, used for veneers and other decorative woodwork.
The coronet of a deer's antler.
Make a whirring sound.
Speak with a regional accent, especially one in which the letter r is prominent.
Form a rough edge on (metal).
--Examples--
‘a soft Scottish burr’
‘burr walnut’
--Word--
bur reed 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
An aquatic reedlike plant with rounded flower heads. Its oily seeds are an important source of winter food for wildfowl.
--Examples--
--Word--
fly 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
(of a bird, bat, or insect) move through the air using wings.
(of an aircraft or its occupants) travel through the air.
Control the flight of (an aircraft)
Transport in an aircraft.
Accomplish (a purpose) in an aircraft.
Release (a bird) to fly, especially a hawk for hunting or a pigeon for racing.
Move or be hurled quickly through the air.
(of accusations or insults) be exchanged swiftly and heatedly.
(of a report) be circulated swiftly and widely.
Hit a ball high into the air.
Wave or flutter in the wind.
(with reference to a flag) display or be displayed on a flagpole.
Go or move quickly.
Depart hastily.
(of time) pass swiftly.
Run away; flee.
Escape from in haste; flee from.
Be successful.
An opening at the crotch of a pair of trousers, closed with a zip or buttons and typically covered with a flap.
A flap of material covering the opening or fastening of a garment or of a tent.
The space over the stage in a theatre.
A one-horse hackney carriage.
An attempt.
--Examples--
‘close the door or the moths will fly in’
‘the bird can fly enormous distances’
‘I fly back to London this evening’
‘he flew Hurricanes in the war’
‘helicopters flew the injured to hospital’
‘pilots trained to fly combat missions’
‘balls kept flying over her hedge’
‘he was sent flying by the tackle’
‘the accusations flew thick and fast’
‘rumours were flying around Manchester’
‘he flied out to the left field’
‘she ran after him, her hair flying behind her’
‘vessels which flew the Spanish flag’
‘flags were flying at half mast’
‘she flew along the path’
‘his fingertips flew across the keyboard’
‘I must fly!’
‘the evening had just flown by’
‘those that fly may fight again’
‘you must fly the country for a while’
‘that idea didn't fly with most other council members’
‘we decided to give it a fly’
--Word--
shot 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The firing of a gun or cannon.
An attempt to hit a target by shooting.
A person with a specified level of ability in shooting.
A critical or hostile remark.
A hit, stroke, or kick of the ball in sports such as football, tennis, or golf.
An attempt to score a goal.
An attempt to do something.
A ball of stone or metal used as a missile shot from a large gun or cannon.
Tiny lead pellets used in quantity in a single charge or cartridge in a shotgun.
A heavy ball thrown by a shot-putter.
A photograph.
A film sequence photographed continuously by one camera.
The range of a camera's view.
A small drink of spirits.
A single serving of espresso coffee.
An injection of a drug or vaccine.
The launch of a space rocket.
--Examples--
‘Mulder killed him with a single shot’
‘they have fired the opening shot in what's expected to be a savage price war’
‘he asked me if I would like to have a shot at a pheasant’
‘Roy was a very good shot’
‘Paul tried one last shot—‘You realize what you want will cost more money?’’
‘his partner pulled off a winning backhand shot’
‘he took a shot that the goalie stopped’
‘several of the competitors will have a shot at the all-round title’
‘metal fragments and lead shot were sent in all directions’
‘a group shot of all the family’
‘the movie's opening shot is of a character walking across a featureless landscape’
‘a prop man was standing just out of shot’
‘he took a shot of whisky’
‘steamed milk with a shot of espresso’
‘a shot of impure heroin’
‘a moon shot’

--Word--
Burroughs, William 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1914–97), American novelist; full name William Seward Burroughs. In the 1940s he became addicted to heroin, and his best-known writing, for example Junkie (1953) and The Naked Lunch (1959), deals with life as a drug addict in a unique, surreal style.

burrow 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A hole or tunnel dug by a small animal, especially a rabbit, as a dwelling.
(of an animal) make a hole or tunnel, typically for use as a dwelling.
Dig into or through something solid.
Hide underneath or press close to something.
Make a thorough inquiry; investigate.
--Examples--
‘moles burrowing away underground’
‘worms that burrow through dead wood’
‘the child burrowed deeper into the bed’
‘journalists are burrowing into the prime minister's business affairs’

--Word--
bursa 
--Type--
noun, proper noun
--Meanings--
A fluid-filled sac or saclike cavity, especially one countering friction at a joint.
A city in north-western Turkey, capital of a province of the same name; population 1,431,200 (est. 2007). It was the capital of the Ottoman Empire from 1326–1402.

--Word--
burst 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Break open or apart suddenly and violently, especially as a result of an impact or internal pressure.
Cause to burst.
Be so full as almost to break open.
Feel a very strong or irrepressible emotion or impulse.
Issue suddenly and uncontrollably.
Open suddenly and forcibly.
Move suddenly and violently.
Suddenly begin doing or producing something.
Separate (continuous stationery) into single sheets.
An instance of breaking or splitting as a result of internal pressure or puncturing; an explosion.
A sudden brief outbreak.
A sudden issuing forth.
A period of continuous and intense effort.
--Examples--
‘one of the balloons burst’
‘the dam burst after days of torrential rain’
‘he burst the balloon’
‘the swollen river was expected to burst its banks’
‘the wardrobe was bursting with piles of clothes’
‘he was bursting with joy and excitement’
‘she was bursting to say something’
‘the words burst from him in an angry rush’
‘a door burst open and a girl raced out’
‘he burst into the room without knocking’
‘she burst on to the British art scene in 1985’
‘Sophie burst out laughing’
‘she burst into tears’
‘the aircraft burst into flames’
‘the mortar bursts were further away than before’
‘a burst of activity’
‘bursts of laughter’
‘her breath was coming in short bursts’
‘he sailed 474 miles in one 24-hour burst’

--Word--
Lancaster, Burt 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1913–94), American film actor; full name Burton Stephen Lancaster. He starred in films such as From Here to Eternity (1953), Elmer Gantry (1960), for which he won an Oscar, and Field of Dreams (1989).

--Word--
Burton upon Trent 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A town in west central England, in Staffordshire; population 45,500 (est. 2009). The town is noted for its breweries.

--Word--
Burundi 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
A central African country on the east side of Lake Tanganyika, to the south of Rwanda; population 11,200,000 (estimated 2015); official languages, French and Kirundi; capital, Bujumbura.
--Examples--

Burundian 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Relating to or characteristic of Burundi or its people.
A native or inhabitant or Burundi.
--Examples--
‘the Burundian literary tradition’
‘almost all Burundians live in rural areas’
--Word--
bus 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A large motor vehicle carrying passengers by road, typically one serving the public on a fixed route and for a fare.
A car, aircraft, or other vehicle.
A distinct set of conductors carrying data and control signals within a computer system, to which pieces of equipment may be connected in parallel.
Transport in a communal road vehicle.
Travel by bus.
Transport (a child of one ethnic group) to a school where another group is predominant, in an attempt to promote racial integration.
Remove (dirty plates and dishes) from a table in a restaurant or cafeteria.
Remove dirty plates and dishes from (a table).
--Examples--
‘a bus service’
‘staff were bussed in and out of the factory’
‘the priest bussed in from a neighbouring parish’

--Meanings--

busby 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A tall fur hat with a coloured cloth flap hanging down on the right-hand side and in some cases a plume on the top, worn by soldiers of certain regiments of hussars and artillerymen.

buscarl 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
In (late) Anglo-Saxon and Anglo-Norman England: a member of a body of men retained, apparently usually by the king, to guard the coast.

--Word--
bush 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A shrub or clump of shrubs with stems of moderate length.
A bunch of ivy as a vintner's sign.
(especially in Australia and Africa) wild or uncultivated country.
Vegetation growing in the bush.
Indigenous rainforest.
Uncivilized or primitive.
A luxuriant growth of thick hair or fur.
A woman's pubic hair.
Spread out into a thick clump.
--Examples--
‘a rose bush’
‘they have to spend a night camping in the bush’
‘the lowland country was covered in thick bush’
‘bush justice’
‘a childish face with a bush of bright hair’
‘her hair bushed out like a halo’

noun
--Meanings--
A small nocturnal tree-dwelling African primate with very large eyes.

bushed 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--

‘unused to solitude, he went bushed’

bushel

noun
--Meanings--
A measure of capacity equal to 8 gallons (equivalent to 36.4 litres), used for corn, fruit, liquids, etc.
A measure of capacity equal to 64 US pints (equivalent to 35.2 litres), used for dry goods.

Bushism 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The policies or principles advocated by former US presidents George H. W. Bush or George W. Bush.
A verbal error made by and considered characteristic of former US president George W. Bush.
--Examples--
‘the politics of national opposition to Bushism are exceedingly complex’
‘a brand new Bushism is doing the media rounds’

--Word--
hammer 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A tool with a heavy metal head mounted at right angles at the end of a handle, used for jobs such as breaking things and driving in nails.
A machine with a metal block for giving a heavy blow to something.
An auctioneer's gavel, tapped to indicate a sale.
A part of a mechanism that hits another part to make it work, such as one exploding the charge in a gun or one striking the strings of a piano.
A metal ball of about 7 kg attached to a wire for throwing in an athletic contest.
The sport of throwing a hammer.
Hit or beat (something) repeatedly with a hammer or similar object.
Strike or knock at or on something violently with one's hand or with a hammer or other object.
Work hard and persistently.
Inculcate something forcefully or repeatedly.
Attack or criticize forcefully and relentlessly.
Utterly defeat in a game or contest.
Beat down the price of (a stock)
Declare (a person or company) a defaulter.
--Examples--
‘he hammered the tack in’
‘she hammered on his door’
‘he hammered the ball wildly over the crossbar’
‘they must hammer away at these twin themes day after day’
‘a commercial image that was hammered into English consciousness’
‘he got hammered for an honest mistake’
‘they hammered St Mirren 4–0’
‘sceptical investors hammered the computer company's stock’
‘Willis was hammered in the recession’
--Word--
harrow 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
An implement consisting of a heavy frame set with teeth or tines which is dragged over ploughed land to break up clods, remove weeds, and cover seed.
Draw a harrow over (land)
Cause distress to.
--Examples--
‘they ploughed and harrowed the heavy clay’
‘Todd could take it, whereas I'm harrowed by it’

--Word--
bushy 
--Type--
adjective, noun
--Meanings--
Growing thickly.
Covered with bush or bushes.
A person who lives in the bush (as distinct from in a town), typically regarded as uncultured or unsophisticated.
--Examples--
‘a dense, bushy plant’
‘his eyebrows were thick and bushy’
‘bushy desert areas’
‘cultural wonders that bushies like me were despised for not having’

--Word--
Bushman 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A member of any of several aboriginal peoples of southern Africa, especially of the Kalahari Desert. Traditionally nomadic hunter-gatherers, many are now employed by farmers.
A person who lives, works, or travels in the Australian bush.
--Examples--

--Word--
rope 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A length of thick strong cord made by twisting together strands of hemp, sisal, nylon, or similar material.
A lasso.
Used in reference to execution by hanging.
The ropes enclosing a boxing or wrestling ring.
A quantity of roughly spherical objects such as onions or beads strung together.
The established procedures in an organization or area of activity.
Catch, fasten, or secure with rope.
Enclose or separate an area with a rope or tape.
(of a party of climbers) connect each other together with a rope.
Climb down or up using a rope.
Persuade someone, despite reluctance, to take part in (an activity)
--Examples--
‘there was no way down, even with a rope’
‘coils of rope’
‘executions by the rope continued well into the twentieth century’
‘a rope of pearls’
‘I want you to show her the ropes’
‘the calves must be roped and led out of the stockade’
‘the climbers were all roped together’
‘police roped off the area’
‘we stopped at the foot of the ridge and roped up’
‘the party had been roping down a hanging glacier’
‘anyone who could sing in tune was roped in’
--Word--
shrike 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A songbird with a strong sharply hooked bill, often impaling its prey of small birds, lizards, and insects on thorns.
Used in names of birds of other families that are similar to the shrike, e.g. cuckoo-shrike, pepper-shrike.
--Examples--

bushwhack 
--Type--
verb
--Meanings--
Live or travel in bush country.
Cut or push one's way through dense vegetation.
Work clearing scrub and felling trees in bush country.
Engage in guerrilla warfare.
Surprise (someone) by attacking them from a hidden place; ambush.
--Examples--
‘I have not seen a bear yet after seven days of bushwhacking’
‘he'd bushwhacked down the steep slopes’

adjective
--Meanings--

--Examples--

noun
--Meanings--

busy 
--Type--
adjective, verb, noun
--Meanings--
Having a great deal to do.
Occupied with or concentrating on a particular activity or object of attention.
(of a time or place) full of activity.
(of a telephone line) engaged.
Excessively detailed or decorated.
Keep oneself occupied.
A police officer.
--Examples--
‘he had been too busy to enjoy himself’
‘the team members are busy raising money’
‘the busy city streets’
‘I've had a busy day’
‘the lavish set designs are a little too busy’
‘she busied herself with her new home’
‘I was picked up by the busies for possession’

--Examples--
--Word--
busy 
--Type--
adjective, verb, noun
--Meanings--
Having a great deal to do.
Occupied with or concentrating on a particular activity or object of attention.
(of a time or place) full of activity.
(of a telephone line) engaged.
Excessively detailed or decorated.
Keep oneself occupied.
A police officer.
--Examples--
‘he had been too busy to enjoy himself’
‘the team members are busy raising money’
‘the busy city streets’
‘I've had a busy day’
‘the lavish set designs are a little too busy’
‘she busied herself with her new home’
‘I was picked up by the busies for possession’

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
busy-idle 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Electronics and Telecommunications. Also in form busy/idle. Indicating or relating to the state of being either busy or idle.

--Type--

--Word--
busyish 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Somewhat busy; quite busy.
--Examples--
--Word--
busily 
--Type--
adverb
--Meanings--
In a very active way.
While giving all one's attention to something.
--Examples--
‘he was busily engaged in other activities’
‘he was busily writing away’
--Word--
business 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A person's regular occupation, profession, or trade.
An activity that someone is engaged in.
A person's concern.
Work that has to be done or matters that have to be attended to.
Commercial activity.
Trade considered in terms of its volume or profitability.
A commercial operation or company.
(in Aboriginal English) traditional law and ritual.
A situation or series of events, typically a scandalous or discreditable one.
A difficult matter.
Actions on stage other than dialogue.
A very enjoyable or popular person or thing.
A group of ferrets.
--Examples--
‘experts who typically conduct their business over the Internet’
‘what is your business here?’
‘it's not my business to interfere’
‘the neighbours make it their business to know all about you’
‘government business’
‘let's get down to business’
‘firms who want to do business with Japan’
‘the tea business’
‘the business community’
‘how's business?’
‘the banks are continuing to lose business’
‘a catering business’
‘maybe something positive will come out of the whole awful business’
‘what a business!’
‘this brandy is the business’
‘his goons will go through the ship like a business of ferrets’
--Word--
busyness 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
The state or condition of having a great deal to do.
The quality of being full of activity.
The quality of being excessively detailed or decorated.
--Examples--
‘it's easy to get caught up in the busyness of life’
‘school started and the busyness began’
‘the busyness and noise of the street’
‘the waitresses seemed unfazed by the busyness of the cafe’
‘the busyness of the interior design’

--Word--
businessese 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
= business-speak.
--Examples--
--Word--
businesslike 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having or indicating an efficient, practical, and systematic approach to one's work or a task.
(of clothing, furniture, etc.) designed or appearing to be practical rather than decorative.
--Examples--
‘his brisk, businesslike tone’
‘a businesslike grey suit’
--Word--
businesslike 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Having or indicating an efficient, practical, and systematic approach to one's work or a task.
(of clothing, furniture, etc.) designed or appearing to be practical rather than decorative.
--Examples--
‘his brisk, businesslike tone’
‘a businesslike grey suit’

--Word--
busk 
--Type--
verb, noun
--Meanings--
Play music in the street or other public place for voluntary donations.
Improvise.
A stay or stiffening strip for a corset.
--Examples--
‘the group began by busking on Philadelphia sidewalks’

buskin 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A calf-high or knee-high boot of cloth or leather.
A thick-soled laced boot worn by an ancient Athenian tragic actor to gain height.
The style or spirit of tragic drama.

--Word--
Busoni, Ferruccio 
--Type--
proper noun
--Meanings--
(1866–1924), Italian composer, conductor, and pianist; full name Ferruccio Benvenuto Busoni. As a composer he is best known for his piano works and his unfinished opera Doktor Faust (1925).
--Examples--

--Word--
bussu 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
More fully "bussu palm". A tropical palm, Manicaria saccifera, native to estuarine and swamp habitats of Trinidad and parts of Central and South America, with a crown of very large entire or partially pinnate leaves, used for thatching.
--Examples--
--Word--
bust 
--Type--
noun, verb, noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A woman's chest as measured around her breasts.
A woman's breasts, especially considered in terms of their size.
A sculpture of a person's head, shoulders, and chest.
Break, split, or burst.
(of a group or couple) separate, typically after a quarrel.
Violently disrupt.
Strike violently.
Escape.
(in blackjack and similar card games) exceed the score of 21, so losing one's stake.
(of the police) raid or search (premises where illegal activity is suspected)
Arrest.
Be caught in the act of doing something wrong.
Reduce (a soldier) to a lower rank; demote.
A period of economic difficulty or depression.
A raid or arrest by the police.
A worthless thing.
A violent blow.
Damaged or broken.
Bankrupt.
--Examples--
‘a 36-inch bust’
‘a woman with big hips and a big bust’
‘they bust the tunnel wide open’
‘the film bust every box office record’
‘the colour control had bust’
‘now they've bust up, she won't inherit the house’
‘men hired to bust up union rallies’
‘Tamara bust him in the eye’
‘she busted out of prison’
‘my flat got busted’
‘two roadies were busted for drugs’
‘I sneaked up on them and told them they were busted’
‘he was busted to private’
‘the boom was followed by the present bust’
‘a drug bust’
‘cynics remain convinced the political process is a bust’
‘a bust on the snout’
‘the vacuum cleaner's bust’
‘six of their sponsors have gone bust’
--Word--
bustard 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A large, heavily built, swift-running bird, found in open country in the Old World. The males of most bustards have a spectacular courtship display.
--Examples--
--Word--
bustard 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A large, heavily built, swift-running bird, found in open country in the Old World. The males of most bustards have a spectacular courtship display.
--Examples--

--Word--
buster 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Used as a mildly disrespectful form of address to a man or boy.
A person or thing that stops or gets rid of a specified thing.
A notable or impressive person or thing.
A violent gale.
--Examples--
‘like it or lump it, buster’
‘a crime-buster’
‘the drug's reputation as a cold-buster’

--Word--
busthead 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
Cheap, strong, alcoholic liquor (especially whisky) which has been home-brewed or illicitly distilled.
--Examples--
--Word--
busty 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a woman) having large breasts.
--Examples--
‘a busty starlet’
--Word--
bustian 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A kind of cotton fabric, chiefly of foreign manufacture, used especially for making waistcoats and certain church vestments.

--Word--
bustle 
--Type--
verb, noun, noun
--Meanings--
Move in an energetic and busy manner.
Cause to move hurriedly in a particular direction.
(of a place) be full of activity.
Excited activity and movement.
A pad or frame worn under a skirt and puffing it out behind.
--Examples--
‘people clutching clipboards bustled about’
‘she bustled us into the kitchen’
‘the streets bustled with people’
‘all the noise and the traffic and the bustle’
--Word--
bustle 
--Type--
verb, noun, noun
--Meanings--
Move in an energetic and busy manner.

--Examples--
‘people clutching clipboards bustled about’
‘she bustled us into the kitchen’
‘the streets bustled with people’
‘all the noise and the traffic and the bustle’

bustle 
--Type--
verb, noun, noun
--Meanings--
Move in an energetic and busy manner.
Cause to move hurriedly in a particular direction.

Excited activity and movement.
A pad or frame worn under a skirt and puffing it out behind.

‘she bustled us into the kitchen’
‘the streets bustled with people’
‘all the noise and the traffic and the bustle’

--Word--
bust 
--Type--
noun, verb, noun, adjective
--Meanings--
A woman's chest as measured around her breasts.
A woman's breasts, especially considered in terms of their size.
A sculpture of a person's head, shoulders, and chest.
Break, split, or burst.
(of a group or couple) separate, typically after a quarrel.
Violently disrupt.
Strike violently.
Escape.
(in blackjack and similar card games) exceed the score of 21, so losing one's stake.
(of the police) raid or search (premises where illegal activity is suspected)
Arrest.
Be caught in the act of doing something wrong.
Reduce (a soldier) to a lower rank; demote.
A period of economic difficulty or depression.
A raid or arrest by the police.
A worthless thing.
A violent blow.
Damaged or broken.
Bankrupt.
--Examples--
‘a 36-inch bust’
‘a woman with big hips and a big bust’
‘they bust the tunnel wide open’
‘the film bust every box office record’
‘the colour control had bust’
‘now they've bust up, she won't inherit the house’
‘men hired to bust up union rallies’
‘Tamara bust him in the eye’
‘she busted out of prison’
‘my flat got busted’
‘two roadies were busted for drugs’
‘I sneaked up on them and told them they were busted’
‘he was busted to private’
‘the boom was followed by the present bust’
‘a drug bust’
‘cynics remain convinced the political process is a bust’
‘a bust on the snout’
‘the vacuum cleaner's bust’
‘six of their sponsors have gone bust’
--Word--
bust-up 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A serious quarrel.
A fight or brawl.
--Examples--
‘the diplomatic bust-up with Germany’
‘a touchline bust-up’
--Word--
busulfan 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A drug which is an alkylating agent with a destructive effect on bone marrow, used especially in the treatment of chronic myeloid leukaemia and in the preparation of patients for bone marrow transplantation. [Chemical name: 1,4-di(methanesulphonyloxy)butane; C6H14O6S2. Busulfan is the International Nonproprietary Name (1996). Busulphan is the British Approved Name (1997). A trademark for this drug is Myleran.]
--Examples--
--Word--
busulfan 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A drug which is an alkylating agent with a destructive effect on bone marrow, used especially in the treatment of chronic myeloid leukaemia and in the preparation of patients for bone marrow transplantation. [Chemical name: 1,4-di(methanesulphonyloxy)butane; C6H14O6S2. Busulfan is the International Nonproprietary Name (1996). Busulphan is the British Approved Name (1997). A trademark for this drug is Myleran.]
--Examples--
--Word--
busway 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A road or section of a road set apart exclusively for buses, typically one equipped with tracks or grooves for guiding them.
--Examples--
--Word--
but 
--Type--
conjunction, preposition, adverb, noun
--Meanings--
Used to introduce a phrase or clause contrasting with what has already been mentioned.
Used to indicate the impossibility of anything other than what is being stated.
Used to introduce a response expressing a feeling such as surprise or anger.
Used after an expression of apology for what one is about to say.
Without it being the case that.
Except; apart from; other than.
Used with repetition of certain words to give emphasis.
No more than; only.
(used at the end of a sentence) though; however.
An argument against something; an objection.
--Examples--
‘he stumbled but didn't fall’
‘this is one principle, but it is not the only one’
‘the food is cheap but delicious’
‘the problem is not that they are cutting down trees, but that they are doing it in a predatory way’
‘one cannot but sympathize’
‘there was nothing they could do but swallow their pride’
‘they had no alternative but to follow’
‘but that's an incredible saving!’
‘but why?’
‘I'm sorry, but I can't pay you’
‘it never rains but it pours’
‘we were never anything but poor’
‘supply currently exceeds demand in all but the most rural areas’
‘the last but one’
‘nobody, but nobody, was going to stop her’
‘he is but a shadow of his former self’
‘choose from a colourful array of mango, starfruit, and raspberries, to name but a few’
‘he was a nice bloke but’
‘no buts—just get out of here’
‘as with all these proposals, ifs and buts abound’

butadiene 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

--Word--
butcher 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A person whose trade is cutting up and selling meat in a shop.
A person who slaughters and cuts up animals for food.
A person who kills people indiscriminately or brutally.
A person selling refreshments, newspapers, etc. on a train or in a theatre.
Slaughter or cut up (an animal) for food.
Kill (a person or people) indiscriminately or brutally.
Ruin (something) deliberately or through incompetence.
--Examples--
‘a pork butcher’
‘they rounded up and butchered 250 people’
‘the film was butchered by the studio that released it’

--Type--
noun
--Meanings--

A predacious Australasian songbird, with a heavy hook-tipped bill.

‘he is but a shadow of his former self’
‘choose from a colourful array of mango, starfruit, and raspberries, to name but a few’
‘he was a nice bloke but’
‘no buts—just get out of here’
‘as with all these proposals, ifs and buts abound’

but and ben 
--Type--
phrase
--Meanings--
A two-roomed cottage; a humble home.

--Word--
bill 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A printed or written statement of the money owed for goods or services.
A draft of a proposed law presented to parliament for discussion.
A programme of entertainment at a theatre or cinema.
A banknote.
A poster or handbill.
List (a person or event) in a programme.
Describe or advertise someone or something in a particular way.
Send a bill to (someone)
Charge (a sum of money)
--Examples--
‘the bill for their meal came to £17’
‘a debate over the civil rights bill’
‘she was top of the bill at America's leading vaudeville house’
‘a ten-dollar bill’
‘he has been hard at work bill posting in a poster and sticker campaign’
‘they were billed to appear but did not show up’
‘he was billed as ‘the new Sean Connery’’
‘we shall be billing them for the damage caused’
‘he had been billed £3,000 for his licence’
‘we billed £400,000’

--Word--
bump 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A light blow or a jolting collision.
(on a person's birthday) a custom by which the person is lifted by the arms and legs and let down on to the ground, once for each year of their age.
(in races where boats make a spaced start one behind another) the point at which a boat begins to overtake or touch the boat ahead, thereby defeating it.
A rising air current causing an irregularity in an aircraft's motion.
A protuberance on a level surface.
A swelling on the skin, especially one caused by illness or injury.
A lump on a person's skull, formerly thought to indicate a particular mental faculty.
An increase.
(in an online forum) an act of posting on an inactive thread in order to move it to the top of the list of active threads.
A loosely woven fleeced cotton fabric used in upholstery and as lining material.
Knock or run into someone or something with a jolt.
Meet by chance.
Hurt or damage (something) by striking it on something else.
(in a race) gain a bump against.
Move or travel with much jolting.
Push (something) jerkily in a specified direction.
Refuse (a passenger) a reserved place on a flight because of deliberate overbooking by the airline.
Displace from a job or role, especially in favour of someone else.
(in an online forum) post on (an inactive thread) in order to move it to the top of the list of active threads.
--Examples--
‘a nasty bump on the head’
‘the children were given the bumps’
‘bumps in the road’
‘her mosquito bites had come up in huge red bumps’
‘there was a bump in the number of outbound flights’
‘I'm giving this thread a well-deserved bump’
‘I almost bumped into him’
‘she bumped the girl with her hip’
‘we might just bump into each other’
‘she bumped her head on the sink’
‘the car bumped along the rutted track’
‘she had to bump the pushchair down the steps’
‘if you check in on time and are bumped, you will be entitled to a full refund’
‘she was bumped for a youthful model’
‘if no one responds after 24 hours, you can bump your thread’
--Word--
butterbur 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A Eurasian waterside plant of the daisy family, the rounded flower heads of which are produced before the leaves. The large, soft leaves were formerly used to wrap butter, and extracts are used medicinally as an anticonvulsant.
--Examples--

--Word--
buttercup 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A herbaceous plant with bright yellow cup-shaped flowers, which is common in grassland and as a garden weed. All kinds are poisonous and generally avoided by livestock.

--Word--
butterfly 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A nectar-feeding insect with two pairs of large, typically brightly coloured wings that are covered with microscopic scales. Butterflies are distinguished from moths by having clubbed or dilated antennae, holding their wings erect when at rest, and being active by day.
Having a two-lobed shape resembling the spread wings of a butterfly.
A showy or frivolous person.
A fluttering and nauseous sensation felt in the stomach when one is nervous.
A stroke in swimming in which both arms are raised out of the water and lifted forwards together.
Split (a piece of meat or fish) almost in two and spread it out flat.
--Examples--
‘a butterfly clip’
‘a social butterfly’
‘butterfly the shrimp using a small sharp knife’

--Word--
smooth 
--Type--
adjective, verb, adverb
--Meanings--
Having an even and regular surface; free from perceptible projections, lumps, or indentations.
(of a liquid) with an even consistency; without lumps.
(of the sea or another body of water) without heavy waves; calm.
Denoting the face of a tennis or squash racket without the projecting loops from the stringing process (used as a call when the racket is spun to decide the right to serve first or to choose ends).
(of movement) without jerks.
(of an action, event, or process) without problems or difficulties.
(of a person or their manner) suavely charming in a way regarded as possibly insincere.
(of food or drink) without harshness or bitterness.
Give (something) a flat, regular surface or appearance.
Modify (a graph, curve, etc.) so as to lessen irregularities.
Deal successfully with (a problem or difficulty)
Free (a course of action) from difficulties or problems.
In a way that is without difficulties.
--Examples--
‘smooth flat rocks’
‘his face was curiously smooth and youthful’
‘cook gently until the sauce is smooth’
‘the smooth summer sea’
‘the trucks gave a smooth ride’
‘graphics are excellent, with fast, smooth scrolling’
‘the group's expansion into the US market was not quite so smooth’
‘his voice was infuriatingly smooth’
‘a lovely, smooth, very fruity wine’
‘she smoothed out the newspaper’
‘you can use glasspaper to smooth the joint’
‘values are collected over a long period of time so that fluctuations are smoothed out’
‘these doctrinal disputes were smoothed over’
‘a conference would be held to smooth the way for the establishment of the provisional government’
‘the course of true love never did run smooth’

button 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A small disc or knob sewn on to a garment, either to fasten it by being pushed through a slit made for the purpose or for decoration.
A small round object resembling a button.
A knob fitted to the point of a foil to make it harmless.
Used in reference to things of little worth.
A small device on a piece of electrical or electronic equipment which is pressed to operate it.
An element of a graphical user interface which a user can select to perform a particular action.
A badge bearing a design or slogan and pinned to clothing.
Fasten (clothing) with buttons.
Fasten the buttons of a garment being worn by someone.
(of a garment) be fastened with buttons.
Stop talking.
--Examples--
‘chocolate buttons’
‘he will never give away anything that is worth a button’
‘just search for the app you want and click the 'buy' or 'install' button’
‘he buttoned up his jacket’
‘he buttoned himself into the raincoat’
‘a dress which buttoned down the front’

--Word--
buttoned-up 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
Reserved and not inclined to reveal information.
Secured to the maximum degree against attack.
--Examples--
‘Fleischer's buttoned-up style’
‘the tank had been buttoned up and had not been seriously damaged’
--Word--
fastening 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A device that closes or secures something.
--Examples--
‘a fly-front fastening’
--Word--
button 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A small disc or knob sewn on to a garment, either to fasten it by being pushed through a slit made for the purpose or for decoration.
A small round object resembling a button.
A knob fitted to the point of a foil to make it harmless.
Used in reference to things of little worth.
A small device on a piece of electrical or electronic equipment which is pressed to operate it.
An element of a graphical user interface which a user can select to perform a particular action.
A badge bearing a design or slogan and pinned to clothing.
Fasten (clothing) with buttons.
Fasten the buttons of a garment being worn by someone.
(of a garment) be fastened with buttons.
Stop talking.
--Examples--
‘chocolate buttons’
‘he will never give away anything that is worth a button’
‘just search for the app you want and click the 'buy' or 'install' button’
‘he buttoned up his jacket’
‘he buttoned himself into the raincoat’
‘a dress which buttoned down the front’
--Word--
hold button 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A button on a telephone that temporarily interrupts a call so that another call may be taken.
--Examples--
--Word--
holder 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A device or implement for holding something.
A person that holds something.
The possessor of a trophy, championship, or record.
A smallholder.
--Examples--
‘I replaced the phone in its holder’
‘a British passport holder’
‘holders of two American hostages’
‘the FA Cup holders’
--Word--
buttonhole 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A slit made in a garment to receive a button for fastening.
A flower or spray worn in a buttonhole on the lapel of a jacket.
Attract the attention of and detain (someone) in conversation, typically against their will.
Make buttonholes in (a garment).
--Examples--
‘reporters buttonhole officials coming out of the press secretary's office’

buttonhook 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A small hook with a long handle for fastening tight buttons (often formerly on buttoned boots).
A play in which a pass receiver runs straight downfield and then doubles back sharply towards the line of scrimmage.

--Word--
buttress 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A structure of stone or brick built against a wall to strengthen or support it.
A projecting portion of a hill or mountain.
A source of defence or support.
Provide (a building or structure) with buttresses.
Increase the strength of or justification for; reinforce.
--Examples--
‘the cathedral's massive buttresses’
‘the political police were the main buttress of the regime’
‘we buttressed the wall as it was showing signs of cracking and collapse’
‘authority was buttressed by religious belief’
--Word--
buttressed 
--Type--
adjective
--Meanings--
(of a building or structure) strengthened or supported with a buttress.
--Examples--
‘a buttressed wall’

‘he butts his head against a wall’

--Word--
buzz 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A low, continuous humming or murmuring sound, made by or similar to that made by an insect.
The sound of a buzzer or telephone.
A telephone call.
An atmosphere of excitement and activity.
A feeling of excitement or euphoria; a thrill.
A general sense of excitement about or interest in someone or something, as reflected in or generated by media coverage or word of mouth.
A rumour.
Make a low, continuous humming sound.
(of the ears) be filled with a humming sound.
Signal to someone with a buzzer.
Telephone (someone)
Move quickly or busily.
Fly very close to (another aircraft, the ground, etc.) at high speed.
Be full of excitement or activity.
(of a person) be euphoric or very stimulated.
Throw (something) hard.
buzz off
Go away.
--Examples--
‘the buzz of the bees’
‘a buzz of conversation’
‘I'll give you a buzz’
‘there is a real buzz about the place’
‘I got such a buzz out of seeing the kids' faces’
‘they created a huge buzz with their latest album’
‘the film has already generated a lot of buzz in the industry’
‘there's a strong buzz that he's in Scotland’
‘mosquitoes were buzzing all around us’
‘I remember a buzzing in my ears’
‘the intercom buzzed loudly’
‘he buzzed the stewardesses every five minutes’
‘he buzzed me on the car phone’
‘she buzzed along the M1 back into town’
‘helicopter gunships were sent to buzz the villages’
‘Westminster is buzzing with anticipation’
‘within an hour, every department was buzzing with the news’
‘twenty-four hours later Marcus was still buzzing’
--Word--
buzzard 
--Type--
noun
--Meanings--
A large hawklike bird of prey with broad wings and a rounded tail, often seen soaring in wide circles.
A vulture, especially a turkey vulture.
--Examples--

buzz 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A low, continuous humming or murmuring sound, made by or similar to that made by an insect.

Move quickly or busily.

buzz off
Go away.

‘the buzz of the bees’
‘a buzz of conversation’
‘I'll give you a buzz’
‘there is a real buzz about the place’
‘I got such a buzz out of seeing the kids' faces’

‘Westminster is buzzing with anticipation’
‘within an hour, every department was buzzing with the news’
‘twenty-four hours later Marcus was still buzzing’

buzz 
--Type--
noun, verb
--Meanings--
A low, continuous humming or murmuring sound, made by or similar to that made by an insect.
The sound of a buzzer or telephone.
A telephone call.
An atmosphere of excitement and activity.
A feeling of excitement or euphoria; a thrill.
A general sense of excitement about or interest in someone or something, as reflected in or generated by media coverage or word of mouth.
A rumour.
Make a low, continuous humming sound.
(of the ears) be filled with a humming sound.
Signal to someone with a buzzer.
Telephone (someone)
Move quickly or busily.
Fly very close to (another aircraft, the ground, etc.) at high speed.
Be full of excitement or activity.
(of a person) be euphoric or very stimulated.
Throw (something) hard.
buzz off
Go away.
--Examples--
‘the buzz of the bees’
‘a buzz of conversation’
‘I'll give you a buzz’
‘there is a real buzz about the place’
‘I got such a buzz out of seeing the kids' faces’
‘they created a huge buzz with their latest album’
‘the film has already generated a lot of buzz in the industry’

noun
--Meanings--
